Since this last authority for the text was not forthcoming until after the publication of the latest critical text of the Symposium, I add the description of it given by the editors:—

“The part covered is from 200 B [beginning with the word bouloi[to] after which 40 lines are lost, the next words being an endeia at the end of 200 E] to the end, comprised in 31 columns, of which four (xix—xxii) are missing entirely, while two others (i and xviii) are represented by small fragments; but the remainder is in a very fair state of preservation....The small and well-formed but somewhat heavy writing exemplifies a common type of book hand, and probably dates from about the year 200 A.D....The corrector's ink does not differ markedly in colour from that of the text, and in the case of minor insertions the two hands are at times difficult to distinguish. But as they are certainly not separated by any wide interval of time the question has no great practical importance....The text, as so often with papyri, is of an eclectic character, showing a decided affinity with no single MS. Compared with the three principal witnesses for the Symposium it agrees now with B against TW, now with the two latter as against the former, rarely with T against BWSee crit. notes on 202 A, 203 A, 205 B, 206 B, 207 D, 211 C. or with W against BTSee crit. notes on 203 B, 211 D, 213 B, 219 E, 220 C (bis).. Similarly in a passage cited by Stobaeus some agreements with his readings against the consensus of BTW are counterbalanced by a number of variations from Stobaeus' textSee crit. notes on 202 C—203 A.. A few coincidences occur with variants peculiar to the inferior MSS., the more noticeable being those with Vindob. 21 alone or in combination with Venet. 184See crit. notes on 201 A (ad fin.), 218 D, 220 A, 220 B, 223 C. and Parisin. 1642 alone or with Vat. 229See crit. notes on 206 B (ad init.), 208 A, 223 C.. Of the readings for which there is no other authority, including several variations in the order of the words, the majority, if unobjectionable, are unconvincing. The more valuable contributions, some of which are plainly superior to anything found in other MSS., are: l. 92 [201 D] ep, l. 112 [202 A] the omission of kai/ (so Stallbaum), l. 239 [204 B] an eih, where BTW have a meaningless a)/n, l. 368 [206 C] kalw as conjectured by Badham
for tw=| k., l. 471 [208 B] metexei as restored by Stephanus (mete/xein MSS.), l. 517 [209 A] tekein confirming a conjecture of Hug (kuei=n MSS.), l. 529 [209 B] epiqumh as conjectured by Stephanus (e)piqumei= MSS.), l. 577 [210 A] kai su omitted by MSS., l. 699 [212 A] qeofilei (-h= BTW), l. 770 [213 B] katide[n (?) (kaqi/zein MSS), l. 898 [218 D] moi (probably) with Vind. 21 (mou BTW), l. 1142 [222 D] diabalei as conjectured by Hirschig (diaba/lh| BTW). On the other hand in many cases the papyrus once more proves the antiquity of readings which modern criticism rejects or suspects.”

It may be added that the editors of the papyrus in citing W have made use of a new collation of that MS. by Prof. H. Schöne of Basel “which often supplements and sometimes corrects the report of Burnet.” And in this edition I have followed the report of W in their apparatus, where available, while relying elsewhere upon that given by Burnet.

(2) Modern criticism. Much attention has been paid by Continental critics during the last century to the text of the Symposium, and for the most part they have proceeded on the assumption that the text is largely vitiated by interpolationsE.g. O. Jahn, Hirschig, Badham, Cobet, Naber, Hartmann. On the other hand, sensible protests have been made by Teuffel and Vahlen; and Rettig's text is, if anything, ultra-conservative.. Even Schanz and Hug, who may be regarded as moderate and cautious critics in comparison with such extremists as Jahn and Badham, have gone to unnecessary lengths in their use of the obelus. Hug, while admitting that we must take into account the freedom and variety of Plato's style and that it is folly to rob a writer of his individuality by pruning away any and every expression which is in strict logic superfluous, and while admitting also that regard must be paid to the characteristic differences of the various speeches in our dialogue, which forbid our taking any one speech as the norm with which others should be squared,—yet maintains that in the speeches, and especially in those of Pausanias and Socrates, he can detect a number of unquestionable glosses. No doubt there are some cases in these speeches in which it is not unreasonable to suspect interpolation, but even Hug and Schanz have, I believe, greatly exaggerated the number of such cases; and I agree with the editor of the Oxford text in regarding the certain instances of corruption or interpolation as extremely few. Consequently, in the text here printed I have diverged but seldom from the ancient tradition, and such changes as I have made have been more often in the
direction of verbal alteration than of omission. I have, however, recorded in the textual notes a selection of the proposed alterations, futile though I consider most of them to be.

div1.head: § x. Bibliography.
div1.p: i. Texts: Bekker (1826), the Zurich ed. (Baiter, Orelli and Winckelmann, 1839), C. F. Hermann (1851), O. Jahn (1864), JahnUsener (1875), C. Badham (1866), M. Schanz (1881), J. Burnet (1901).
Critical essays or notes by Bast (1794), Voegelin, Naber, Teuffel, M. Vermehren (1870), J. J. Hartmann (1898).

ii. Annotated Editions: J. F. Fischer (1776), F. A. Wolf (1782), P. A. Reynders (1825), L. I. Rückert (1829), A. Hommel (1834), G. Stallbaum (2nd ed. 1836), G. F. Rettig (2 vols. 1875—6), A. Hug (2nd ed. 1884).

iii. Treatises on the subject-matter: M. H. L. Hartmann (Chronol. Symp. Pl. 1798), G. Schwanitz (Observ. in Pl. Conv. 1842), M. Lindemann (De Phaedri orat. 1853, De Agath. or. 1871), J. H. Deinhardt (Ueber den Inhalt u. s. w. von Pl. Symp. 1865), M. Koch (Die Rede d. Sokr. u. das Problem der Erotik, 1886), W. Resl (Verhältnis der 5 erster in Pl. Symp. Reden u. s. w. 1886), C. Boetticher (Eros u. Erkenntnis bei Pl. 1894), C. Schirlitz (Beiträge z. Erklärung d. Rede d. Sokr. u.s.w. 1890), P. Crain (De ratione quae inter Pl. Phaedr. et Symp. intercedat, 1906).

Other more general works consulted are: Teichmüller (Litt. Fehden, 1881), F. Horn (Platonstudien, 1893), W. Lutoslawski (Plato's Logic, 1897), T. Gomperz (Greek Thinkers, E.T. II. 1905), H. Raeder (Platons Philos. Entwickelung, 1905), J. Adam (Religious Teachers of Greece, 1908).
iv. Translations: E. Zeller (1857), A. Jung (2nd ed. 1900), B. Jowett, J. A. Stewart (selections, in The Myths of Plato, 1905).

div1.head: Preface
div1.p: *dokw= moi ktl. The speaker, Apollodorus (see Introd. § II. A), is replying to certain unnamed e(tai=roi who had been questioning him concerning the incidents and speeches which took place at Agathon's banquet. The plural punqa/nesqe (and u(mi=n, u(mei=s 173 C, D below) indicates that there were several e(tai=roi present: the traditional heading of the dialogue, *e*t*a*i*r*o*s, is due to the fact that all but one are kwfa\ pro/swpa.
ou)k a)mele/thtos . mele/th and meleta=n are regular terms for the “conning over” of a speech or “part”: cp. Phaedrus 228 B.

kai\ ga\r e)tu/gxanon. These words explain the preceding statement dokw=... ou)k a)mele/thtos ei)=nai, and serve to introduce not only the sentence immediately following but the whole of the succeeding passage down to 173 B where the initial statement is resumed by the words w(/ste...ou)k a)meleth/tws e)/xw.
*falhro/qen. Phalerum, the old port of Athens, was about 20 stadia (2 1/2 miles) distant from the city on the S.E.
kai\ pai/zwn...perimenei=s; Where does the joke come in?

(1) Ast, Hommel, Stallbaum and Jowett look for it in the word *falhreu/s, which they take to be a play on falaro\s (“bald-headed,” so Jowett) or falari/s (“bald-coot”) in allusion to the bald crown or the peculiar gait of Apollodorus. But what evidence is there to show that A. either was bald or walked like a coot?

(2) Another suggestion of Hommel's is to write (with the vulgate) o( *)apollo/dwros and assume an etymological allusion to the opportuneness of the meeting (as “Apollo-given”). This also is far-fetched.

(3) Schütz, followed by Wolf and Hug, finds the paidia/ in the playfully
official style of the address, in which the person is designated by the name of his deme, this being the regular practice in legal and formal proceedings (cp. Gorg. 495 D *kalliklh=s e)/fh *)axarneu/s...*swkra/ths...o( *)alwpekh=qen: Ar. Nub. 134); but (as Stallb. objected) the order of the words in that case should be rather w)= ou(=tos *)a. o( *falhreu/s. Hug also finds paidia/ in the hendecasyllabic rhythm (w)= *fal. ou(=tos *)ap.), and the poetic combination w)= ou(=tos (Soph. O. C. 1627, Aj. 89).

(4) Rettig, reading o( *falhreu/s, omits (with Badham) the proper name *)apollo/dwros as an adscript. This seems, on the whole, the best and simplest solution. Glaucon, at a distance behind, feigns ignorance of the identity of “the Phalerian,” and shouts after Apollodorus “Ho there! you Phalerian, halt,” in a “stop thief!” tone. It is plausible to suppose also that a certain contempt is conveyed in the description *falhreu/s (“Wapping-ite”): porttowns are often places of unsavoury repute: cp. Phaedrus 243 C e)n nau/tais pou teqramme/non: Juv. Sat. VIII. 174 “permixtum nautis et furibus ac fugitivis.”

For the summons to halt cp. Ar. Plut. 440 ou(=tos, ti/ dra=|s; w)= deilo/taton su\ qhri/on, | ou) perimenei=s; Thesm. 689 poi= poi= su\ feu/geis; ou(=tos, ou(=tos, ou) menei=s; also Eq. 240, 1354. These passages support the future perimenei=s rather than the present: “futurum est fortius imperantis; praesens modeste cohortantis aut lenius postulantis” (Stallb.). For the future as a lively imperative cp. 175 A, 212 D.

e)n tw=| sundei/pnw|. Similarly in Aristoph. Gerytades (frag. 204 e)n toi=si sundei/pnois e)painw=n *ai)sxu/lon) su/ndeipnon is used for the more precise sumpo/sion: and a lost play of Sophocles bore the title *)axaiw=n su/llogos h)\ su/ndeipnon h)\ su/ndeipnoi (see fragg. 146 ff., Dindf.).
ti/nes h)=san. For phrases of this kind, “satis libere subjecta orationi,” see Vahlen, Op. Acad. II. 393.
*foi/nikos tou= *fili/ppou. Nothing is known of this man. See Introd. § II. A.
dikaio/tatos ga\r ktl. tou= e(tai/rou is almost equivalent to e(tai/rou ge o)/ntos, giving the reason why Apollodorus is dikaio/tatos.
parege/nou th=| sunousi/a|. Cp. Hom. Od. XVII. 173 kai/ sfin paregi/gneto daiti/: and the exordium of the Phaedo (57 A) au)to\s, w)= *f., parege/nou *swkra/tei ...h)\ a)/llou tou h)kou/sas;

*panta/pasin e)/oike/ soi ktl. “It is quite evident that his narration was of
the vaguest kind.” dihgei=sqai is here the infin. of dihgei=to. The emphatic repetition of ou)de\n safe/s is a ground for suspecting that the reference is to a published account in which the facts were distorted.

*po/qen...w)= *glau/kwn; “What makes you think so, Glaucon?” There is an implicit negation in the question put thus: cp. Gorg. 471 D, Menex. 235 C. This Glaucon is perhaps the same as the father of Charmides (Charm. 154 A, etc.), but probably not the same as the Glaucon of the Republic, though Böckh and Munk would identify the two.
pollw=n e)tw=n ktl. For the bearing of this passage on the dramatic date of this prologue, see Introd. § VIII.
e)pimele\s pepoi/hmai...ei)de/nai. The nearest Platonic parallel for this construction is Ep. vii. 334 A polloi=s...u(mnei=n tau=ta e)pimele/s.

peritre/xwn o(/ph| tu/xoimi, i.e. with no fixed principle of conduct,— “like a wave of the sea, driven with the wind and tossed.” Cp. Tim. 43 B a)ta/ktws o(/ph| tu/xoi proie/nai: Seneca de vita beata I. 2 “quamdiu quidem passim vagamur non ducem secuti...conteretur vita inter errores brevis,” etc.
oi)o/menos ti\ poiei=n. For ti, magnum quid, cp. 219 C, Phaedrus 242 E, etc.
*pai/dwn o)/ntwn h(mw=n e)/ti. Sc. Apollodorus and Glaucon. Plato, too, born about 427 B.C., was a pai=s at the date of Agathon's victory (416 B.C.).
th=| prw/th| tragw|di/a|. “Respicit Plato ad tetralogias” (Reynders).
th=| u(sterai/a| h(=|. For this (compendious) construction cp. Thuc. I. 60 tessarakosth=| h(me/ra| u(/steron...h(=| *poti/daia a)pe/sth (with Shilleto's note); Lys. XIX. 22.

ta\ e)pini/kia e)/quen. “Made a sacrificial feast in honour of his victory.” On this occasion it was the author himself who provided the feast and offered the sacrifice. Sometimes however it was the Choregus (e.g. Ar. Ach. 886), and
sometimes the friends of the successful competitor (e.g. Xen. Symp. I. 4). Similarly at Rome it was customary for the dux gregis to entertain his troupe after a victory (see Plaut. Rud. 1417 ff.).
*)aristo/dhmos. See Introd. § II. A.
*kudaqhnaieu/s. Schol. *kudaqh/naion: dh=mos e)n a)/stei th=s *pandioni/dos fulh=s. kalei=tai de\ kai\ *ku/daqon. The poet Aristophanes also belonged to this deme.

a)nupo/dhtos. In this peculiarity A. imitated Socrates, see 174 A, 220 B, Ar. Nub. 103 tou\s a)nupodh/tous le/geis: | w(=n o( kakodai/mwn *swkra/ths kai\ *xairefw=n, ibid. 362. It is a peculiarity which would appeal to disciples with a penchant for the simple life, such as those of the Cynic persuasion.
e)rasth\s. “An admirer.” Cp. the application of e(tai=ros in 172 B supra.
e)kei/nou...e)kei=nos. Both pronouns refer to the same person, Aristodemus. The statement here made is not without significance, see Introd. § II. A.

*ti/ ou)=n...ou) dihgh/sw. “Haec interrogatio alacritatem quandam animi et aviditatem sciendi indicat” (Stallb.). Cp. Meno 92 D (with E. S. Thompson's note, where a full list of the Platonic exx. is given).

pa/ntws de\ ktl. “For to be sure,” confirming the preceding clause with a new argument. A good parallel is Laws I. 625 A pa/ntws d' h(/ ge e)k *knwsou= o(do\s ei)s to\ tou= *dio\s a)/ntron kai\ i(ero/n, w(s a)kou/omen, i(kanh/.
o(/per a)rxo/menos ei)=pon. See 172 A ad init.

ei) ou)=n dei=...xrh\. The comma is better placed before tau=ta, with Usener and Burnet, than after it, with Hug and earlier editors. A similar turn of expression is Soph. Trach. 749 ei) xrh\ maqei=n se, pa/nta dh\ fwnei=n xrew/n .

au)to\s poiw=mai. Here Apollodorus seems to claim to be no mere disciple, but himself an exponent of philosophy. So far as it goes this might indicate that Apollodorus represents the real author, Plato. For A.'s delight in philosophic lo/goi, cp. what is said of Phaedrus in Phaedrus 228 B, where Socr. too is called o( nosw=n peri\ lo/gwn.

u(perfuw=s w(s xai/rw. This may be explained as a mixture of two constructions, viz. (1) u(perfue/s e)stin w(s xai/rw, (2) u(perfuw=s xai/rw: it is found also in Gorg. 496 C, Phaedo 66 A, Theaet. 155 C (but in all these places some codd. and edd. omit w(s).

xrhmatistikw=n. For this word in the masc., “money-makers,” cp. Rep. 581 C o(/ ge xrhmatistiko\s pro\s to\ kerdai/nein th
 tou= tima=sqai h(donh
 h)\ th
 tou= manqa/nein ou)deno\s a)ci/an fh/sei ei)=nai, ei) mh\ ei)/ ti au)tw=n a)rgu/rion poiei=: also Phaedrus 248 D. In Meno 78 C (a)gaqa\...xrusi/on le/gw kai\ a)rgu/rion kta=sqai) we have an expression of the sentiments of a xrhmatistiko/s. For Apollodorus' sentiment, cp. Isocr. c. Soph. 291 D le/gousi me
 w(s ou)de
 de/ontai xrhma/twn, a)rguri/dion kai\ xrusi/dion to
 plou=ton a)pokalou=ntes (where the ref. is probably to Antisthenes): cp. also what Alcib. says of Socr., 216 E, 219 E. The glosshunting critics, strangely enough (as Vahlen remarks), have left the words u(ma=s tou\s e(tai/rous unscathed.

a)lhqh= oi)/esqai. oi)/esqai here is substituted for h(gei=sqai, and the following ou)k oi)/omai is in antithesis, not to the oi)/omai preceding, but to h(gei=sqe. Apollodorus, conscious of his inferiority to Socrates, his ideal, is willing to admit that he is not as yet wholly eu)dai/mwn.

a)ll' eu)= oi)=da. Sc. o(/ti kakodai/mone/s e)ste. For this exposure of the true condition of “the children of this world” who are eu)dai/mones in their own conceit, and despise others, one may cite Apoc. iii. 17 “Thou sayest, I am rich and increased with goods and have need of nothing; and knowest not that thou art wretched and miserable and poor and blind and naked.”
*)aei\ o(/moios ei)=. “Semper tibi hac in re constas” (Stallb.): “you are quite incorrigible.” So below we have a)ei\ toiou=tos ei)=. Cp. Charm. 170 A a)ll' e)gw\ kinduneu/w a)ei\ o(/moios ei)=nai.
a)texnw=s pa/ntas. This seems to be the sole instance in Plato of this combination “all without exception”; but cp. Rep. 432 A di) o(/lhs a)texnw=s te/tatai.

plh\n *swkra/tous. “Save Socrates only”: notice the emphasis on these words, repeated twice. We may discern, perhaps, in this an allusion, by way
of antithesis, to the kathgori/a *swkra/tous of the sophist Polycrates (see Introd. § II. A).

to\ maniko\s kalei=sqai. There can be little doubt (pace Naber) that maniko/s, not malako/s, is the true reading: it is supported by the words mai/nomai kai\ parapai/w in Apollodorus's reply. Stallbaum supposes an ellipse of some such phrase as dokei=s de\ labei=n au)to/qen before e)n me
 ga ktl., and (with Wolf) explains maniko/s as referring to the vehemence and excess of Apollodorus both in praise and blame: cp. Polit. 307 B, and Apol. 21 A where Chaerephon (termed maniko/s in Charm. 153 B) is described as sfodro\s e)f' o(/ ti o(rmh/seien. But the connexion of the sentence e)n me
 ga ktl. with the preceding clause is better brought out by Hug; he supplies (after ou)k oi)=da) “so ganz ohne Grund wirds wohl nicht sein,” so that the line of thought is— “Though I do not know exactly why you got the nickname ‘fanatic’—yet in your speeches at any rate you do something to justify the title.” For a similar use of me
 ga cp. Polit. 264 C e)n me
 ga tai=s krh/nais ta/x' a)
 i)/sws ei)/hs h)|sqhme/nos. For maniko/s cp. also Meno 91 C where Anytus regards para\ sofista\s e)lqei=n as a sign of mani/a: and Acts xxvi. 24 *mai/nh| *pau=le: ta\ polla/ se gra/mmata ei)s mani/an peritre/pei.
a)griai/neis. “Rage like a wild beast,” “snarl and snap.” Cp. Rep. 493 B (qre/mma me/ga) h(merou=tai/ te kai\ a)griai/nei.
*)=w fi/ltate ktl. Ironical—“Why, my very dear Sir, it is surely quite obvious that in holding this view about myself and others I display madness and eccentricity!”
parapai/w. A a(/pac ei)rhme/non in Plato. For the musical metaphor cp. Ophelia's “I see that sovereign and most noble reason, Like sweet bells jangled, out of tune and harsh.”

*ou)k a)/cion...e)ri/zein. “We mustn't quarrel.” e)ri/zein, though here used jocularly, is properly a strong term, cp. Prot. 337 B a)mfisbhtei=n me/n, e)ri/zein de\ mh/: Rep. 454 A ou)k e)ri/zein, a)lla\ diale/gesqai (see Adam ad loc.).

ma=llon d). Instead of beginning at once with the speech of Phaedrus, Apollodorus proceeds to give an account of the preliminary incidents which led up to the lo/goi. For the significance of this, see Introd. § II. A.
e)c a)rxh=s...peira/somai dihgh/sasqai. The same formula occurs in Phaedo 59 C, Euthyd. 272 D, Epist. vii. 324 B.

div1.head: Aristodemus's Prologue
div1.p: *)/efh ga/r. Sc. o( *)aristo/dhmos. The whole narrative of the dialogue from this point on is dependent upon this initial e)/fh and therefore written in or. obliqua. oi( (sibi)=*)aristodh/mw|.

leloume/non. For the practice of bathing and anointing before meals see Hom. Od. VI. 96—7, Xen. Symp. I. 7: Ar. Plut. 614 eu)wxei=sqai...lousa/menos, liparo\s xwrw=n e)k balanei/ou. The comic poets were fond of gibing at Socrates and philosophers in general as “unwashed,” e.g. Ar. Av. 1554 a)/loutos ou(= yuxagwgei= *swkra/ths: id. Nub. 835 ff.: Aristophon ap. Mein. III. 360 ff. Aristotle, however, was a champion of the bath, Athen. 178 F a)prepe\s ga\r h)=n, fhsi\n *)aristote/lhs (fr. 165), h(/kein ei)s to\ sumpo/sion su\n i(drw=ti pollw=| kai\ koniortw=|.

ta\s blau/tas. Schol. blau/tas: u(podh/mata. oi( de\ blauti/a, sanda/lia i)sxna/. For Socrates' habit of going barefoot, see 220 B infra, Phaedr. 229 A, Xen. Mem. I. 6. 2, and the note on a)nupo/dhtos, 173 B supra.

tau=ta dh\ e)kallwpisa/mhn . tau=ta is better taken (with Hug and Hommel) as accus. of “internal object” than (with Stallb.) as accus. of “remoter object,” equiv. to dia\ tau=ta (cp. Prot. 310 E). Elsewhere in Plato kallwpi/zesqai means to “plume oneself,” “swagger,” e.g. Rep. 605 D. Observe the word-play: “I have put on my finery, because he is such a fine man” (Jowett): cp. the proverb o(/moios o(moi/w| (195 B).
para\ kalo\n. Sc. *)aga/qwna—“to Agathon's (house)”; equiv. to ei)s *)aga/qwnos above. For “the handsome Agathon,” see Prot. 315 D—E (th\n i)de/an pa/nu kalo/s), Ar. Thesm. 191 ff.

pw=s e)/xeis pro\s ktl. Cp. 176 B pw=s e)/xei pro\s to\ e)rrw=sqai pi/nein; Prot. 352 B, Parm. 131 E. Cobet's excision of e)qe/lein a)/n is wanton: cp. (with Ast) Phaedo 62 C to\ tou\s filoso/fous r(a|di/ws a)\n e)qe/lein a)poqnh/skein.

a)/klhtos. The jester (gelwtopoio/s) who frequents feasts as an uninvited guest seems to have been a stock character in Epicharmus; and in Xen. Symp. Philippus is a person of this type. Araros the comic poet was, apparently, the first to dub them para/sitoi. Cp. also Archil. 78. 3 ou)de\
mh
 klhqei\s (u(f' h(mw=n) h)=lqes, oi(=a dh\ fi/los; and Plut. Q. Conv. VII. 6. 1, p. 707 B to\ de\ tw=n e)piklh/twn e)/qos, ou(\s nu=n “skia\s” kalou=sin, ou) keklhme/nous au)tou/s, a)ll' u(po\ tw=n keklhme/nwn e)pi\ to\ dei=pnon a)gome/nous, e)zhtei=to po/qen e)/sxe th
 a)rxh/n. e)do/kei d' a)po\ *swkra/tous *)aristo/dhmon a)napei/santos ou) keklhme/non ei)s *)aga/qwnos i)e/nai su
 au)tw=| kai\ paqo/nta “ti geloi=on” (see 174 C, with note). In Lat. vocare is similarly used of “inviting” (aliquem ad cenam Ter. And. 2. 6. 22), and invocatus=a)/klhtos in Plaut. Capt. 1. 1. 2 (“invocatus soleo esse in convivio”).

diafqei/rwmen metaba/llontes . diafqei/rw is sometimes used of “spoiling” or “stultifying” a statement or argument, e.g. Gorg. 495 A, Prot. 338 D. And metaba/llein of linguistic alteration (transposition, etc.), as in Crat. 404 C (*fersefo/nh for *ferre/fatta).

w(s a)/ra ktl. The force of a)/ra is to indicate that the proverb, when amended, “still, after all” holds good. Two forms of the proverb are extant, viz. (1) au)to/matoi d) a)gaqoi\ deilw=n e)pi\ dai=tas i)/asi (see Schol. ad h. l., Athen. IV. 27); and (2) au)to/matoi d) a)gaqoi\ a)gaqw=n e)pi\ dai=tas i)/asi. The latter form is vouched for by the poeta anon. quoted by Athen. I. 8 A (Bergk P. L. G. p. 704), a)gaqo\s pro\s a)gaqou\s a)/ndras ei(stiasa/menos h(=kon: Bacchyl. fr. 33 (22 Blass) au)to/matoi d' a)gaqw=n dai=tas eu)o/xqous e)pe/rxontai di/kaioi fw=tes [cp. Zenob. II. 19 au)to/matoi d' a)gaqoi\ a)gaqw=n kte(.: ou(/tws o( *bakxuli/dhs e)xrh/sato th=| paroimi/a|, w(s *(hrakle/ous e)pifoith/santos e)pi\ th\n oi)ki/an *kh/ukos tou= *traxini/ou kai\ ou(/tws ei)po/ntos]: Cratinus fr. 111 (Mein.) oi(/d' au)=q' h(mei=s, w(s o( palaio\s | lo/gos, au)toma/tous a)gaqou\s i)e/nai | komyw=n e)pi\ dai=ta qeatw=n: also a number of post-Platonic passages cited by Hug, such as Plut. Q. Conv. VII. 6 ad fin. According to the Scholiast (1) is the original form, which was altered (metalla/cas) to (2) by Cratinus and Eupolis; and this is the view adopted by Stallbaum, Rettig and others. But Hug's elaborate investigation of the matter proves convincingly, I think, that the Scholiast is wrong and that the form with a)gaqoi\ a)gaqw=n was the original, of which the form with a)gaqoi\ deilw=n is a parody by Eupolis (or Cratinus). This view, first suggested by Schleiermacher, is also supported by Bergk (ad Bacchyl. fr. 33): “Schol. Plat. Sym. 174 B a vero aberrat cum dicit a principio deilw=n e)pi\ dai=tas fuisse, quamquam fidem habuerunt cum alii tum Müller Dor. II. 481: neque enim par fuit Herculem tam gravi opprobrio hospitem laedere. Eupolis primus, ut videtur, ludibundus deilw=n substituit. Locum difficilem Platonis, qui falso criminatur Homerum corrupisse proverbium quod ille omnino non respexit, nemodum probabiliter expedivit. Alia varietas, quam nostri homines commenti sunt, deiloi\ deilw=n, omni auctoritate destituta est.” The main difficulty in the way of accepting this view lies in the words diafqei/rwmen metaba/llontes. For even if (with most modern editors) we accept Lachmann's brilliant conjecture *)agaqwn)(i), the change thus involved is so slight that it could hardly be called a diafqora/, nor could the alteration involved in the Homeric account be spoken of as a
double one (diafqei=rai kai\ u(bri/sai). The former objection, if it stood alone, might be obviated by the device of inserting mh/ before diafqei/rwmen: but in view of the passage as a whole this device is inadmissible. We seem forced to conclude that, whatever the original form of the proverb may have been (and as to this Hug's view is probably right), the form which Plato had here in mind was the form (1) given by Eupolis: and if Plato knew this form to be only a parody of the original (2), we must suppose further that the serious way in which he deals with it, as if it really were a “wise saw,” is only a piece of his fun—a playful display of Socratic irony. (Cp. Teuffel, Rhein. Mus. XXIX. pp. 141—2.)

*)aga/qwn)...a)gaqoi/. For the dative cp. Prot. 321 C a)porou=nti de\ au)tw=| e)/rxetai *promhqeu/s. Similar exx. of paronomasia occur in 185 C, 198 C, Gorg. 513 B (dh=mos and Demus, son of Pyrilampes), Rep. 614 B (a)/lkimos, Alcinous): cp. Riddell Digest § 323. Teuffel (loc. cit.) prefers to retain a)gaqw=n, partly because of the plur. dai=tas, partly to avoid the elision of the iota; but neither of these objections is serious, and as to dai=tas, the feast in question lasted at least two days, which might in itself suffice to justify the plural. Jowett's transl. implies that he retains a)gaqw=n and supposes (1) to have been the original form of the proverb “demolished” by Socr. and Homer.

*(/omhros me\n ga\r. The antithesis—h(mei=s de\ mo/non diafqei/romen, or the like— is easily supplied from the context: for me\n ga\r, elliptical, cp. 176 C, and 173 D supra. The suggestion that Homer wilfully distorted a proverb which in his day was non-existent is, as Hug observes, obviously jocose.

u(bri/sai. The word may retain a flavour of its juridical sense—“liable to a criminal prosecution for assault and battery”: and if so, diafqei=ra too may hint at the crime of “seduction.” Homer is chargeable not only with seducing but with committing a criminal assault upon the virgin soundness of the proverb.

malqako\n ai)xmhth/n. “A craven spearman.” Il. XVII. 587 oi(=on dh\ *mene/laon u(petre/sas, o(\s to\ pa/ros per | malqako\s ai)xmhth/s. malqako/s, as a variant for malako/s, is used by P. also in 195 D, Phaedrus 239 C. Both forms, *mene/lews and *mene/laos, are found in Attic prose; the latter, e.g., in Euthyd. 288 C. In Athenaeus V. 3, 188 B we have a criticism of this treatment of Menelaus.

a)/klhton e)poi/hsen e)lqo/nta. See Il. II. 408 au)to/matos de/ oi( h)=lqe boh\n a)gaqo\s *mene/laos: cp. Athen. V. 178 A. Thus the u(/bris with which Homer is charged
consists in making not an a)gaqo/s but a malqako/s (=deilo/s) come a)/klhtos a)gaqw=n e)pi\ dai=tas.
e)pi\ sofou= a)ndro\s . sofo/s, “accomplished,” was “a fashionable epithet of praise in Plato's time, especially applied to poets” (see Rep. 331 E, 489 B, with Adam's notes).

o(/ra ou)=n ktl. This correction of the traditional a)=ra...ti is certain. Cp. 189 A o(/ra ti/ poiei=s: Phaedo 86 D o(/ra ou)=n...ti/ fh/somen. For the dangers of violating etiquette on such occasions, see Ar. Av. 983 ff. au)ta e)ph
 a)/klhtos i)w
 a)/nqrwpos a)lazw
 | luph=| qu/ontas kai\ splagxneu/ein e)piqumh=|, | dh\ to/te xrh\ tu/ptein au)to
 pleurw=n to\ metacu/.

*su/n te du/) ktl. See Il. X. 224 (Diomedes loq.) su/n te du/) e)rxome/nw kai/ te pro\ o( tou= e)no/hsen | o(/ppws ke/rdos e)/h|. The same verses are quoted more exactly in Prot. 348 C: cp. also Arist. Pol. III. 1287^{b} 13; Cic. ad fam. IX. 7. For exx. of how Plato “variis modis multis affert aliena,” see Vahlen Op. Acad. I. pp. 476 ff.
e)peidh\ de\ gene/sqai. The infin. in place of the indic. is due to assimilation: cp. Rep. 614 B e)/fh de/, e)peidh\ ou(= e)kbh=nai th\n yuxh/n, poreu/esqai: see Goodwin G. M. T. § 755.

kai/ ti...geloi=on paqei=n. It was an awkward situation in smart society. Cp. Plut. Conv. 6 p. 628 e)/laqe ga\r kata\ th\n o(do\n u(poleifqei\s o( *swkra/ths, o( de\ pareish=lqen, a)texnw=s skia\ probadi/zousa sw/matos e)co/pisqe to\ fw=s e)/xontos.

oi(= (sibi) goes with a)panth/santa. Porson's insertion (from Photius) of tw=n before e)/ndoqen is no improvement: e)/ndoqen is to be taken with a)panth/santa, and there is no indication that there were any e)/cwqen pai=des.
ei)s kalo\n h(/keis. “Soyez le bienvenu!” For the construction see Goodwin, § 317.

xqe\s zhtw=n se ktl. Hug regards this as a piece of polite mendacity on the part of Agathon. Are we, then, to construe Alcibiades' statement, xqe\s me\n ou)x oi(=o/s te ktl. (212 E) as a similar exhibition of “Salonweltlichkeit”?
par' *)e. katakli/nou. Usually each kli/nh held two, but in 175 C it is said that Agathon had a couch to himself, while in 213 A we find three on the same couch.

a)poni/zein to\n pai=da. The article indicates that a special slave was set apart for this duty. For the custom of foot-washing see Plut. Phoc. 20; Petron. Sat. 31; Evang. Luc. vii. 44; Joann. xiii. 5. For the hand-washing see Ar. frag. 427 fe/re, pai=, taxe/ws kata\ xeiro\s u(/dwr, | para/pempe to\ xeiro/maktron.

*swkra/ths ou(=tos ktl. The ipsissima verba of the pai=s are here repeated, hence the use of ou(=tos and of the def. article with proqu/rw|: in the corrections proposed by Madvig and Herwerden this point is overlooked. For pro/quron, “porch,” i.e. the space between the house-door (au)lei/a) and the street, see Smith D. A. I. 661^{b}.
ou)/koun kalei=s ktl. kalei=s is of course future, not pres. as Rückert wrongly supposed. For the constr. see Goodwin G. M. T. § 299.

pa/ntws parati/qete. For the use of pa/ntws with imper., cp. Xen. Cyrop. VIII. 3. 27 pa/ntws toi/nun...dei=co/n moi: id. Oecon. XII. 11, III. 12. For parati/qhmi of “putting on the table,” cp. Rep. 372 C tragh/mata/ pou paraqh/somen au)toi=s ktl. Reynders adopts the reading pa/ntas, kai\ parati/qete.

e)peida\n...mh\ e)festh/kh|. These words are difficult. They should naturally mean (as Stallb. puts it) “si quando nemo vobis est propositus”; and so Stallb. proposes to construe them, taking the clause as dependent on and limiting o(/ ti a)\n bou/lhsqe. This, however, is, as Hug argues, almost certainly wrong. If we retain the text of the MSS. we can only explain the phrase by assuming an ellipse—“serve up what dishes you like (as you usually do) whenever no one is in command.” So Zeller renders “tragt uns getrost auf, was ihr wollt, wie ihr es gewohnt seid, wenn man euch nicht unter Aufsicht nimmt,” etc.; and Rieckher (Rhein. Mus. XXXIII. p. 307) “Machet es wie ihr es immer macht, wenn man euch nicht beaufsichtigt (und das habe ich ja noch nie gethan), und setzt uns vor was ihr möget.” Most of the emendations offered (see crit. n.) are based on the assumption that the clause in question qualifies the leading clause (pa/ntws parati/qete): none of them are convincing, and the construction ou) mh\...e)festh/kh| (the pres.-perf.) assumed by Schanz and Hug lacks support. If compelled to resort to conjecture, the best device might be to read ei)/ ge mh/ for e)peida/n, cut out the mh/ after u(mi=n, and change the mood of the verb to e)fe/sthken—following in part the suggestions of Usener. The ordinary text does not admit of Jowett's rendering, “serve up whatever you please, for there is no one to give you orders; hitherto I have never left you to yourselves.” As regards the force of o(\...e)poi/hsa, L. Schmidt explains the clause to mean “nunquam autem rem ita ut nunc institui,” implying that the concession to the slaves was unusual: Teuffel, on the contrary, sees in it a piece of ostentation on the part of Agathon, boasting of his humanity. The former is clearly wrong.

polla/kis keleu/ein. This is an ex. of the pres. infin. representing an impf. indic.: “He said, e)deipnou=men, o( de\ *s. ou)k ei)sh/|ei: o( ou)=n *)a. e)ke/leuen: e)gw\ de\ ou)k ei)/wn” (Goodwin G. M. T. § 119, where see parallels). The accus. e(/, of the speaker, is here used in preference to the more regular nomin. (au)to/s) in order to balance the accus. to\n *)aga/qwna: cp. Gorg. 474 B e)gw\ oi)=mai kai\ e)me\ kai\ de\...h(gei=sqai, and below 175 E.

w(s ei)w/qei. To be taken closely with ou) p. xr.: we should rather say “contrary to his usual custom,” the sense being “he arrived unusually soon for him.” For a striking instance of Socrates' e)/qos see 220 C, where polu\n xro/non die/triyen.

ma/lista...deipnou=ntas. For ma/lista of approximate measurement, cp. Parm. 127 B peri\ e)/th ma/lista pe/nte kai\ e(ch/konta: Tim. 21 B, Crito 43 A. Nowhere else in Plato is mesou=n joined with a participle, nor does L. and S. supply any parallel.

e)/sxaton...mo/non. Agathon occupied the last kli/nh on the right: this was the “lowest seat” at the table, and commonly taken, in politeness, by the host. The seat of honour (pronomh/) was the left-hand place on the kli/nh furthest to the left. Thus if four kli=nai are placed in a row, numbered A—D, and each seating two persons, the person who occupies A^{1} is termed prw=tos, and the occupant of D^{2} e)/sxatos: as thus

At this “Banquet” Phaedrus as occupying A^{1} is described as prw=tos in 177 D: see also the discussion between Socrates and Alcibiades in 222 E. Cp. Theophr. Char. 21 o( de\ mikrofilo/timos toiou=to/s tis oi(=os spouda/sai e)pi\ dei=pnon klhqei\s par' au)to
 to
 kale/santa deipnh=sai: Stob. Flor. XIII. 36 *dionu/sios...a)tima/zwn au)to
... kate/klinen au)to
 e)n th=| e)sxa/th| xw/ra|.

tou= sofou=...a)polau/sw . tou= sofou= is neut., being the antecedent of o(/, not in agreement with sou: “that I may enjoy the piece of wisdom which occurred to you.” The omission of a(pto/meno/s sou by B is probably accidental: without the words (as Teuffel observes) Socr.'s remark (e)a\n a(pt.) would be less natural.

ou) ga a)
 proape/sths. The protasis is suppressed: Stallbaum supplies ei) mh\ eu(=res au)to/: while Hug explains the phrase as a conflate of two thoughts, viz. (1) ou)k a)
 a)pe/sths ei) mh\ eu(=res, and (2) ou) proape/sths pri
 eu(rei=n.
ei)s to\ kenw/teron. Ficinus renders “ut in vacuum hominem ex pleniore ipso contactu proflueret,” and many edd. adopt to/n in preference to to/ (so too Jowett's transl.).

w(/sper to\...u(/dwr ktl. Editors from Rückert down generally accept the explanation of this passage offered by Geel. Two cups, one empty the other full, are placed in contact: a woollen thread, with one end inserted in the full cup, the other hanging into the empty cup, serves by the law of capillarity to convey the fluid from the one to the other.
fau/lh...kai\ a)mfisbhth/simos. “Meagre” in quantity and “questionable” in quality, in antithesis to pollh/ in quantity and kalh/ in quality.

pollh\n e)pi/dosin e)/xousa. Hug supposes an astral allusion—“like a quicklyrising star.” This, however, is not necessarily conveyed by the term e)pi/dosis, for which cp. Theaet. 146 B h( neo/ths ei)s pa=n e)pi/dosin e)/xei, and the intrans. use of e)pidido/nai, Prot. 318 A, Theaet. 150 D, etc.
ou(/tw sfo/dra ktl. Notice the ironical tone—exaggeration coupled with a purple patch of poetic diction: “shone out with such dazzling splendour before the eyes of three myriads of Greek spectators.”
*(ubristh\s ei)=. “What a scoffer you are!” Observe that u(/bris is one of the main charges laid against Socr. by Alcibiades also (219 C, etc.); cp. Introd. § II. B.

tau=ta...diadikaso/meqa. “We will formally plead our claims in regard to these heads.” “Technically diadicasia denotes the proceedings in a contest for preference between two or more rival parties either as to the possession
of property or as to exemption from personal or pecuniary liabilities....The essential difference between diadicasia and the ordinary di/kai is, that all claimants are similarly situated with respect to the subject of dispute, and no longer classified as plaintiffs and defendants” (Smith, D. A. I. 620^{b}). peri\ th=s sofi/as, added loosely as an afterthought, serves to define tau=ta: Teuffel, as against Jahn, rightly defends the words; and they serve to strike one of the keynotes of the dialogue.

dikasth=|...tw=| *dionu/sw|. Dionysus is an appropriate choice since it was under his auspices that Agathon (prw/|hn) had engaged in an a)gw/n and won a prize for poetic sofi/a. There may also lie in the words (as Wolf and Rettig suppose) a jocular allusion to the sofi/a which is ars bibendi, wherein also Agathon was dunatw/tatos (176 C). Compare also the pastoral pipe-contests of Theocritus, and Theognis 993 ff. ei)...a)=qlon... | soi/ t' ei)/h kai\ e)moi\ sofi/hs pe/ri qhrisa/ntoin, | gnoi/hs x' o(/sson o)/nwn kre/ssones h(mi/onoi. Cp. Introd. § II. B.

sponda/s...nomizo/mena. Plato spares us the details of the ritual proper to such occasions. From other sources we may gather that it included (1) a libation of unmixed wine to a)gaqo\s dai/mwn (Ar. Eq. 105, etc.); (2) the clearing, or removal, of the tables (Xen. Symp. II. 1); (3) the fetching, by the pai=des, of a second supply of water for the hands (Ar. Vesp. 1217 etc.); (4) the distribution of wreaths among the guests (Theogn. 1001, Ar. Acharn. 1145); (5) the pouring out of three libations, viz. a to Zeus Olympios and the Olympian gods, b to the Heroes, and c to Zeus Soter (Schol. ad Phileb. 66 D; Aesch. Suppl. 27, etc.); (6) the singing of a Te Deum (a)/|dein to\n qeo/n, paiani/zein Xen. Symp. II. 1, Alcman fr. 24 B, etc.): see Hug's exhaustive note. Rückert wrongly makes ta)=lla ta\ nomizo/mena depend on a)/|santas: supply (as Reynders) poihsame/nous. For kai\ ta)=lla, cp. (with Vahlen) Euthyd. 294 C, Rep. 400 D: for ta\ nomizo/mena, quae moris sunt, cp. II. Alc. 151 B.

ti/na tro/pon r(a=|sta. Schol. r(a=|sta: to\ h(/dista e)ntau=qa shmai/nei. Cp. Od. IV. 565 th=| per (sc. in Elysium) r(hi/sth bioth/: and the combination r(a=|sta kai\ h(/dista, Xen. Mem. II. 1. 9. (See also Vahlen Op. Acad. II. 212 ff. ad Phaedo 81 C).
pa/nu xalepw=s e)/xw. The notion is “I was roughly handled in my bout with the wine-god yesterday”: cp. Theaet. 142 B xalepw=s e)/xei u(po\ trauma/twn tinw=n.

bebaptisme/nwn: “soaked,” “drenched.” Cp. Lucian Bacch. 7 karhkai\ bebaptisme/nw|: and the use of bebregme/nos, Eubul. Incert. 5; me/qh| barou=nti brexqei/s Eur. El. 326: Sen. Ep. 83 mersus vino et madens; Hor. C. IV. 5. 39 dicimus...sicci...dicimus uvidi. A similar “baptism” is described in Evenos 2. 5—6, ei) de\ polu\s pneu/seien (sc. o( *ba/kxos) a)pe/straptai me\n e)/rwtas, | bapti/zei d' u(/pnw| gei/toni tou= qana/tou: of which we find an echo in Clem. Alex. Paed. II. ii. 27^{2} (Stählin) u(po\ me/qhs baptizo/menos ei)s u(/pnon. There may be an underlying allusion to Eupolis' play *baptai/ (cp. Bergk P. L. G. II. p. 268).
e)cairw= lo/gou: “I leave out of account”: cp. Phaedrus 242 B, Rep. 394 B, 492 E. For Socrates as inconvincible “with wine and wassail,” see Alcibiades' description, 220 A.
peri\ tou= mequ/skesqai. A favourite subject of discussion with moralists, e.g. Theognis 473 ff., 500 ff.; Laws I. 677 D ff., Xen. Symp. II.; and the treatise peri\ me/qhs of Antisthenes.

h(=tton...a)hdh/s. “Less likely to bore you,” sc. than if you were in the mood for wine-bibbing. Compare (with Wolf) Hor. Sat. II. ii. 1 ff. quae virtus et quanta, boni, sit vivere parvo...discite non inter lances mensasque nitentes.

xalepo
...h( me/qh. Similarly in 180 B we have neut. adj. with masc. subst. (qeio/teron...e)rasth/s). For the sentiment cp. Ar. Vesp. 1253 kako
 to\ pi/nein: ktl.: Theogn. 211 oi)=no/n toi pi/nein poulu
 kako/n: Xen.
Symp. II. 26 h)
 me
 a)qro/on to\ poto
 e)gxew/meqa, taxu\ h(mi=n kai\ ta\ sw/mata kai\ ai( gnw=mai sfalou=ntai ktl. For the pedantic reference to h( i)atrikh/, cp. 186 A.
kraipalw=nta. Tim. Lex. Plat. explains by e)/ti a)po\ th=s me/qhs baruno/menon. For the accus., in place of dat. (in appos. to a)/llw|), cp. 188 D h(mi=n...duname/nous: Rep. 414 A, etc.

nu=n d)...oi( loipoi/. With oi( loipoi/ we must supply soi\ pei/sontai, as Stallb. and Winckelmann observed. Rettig alone, of later editors, retains the reading nu=n d' au)= eu)= bou/lontai, with Wolf's rendering, “nunc bene est, quod item reliquos id velle video”; but, as Hug remarks, that eu)= bou/lontai can mean “bene est quod volunt” lacks proof.

ou(/tw...pro\s h(donh/n . ou(/tws is frequently used thus in combination with adverbs (esp. r(adi/ws, ei)kh=|, a(plw=s, and the like; see Blaydes on Ar. Vesp. 461) where it has “a diminishing power” (L. and S.), e.g. 180 C infra, Gorg. 503 D; cp. the force of sic in such phrases as “iacentes sic temere” (Hor. C. II. xi. 14).

tou=to me\n ktl. The antithesis to the me/n-clause lies, not in the clause e)pa/nagkes de\ m. ei)=nai, but in to\ meta\ tou=to ktl. Cp. Arist. Pol. 1278^{b} 6 e)pei\ de\ tau=ta diw/ristai, to\ meta\ tau=ta skepte/on po/teron ktl.
e)pa/nagkes. Cp. Theogn. 472 pa=n ga\r a)nagkai=on xrh=m' a)nihro\n e)/fu: | tw=| pi/nein d' e)qe/lonti parastado\n oi)noxoei/tw—where a similar relaxation of compulsory rules is advocated.
ei)shgou=mai. “I propose,” suadeo: cp. Crito 48 A; Xen. Mem. II. 7. 10.

th\n...au)lhtri/da. It was the fashion at convivia to provide pipers, dancers, jesters, jugglers et hoc genus omne to amuse the guests. Cp. Xen. Symp. II. 1, Rep. 373 A kli=nai/ te...kai\ e(tai=rai kai\ pe/mmata (with Adam's note); Ar. Ach. 1090 ff.; also Protag. 347 C, D (see next page).
tai=s e)/ndon. Sc. e)n tw=| gunaikei/w|.

di) oi(/wn lo/gwn. For an appreciation of the sunousi/a dia\ lo/gwn, cp. Theogn. 493 ff. u(mei=s d' eu)= muqei=sqe para\ krhth=ri me/nontes... | e)s to\ me/son fwneu=ntes o(mw=s e(ni\ kai\ suna/pasin: | xou)/tws sumpo/sion gi/netai ou)k a)/xari. Simplic. in Epict. 33. 6, p. 266 kalw=s ei)/rhtai o(/ti h( xwri\s lo/gwn tra/peza fa/tnhs ou)de\n diafe/rei which is probably a reminiscence of Protag. 347 C, D kai\ ga\r ou(=toi (sc. oi( fau=loi kai\ a)gorai=oi), dia\ to\ mh\ du/nasqai a)llh/lois di) e(autw=n sunei=nai e)n tw=| po/tw| mhde\ dia\ th=s e(autw=n fwnh=s kai\ tw=n lo/gwn tw=n e(autw=n u(po\ a)paideusi/as, timi/as poiou=si ta\s au)lhtri/das ktl. Cp. Phaedrus 276 D.

*fa/nai dh\ ktl. It is tempting to excise (with Hermann, Teuffel and Hug) the first kai/ and to construe fa/nai closely with bou/lesqai, as balancing keleu/ein ei)shgei=sqai, pa/ntas being the subject of both the leading infinn., fa/nai and keleu/ein: cp. 177 E cune/fasa/n te kai\ e)ke/leuon: Euthyd. 274 C o(/ te ou)=n *kth/sippos sune/fh...kai\ oi( a)/lloi, kai\ e)ke/leuon...e)pidei/casqai ktl. If the first kai\ be retained, it seems most natural to take keleu/ein as dependent on fa/nai: Stallb., however, puts a comma after bou/lesqai, as if making keleu/ein parallel to fa/nai: and so too, apparently, Zeller.

kata\ th
 *melani/pphn. Euripides wrote two plays of this name, M. h( sofh/ and M. desmw=tis. The reference here is to the former (Frag. 488 Nauck), ou)k e)mo\s o( mu=qos a)ll' e)mh=s mhtro\s pa/ra, ktl. Melanippe, a daughter of Aeolus, bore two sons to Poseidon; they were suckled by a cow, and brought to their grandfather Aeolus as bougenh= te/rata: when he proposed to burn them, Melanippe appeared and tried to dissuade him, arguing o(/ti ou)de
 te/ras e)sti/n. According to another account, M. was a daughter of Cheiron, seduced by Aeolus, and finally metamorphosed into a mare. Cp. Apol. 20 E ou) ga e)mo
 e)rw= to
 lo/gon, ktl.: Hor. Sat. II. ii. 2 nec meus hic sermo est sed quae praecepit Ofellus.
*ou) deino/n ktl. With this passage, cp. Isocr. IX. 5—8, and X. 12 with its scornful reference to encomiasts of “humble-bees, salt-diets, and the like” (see Introd. § II. B (e)).

u(/mnous kai\ paiw=nas. Properly speaking u(/mnoi are odes set for the lyre, paiw=nes odes set for the flute and sung esp. in honour of Apollo. “The paean is a hymn (1) of supplication or propitiation during the pain or danger; (2) a thanksgiving after it is past” (see Smith, D. A. II. 307 s.v.).

thlikou/tw|. “A god so venerable”: Phaedrus holds Eros to be the most ancient of deities, see 178 B. The complaint was not entirely well-grounded, since before this date (416 B.C.) hymns to Eros of a eulogistic character had already been published by Sophocles (Antig. 781 ff.), and Euripides (Hippol. 525 ff.), and possibly others.

ei) de\ bou/lei. This phrase serves to introduce a fresh point, marking the transition from poets to “sophists”; cp. 209 D, 220 D (ei) de\ bou/lesqe), Lach. 188 C, etc.: but to add an infin., as here (ske/yasqai), is unusual.
tou\s xrhstou\s sofista/s. “The worthy sophists”; considering that Phaedrus is the speaker, we must suppose that the adj. is seriously meant, not ironical.
kataloga/dhn cuggra/fein. “Writing in prose,” oratione soluta. Cp. Isocr. II. 7 kai\ tw=n meta\ me/trou poihma/twn kai\ tw=n kataloga/dhn suggramma/twn: Lysis 204 D, Laws 811 E, 975 D.

w(/sper...*pro/dikos. This alludes to Prodicus's celebrated parable “The Choice of Heracles,” for which see Xen. Mem. II. i. 21 ff. For Prodicus of Ceos, see Zeller Presocr. Phil. vol. II. pp. 416 ff., 473 (E. T.); Gomperz Gr. Thinkers (E. T.) I. pp. 425 ff.
h(=tton kai\. For the unusual position of kai\ after the comparative, cp. Xen. Cyr. I. vi. 38 tau=ta ga\r ma=llon kai\ e)capata=n du/natai.

e)nh=san a(/les. Logically, of course, the subject ought to be e)/painos, not a(/les. The same bibli/on is alluded to in Isocr. X. 12 tw=n...tou\s bombuliou\s kai\ tou\s a(/las kai\ ta\ toiau=ta boulhqe/ntwn e)painei=n: its authorship is now generally ascribed (as by Sauppe, Blass, Hug) to the rhetor Polycrates: see further Introd. § II. B (e).
to\ ou)=n...u(mnh=sai. The infin. may be explained (with Ast) as an ex. of the infin. “indignantis,” cp. Ar. Nub. 819 to\ *di/a nomi/zein o)/nta thlikoutoni/.

e)/ranon ei)senegkei=n. Symbolum dare: cp. Laws 915 E, 927 C w(s e)/ranon ei)sfe/ronta e(autw=|—the only other instances of e)/ranos in Plato. For a defence of the text against Hartmann, who excises kai\ xari/sasqai, see Vahlen Op. Acad. II. 296. This passage is echoed in Aristid. Or. t. I. p. 18.
dokei= ga/r moi. “My sentence is,” an official formula: cf. Dem. I. 2, IV. 17. Hence the point of Socrates' phrase e)nanti/a yhfiei=tai, four lines below.
lo/gon...e)/painon. Cp. 214 B, Phaedrus 260 B suntiqei\s lo/gon e)/painon kata\ tou= o)/nou.
e)pi\ decia\. “From left to right”: cp. Rep. 420 E (with Adam's note); Theaet. 175 E. Critias 2. 7 kai\ propo/seis o)re/gein e)pide/cia.
ka/lliston. Notice that, in Eryximachus' view, the first requisite is ka/llos, and contrast the view of Socrates in 198 D ff.

path\r tou= lo/gou. I.e. ei)shghth\s tou= l., as Plutarch explains (Plat. Q. 1000 F): the same phrase recurs in Phaedrus 257 B, cp. Theaet. 164 E o( path\r tou= mu/qou: Lysis 214 A pate/res th=s sofi/as kai\ h(gemo/nes.

ta\ e)rwtika/. The objects or principles with which h( e)rwtikh\ te/xnh (Phaedrus 257 A) is concerned; cp. 186 C, 212 B, Lysis 204 B. This passage is alluded to by Themist. Or. XIII. p. 161, Max. Tyr. diss. XXIV. p. 288: for its significance here, see Introd. § II. B.
ou)/te pou...kai\ . kai\ is used rather than ou)/te because Pausanias and Agathon formed “ein Liebespaar” (Hug).

peri\ *dio/nuson kai\ *)afrodi/thn. There are many points of mutual connexion between Eros, Dionysus and Aphrodite. Thus, Dionysus is the patron-god of the theatre, as shown by the phrases oi( peri\ to\n *d. texni=tai, “actors” (Arist. Probl. XXX. 10), and *dionusoko/lakes, “stage-lackeys” (Arist. Rhet. III. 1205^{a} 23); and on the comic stage erotic scenes were frequent. Moreover, Dionysus was sometimes represented (as by Praxilla of Sicyon, c. 450 B.C.) to be a son of Aphrodite; and in Aristoph. fr. incert. 490 (Df.) oi)=nos is termed *)afrodi/ths ga/la. For the traditional inter-connexion of “Wein, Weib und Gesang,” we may also compare Solon 26 e)/rga de\ *kupro-
genou=s nu=n moi fi/la kai\ *dionu/sou | kai\ *mouse/wn, a(\ ti/qhs' a)ndra/sin eu)frosu/nas. Echoes of this phrase are to be found in Aristaen. I. ep. 3, p. 11; Plut. amat. 750 A; Lucian Symp. p. 444.
h(mi=n toi=s u(sta/tois . u(/statos here is equivalent to e)/sxatos as used in 175 C (where see note), i.e. placed on the extreme right.
e)carke/sei h(mi=n. “We shall be content,” i.e. we shall not be called upon to speak: for the impers. e)carkei= c. dat. cp. 176 C, 192 B, 210 C.
tu/xh| a)gaqh=|. “In Gottes Namen” (Wolf); cp. Phileb. 57 E, Tim. 26 E.
pa/ntes a)/ra. For the position of a)/ra cp. Prot. 319 A h)= kalo/n, h)=n d' e)gw/, te/xnhma a)/ra ke/kthsai: Rep. 358 C polu\ ga\r a)mei/nwn a)/ra ktl.

div1.head: Speech of Phaedrus
div1.p: a)ciomnhmo/neuton. We should expect rather the plural. We must suppose that the sentence is slightly confused, the original idea being to put a(\ de\ ma/lista e)/doce/ moi a)ciomnhmo/neuta (tau=ta e)rw=), which was altered owing to the insertion, as an afterthought, of kai\ w(=n: then, instead of proceeding w(=n e)/doce/ moi a)/cion to\ memnh=sqai (or memnh=sqai tou= lo/gou), the word originally in mind was put down, but in the sing.: but it is tempting to restore either a)ciomnhmo/neut' ei)=nai (supposing ei)=nai to be corrupted from a compendium), or a)/cion mnhmoneu/ein. Prot. 343 A (r(h/mata braxe/a a)ciomnhmo/neuta) is the only other instance of the word in Plato: there may be an echo of the present passage in Xen. Symp. I. 1 e)moi\ dokei= tw=n kalw=n ka)gaqw=n a)ndrw=n e)/rga...a)ciomnhmo/neuta ei)=nai. For the significance of the statement here made by Apollod., see Introd. § II. B (g).
*prw=ton me\n ga\r ktl. For the discourse of Phaedrus (178 A—180 B) see Introd. § I. (analysis), § III. (1).
w(/sper le/gw. “As has been stated”: the present tense (186 E, 193 A, etc.) is commoner than the past tense (ei)=pon 173 C, 182 D, etc.) in this formula. The reference is to 177 D.
e)nqe/nde poqe\n. “Roughly at this point,” hinc fere: the combination recurs 199 C, Phaedrus 229 B, Euthyd. 275 E; so e)nteu=qe/n poqen Phaedrus 270 A, Rep. 524 C.
kata\ th)n ge/nesin. “In respect of his origin.”

e)n toi=s presbu/taton. For the doctrine of the antiquity of Eros, cp. Xen. Symp. VIII. 1 tw=| me\n xro/nw| i)sh/likos toi=s a)eigene/si qeoi=s...*)/erwtos: Ar. Av. 700 pro/teron d' ou)k h)=n ge/nos a)qana/twn, pri\n *)/erws sune/micen a(/panta. Agathon, in 195 A, expressly contradicts Phaedrus on this point. Bast excised h)= d' o(/s on the ground that “in fine periodi Platonicae non magis usurpatur quam inquit Latinorum.”
tekmh/rion de\...ga\r. Cp. Critias 110 E, Apol. 40 C: Xen. Symp. IV. 17 tekmh/rion de/: qallofo/rous ga\r...e)kle/gontai.

gonh=s...ou)/te le/gontai. This is a rash statement on the part of Phaedrus; for Alcaeus (fr. 13 Bgk.) makes Eros son of Zephyros and Iris; Simonides (fr. 43), son of Ares and Aphrodite; Euripides (Hippol. 534), son of Zeus; Sappho (fr. 132), of Gê and Uranos; Ibycus (fr. 31), of Chaos; see also the statements in 199 D, 203 ff. infra. On the other hand ignorance or doubt as to the parentage of Eros is expressed in Theocr. Id. XIII. 1, 2 ou)x a(mi=n to
 *)/erwta mo/nois e)/tex' ...w(=|tini tou=to qew=n poka te/knon e)/gento; Anth. Pal. V. 176. 7—8 patro\s d' ou)ke/t' e)/xw fra/zein ti/nos: ou)/te ga *ai)qh/r, | ou) *xqw/n fhsi tekei=n to
 qrasu/n, ou) *pe/lagos. For the usual Greek assumption that the poets are religious teachers, cp. Ar. Ran. 1054 toi=s me
 ga paidari/oisin | e)/sti dida/skalos o(/stis fra/zei, toi=s h(bw=sin de\ poihtai/: and see Adam, R. T. G. pp. 9 ff.

i)diw/tou. For this distinction between the prose-writer and the poet, cp. Phaedrus 258 D; Laws 890 A; Rep. 366 E. The term i)diw/ths may be taken as a survival of the time when the poet alone had his work “published”—at religious festivals, theatrical shows, kw=moi, etc.

*)hsi/odos ktl. The reference is to Theog. 116 ff. h)/toi me\n prw/tista *xa/os ge/net' , au)ta\r ktl. Cp. Ar. Av. 693 ff. *xa/os h)=n kai\ *nu\c ktl. The order of the text I have adopted, in the passage following, is that proposed by Schanz, except that he reads o(mologei= <o(/s> fhsi, while Burnet, accepting the transposition, prints su/mfhsi instead of o(mologei= fhsi. Hug and others eject the clause fhsi...*)/erwta as a marginal prose paraphrase of the words of Hesiod; since, as it stands in the traditional order, the clause is obviously tautologous: but tautology is in itself no objection, but rather characteristic of Ph.'s style
(see Teuffel in Rhein. Mus. XXIX. p. 133); and there is force in Hermann's remark “aegre intelligo quomodo aliquis clarissimis poetae verbis (paraphrasin) addendam existimaverit, multoque verisimilius videtur Hesiodi locum...postmodo adscriptum...irrepsisse.” I bracket the clause as a gloss on o(mologei=. The clause *parmeni/dhs...pa/ntwn is rightly defended by Hug, against Voegelin and others, on the grounds that (1) ou(/tw pollaxo/qen in the following sentence is more appropriate after three than after two instances, and (2) Agathon in 195 C, when alluding to Phaedrus's speech, expressly mentions *(hsi/odos kai\ *parmeni/dhs. The authority of Hesiod is similarly cited by Plut. amat. 756 E.

*)akousi/lews. Acusilaus of Argos, the “logographer,” about B.C. 475 (?), wrote in the Ionic dialect several books of Genealogies, largely based on Hesiod (see the fragg. in A. Kordt, De Acusilao, 1903). But the reputed work of A., extant in the time of Hadrian, was probably a forgery: a collector of myths is not, properly speaking, a “logographer” at all (see Jevons, Gk. Lit. p. 299). Cp. Clem. Alex. VI. ii. 26. 7 ta\ de\ *(hsio/dou meth/llacan ei)s pezo\n lo/gon kai\ w(s i)/dia e)ce/negkan *eu)/mhlo/s te kai\ *)akousi/laos oi( i(storiogra/foi. Hug, retaining the order of the MSS., would explain the fact that A. is put last as due to his being an i)diw/ths, the others poihtai/.

*parmeni/dhs. See Parmen. frag. 132 (Karsten), R. and P. 101 A; Arist. Met. I. 4. 984^{b} 25; Plut. amat. 756 F. It is to be presumed that the famous Eleate relegated this theogony to his “Way of Opinion.” Cp. Spenser's lines (H. to Love), “Or who alive can perfectly declare The wondrous cradle of thine infancie... For ere this worlds still moving mightie masse Out of great Chaos ugly prison crept... Love... Gan reare his head, by Clotho being waked.”

th\n *ge/nesin...mhti/sato. Hermann and Hug follow Stallbaum in supplying *ge/nesis as the subject of mhti/sato: cp. Phaedo 94 D ou(= le/gei to\n *)odusse/a sth=qos de\ plh/cas kradi/hn h)ni/pape mu/qw|. For the personification of ge/nesis, cp. Hom. Il. XIV. 201 *)wkeano/n te qew=n ge/nesin kai\ mhte/ra *thqu/n (cited by Plato in Theaet. 180 D, Crat. 402 B). Plutarch (loc. cit. differs by making *)afrodi/th the subject of mhti/sato. It is, of course, possible that another (suppressed) subject is intended; since we do not know what the context was in the original.
presbu/tatos de\ w)\n ktl. The partic. gives the impression of a causal connexion—as if beneficence must be in direct proportion to antiquity!
megi/stwn...ai)/tios. Cp. 197 C below; Ar. Plut. 469 a)gaqw=n a(pa/ntwn ai)ti/an.

eu)qu\s ne/w| o)/nti. “From his earliest youth”: this properly applies only to the paidika/. With paidika/ supply xrhsta/. For a similar estimate of the value of fi/loi, see Lysis 211 E, Xen. Mem. II. 4. 1 ff.

a)nqrw/pois...bi/ou. For h(gei=sqai c. dat. of person and gen. of thing, cp. Hom. Od. XXIII. 134 h(mi=n h(gei/sqw o)rxhqmoi=o: Xen. Cyr. VIII. 7. 1 tou= xo/rou h(gh/sato *pe/rsais. It would be easy, however, by inserting dia/ after the termin. -ai, to restore a favourite Platonic phrase dia\ panto\s tou= bi/ou (cp. 203 D, Phileb. 39 E).

sugge/neia. “Kindred,” implying nobility of kin: for the concrete use cp. Gorg. 472 B, Laws 730 B, 874 A, etc., and esp. Rep. 491 C ka/llos kai\ plou=tos kai\ i)sxu\s sw/matos kai\ cugge/neia e)rrwme/nh e)n po/lei. Taking sugge/neia here in a similar sense, we can dispense with Wyttenbach's plausible conj., eu)ge/neia (for which cp. Euthyd. 279 B, Ar. Rhet. II. 15, Soph. Antig. 38), which Reynders adopts.

ai)sxu/nhn...filotimi/an. Cp. Lys. XIV. 2, and 42 (in Alcib.) e)pi\ me\n toi=s kaloi=s ai)sxu/nesqai, e)pi\ de\ toi=s kakoi=s filotimei=sqai, “taking glory for shame and shame for glory.” Remembering that Phaedrus was a professed admirer of Lysias, we may, perhaps, recognize here a verbal echo. For a discussion of ai)sxu/nh (not distinguished from ai)dw/s) see Arist. Eth. Nic. IV. ix. 1128^{b} 10, and Rhet. II. vi. 1383^{b} 12.
ou)/te po/lin ou)/te i)diw/thn. Notice that in the subsequent treatment of these two heads the order is reversed (to secure rhetorical “Chiasmus”).

ei)/ ti ai)sxro\n ktl. Cp. Xen. Cyneg. XII. 20 o(/tan me\n ga/r tis o(ra=tai u(po\ tou= e)rwme/nou a(/pas e(autou= e)sti belti/wn kai\ ou)/te le/gei ou)/te poiei= ai)sxra\ ou)de\ kaka/, i(/na mh\ o)fqh=| u(p' e)kei/nwn. Also 194 C infra.

h)\ pa/sxwn ktl. Cp. “It hath been said by them of old time, An eye for an eye, and a tooth for a tooth.” Ordinary Greek ethics approved of retaliation:
cp. Xen. Cyrop. VIII. 7. 7; see Dobbs, Philos. and Popular Morals, etc. p. 39. For another incentive to courage, see Rep. 467 B.
tau)to\n de\ tou=to. “In exactly similar fashion,” adverbial accus.: so tau)ta\ tau=ta Meno 90 E.
tou\s e)rasta\s. The plural is due to the fact that it was usual for a number of e)rastai/ to pay court to the same paidika/ (cp. Charm. 154 A).

ei) ou)=n mhxanh/ tis ktl. Here Ph. passes on to his second head,—the benefits derived from Eros in civic and national life (po/lin, 178 D above). For the phrase cp. Laws 640 B ei) d' h)=n tis mhxanh/ ktl.: Parm. 132 D, Phileb. 16 A.

strato/pedon e)rastw=n. It is noteworthy that Xen. (Symp. VIII. 32) puts a similar statement in the mouth of Pausanias—*pausani/as ge...ei)/rhken w(s kai\ stra/teuma a)lkimw/taton a)\n ge/noito e)k paidikw=n te kai\ e)rastw=n (cp. Introd. § VIII. ad fin.). Cp. also Xen. Cyrop. VII. 1. 30 ou)k e)/stin i)sxurote/ra fa/lagc h)\ o(/tan e)k fi/lwn summa/xwn h)qroisme/nh h)=|. This principle was exemplified in the famous i(ero\s lo/xos of the Thebans, organized by Gorgidas (or Epaminondas), which fought first at Leuctra, 371 B.C., see Athen. XIII. 561 F, 602 A. A Roman analogy is afforded by Scipio's fi/lwn i)/lh. The parallel in Xenophon is of itself sufficient to refute Jahn's athetesis of h)\ strato/pedon.

ou)k e)/stin o(/pws a)
 ktl. Hug, retaining h)\ before a)pexo/menoi, would supply, with the participles, from the context “welche Gefühle allein durch den Eros in wirksamer Weise erregt werden.” This, however, is exceedingly awkward; and his further remark that ou)k a)/meinon oi)kh/seian a)
 h)\ a)pexo/menoi is equivalent to a)/rist' a)
 oi)k. a)pex. does nothing to lessen the difficulty. By ejecting h)\, as a very natural interpolation after the comparative by a copyist careless of the sense, we obtain the meaning required—“it would be impossible for them to secure a better constitution of their city, since thus they would abstain” etc.
maxo/menoi ktl. Cp. Rep. 471 D a)/rist' a)\n ma/xointo tw=| h(/kista a)polei/pein a)llh/lous...a)/maxoi a)\n ei)=en: Xen. Symp. VIII. 32 ff.

lipw\n ta/cin h)\ o(/pla a)pobalw/n. “The principal military offences at Athens were dealt with by one law. A citizen was liable to indictment, and, if convicted, to disfranchisement for (1) Failure to join the army—a)stratei/as: (2) Cowardice in battle—deili/as: (3) Desertion of his post—lipotaci/ou: (4) Desertion from the army—lipostrati/ou. Of these terms, lipotaci/ou was that used in the widest sense, and might include any of the others” (Smith, D. A. I. 212^{b}). Cp. Rep. 468 A, Laws 943 D ff., and the compounds r(i/yaspis (Laws 944 B, C; Ar. Vesp. 19), a)spidapoblh/s (Vesp. 592). The conduct of the ideal e)rasth/s on such an occasion is shown in 220 E infra.

kinduneu/onti. For the sing. dat. referring to paidikoi=s, cp. Phaedrus 239 A, and 184 D infra. After kinduneu/onti we should expect the sentence to conclude with ou)dei\s tolmw/|h a)\n or the like: the fact that a new ending is substituted may be regarded (with Ast) as due to the agitation (real or pretended) of the speaker “vom furor eroticus ergriffen.”

e)/nqeon pro\s a)reth/n. For e)/nqeos, “god-inhabited,” “inspired,” cp. Ion 533 E e)/nqeoi o)/ntes kai\ katexo/menoi: ibid. 534 B and below, 180 B. fu/sei, denoting “natural” temper, is here opposed to this supervenient grace. For the thought cp. Spenser (H. to Love), “(The lover) dreads no danger, nor misfortune feares...Thou cariest him to that which he hath eyde Through seas, through flames, through thousand swords and speares.”
*(/omhros. See Il. X. 482 tw=| d' e)/mpneuse me/nos glaukw=pis *)aqh/nh: ib. XV. 262, Od. IX. 381. Cp. the (Lacedaemonian) term ei)spnh/las for e)rasth/s: also Xen. Symp. IV. 15.
u(perapoqnh/skein. Cp. Isocr. Hel. 217 C h(=s e(/neka polloi\ tw=n h(miqe/wn a)poqnh/skein h)qe/lhsan.

ou) mo/non o(/ti. This expression may be defended by Thuc. IV. 85. 3 kai\ ga\r ou) mo/non o(/ti au)toi\ a)nqi/stasqe, a)lla\ kai\ oi(=s a)\n e)pi/w, h(=sso/n tis e)moi\ pro/seisin: Arist. Pol. VII. 11. 1331^{a} 11 ou)x o(/ti tei/xh mo/non periblhte/on (with Newman's note): Xen. Mem. II. 9. 8. Jahn's ou)x o(/ti would give, as Teuffel argues, the
wrong sense “I do not say men do so, cela va sans dire.” We may explain ou) mo/non o(/ti as elliptical for ou) mo/non (le/gw) o(/ti.

a)/ndres...ai( gunai=kes. The addition of the article serves to signalize the second case as the more striking: cp. I. Alcib. 105 B e)n *(/ellhsin...e)n toi=s barba/rois: Phileb. 45 E, ib. 64 C; Vahlen on Arist. Poet. IV. 1449^{a} 1.
*)/alkhstis. Besides Euripides, Phrynichus (438 B.C.) and later Antiphanes (354 B.C.) made Alcestis the theme of a tragedy: see also the Skolion by Praxilla in Bergk P. L. G. III. § 1293.
u(pe\r tou=de tou= lo/gou. “In support of my argument.”
ei)s tou\s *(/ellhnas. Cp. Protag. 312 A ei)s tou\s *(/ellhnas sauto\n sofisth\n pare/xwn: Gorg. 526 B: Thuc. I. 33. 2.
e)qelh/sasa mo/nh ktl. Cp. Eur. Alc. 15 ff. pa/ntas d' e)le/gcas...*ou)x eu(=re plh\n gunaiko\s h(/tis h)/qele | qanei=n pro\ kei/nou.

ou(\s e)kei/nh ktl. See Eur. Alc. 683 ff. where the appeal of Admetus is thus answered by his father Pheres: ou) ga\r patrw=|on to/nd' e)deca/mhn no/mon | pai/dwn proqnh/skein pate/ras ou)d' *(ellhniko/n.
a)llotri/ous. Admetus might have described his a)llo/trioi prosh/kontes as “a little more than kin and less than kind.”
eu)ariqmh/tois. A grandiose synonym for o)li/gois.

e)/dosan tou=to ge/ras...a)gasqe/ntes. Cp. Phaedrus 259 B o(\ ge/ras para\ qew=n e)/xousin a)nqrw/pois dido/nai, ta/x' a)\n doi=en a)gasqe/ntes. a)/gamai can take either the genitive (Rep. 426 D, etc.) or the accus. (Symp. 219 D, etc.). This passage is alluded to by Plut. amat. 762 A le/gontes e)c a(/|dou toi=s e)rwtikoi=s a)/nodon ei)s fw=s u(pa/rxein.
ou(/tw...timw=sin. Cp. Xen. Symp. VIII. 28 a)lla\ kai\ qeoi\ kai\ h(/rwes th\n th=s yuxh=s fili/an peri\ plei/onos...poiou=ntai.

*)orfe/a. For the legend of Orpheus and his wife Eurydice, see Paus. IX. 30, Virg. Georg. IV. 454 ff., Ovid Met. X. 1 ff. Phaedrus modifies the usual story (1) by making Eurydice a fa/sma, and Orpheus consequently a)telh/s (cp. Stesichorus' treatment of the Helen-legend, followed also by Euripides in his Helena, and Phaedrus 243 B): (2) by making O.'s descent an act of malaki/a rather than of to/lma (as Hermesianax 2. 7, Ov. Met. X. 13 ad Styga Taenaria est ausus descendere porta ): (3) by representing O.'s death to be a penalty for this cowardice rather than for his irreverence to Dionysus (as Aeschylus Bassarai, etc.). For Orpheus and Orphism in general, see Miss J. Harrison Proleg. pp. 455 ff.

a(/te w)\n kiqarw|do/s. As if the “soft Lydian airs” of the cithara conduced to effeminacy. For the cithara, as distinguished from the lu/ra, see Rep. 399 D—E (with Adam's note). It is worth noticing that Spenser (H. to Love) cites Orpheus as an instance of e)/nqeos to/lma—“Orpheus daring to provoke the yre Of damned fiends, to get his love retyre.”

toiga/rtoi dia\ tau=ta. Cp. Isocr. VII. 52, Andoc. I. 108, Dem. XXIII. 203; an example of the rhetorical trick of amplitude. Phaedrus, as Hug observes, is blind to the obvious corollary that Eros sometimes fails to implant to/lma.
ou)x w(/sper. “Whereas, on the contrary”: cp. Gorg. 522 A, 189 C infra.

ei)s maka/rwn nh/sous. Cp. Pind. Ol. II. 78 ff., Skolion ap. Bgk. P.L.G. III. 1290. Achilles, after death, is variously located, by Homer (Od. XI. 467 ff.) in Hades, by Ibycus (fr. 37) in Elysium, by Arctinus and others in Leuke (“whiteisland”), for which see Pind. Nem. IV. 49, and Rohde Psyche II. 369 ff. For the situation of the m. nh=soi, see Strabo I. 3: cp. Adam R. T. G. 135 f.
w(s a)poqanoi=to. See Hom. Il. XVIII. 96 au)ti/ka ga/r toi e)/peita meq' *(/ektora po/tmos e(toi=mos: ibid. IX. 410 ff.; Apol. 28 C, D.
oi)/kad' ...teleuth/soi. This clause is echoed, as Wolf observed, by Aeschines I. 145 e)panelqw\n oi)/kade ghraio\s...a)poqanei=tai.

bohqh/sas. Cp. Arist. Rhet. I. 3. 1359^{a} 3 oi(=on *)axille/a e)painou=sin o(/ti e)boh/qhse tw=| e(tai/rw| *patro/klw| ei)dw\s o(/ti dei= au)to\n a)poqanei=n e)co\n zh=n. Isocrates (in Panegyr. 53) lauds the Athenians for a similar nobility of conduct.
e)papoqanei=n. This and 208 D are the only classical instances cited of this compound; nor does there seem to be another class. instance of u(peragasqh=nai.

*ai)sxu/los de\ fluarei=. The reference is to Aesch. Myrmidons (fr. 135, 136 N.). Sophocles, too, wrote an *)axille/ws *)erastai/: cp. also Xen. Symp. VIII. 31. Achilles, like Asclepius and others, was worshipped in some places (e.g. Epirus) as a god, in others (e.g. Elis) as a hero.
a)ll) a)/ra kai\ . “*)/ara h. l. stare potest, valet: nimirum” (Wyttenbach): for a)/ra affirmative in a universal statement, cp. 177 E, Rep. 595 A. To alter to a(/ma, as Burnet, is unnecessary.
kalli/wn. For the beauty of Achilles, see Il. II. 673. Ov. Trist. II. 411 refers to Sophocles' play—“nec nocet auctori mollem qui fecit Achillem”: cp. Lucian dial. mort. 18. 1.

a)ge/neios. The hero is so represented in art; and the Schol. ad Il. I. 131 applies to him the epithet gunaikopro/swpos. Similarly Apollo, in Callim. H. II. 36 f. ou)/pote *foi/bou | qhlei/hs' ou)d' o(/sson e)pi\ xno/os h)=lqe pareiai=s.

new/teros. See Il. XI. 786 gene/h| me\n u(pe/rtero/s e)stin *)axilleu/s | presbu/teros de\ su/ (sc. *pa/troklos) e)ssi: and Schol. ad Il. XXIII. 94. For the relative ages of paidika/ and e)rasth/s, see 181 B ff. below; Xen. Anab. II. 6. 28 au)to\s de\ (sc. Meno) paidika\ ei)=xe *qaru/pan a)ge/neios w)\n geneiw=nta (mentioned as an enormity); Ov. Met. X. 83 ff.
ma/lista me\n...ma=llon me/ntoi. This savours of a Hibernicism: cp. Gorg. 509 B me/giston tw=n kakw=n...kai\ e)/ti tou/tou mei=zon.
qauma/zousi. Cp. Rep. 551 A e)painou=si/ te kai\ qauma/zousi kai\ ei)s ta\s a)rxa\s a)/gousi: Xen. Symp. IV. 44.

qeio/teron...e)/nqeos. Cp. 179 A, 209 B ad init.; Schol. ad Eur. Hippol. 144
e)/nqeoi le/gontai oi( u(po\ fa/smato/s tinos a)faireqe/ntes to\n nou=n, kai\ u(p' e)kei/nou tou= qeou= tou= fasmatopoiou= katexo/menoi kai\ ta\ dokou=nta e)kei/nw| poiou=ntes. See Rohde Psyche II. 19 ff.

*ou(/tw dh\ ktl. In this epilogue kai\ presb. kai\ tim. summarize the first part of the speech; kai\ kuriw/taton ktl., the second part. Cp. Isocr. Hel. 218 D ka/llous...mete/sxen o(\ semno/taton kai\ timiw/taton kai\ qeio/taton tw=n o)/ntwn e)sti/n.

div1.head: Speech of Pausanias
div1.p: a)/llous tina\s ei)=nai. The construction here has been misunderstood: Hirschig proposed to write ei)pei=n for ei)=nai, while Hug bids us supply le/gontas. Evidently both suppose that a)/lloi tine\s mean persons, but it seems better to take them to be lo/goi and to construe meta\ *fai=dron as a compendium for meta\ to\n *fai/drou lo/gon. By this means we secure the word required, lo/gous, as the antecedent to w(=n: for diamnhmoneu/ein would be less naturally used of a person than of a speech (cp. 178 A pa/ntwn...e)me/mnhto). For the brachylogy, cp. Thuc. I. 71. 2 a)rxaio/tropa u(mw=n ta\ e)pithdeu/mata pro\s au)tou/s e)stin (with Shilleto's n.).

to\...e)gkwmia/zein *)/erwta. This clause is best taken, with Stallb. and Hug, as nomin. in epexegetic apposition to probeblh=sqai o( lo/gos. Equally improbable are Rückert's view that the clause is accus. (“quatenus sic simpliciter” etc.), and Hommel's that it is exclamatory.
a(plw=s ou(/tws. Cp. 176 E.
nu=n de\ ou) ga/r. We may assume the ellipse of ou) kalw=s e)/xei after nu=n de/: cp. Theaet. 143 E, Apol. 38 B, etc.
prorrhqh=nai. Hommel renders by “prius praefari,” Hug by “edicere.” In favour of Hommel's view cp. prourrh/qh 198 E, tou/twn prorrhqe/ntwn Laws 823 D; Rep. 504 A.

ou)k e)/stin...*)afrodi/th. Cp. Hes. Theog. 201 th=| d' *)/eros w(ma/rthse kai\ *(/imeros e(/speto kalo\s | geinome/nh| ta\ prw=ta qew=n t' ei)s fu=lon i)ou/sh|: Orph. H. 55. 1 *ou)rani/h polu/umne, filommeidh\s *)afrodi/th... (8) mh=ter e)rw/twn.
mia=s ou)/shs. Cp. Xen. Symp. VIII. 9 ei) me\n ou)=n mi/a e)sti\n *)afr. h)\ dittai/ ktl.

tw\ qea/. Plato uses both qeo/s (181 C, Rep. 327 A, etc.) and qea/ (Rep. 388 A, 391 C, etc.) for “goddess,” and qea/ here serves to preclude confusion with *)/erws. For the notion of a dual Aphrodite cp. Xen. l. c., Apuleius apol. 12, Plotin. Enn. III. 5. 293 B. For Aphrodite Urania, with a temple in Athens, see Hdt. I. 105, 131, etc.; Paus. I. 14. 6. See also Cic. N. D. III. 23; Pind. fr. 87.

*pa/ndhmon. For the temple in honour of A. Pandemos, see Paus. I. 22. 3. It is doubtful whether the title originally attached to her as the common deity of the deme, or as the patroness of the e(tai=rai. But whatever its origin, the recognized use of the title at the close of the 5th century was to indicate Venus meretrix.

kai\ *)/erwta ktl. The notion of a duality, or plurality, in Eros is also hinted at in Eurip. fr. 550 e(no\s d' *)/erwtos o)/ntos ou) mi/) h(donh/: | oi( me\n kakw=n e)rw=sin, oi( de\ tw=n kalw=n: fr. adesp. 151 dissa\ pneu/mata pnei=s *)/erws. Cp. Phaedrus 266 A.

e)painei=n...qeou/s. This is merely a formal saving clause, to avert possible Nemesis, and although it involves the speaker in something like selfcontradiction, there is no good reason to suspect corruption in the text (if correction be required, the easiest would be eu)fhmei=n, cp. Epin. 992 D eu)fhmei=n pa/ntas qeou\s ktl.). The laudation of base gods would sound less strange in ancient than in modern ears; and Eryximachus uses very similar language in 188 D (cp. 195 A).

au)th\ e)f' e(auth=s ktl. Gellius XVII. 20 ignores prattome/nh in his rendering (“Omne,” inquit, “omnino factum sic sese habet: neque turpe est,
quantum in eo est, neque honestum, uelut est quas nunc facimus ipsi res, bibere cantare disserere. nihil namque horum ipsum ex se honestum est; quali cum fieret modo factum est, tale extitit,” etc.): Proclus also (in Alcib. I. p. 215) omits it. It must certainly, I think, be ejected, since it only serves to confuse the argument; none of the alternatives proposed are at all probable; while Rettig's attempt to justify its retention by the device of setting a comma before it is merely absurd. For the language cp. Meno 88 C pa/nta ta\ kata\ th
 yuxh
 au)ta\ me
 kaq' au(ta\ ou)/te w)fe/lima ou)/te blabera/ e)stin: Phaedrus 258 C, D. See also Eryx. 397 E; Arist. Pol. 1333^{a} 9, for the moral indifference of pra/ceis kaq' au(ta/s.

o(/ ti a)
 tu/xh|. “At random”; so o(/ ti a)
 tu/xwsi 181 B below: Prot. 353 A oi(\ o(/ ti a)
 tu/xwsi tou=to le/gousi.
w(=n kai\ e)rw=si. “In the actual objects of their passion”: the full statement would be e)rw=si tw=n swma/twn e)kei/nwn (sc. pai/dwn h)\ gunaikw=n) w(=n e)rw=si ma=llon h)\ tw=n y.
to\ diapra/casqai. A polite euphemism for the sexual act: cp. 182 C, Phaedrus 256 C; Lysias I. 33.
e)/sti ga\r...a)/rrenos. Observe that the reasons are put in chiastic order.

kai\ e)/stin...*)/erws. This clause is obviously open to suspicion as (1) anticipating the sense of o(/qen dh\ ktl., and (2) standing in partial contradiction to the later statement (181 D ad init.) ou) ga\r e)rw=si pai/dwn.

u(/brews a)moi/rou. For u(/bris as especially associated with juvenile “lustihead,” cp. Euthyd. 273 B u(bristh\s dia\ to\ ne/os ei)=nai: Lysias XXIV. 16 u(bri/zein ei)ko\s... tou\s e)/ti ne/ous kai\ ne/ais tai=s dianoi/ais xrwme/nous: Soph. fr. 705 u(/bris de/ toi...e)n ne/ois a)nqei= te kai\ fqi/nei pa/lin.

e)/pipnoi. “Driven by the spirit”: the only other exx. of the word in Plato are Crat. 428 C and Meno 99 D fai=men a)\n qei/ous te ei)=nai kai\ e)nqousia/zein, e)pi/pnous o)/ntas kai\ katexome/nous e)k tou= qeou= (cp. 179 A n., 180 B n.).

tou=to de\. Sc. to\ nou=n i)/sxein. This is in contradiction to the statements of Phaedrus, 178 C (eu)qu\s ne/w| o)/nti), 180 A (e)/ti a)ge/neios h)=n). For geneia/skein (pubescere), cp. Solon 27. 5—6 th=| trita/th| de\ ge/neion a)ecome/nwn e)/ti gui/wn | laxnou=tai, xroih=s a)/nqos a)meibome/nhs. Cp. Spenser F. Q. II. xii. 79 “And on his tender lips the downy heare Did now but freshly spring, and silken blossoms beare”: Hor. C. IV. 10. 2 (pluma).

pareskeuasme/noi ktl. For the change of construction from w(s with fut. partic. to (fut.) infin., cp. Charm. 164 D, Rep. 383 A poiei=n w(s mh/te...o)/ntas... mh/te...para/gein. The clause e)n a)frosu/nh|...ne/on is best taken closely with the preceding participle, and katagela/santes...a)potre/xontes closely together. For e)capath/santes cp. 184 E, 185 A: Theogn. 254 a)ll' w(/sper mikro\n pai=da lo/gois m' a)pata=|s. This a)pa/th and katagela=n are forms of the u(/bris mentioned above, 181 C: cp. 219 C, 222 A.
mh\ e)ra=n pai/dwn . pai=s, as here used, is Theognis' mikro\s pai=s, the paida/rion of 210 B infra.

a)/dhlon oi(= teleuta=|. Cp. Phaedrus 232 E tw=n me
 e)rw/ntwn polloi\ pro/teron tou= sw/matos e)pequ/mhsan h)\ to
 tro/pon e)/gnwsan ktl.: Theogn. 1075 ff. prh/gmatos a)prh/ktou xalepw/tato/n e)sti teleuth
 | gnw=nai...o)/rfnh ga te/tatai: Alcid. Odyss. 5 pa=sa/ te a)pori/a h)=n poi= pote probh/soito h(...teleuth/. A similar
sentiment occurs in the Clown's song in Twelfth-Night: “What's to come is still unsure...Youth's a stuff will not endure.”

kaki/as kai\ a)reth=s. Possibly these genitives are to be construed (with Rückert) as dependent on the preceding adverb oi(=: cp. Soph. O. T. 413 ou) ble/peis i(/n' ei)= kakou= (Madv. Gr. Synt. § 50 B). Hug, however, takes them to be governed by pe/ri, comparing for the separation of prepos. from case Apol. 19 C, Soph. Aj. 793.
tou/tous...e)rasta\s. For ou(=tos contemptuous cp. Apol. 17 B, Rep. 492 D ou(=toi oi( paideutai/ te kai\ sofistai/ (“ou(=toi is the contemptuous isti” Adam).

to\ toiou=ton. Sc. mh\ e)ra=n pai/dwn (D ad fin.). For the db. accus. with -anagka/zw, cp. Rep. 473 A tou=to mh\ a)na/gkaze/ me: Phaedrus 242 B. Hommel, perversely, construes to\ toiou=ton as an adverbial accus., “ganz in der Weise wie” etc.

tw=n e)leuqe/rwn gunaikw=n. For the legal penalties (by a grafh\ moixei/as or u(/brews or a di/kh biai/wn) for rape and adultery, see Lysias I. 26, 30, 49. One of the lesser penalties was that alluded to by Catullus XV. 18 f., Quem...Percurrent raphanique mugilesque.

xari/zesqai e)rastai=s. xari/zesqai, obsequi, “to grant favours”—the converse of diapra/casqai—is a vox propria in this connexion: cp. Schol. ad Phaedrus 227 C to\ xariste/on e)sti\n...to\ pro\s a)frodi/sion e(auto\n sunousi/an e)pidido/nai tini/. For the sentiment here disputed, see Xen. Symp. VIII. 19 ff.; Mem. I. 2. 29; and the paradox in Phaedrus 233 E i)/sws prosh/kei ou) toi=s sfo/dra deome/nois xari/zesqai. Aeschines I. 136 agrees with Pausanias.
th\n a)kairi/an. “Impropriety” or “tactlessness”: for exx. of such a)kairi/a, see 181 D, Phaedrus 231 D ff.

o(...no/mos . no/mos here includes both “law” proper and “public sentiment” or “custom” (“die Anschauungen des Volkes,” Hug) which are distinguished in Dem. de Cor. 114: cp. Thuc. VI. 18. 7: but in Thuc. VI. 16. 2 no/mos is “custom.”

kai\ e)n *lakedai/moni. I follow Winckelmann and others (see crit. n.) in bracketing these words: possibly they should be transposed to a place in the next clause, either after ga or after *boiwtoi=s (in suggesting this I find myself anticipated by an anonymous critic, ap. Teuffel, Rhein. Mus. XXIX. p. 145). That Laconia was a hot-bed of paederasty might be inferred à priori from its military-oligarchical constitution, and is betokened by the verb lakwni/zein used as a synonym for paidikoi=s xrh=sqai (Ar. frag. 322), and the adj. kusola/kwn for paiderasth/s. It is certainly unlikely that a poiki/los no/mos would be ascribed to the Laconians, and unlikely too that they would be classed apart from the mh\ sofoi\ le/gein. Moreover, in 182 D ff. it is o( e)nqa/de (h(me/teros) no/mos which is treated as poiki/los, and no mention is made there of a similar Laconian no/mos. For Laconian mores, Stallb. cites Xen. Rep. Lac. II. 13; Plut. Lac. Inst. p. 237 B; Aelian V. H. III. 10. 12. In Xen. Symp. VIII. 35 the Lacedaemonians are lauded—qea
 ga ou) th
 *)anai/deian a)lla\ th
 *ai)dw= nomi/zousi (which ought, perhaps, to be construed as implying that they are slighted here).
e)n *)/hlidi ktl. Cp. Xen. Symp. VIII. 34, Rep. Lac. l.c., Athen. XIII. 2. The Cretan a(rpagmo\s paidw=n (Laws VIII. 836) points to a similar state of things.

th=s de\ *)iwni/as. The genitive is taken by Hug as dependent on pollaxou=, by Stallb. as dependent on o(/soi, “vel potius ex demonstrativo ante o(/soi intelligendo.” Hug quotes Xen. Hell. IV. 4. 16 pollaxo/se kai\ th=s *)arkadi/as e)mbalo/ntes.

o(/soi...oi)kou=si. The grammar is loose—“per synesin additur o(/soi perinde ac si praecessisset ‘apud Ionas autem et multos alios’” (Stallb.). The language is most appropriate to a time after the Peace of Antalcidas (387 B.C.), when the Greeks of Asia Minor were again reduced to subjection to the Great King (see Bury, Hist. Gr. p. 552); cp. Crat. 409 E oi( u(po\ toi=s barba/rois oi)kou=ntes: Laws 693 A.

tou=to/ ge kai\ ktl. Strictly we should supply, with tou=to, to\ xari/zesqai e)rastai=s, but the notion latent is probably the more general one to\ e)ra=n (pai/dwn). The palaestrae (gymnasia) were recognized as the chief seats of
filosofi/a and paiderasti/a as well as of filogumnasti/a. Cp. (for paiderasti/a) Ar. Nub. 973 ff., 980 au)to\s e(auto\n proagwgeu/wn toi=s o)fqalmoi=s: Laws 636 B: Xen. Cyrop. II. 3. 21: Cic. Tusc. IV. 33. 70 in Graecorum gymnasiis...isti liberi et concessi sunt amores. Bene ergo Ennius: flagiti principium est nudare inter cives corpora: Plut. amat. 751 F ff. The gymnasia also served, at Athens, as headquarters of political clubs, cp. Athen. XIII. 602.

fronh/mata...e)ggi/gnesqai. For fron. mega/la cp. 190 B. For e)ggi/gnesqai cp. Xen. Rep. Lac. v. 6 w(/st' e)kei= h(/kista me\n u(/brin...e)ggi/gnesqai: and 184 A infra. The genitive tw=n a)rxome/nwn, in place of the more natural dative, may be explained, with Stallb., as due to “a confusion of two constructions,” the gen. being dependent on fron. meg. and the dat. after the verb omitted. For the thought, cp. (with Jowett) Arist. Pol. v. 11. 15.

o(\ dh\...e)mpoiei=n. The neut. sing., which is acc. after e)mpoiei=n, serves to grasp under one general head the preceding plurals. For this common use of filei=, solet, cp. 188 B infra, Phileb. 37 B. Hug, excising the kai\ after pa/nta, construes ta\ a)/lla pa/nta as a second object, parallel to o(/. But no change is needed: the phrase means “prae ceteris omnibus maxime amor,” as Stallb. renders, cp. the usage of a)/llos te kai/, ta/ te a)/lla kai/ in 220 A, Apol. 36 A, etc.

o( ga\r *)aristogei/tonos ktl. For the exploits of these tyrannicides, who slew the Pisistratids in 514 B.C., see Bury H. G. p. 205.
