Aristogeiton was the e)rasth/s of Harmodius, and popular sentiment invested the pair, in later days, with a halo of glory as the patron-saints and martyrs of Love and Liberty. Cp. Skolia 9 (Bgk. P. L. G. III. p. 646) e)n mu/rtou kladi\ to\ ci/fos forh/sw, | w(/sper *(armo/dios kai\ *)aristogei/twn, | o(/te to\n tu/rannon ktane/thn | i)sono/mous t' *)aqh/nas e)poihsa/thn: Ar. Ach. 980, Lys. 632. The exploit was also commemorated by Antenor's bronzes and a group by Critias and Nesiotes (reproduced in Bury H. G. p. 209).

e)te/qh. As aor. pass. of ti/qesqai, this is equiv. to e)nomi/sqh (cp. two ll. below). It is plain that qeme/nwn must here be taken to include both rulers and subjects. For pleoneci/a, “arrogant greed,” as opposed to h( tou= i)/sou timh/, see Rep. 359 C. For the theory implied in the following passage, that e)/rws and a)/ndreia go together (as Phaedrus also had contended, 178 D ff.), cp. Bacon, Essay x. (Of Love): “I know not how, but Martiall men are given to Love: I think it is but as they are given to Wine; for perils commonly aske to be paid in pleasures.”

*)enqumhqe/nti ga\r ktl. The construction is grammatically incomplete: one would expect do/ceien a)/n, or the like, to govern the dative. It is not till we get to 183 C (tau/th| me\n ou)=n ktl.) that we find the sense resumed.
para\ pa/ntwn. Jowett's “all the world” is misleading: the treatment is here confined to Athenian no/mos.
pro\s to\ e)pixeirei=n ktl. “Quod attinet ad amasii capiendi conatum” (Stallb.).
e)cousi/an...e)painei=sqai. Here, as often, the main idea is put in the participle. Again Jowett misleads, in rendering o( no/mos “the custom of mankind.”

qaumasta\ e)/rga . “qaumasta\ vel qauma/sia poiei=n vel e)rga/zesqai est sich wunderlich geberden...quod dicitur de iis qui vel propter dolorem et indignationem vel ob ingentem laetitiam vel etiam prae vehementi aliqua cupiditate insolito more se gerunt” (Stallb.). Cp. 213 D, Apol. 35 A, Theaet. 151 A.

plh\n tou=to [filosofi/as]. filosofi/as is most probably corrupt: if retained, it would be better to construe it as genit. of object (“the reproaches levelled against philosophy”) than as genit. of subject or origin (as Ast, Stallb., Kreyenbühl), for which we should expect rather filoso/fwn. The simplest and best remedy is, with Schleiermacher, to eject filosofi/as as a gloss on the misreading tou/tou. For o)/neidos, cp. Rep. 347 B to\ filo/timo/n te kai\ fila/rguron ei)=nai o)/neidos le/getai. For karpou=sqai, in malam partem, cp. Rep. 579 C; Eur. Hipp. 1427 k. pe/nqh. In their translations, Jowett follows Ast, but Zeller adopts Schl.'s excision.

koimh/seis e)pi\ qu/rais. Cp. 203 D; Ov. A. A. II. 238 frigidus et nuda saepe iacebis humo : Hor. C. III. 10. 2 asperas | porrectum ante fores, etc. For the other love-symptoms cp. also Xen. Cyrop. v. 1. 12.

ai)sxunome/nwn u(pe\r au)tw=n. For this construction cp. Euthyd. 305 A, Charm. 175 D. With the whole of this passage cp. Xen. Symp. IV. 15, VIII. 12 ff.: Isocr. Hel. 219 B mo/nous au)tou\s (sc. tou\s kalou\s) w(/sper tou\s qeou\s ou)k a)pagoreu/omen qerapeu/ontes, a)ll' h(/dion douleu/omen toi=s toiou/tois h)\ tw=n a)/llwn a)/rxomen...kai\ tou\s me\n u(p' a)/llh| tini\ duna/mei gignome/nous loidorou=men kai\ ko/lakas a)pokalou=men, tou\s de\ tw=| ka/llei latreu/ontes filoka/lous kai\ filopo/nous ei)=nai nomi/zomen (with which cp. also 184 C below).

tw=| d' e)rw=nti...diaprattome/nou. For the gen. absolute after a dative, cp. Laws 839 B h(mi=n tis parasta\s a)nh\r...loidorh/seien a)\n w(s a)no/hta...tiqe/ntwn: Phileb. 44 C is a less certain case. For the sense of the passage, cp. Bacon, Essay x. (Of Love): “It is a strange thing to note the excesse of this passion; and how it braves the nature and value of things; by this, that the speaking in a perpetual hyperbole is comely in nothing but in Love.”
w(/s ge le/gousin ktl. These words qualify the following, not the preceding, clause: Pausanias himself censures perjury in 183 E. For w(/s ge, cp. Rep. 352 D, 432 B.

a)frodi/sion ga\r o(/rkon ktl. This proverbial expression is found in two forms,—a)frodi/sios o(/rkos ou) da/knei (Hesych.) and a)fr. o(/rkos ou)k e)mpoi/nimos (Suid.). The Scholiast quotes Hesiod (fr. 5 G.) e)k tou=d' o(/rkon e)/qhken a)mei/nona (a)ph/mona G. Hermann) a)nqrw/poisi | nosfidi/wn e)/rgwn pe/ri *ku/pridos. Cp. Soph. fr. 694 o(/rkous de\ moixw=n ei)s te/fran e)gw\ gra/fw: Callim. Epigr. 27 (Anth. Pal. v. 5. 3) a)lla\ le/gousin a)lhqe/a, tou\s e)n e)/rwti | o(/rkous mh\ du/nein ou)/at' e)s
a)qana/twn: Aristaen. II. 20: Ov. A. A. I. 633 Iuppiter ex alto periuria ridet amantum : Tibull. I. 4. 21 ff. nec iurare time: Veneris periuria venti | irrita... ferunt, etc. As to the text, the parallels quoted lead us to expect a fuller expression. Hertz's o(/rkon <o(/rkon>, adopted by Hug, is ingenious but rather weak in sense. I prefer to insert ku/rion (abbreviated ko_n) after o(/rkon. For ku/rios, “valid,” cp. Laws 926 D: Ep. vi. 323 C, and see L. and S. s.v. II. 2: ou) ku/rios is equiv. to a)/kuros, irritus. To Jahn's insertion <e)mpoi/nimon> Teuffel rightly objects that it smacks but little of the proverbial manner.
kai\ oi( qeoi\ kai\ oi( a)/nqrwpoi. This seems to balance the statement made by Phaedrus, 179 C—D.

toi=s e)rwme/nois. From this dative (governed by e)pisth/santes), we must supply an acc. (tou\s e)rwme/nous) to act as subject to diale/gesqai. For the general sense of the passage, cp. Phaedrus 255 A e)a\n...u(po\ cumfoithtw=n h)/ tinwn a)/llwn diabeblhme/nos h)=|, lego/ntwn w(s ai)sxro\n e)rw=nti plhsia/zein: ibid. 234 B.

kai\...prostetagme/na h)=|. Hug, after Jahn and others, condemns this clause on the grounds that (1) h)=| is wanting in B; (2) the change of number, from paidagwgou/s to paidagwgw=|, is awkward; (3) the clause contains nothing new. But there is point in the change from plur. to sing. as serving to individualize the parents' action; and the clause does add to the statement in the context the further idea that the paedagogi are appointed not only as a general safeguard, but with special instructions to ward off this particular danger. tau=ta, the subject of prost. h)=|, represents (as Stallb. notes) mh\ e)w=si diale/gesqai toi=s e)rastai=s.

ou)x a(plou=n e)sti/n. Stallbaum, ejecting ou)x with Bast, renders a(plou=n by
“verum simpliciter,” citing Phaedo 62 A, Phaedrus 244 A, Protag. 331 B. Retaining ou)x, we cannot take the foll. accus. and infin. as the subject (with Wolf), but must supply to\ xari/zesqai (with Hug) from the context.
ai)sxrw=s me\n...kalw=s de\. With each adverb, sc. xari/zesqai: cp. Rep. 339 C to\ de\ o)rqw=s...to\ de\ mh\ o)rqw=s (sc. tiqe/nai).

tw=| tou= sw/matos a)/nqei l. Youth “is like the flower of the field, so soon passeth it away, and it is gone.” Cp. Mimn. 2. 7 mi/nunqa de\ gi/gnetai h(/bhs karpo/s: Theogn. 1305 paidei/as poluhra/tou a)/nqos | w)ku/teron stadi/ou: Ségur's refrain “Ah! le Temps fait passer l'Amour”: Spenser (H. to Beautie) “For that same goodly hew of white and red, With which the cheeks are sprinckled, shal decay, And those sweete rosy leaves, so fairely spred Upon the lips, shall fade and fall away” etc.: Rep. 601 B ou)kou=n e)/oiken toi=s tw=n w(rai/wn prosw/pois... o(/tan au)ta\ to\ a)/nqos proli/ph|: Xen. Symp. VIII. 14 to\ me\n th=s w(/ras a)/nqos taxu\ dh/pou parakma/zei, ktl.: Tyrt. 10. 28 o)/fr' e)rath=s h(/bhs a)glao\n a)/nqos e)/xh|: Mimnerm. 1. 4. So Emerson (On Beauty) “The radiance of the human form...is only a burst of beauty for a few years or a few months, at the perfection of youth, and in most rapidly declines. But we remain lovers of it, only transferring our interest to interior excellence.”

oi)/xetai a)popta/menos. A reminiscence of Il. II. 71. For the thought, cp. 181 D above: Xen. Symp. l.c. a)polei/pontos de\ tou/tou (sc. tou= th=s w(/ras a)/nqous), a)na/gkh kai\ th\n fili/an sunapomarai/nesqai. Cp. also Phaedrus 232 E, 234 A.
suntakei/s. “Fused into one” by the flame of love. Cp. 192 D, Eur. fr. 964 pa=sa ga\r a)gaqh\ gunh\ | h(/tis a)ndri\ sunte/thke swfronei=n e)pi/statai: id. Supp. 1029.

tou/tous dh\. With the text as it stands in the MSS., tou/tous refers to the e)rastai/ only, who are divided into two classes, the good (toi=s me\n) and the bad (tou\s de\). But in the next clause toi=s me\n refers to the e)rastai/ en bloc, and toi=s de\ to the e)rw/menoi. This is extremely awkward; and it is a further objection to the clause that the statement it contains is premature, and would fit in better below (184 D—E). I therefore follow Voegelin and Hug in obelizing. For the language, cp. Theogn. 1299 ff. w)= pai=, me/xri ti/nos me profeu/ceai; w(/s se diw/kwn | di/zhm' ...a)ll' e)pi/meinon, e)moi\ de\ di/dou xa/rin.

i(/na xro/nos ktl. For the touchstone of time, cp. Simon. fr. 175 ou)k e)/stin mei/zwn ba/sanos xro/nou ou)deno\s e)/rgou | o(\s kai\ u(po\ ste/rnois a)ndro\s e)/deice no/on: Soph. O. T. 614 xro/nos di/kaion a)/ndra dei/knusin mo/nos : Eur. Hippol. 1051 mhnuth\n xro/non. On the signif. of ba/sanos, see Vahlen Op. Acad. II. 7 ff.: cp. Gorg. 486 D, Rep. 413 E; Clem. Al. Strom. I. 291 D.

to\ u(po\ xrhma/twn...a(lw=nai. Cp. 185 A plou/tou e(/neka xarisa/menos: 216 D me/lei au)tw=| ou)de\n...ei)/ tis plou/sios: Ar. Plut. 153 ff. kai\ tou/s ge pai=das...dra=n... ta)rguri/ou xa/rin. As against the deletion of the second ai)sxro/n by Hirschig, see the parallels collected by Vahlen Op. Acad. II. 359. For polit. duna/mewn, cp. Xen. Mem. IV. 2. 35; this may be a hit at Alcibiades, cp. 216 B.

ei)s xrh/mata...politika\s. The reasons for which Hug, after Hirschig and others, rejects these words—as (1) superfluous for the sense, and (2) spoiling the responsion of the clauses e)a/n te karterh/sh| and a)/n te...katafronh/sh|—are not convincing. This is the only ex. of dia/pracis, actio, cited by L. and S.

e)/sti ga\r ktl. Hug, objecting to the “ganz unerträgliche Anakoluthie,” follows Vermehren in excising the clause e)/sti...no/mos, as a gloss on the following neno/mistai, and writing w(s ga\r for w(/sper. This is too rash. For the sense, cp. 183 B and the passage from Isocr. Hel. 219 B there quoted.

h)=n...ei)=nai. For simple h)=n (e)/sti) with accus. and infin. cp. Phaedo 72 D a)ll' e)/sti tw=| o)/nti...ta\s tw=n teqnew/twn yuxa\s ei)=nai. For e)qe/lwn as adj. (“volun
tarily”) in prose, cp. Xen. Anab. VI. 2. 6; Lys. XIX. 6: in poetry the use is common, e.g. Soph. O. T. 649.

ou(/tw dh\ ktl. In this clause the method of action permissible to paidika/ is presented as parallel to that permissible to e)rastai/. That there is some corruption in the text is indicated by the divergence of the MSS. in regard to the words after a)/llh: but of the many emendations suggested (see crit. n.) none is convincing. Perhaps the safest plan is to bracket mw=n...e(kou/sios, as an adscript meant to suggest a subject for lei/petai, and to supply o(do/s as subject from the preceding context.

sofi/an...me/ros a)reth=s. Cp. Protag. 329 E, Rep. 427 E (with Adam's n.): “the nearest approach to the doctrine before Plato is in Xen. Mem. III. 9. 1—5.” How many me/rh a)reth=s are assumed here by Pausanias is, of course, left indefinite. (See also 196 B n.)

o(/tan ga\r ktl. Notice the balance and rhythm of the clauses in this sentence—(a^{1}) o(/tan...e(ka/teros, (b^{1}) o( me\n...u(phretw=n, (b^{2}) o( de\...u(pourgw=n, (c^{1}) o( me\n...cumba/llesqai, (c^{2}) o( de\...kta=sqai, (a^{2}) to/te dh\...e)ntau=qa, (a^{3}) cumpi/ptei...ou)damou=.

u(phretei=n...u(pourgei=n. Both words are used in an erotic sense. So u(pourgi/a is used in re venerea, Amphis *)ial. That u(pourgw=n <u(pourgei=n> is the best restoration is shown by Vahlen Op. Acad. I. 499 ff.: cp. 193 C.

ei)s pai/deusin...kta=sqai. If the text is right we must suppose that kta=sqai is here equiv. to w(/ste kta=sqai, appended to the main verb cumba/llesqai which is to be supplied with ei)s pai/deusin ktl. (so Vahlen). Of the corrections suggested (see crit. n.) Schanz's is the neatest, but spoils the sense-balance with cumba/llesqai. The corruption is, perhaps, to be sought elsewhere: the expression th\n a)/llhn sofi/an is open to suspicion, since sofi/an as here used after a)/llhn stands as a generic subst. whereas sofi/a has just been termed (184 C) me/ros a)reth=s: moreover, we should expect that sofi/a should itself constitute the kth=ma of the recipient, just as fro/nhsis is itself the contribution of o( cumballo/menos. On these grounds, I venture to suggest that another fem. subst., such as didaxh/n, may have fallen out after a)/llhn (e)kpai/deusin for ei)s p. is just possible).
e)pi\ tou/tw|. “In this case,” i.e. in the quest for a)reth/, in contrast to “the other cases” where lucre or position is coveted (184 A).

ei) ga/r tis ktl. Observe the effort after rhythm, with strophe and antistrophe. For the thought, see 184 A and cp. Isocr. Hel. 219 C tw=n e)xo/ntwn to\ ka/llos tou\s me\n misqarnh/santas...a)tima/zomen.

kai\ mh\ la/boi xrh/mata. In defence of the text here, against the excisions of Cobet and Hug, see Vahlen, Op. Acad. II. 366: cp. Hipp. Min. 372 E su\ ou)=n xa/risai kai\ mh\ fqonh/sh|s i)a/sasqai th\n yuxh/n mou: Thuc. II. 13. 1 mh\ tou\s a)grou\s au(tou= parali/ph| kai\ mh\ dh|w/sh|.

dia\ th\n fili/an e)rastou=. This phrase also is rejected by Hug (followed by Hirzel) on the grounds that (1) “an der correspondierenden Stelle nichts steht,” (2) we should expect rather dia\ to\n e)/rwta tou= e)rastou= (cp. 182 C). The latter objection falls if, with Rückert, we take e)rastou= as object. gen. (“suam caritatem erga amatorem”). fili/a e)rastou= here is, I take it, equiv, to the compound filerasti/a (213 D, cp. 192 B).
kalh\ h( a)pa/th. Sc. tw=| e)capatwme/nw|.
dokei= ga\r au)= kai\ ou(=tos. This corresponds to dokei= ga\r o( toiou=tos ktl. in 185 A.

div1.head: First Interlude
div1.p: e)k tou= paraxrh=ma. For the sense subito s. ex tempore, cp. Crat. 399 D, Critias 107 E. On extempore, as opposed to premeditated orations, see Alcidamas de Soph. 3 ei)pei=n e)k tou= parauti/ka ktl.
sumba/llomai. “This is my contribution,” with allusion to the literary e)/ranos mentioned in 177 C.

i)/sa le/gein. This alludes to the i)/sa sxh/mata (including sound-echoes etc., as well as “isokolia”) of the rhetorical texni=tai (see Spengel, rhet. Gr. II. pp. 436—7). We may render (after Jowett): “When Paūsăn&ibreve;ās had cōme t&obreve; ă paūse—a pretty piece of ‘isology’ I have been taught by the professors—” etc. The title oi( sofoi/ is variously applied in Plato to the Orphics (Rep. 583 B), to poets (Rep. 489 B), and, as here, to linguistic craftsmen. For sofi/a as applied to etymological “puns,” cp. Crat. 396 C, D, and the use of sofi/zesqai (in connexion with the etymology of ou)rano/s) in Rep. 509 D (see Adam's n. ad loc.). For a rhetorical repetition of the same word (pau/w), see Gorg. Hel. 2 th\n me\n kakw=s a)kou/ousan pau=sai th=s ai)ti/as, tou\s de\ memfome/nous...pau=sai th=s a)maqi/as.

lu/gga. The Scholiast has a long note here: to\ tou= lugmou= su/mptwma e)pigi/netai tw=| stoma/xw| dia\ plh/rwsin h)\ ke/nwsin h)\ yu=cin, e)ni/ote de\ kai\ dia\ dh=cin drime/wn u(grw=n kai\ farmakwdw=n tai=s poio/thsin...o(/tan de\ u(po\ plhrw/sews lugmo\s ge/nhtai, e)/metos tou/tois i)/ama kai\ tw=n a)/krwn tri=yis kai\ pneu/matos katoxh/. The hiccough of Aristophanes is part of the comic relief in the piece (see Introd. § II. c). For plhsmonh/, as a cause of disorder, cp. 186 C n., Hippocr. de diaet. III. 72 ff.
e)n th=| ka/tw au)tou=. Sc. kli/nh|—referring to what might jocosely be termed the clinical position of the worthy doctor. Cp. n. on e)/sxaton katakei/menon, 175 C.
e)n tw=| sw=| me/rei. Cp. Meno 92 E a)lla\ su\ dh\ e)n tw=| me/rei au)tou= ei)pe/.
e)a\n me/n soi ktl. We have here a case of “aposiopesis” or suppressed apodosis; cp. Protag. 311 D; Hom. Il. I. 135 ff.: see Goodwin G. M. T. § 482.

a)nakogxuli/ason. Schol. a)nakogxulia/sai: to\ klu/sai th
 fa/rugga, o(\ le/gomen a)nagargari/sai. With Eryximachus's treatment of lu/gc, cp. Hippocr. de diaet, III. 75 ff. gi/netai de\ kai\ toia/de plhsmonh/: e)s th
 u(sterai/hn to
 si=ton e)rugga/netai ktl.

div1.head: Speech of Eryximachus
div1.p: pta/re. Cp. Hippocr. Aphor. VI. 13 u(po\ lugmou= e)xome/nw| ptarmoi\ e)pigeno/menoi lu/ousi to\n lugmo/n: Arist. Probl. 33.
*ou)k a)\n fqa/nois le/gwn. A familiar idiom: “the sooner you speak the better” (see Goodwin G. M. T. § 894): more rarely of 1st person, 214 E infra.

ou)x i(kanw=s. Schanz's ou)xi\ kalw=s is ingenious but needless: for a similar variety in antithesis Vahlen cites Theaet. 187 E krei=tton ga/r pou smikro\n eu)= h)\ polu\ mh\ i(kanw=s pera=nai. For dei=n redundant cp. Alc. II. 144 D, 146 B, Rep. 535 A, Laws 731 D, E: Schanz in nov. comm. p. 83 regards both a)nagkai=on ei)=nai and dei=n e)me/ as interpolations by copyists who failed to see the force of dokei==aptum videtur; but in his text he excises only dei=n: against this, see Teuffel, Rh. Mus. XXIX. p. 140.

th=s i)atrikh=s. Eryx. speaks, as a member of the Asclepiad guild, of “our art”: for his glorification of “the art,” see also 176 D, 196 A, and Agathon's allusion in 196 D. Cp. Theaet. 161 E to\ de\ dh\ e)mo/n te kai\ th=s e)mh=s te/xnhs th=s maieutikh=s ktl., where also Naber excises th=s m. (cp. Vahlen Op. Ac. II. 273).
w(s me/gas ktl. This w(s-clause serves to repeat in another form the initial o(/ti-clause, thus making two object-clauses to one main clause in the sentence, for which cp. 211 E infra, Apol. 20 C.
e)pi\ pa=n...tei/nei. Cp. 222 B e)pi\ plei=ston tei/nontes (lo/gous): we might render “of universal scope.”
presbeu/wmen. For the sense, “venerate,” cp. 188 C, and presbu/teron 218 D: Crito 46 C tou\s au)tou\s presbeu/w kai\ timw=: Rep. 591 C.

to\ de\ a)no/moion ktl. “Things dissimilar in themselves crave dissimilar objects”: e.g. the appetites of the sound body differ from those of the sick body. Cp. Hippocr. de nat. hom. 9 o(ko/sa plhsmonh\ ti/ktei noush/mata, ke/nwsis i)h=tai, o(ko/sa de\ a)po\ kenw/sios ge/netai noush/mata, plhsmonh\ i)h=tai...to\ de\ cu/mpan gnw=nai, dei= to\n i)htro\n e)nanti/on i(/stasqai toi=si kaqestew=si kai\ noush/masi kai\ ei)/desi ktl.

o( e)pi\ tw=| u(gieinw=| e)/rws. “The craving felt by the sound body”: cp. e)pi\ tai=s yuxai=s, 186 A. In the doctor's parable, to\ u(gieino/n corresponds to the good, to\ nosw=des to the bad e)rasth/s.
e)/sti dh/. This is, as Hug observes, a favourite opening with Eryx.: cp. e)/sti ga/r, 186 C; e)/sti de/, 186 D, 187 A.

e)/sti ga i)atrikh/ ktl. Cp. (with Poschenrieder) Hippocr. de flat. I. p. 570 K. pa/lin au)= plhsmonh
 i)h=tai ke/nwsis: ke/nwsin de\ plhsmonh/...ta\ e)nanti/a tw=n e)nanti/wn e)sti
 i)h/mata. i)htrikh\ ga/r e)sti pro/sqesis kai\ a)fai/resis, a)fai/resis me
 tw=n u(perballo/ntwn, pro/sqesis de\ tw=n e)llipo/ntwn: o( de\ ka/llista tou=to poie/wn a)/ristos i)htro/s. Also Phileb. 32 A, 35 A for “repletion” and “depletion” in connexion with bodily fu/sis: and Tim. 82 A gh=s puro\s u(/datos te kai\ a)e/ros...h( para\ fu/sin pleoneci/a kai\ e)/ndeia...sta/seis kai\ no/sous pare/xei.

o( diagignw/skwn ktl. In this passage there is a distinction implied between pure and applied i)atrikh/, between medicine as a science (e)pisth/mh) and as an art (te/xnh). diagignw/skw is here used almost in the technical sense of making a medical diagnosis (cp. Hippocr. de nat. hom. 9 th\n dia/gnwsin... poie/esqai): possibly earlier “Asclepiads” than Hippocrates may have earmarked dia/gnwsis as a medical term. Cf. the distinction between kata\ gnw/mhn and kata\ xeirourgi/hn in Hippocr. de morbis I. 6.

o( metaba/llein poiw=n ktl. Cp. Hippocr. de morbo sacro, p. 396 L. o(/stis de\ e)pi/statai e)n a)nqrw/poisi th
 toiau/thn metabolh
 kai\ du/natai u(gro
 kai\ chro
 poie/ein kai\ qermo
 kai\ yuxro
 u(po\ diai/ths to
 a)/nqrwpon, ou(=tos kai\ tau/thn th
 nou=son i)w=|to a)/n: id. de nat. hom. 9 th
 qerapei/hn xrh\ poie/esqai...th=| tw=n diaithma/twn metabolh=| ktl. In later Greek dhmiourgo/s becomes the vox propria for a medical “practitioner,” as dhmosieu/ein for “to practise”: similarly xeirote/xnhs, Hippocr. peri\ paqw=n 1.
w(/ste...kta=sqai. Supply as subject ta\ sw/mata.

kai\ e)no/nta e)celei=n. Schanz would excise these words; but though they present a rather awkward case of brachylogy, they are otherwise unobjectionable. Herwerden's proposal (see crit. n.), though supplying the right sense, is needless; while Lehrs is obviously blundering when he construes e)no/nta as neut. plural, “und wieder auch das Vorhandene fortzubringen.” Hommel gives the meaning rightly, “und die einwohnende (Neigung), die nicht einwohnen darf, heraus zu treiben.”

dei= ga\r dh\. “For he must, as a matter of fact”—an appeal to recognized
axioms of “the Art.” Hippocrates based his medical theory on the assumption of two pairs of opposite and primary qualities, yuxro/n)(qermo/n, and chro/n)(u(gro/n. By the permutations and combinations of these he sought to account for all varieties of physical health and disease: see e.g. Hippocr. de morb. I. 2; de affect. 1. Cp. Lysis 215 E: Theo. Smyrn. Math. p. 15 Bull. kai\ tou=to to\ me/giston e)/rgon qeou= kata\ mousikh/n te kai\ i)atrikh\n, ta\ e)xqra\ fi/la poiei=n: also Tim. 82 A for the “hot” and “cold” in health and disease.

pikro\n glukei=. Ast's excision of these words (approved by Stallb., Hug, and others) is, at first sight, plausible, inasmuch as these opposites of taste seem hardly on a par with the other two pairs of primary opposites. But in Lysis 215 E the same three pairs are mentioned, with o)cu/)(a)mblu/ as a fourth, as exx. of the law of e)piqumi/a tw=n e)nanti/wn. Moreover, it is obvious that the question of savours is of special importance in medical science: cp. Theaet. 166 E tw=|...a)sqenou=nti pikra\ fai/netai a(\ e)sqi/ei kai\ e)/sti: Hippocr. peri\ diai/ths II. 56 ta\ gluke/a...kai\ ta\ pikra\...qermai/nein pe/fuke, kai\ o(/sa chra/ e)sti kai\ o(/sa u(gra/: id. de nat. hom. 2, 6: and the connexion between pikro/ths and xolh/ brought out in Tim. 83 A ff. Further, as Hommel observed, pa/nta ta\ toiau=ta after only two exx. is unusual.

o( h(me/teros pro/gonos *)a. Asclepius in Homer is not more than i)hth a)mu/mwn: in Pindar (Pyth. III.) and later poets he is the son of Apollo and Coronis. The earliest seats of his worship seem to have been Thessaly and Boeotia, and his cult, as a “chthonic” and “mantic” deity, may have its roots in a primitive ophiolatry (see Rohde, Psyche I. 141 ff.). Cp. Orph. Fr. 272 dio\ kai\ oi( qeolo/goi th
 me
 ei)s *)asklhpio
 a)nafe/rousin u(gi/eian th
 i)atrikh
 pa=san tw=n para\ fu/sin ktl. Also Orph. H. 67, addressed to A. as *)ihth pa/ntwn, *)asklhpie/, de/spota paia/n ktl. The Asclepiadae were a recognized medical guild, with hereditary traditions; their most famous schools were at Cos and Cnidus, for which see the account in Gomperz G. T. (E. tr.) vol. I. pp. 275 ff.: cp. Phaedrus 270 C (with Thompson's note).
oi(/de oi( poihtai\. The “deictic” oi(/de points to the presence of Aristophanes and Agathon.

gumnastikh\. The curative value of physical training is said to have been emphasized especially by Iccos of Tarentum and Herodicus of Selymbria, both 5th century experts in dieting. For the latter as an advocate of walking exercise see Phaedrus 227 D (with Schol. ad loc.); cp. Rep.
406 A: for the former, as an example of abstinence, see Laws 839 E. That Plato himself recognizes the connexion between i)atrikh/ and gumnastikh/ is shown by such passages as Gorg. 452 A ff., 464 B ff., Soph. 228 E, Polit. 295 C.

kai\ gewrgi/a. The appositeness of gewrgi/a is not so evident as that of gumnastikh/, but the use of the word here is defended by 186 A (toi=s e)n th=| gh=| fuome/nois) and by other exx. of a similar collocation, such as Lach. 198 D, Laws 889 D (cp. also Protag. 334 A f.). The art which deals with futa/ is regarded as analogous to that which deals with zw=|a, involving a similar command of the permutations and combinations, the attractions and repulsions (ta\ e)rwtika/), of the fundamental qualities.

to\ e(\n ga/r fhsi ktl. The words of Heraclitus (Fr. 45) are given in Hippol. refut. haer. IX. 9 thus: ou) cuni/asin o(/kws diafero/menon e(wutw=| o(mologe/ei: pali/ntropos a(rmoni/h o(/kwsper to/cou kai\ lu/rhs: cp. Plut. de Is. 45 pali/ntonos ga\r a(rmoni/h ko/smou o(/kwsper lu/rhs kai\ to/cou kaq' *(hra/kleiton: Soph. 242 E. Probably, as Burnet holds, the original word used by H. was pali/ntonos, not pali/ntropos, and a(rmoni/h combines the original sense of “structure” with the musical sense “octave,” the point of the simile being (see Campbell, Theaet. p. 244) “as the arrow leaves the string the hands are pulling opposite ways to each other, and to the different parts of the bow (cf. Plato, Rep. 4. 439); and the sweet note of the lyre is due to a similar tension and retention. The secret of the universe is the same.” That is to say, the world, both as a whole and in its parts, is maintained by the equilibrium resultant from opposite tensions. For more detailed discussion of the theory see Burnet, Early Gk. Phil. pp. 158 ff., Zeller, Pre-Socr. (E. T.) vol. II. pp. 33 ff. The to/con H. had in mind is probably, as Bernays suggested, the Scythian bow— the fo/rmigc a)/xordos of Arist. Rhet. III. 1412^{b} 35 (see the woodcut in Smith, D. A. s.v. “arcus”).

a)ll) i)/sws ktl. Eryximachus argues that H.'s dictum is defensible only if we understand the opposites to be not co-existent: the discordant cannot be simultaneously concordant, though it may be capable of becoming so in lapse of time (pro/teron...u(/steron). For to\ o)cu\ kai\ baru/ as matter for a(rmoni/a cp. Heraclit. Fr. 43 (R. and P. § 27) ou) ga\r a)\n ei)=nai a(rmoni/an mh\ o)/ntos o)ce/os kai\ bare/os, ou)de\ ta\ zw=|a a)/neu qhle/os kai\ a)/rrenos, e)nanti/wn o)/ntwn: Soph. 253 A; Phileb. 17 C, 26 A; Laws 665 B.

o(mologhsa/ntwn ktl. Cp. Theo. Smyrn. math. p. 15 kai\ oi( *puqagorikoi\ de/, oi(=s pollaxh=| e(/petai *pla/twn, th
 mousikh/n fasin e)nanti/wn sunarmogh
 kai\ tw=n pollw=n e(/nwsin kai\ tw=n di/xa fronou/ntwn sumfro/nhsin, ou) ga r(uqmw=n mo/non kai\ me/lous suntaktikh/n, a)ll' a(plw=s panto\s susth/matos: te/los ga au)th=s to\ e(nou=n te kai\ sunarmo/zein. For the Pythagorean a(rmoni/a see Philolaus, fr. 4. 3 (R. and P. § 56) ta\ de\ a)no/moia...a)na/gka ta=| toiau/ta| a(rmoni/a| sugkeklei=sqai ktl. The same notion of a cosmic a(rmoni/a or o(mologi/a appears in Orph. fr. 139 th
 *)afrodi/thn...ta/cin kai\ a(rmoni/an kai\ koinwni/an pa=si toi=s e)gkosmi/ois...(o( dhmiourgo\s) fili/as e)sti
 ai)/tios toi=s dhmiourgh/masin kai\ o(mologi/as.

sumfwni/a. Cp. Crat. 405 D peri\ th\n e)n th=| w)|dh=| a(rmoni/an, h(\ dh\ sumfwni/a kalei=tai: Rep. 430 E, 398 D, E with Adam's notes: “in its musical application sumfwni/a is used both of consonance in the octave or double octave and also of other musical intervals”: “a(rmoni/a ‘reconciles’ o)cu/ and baru/ by a proper arrangement of notes of higher and lower pitch. In the wider sense, therefore, any o(mologi/a of o)cu/ and baru/ is a a(rmoni/a, but in practice the word was used specifically of certain scales or modes.”

diafero/menon de\ au)= ktl. With the MS. text the sequence of thought is disjointed and obscure; au)= seems out of place, and the next clause (w(/sper ge kai\ ktl.) seems to imply that the possibility rather than the impossibility of harmonizing opposites is stated in the present clause (cp. Susemihl, Philol. Anz. VII. 412). Hence, rather than alter au)= with Schanz, I prefer to read diafero/menon de\ au)= kai\ mh\ o(mologei=n a)dunatou=n (or a)du/naton) <dunato\n> a(rmo/sai: this gives a proper antithesis to the clause preceding.
o(mo/noian. It is possible that this word may contain an allusion to Antiphon's work peri\ o(monoi/as, for which see Dümmler, Akad. p. 79.

au)th=| th=| susta/sei a(rmoni/as. “In the constitution of harmony per se”: e)n au)th=| th=| a(rmoni/a| might have sufficed, but the addition of susta/sei serves to emphasize the fact that a(rmoni/a is a synthesis—o(mologi/a—of a plurality of
elements: cp. Laws 812 C ta\s tw=n a(rmoniw=n susta/seis: Epin. 991 E a(rmoni/as su/stasin a(/pasan. For r(uqmo/s, see Adam's note on Rep. 398 D: “The elements of music are r(uqmo/s and a(rmoni/a. The former ‘reconciles’ taxu/ and bradu/ by arranging a proper sequence of short and long notes and syllables”: also Laws 665 A th=| de\ th=s kinh/sews ta/cei r(uqmo\s o)/noma ei)/h, th=| de\ au)= th=s fwnh=s... a(rmoni/a, ktl., Phileb. 17 D (with my note).
Eryximachus analyses Music into Theory (au)th\ h( su/stasis) and Practice (kataxrh=sqai r(.), the latter being further subdivided into melopoii/a and paidei/a.

paidei/a e)klh/qh. For “education” as “the right use of melody and verse,” compare what Plato has to say about the psychological effects of music and its place in education in Rep. II., III., Laws II., VIII. Of course paidei/a in the ordinary sense includes also gymnastic; cp. Rep. II. 376 E, Laws 659 D: in dancing to music (o)rxhstikh/ Laws 816 A) we have a combination of both. It is worth noticing that in the Pythagorean quadrivium mousikh/ had a place beside a)riqmhtikh/, gewmetri/a and sfairikh/ or a)stronomi/a: see Adam's Republic vol. II. pp. 163 ff.
pa/lin...o( au)to\s lo/gos. Pausanias was the author of the lo/gos, cp. 186 B supra.

*polumni/as. “The Muse of the sublime hymn” here replaces Aphrodite, being selected out of the Nine probably, as Ast supposes, because the first part of her name is congruous with the character of Aphr. pa/ndhmos.
prosfe/rh|...karpw/shtai...e)mpoih/sh|. Supply as subject the indef. tis.
kaq' o(/son parei/kei. “So far as possible.” Cp. Rep. 374 E, Laws 734 B.

h( tw=n w(rw=n...su/stasis. For the influence of the seasons on health see Hippocr. de nat. hom. 7 w(s ga\r o( e)niauto\s mete/xei me\n pa=s pa/ntwn kai\ tw=n qermw=n kai\ tw=n yuxrw=n kai\ tw=n chrw=n kai\ tw=n u(grw=n ktl.: cp. Phileb. 26 B.
a(\ nu=n dh\...e)/legon. See above, 186 D.
ou)de\n h)di/khsen ktl. For these aorists, following presents, see Goodwin G. M. T. § 155.

a)no/moia...nosh/mata. “Divers diseases”: the adj. is similarly used in Arist. Poet. 24. 1459^{b} 30 e)peisodiou=n a)nomoi/ois e)peisodi/ois, “relieving the story with varying episodes” (Butcher): cp. id. H. An. IV. 1. 523^{b} 12: Hippocr. de flat. 3 doke/ei me
 ou)=n ta\ noush/mata ou)de
 a)llh/loisin e)oike/nai dia\ th
 a)lloio/thta kai\ a)nomoio/thta tw=n to/pwn.

pa/xnai...kai\ e)rusi=bai. Timaeus defines thus: e)rusi/bh miltw/dhs dro/sos: pa/xnh de\ dro/sos xionw/dhs. Roman religion had a goddess Robigo. Ruhnken (ad Tim. p. 122) cites Orph. de lap. 15, v. 91 kai\ ai)qeri/hn e)rusi/bhn, | h(/te katourano/qen ptame/nh poti\ karpo\n e)ruqrh/, | a)mfi\ peri\ staxu/essi perismu/xousa ka/qhtai.

tw=n toiou/twn gi/gnetai ktl. There are two difficulties in this passage: (1) the singular verb after the plural subjects is harsh; to explain it we must assume a mental unification of the subjects, of which similar but easier instances occur in Rep. 363 A, 618 D, Laws 925 E. We might evade this difficulty by removing the colon at futoi=s, marking kai\ ga\r...e)rusi=bai as parenthetic, and thus construing a)/lla...nosh/mata as the direct subject of gi/gnetai. (2) We should naturally expect toiou/twn to have the same reference
here as tw=n toiou/twn has above (viz. to the combinations of elements in which the bad Eros predominates), whereas it seemingly stands in agreement with <*>owtikw=n: this being so, what does e)rwtikw=n precisely mean? For it cannot well retain, in this connexion, its proper meaning as genitive of ta\ e)rwtika/ “the laws of affinity” (186 C, 187 C). Ought we, then, to put a stop after gi/gnetai and begin a new sentence with e)rwtikw=n ou)=n e)pisth/mh ktl.?

a)stronomi/a. The term as here used includes what we should rather call “meteorology”: cp. Rep. 527 D tri/ton qw=men a)stronomi/an;...to\ ga\r peri\ w(/ras eu)aisqhtote/rws e)/xein kai\ mhnw=n kai\ e)niautw=n...nautili/a| prosh/kei. For “astronomy” as a regular part of the school curriculum see n. on paidei/a 187 D, and cp. Theaet. 145 C, D; Protag. 318 E.
h( peri\ qeou/s...koinwni/a. Simpler would have been h( qew=n...koinwni/a, but, as Hug remarks, “Eryximachus liebt das unbestimmte peri/ c. accus.”

a)se/beia. “Undutifulness,” impietas. Reverence to parents and country was a matter of religious obligation; cp. Xen. Mem. II. 2. 13 e)a\n de/ tis gone/as mh\ qerapeu/h|, tou/tw| di/khn te e)piti/qhsi (h( po/lis) ktl.; ib. IV. 4. 20; Rep. 615 C.
[peri\] to\n e(/teron. Perhaps an original ph| was mistaken for a compendium of peri/: for the combination a)lla/ ph|, cp. Theaet. 191 B a)lla/ ph| dunato/n.

a(\ dh\...i)atreu/ein. The infinitives may be taken as epexegetic of a(\ (so Stallb., Zeller), or a(\ may be construed separately as accus. of respect (“qua in caussa” Ast; “in welcher Beziehung” Hommel). There is no need to eject or emend tou\s *)/erwtas: the phrase used 4 ll. above, peri\ *)/erwtos fulakh/n te kai\ i)/asin, supports *)/erwtas here.

*ou(/tw pollh\n. The German translators mostly take ou(/tw as qualifying the adjj., “so vielfach und gross” (Zeller, Schleierm.), but Hommel is probably right in taking ou(/tw by itself (“hoc modo,” “itaque”) comparing ou(/tw pollaxo/qen 178 C. Cp. Hippocr. de flat. 3 ou(=tos (sc. o( a)h\r) de\ me/gistos e)n toi=si pa=si tw=n pa/ntwn duna/sths e)sti/n: a)/cion de\ au)tou= qeh/sasqai th\n du/namin.

kai\...para\ qeoi=s. Hug condemns these words, as implying a slur on the righteousness of the gods. But the phrase is merely a stock formula, like our “heaven and earth,” not intended to bear rigid analysis: cp. 186 B, 187 E kai\ toi=s a)nqrwpei/ois kai\ toi=s qei/ois.

kai\ a)llh/lois...qeoi=s. For the accus. duname/nous after h(mi=n cp. 176 D. The kai\ after ei)=nai is rendered “auch” by Hug, as if o(milei=n governed a)llh/lois and fi/lous ei)=nai the other datives, but Zeller's rendering, which makes both the infinitives govern both sets of datives, seems more natural.
kai\ e)gw\, i.e. “I as well as Pausanias”: see 185 E ad fin.
e)peidh\ kai\ . kai\ implies a suppressed reason—“since (it is your turn) and you are cured of your cough.”

div1.head: Second Interlude
div1.p:
to
 ptarmo
. This was one of the remedies prescribed by Eryx. in 185 E, hence the def. article. prosfe/rein is a vox propria for medical “applications,” cp. 187 E, Phaedrus 268 A; Hippocr. de flat. 1 oi(=os t' a)
 prosfe/rein ta\ cumfe/ronta tw=| sw/mati: id. de affect. 1 o_sa de\ tou\s xeirote/xnas ei)ko\s e)pi/stasqai kai\ prosfe/rein kai\ diaxeiri/zein ktl.
to\ ko/smion. This is in ridicule of the theory of medicine stated in 186 C ff and of the use of the term ko/smios in 187 D, 188 C.
[*)aristo/fanes]. I follow Sauppe and Hug in regarding the proper name as a gloss on w)gaqe/: as a rule, w)gaqe/ stands alone.

ou)/ ti...ei)/pw. In geloi=a Arist. applies the term used by Eryx. in a different sense, distinguishing between geloi=a, ridicula, and katage/lasta, deridenda; whereas Eryx. had meant by geloi=on what A. calls katage/laston, cp. 199 D, 221 E.
th=s h(mete/ras mou/shs. This may allude (as Rettig thinks) to Eryximachus's *ou)rani/a mou=sa and *polumni/a, and to his phrase e)n th=| h(mete/ra| te/xnh| (187 D, E).

*balw/n ge ktl. “So you think you are going to get off scot-free!” Suidas s.v. balw/n explains by pro\s tou\s kako/n ti dra/santas kai\ oi)ome/nous e)kfeu/gein. Cp. Rep. 344 D oi(=on e)mbalw\n lo/gon e)n nw=| e)/xeis a)pie/nai: Phaedo 91 C; Plut. de s. n. v. 548 B a)ll' ou)d' ei) balw\n, ei)=pen, a)phlla/gh, kalw=s ei)=xe periora=n to\ be/los e)gkei/menon.

div1.head: Speech of Aristophanes
div1.p: *kai\ mh/n ktl. This clause has reference to what Eryx. had said, not in 189 B, but in 188 E (ei)/ pws a)/llws e)n nw=| e)/xeis ktl.)—“Yea verily, it is my intention to act as you suggested.”
panta/pasi...ou)k. “To have completely failed to discern.” For du/namis ()( fu/sis) as a rhetorical category, cp. Isocr. Hel. 218 D r(a/|dion de\ gnw=nai th\n du/namin au)tou= ktl.

e)pei\ ai)sq. ge ktl. For e)pei\...ge cp. Rep. 352 C. The following infinitives (with a)/n) are governed by dokou=sin, repeated in thought from the main clause. For the sense, cp. Isocr. Hel. 221 A w(s...duname/nhn, a)naqh/masi kai\ qusi/ais kai\ toi=s a)/llais proso/dois i(la/skesqai kai\ tima=n au)th\n xrh/.
ou)x w(/sper. “Whereas”: cp. 179 E.
i)atro\s. This term recalls the doctor's speech, esp. 186 B ff., 188 C ff.; cp. Phaedrus 252 A.
e)gw\ ou)=n peira/somai. “Parodie des Pausanias (180 D) und Eryximachos (186 A)” (Rettig).

ei)shgh/sasqai. The force of this word is lost if we render it “narrate,” “relate” with L. and S.: it means “to initiate into”: cp. 176 E, Xen. Mem. II. 7. 10. For the next clause cp. Menex. 240 D h(gemo/nes kai\ dida/skaloi toi=s a)/llois geno/menoi.

fu/sin...paqh/mata. This is the order of A.'s exposition—peri\ fu/sews 189 D—190 C, peri\ paqhma/twn 190 C—193 A. For various views of physiologists as to the fu/sis a)nqrw/pou, see Hippocrates' tract with this title, where the theory that man e(/n ti ei)=nai (ai(=ma, xolh/, fle/gma, etc.) is combated. Aristotle's exposition is intended, no doubt, as a caricature of the medicos of his age (see Introd. § iii. 4).

a)ndro/gunon ktl. Suidas a)ndro/gunos: o( ta\ a)ndro\s poiw=n kai\ ta\ gunaikw=n pa/sxwn. Rückert wrongly renders ei)=dos by “genus”: it means “forma” (as Stallb.). ei)=dos kai\ o)/noma are taken by Rückert and Hug as nomin., by Stallb. as accus. of respect, the construction being e(\n ga\r (sc. tw=n genw=n) h)=n to/te a)ndro/gunon: the latter way seems the better. Rettig proposes to insert to/ before e(/n, which would give the same sense. If ei)=dos kai\ o)/noma are construed as accus., it is better to take them closely with a)ndro/gunon
than with e)c a)mfot. ktl. (as Stallb.). For a)ndro/gunos, see also Hippocr. de diaet. 28.

For the description cp. Emped. 257 ff. (St.) polla\ me\n a)mfipro/swpa kai\ a)mfi/sterna fu/esqai | ...memigme/na th=| me\n a)p' a)ndrw=n | th=| de\ gunaikofuh=, stei/rois h)skhme/na gui/ois: Lucr. V. 837 ff. portenta...androgynum, interutrasque nec utrum, utrimque remotum: Ov. Met. IV. 378 nec femina dici | nec puer ut possint; neutrumque et utrumque videntur : Livy XXVII. 11. 4. Theophrastus (Char. 16) mentions Hermaphroditus-statues; and the Orphic conception of Eros-Phanes may also be compared.
nu=n de\ ktl. “But now the name exists solely as a term of reproach”: cp. the use in Latin of semivir, Virg. A. IV. 215 ille Paris cum semiviro comitatu: Livy XXXIII. 28. 7.

o(/lon h)=n ktl. Cp. Emped. 265 (St.) ou)lofuei=s me\n prw=ta tu/poi xqono\s e)cane/tellon. o(/lon is predicate and not merely (as Ast, Schleierm.) a qualifying adj. with to\ ei)=dos. Certainly, as Rettig notes, Zeller's “ganz rund” is impossible. Rabelais (I. 8) has a reference to this passage—“ung corps humain ayant deux testes, l'une virée vers l'autre, quatre bras, quatre pieds, et deux culs; tel que dict Platon, in Symposio, avoir esté l'humaine nature à son commencement mysticq”—in his description of Gargantua's equipment.

kefalh\n d' e)p) ktl. “Quis non Iani meminerit?” (Hommel). The notion of a similar double-fronted, androgynous being is found in the Talmud, and Euseb. pr. Evang. XII. 12 quotes our passage as a plagiarism from Moses.

oi( kubistw=ntes. Schol. kubisth\r o( o)rxhsth/s, kai\ kubista=n to\ o)rxei=sqai. Cp. Il. XVI. 750, and the evolutions of the “tumbler” Hippoclides described in Hdt. VI. 129: also Xen. Symp. II. 11, VII. 3. The kai/ before ei)s o)rqo/n reads awkwardly; if retained, we must render it “actually” (adeo, Wolf), but possibly i)/sa or i)/sa kai\ may have been the original. Rettig quotes Cic. de Fin. V. 35 si aut manibus ingrediatur quis aut non ante sed retro fugere, plane se ipse et hominem exuens ex homine naturam odisse (videtur).

o(/ti to\ me
 a)/rren ktl. Aristophanes too can pose as an erudite physicist. His astronomical lore may come partly from Parmenides, partly from the Pythagoreans. Cp. Arist. de gen. an. I. 2 a)/rren ga le/gomen zw=|on to\ ei)s a)/llo gennw=n, qh=lu de\ to\ ei)s au(to/: dio\ kai\ e)n tw=| o(/lw| th
 th=s gh=s fu/sin w(s qh=lu kai\ mhte/ra nomi/zousin, ou)rano
 de\ kai\ h(/lion...w(s gennw=ntas kai\ pate/ras prosagoreu/ousin. For the moon as bisexed, cp. Orph. Hymn. IX. 4 (qh=lu/s te kai\ a)/rshn); Macrob. III. 8 Philochorus affirmat Venerem esse lunam et ei sacrificium facere viros cum veste muliebri, mulieres cum virili, quod eadem et mas aestimetur et femina. Procl. in Tim. p. 326 C (ou(/tw dh\ kai\ selhniakh
 yuxh
 ei)s a)ndro\s katie/nai fu/sin, kaqa\ th
 *mousai/ou fasi/, kai\ a)pollwniakh
 (h(liakh
 Jahn) ei)s gunaiko/s, kaqa/per i(storou=si th
 *si/bullan) shows that opinion on the matter was not uniform: see also Plutarch, Is. et Os. II. 368 C, 371 F ff.
o(/ti...mete/xei. Vögelin and others rightly defend this clause against athetizers like Jahn: it adds to the impression of “komische Gelehrsamkeit.”
periferh=. “Globular” rather than “circular” (“kreisformig,” Ast, Schleierm.). For porei/a, incessus, cp. Tim. 45 A, Polit. 266 B.

ta\ fronh/mata mega/la ei)=xon. They were “high minded” and had “proud looks”; they did not “refrain their soul and keep it low”: “mega/la fronh/mata dicuntur habere qui contra dominos conspirant, cp. 182 C” (Hommel).

o(\ le/gei *(/omhros. See Od. XI. 305 ff., Il. V. 385 ff. We may compare also Ps. ii. 2, “The kings of the earth set themselves...against the Lord”; and the Babel tradition (Gen. xi. 4 ff.; cp. Orig. c. Cels. IV. p. 515 A ff.).

ou)/te ga\r...ei)=xon. This obviously implies, as Hug remarks, moral rather than physical impossibility—the inexpedience of killing the goose that lays the golden egg. Supply h)fa/nisan with keraunw/santes.
h)fani/zeto. For the impf. without a)/n, cp. (with Stallb.) Rep. 450 D, Euthyd. 304 D; Ar. Nub. 1212.
mo/gis...e)nnoh/sas. Notice the comic touch: the omniscient Zeus has to cudgel his brains over the business!
w(s a)\n ei)=en. For this construction after a present, cp. Xen. Cyrop. I. 2. 5 (Goodwin G. M. T. § 349, cp. § 351).
a)sqene/steroi geno/menoi. Although these words are superfluous, a little legal verbosity may be excused in a comedian's Zeus.

xrhsimw/teroi. “More lucrative.” Zeus, with a sharp eye to “the loaves and fishes,” contrives to kill two birds with one stone. The propagation of piety by making fissures in men is an idea that tickles, and the discovery of the benefits—from the Olympian point of view—which result from schisms of this sort is no/hma geloio/taton. This passage is alluded to by Musonius ap. Stob. flor. LXVII. 20; Julian, Ep. LX. p. 448 C.
e)a\n d) e)/ti ktl. The ingenious Deity has still “a rod in pickle”: the process of bisection may be repeated ad lib. until the wicked are left literally with not a leg to stand on.

a)skwli/zontes. Schol. a)skwlia/zein kuri/ws me\n to\ e)pi\ tou\s a)skou\s a(/llesqai a)lhlimme/nous, e)f' ou(\s e)ph/dwn geloi/ou e(/neka: tine\s de\ kai\ e)pi\ tw=n sumpefuko/si toi=s ske/lesin a(llome/nwn. h)/dh de\ tiqe/asi kai\ e)pi\ tou= a(/llesqai to\ neu=ron (to\n e(/teron cj. Bekk.) tw=n podw=n a)ne/xonta, h)\ w(s nu=n e)pi\ ske/lous e(no\s bai/nonta. e)/sti de\ kai\ to\ xwlai/nein. Hesych. a)skwli/zontes: e)f' e(no\s podo\s e)fallo/menoi. Cp. Schol. ad Ar. Plut. 1130: Virg. Georg. II. 383 inter pocula laeti | mollibus in pratis unctos saluere per utres. See also Smith D. A. s.v. “ascoliasmus.”

w(/sper oi( ta\ o)/a ktl. For o)/a (see crit. n.) cp. Pollux VI. 79 h)=n de\ trwga/lia ka/rua murti/des me/spila, a(\ kai\ o)/a kalei=tai: Tim. (Phot., Suid.) o)/a: a)krodru/wn
ei)=dos mh/lois mikroi=s e)mfere/s. It is the “sorb-apple” or “service-berry,” Lat. sorbum; for the mode of preserving these cp. Varro de re rust. I. 59 (putant manere) sorba quidam dissecta et in sole macerata, ut pira, et sorba per se ubicumque sint posita, in arido facile manere: and for tarixeu/ein in this sense of “drying,” cp. Phot. (Suid.) tarixeu/ein:...shmai/nein de\ kai\ to\ chrai/nein.

The clause h)\ w(/sper...tai=s qrici/n is condemned by most edd. It is an objection to the phrase that, as Rettig notes, we ought naturally to supply with it not only the appropriate te/mnontes but also the inappropriate me/llontes tarixeu/ein: this objection however is not insuperable, and if necessary te/mnontes might be transposed. It is argued on the other hand by Hommel and Vögelin that a second simile is really required, the sorb-slicing describing only the mode of operation, whereas the egg-slicing adds the idea of ease and facility. That w)/|a qrici\ diairei=n was a proverbial saying is shown by Plut. amat. 24, p. 770 B oi)=sqa tou\s paidikou\s e)/rwtas <ei)s> a)bebaio/thta polla\ le/gousi kai\ skw/ptousi le/gontes w(/sper w)/|on au)tw=n trixi\ diairei=sqai th\n fili/an. Rückert supposes “ovorum per crines dissectionem ludi genus fuisse; fortasse ex ovorum dissectione per crines facta convivae futura praedicere solebant”: Zeller writes “vielleicht ein Gesellschafts- oder Liebesspiel, das darin bestanden haben könnte, dass zwei Tischgenossen sich in die zwei Hälften eines hartgesottenen Eies theilten, nachdem es mit einem dem Einen von ihnen ausgezogenen Haare zerschnitten war, also ein griechisches Vielliebchen.” It is, perhaps, possible that it had some connexion with (Orphic) magic and divination by w)|oskopi/a. For the process of bisection, cp. Phaedrus 265 E.
th\n au(tou= tmh=sin. Here tmh=sis denotes, of course, the result rather than the process: Naber's pro/tmhsin, umbilicum, is ingenious but needless.
ta)=lla i)a=sqai. Apollo, as a)ke/sios and i)hth/r, very properly plays the part of surgeon's assistant.
ta\ su/spasta balla/ntia. “Round pouches with strings to draw”: see Smith D. A. I. 565.
dih/rqrou. “Shaped out,” “moulded”; cp. Phaedrus 253 D. Cp. Aelian, H. A. II. 19, V. 39, VI. 3.
to\n kala/poda. “The (cobbler's) last”: Lat. forma (Hor. Sat. II. 3. 106), or tentipellium. Suidas (s.v. ka=la) ka=lon ga\r to\ cu/lon: e)c ou(= kai\ kalo/pous, o( cu/linos pou=s.

mnhmei=on...pa/qous. The residue of the wrinkles was intended to serve as a memorial “of man's first disobedience...and all our woe.” This repeats the idea already expressed in 190 E above (i(/na qew/menos ktl.).
h( fu/sis. Creuzer renders this by “nos homines,” disapproving of Ficinus' “natura” and Schleierm.'s “forma”: but fu/sis is no mere periphrasis but connotes original nature or form.

poqou=n e(/kaston ktl. To attempt to restore the Bodleian reading cunei=nai, as several of the later critics do, involves too much alteration; thus Hug writes tw=| au(tou= cunei=nai, Usener e)po/qoun...tw=| au(tou= cunei=nai. Notice the “constructio ad sensum,” poqou=n...periba/llontes...a)pe/qnh|skon. There is an echo of this passage in Philo de op. mund. 53 p. 36 M.
th=s a)/llhs a)rgi/as. “General inactivity,” implying that the limo/s itself was due to a)rgi/a. Cp. Rep. 554 A, C (with Adam ad loc.).
ei)/te a)ndro/s. Abbreviated for ei)/te a)ndro\s tou= o(/lou e)ntu/xoi h(mi/sei. Notice that the third possibility (ei)/t' a)ndrogu/nou) is omitted.

w(/sper oi( te/ttiges. This is not merely a piece of natural history;
it contains also an allusion to the cicada as the symbol of Athenian autochthony: cp. Polit. 271 A to\ me\n e)c a)llh/lwn ou)k h)=n e)n th=| to/te fu/sei gennw/menon, to\ de\ dh\ ghgene\s ei)=nai/ pote ge/nos lexqe/n ktl.: Thuc. I. 6, Ar. Eq. 1331. For the mode of propagation of cicadae, cp. Ael. H. A. II. 22 tai=s a)fu/ais o( phlo\s ge/nesi/s e)sti: di) a)llh/lwn de\ ou) ti/ktousin ou)de\ e)pigi/nontai ktl.: the female lays her eggs in the sand, where the young are hatched out by the sun's heat. Cp. also Plut. amat. 767 C.

ou(/tw...pro/sqen. Hommel explains ou(/tw by hac ratione, qua dixi; Rückert by uti nunc posita sunt, which seems preferable. au)tw=n (sc. ta\ ai)doi=a) by itself reads rather awkwardly; but, as Vögelin points out, a glossator would certainly have added the missing words. It is, perhaps, just possible that ta\ ai)doi=a fell out before kai\ dia\, owing to similarity of letters; but the insertion of tau=t) is a simpler change.

gi/gnoito to\ ge/nos, i.e. to\ a)nqrw/pinon ge/nos, cp. 190 D to\ ge/nos...a(/nqrwpoi. There is no reason to tamper with the text: the present tense secures the notion of continuance without need of supplements such as Rückert's sw=n or e)/ti. (A neater change would be tei/noito.)

e)pi\ ta\ e)/rga. In contrast to their former a)rgi/a (191 B). Cp. Hesiod's title e)/rga kai\ h(me/rai. bi/os is here practically equiv. to h( tou= bi/ou kataskeuh/ (Laws 842 C); and the phrase means “husbandry and other means of subsistence.”
e)/sti dh\ ou)=n. Here at last we come to the point of the whole tale—the function and value of Eros.
e)k to/sou. “From such early times,” tam longo ex tempore: the only other ex. in Plato is Laws 642 E, but the phrase is common in Hdt., e.g. V. 88, VI. 84.
sunagwgeu\s. “A unifier,” in the sense of “restorer.” This subst. is unique in Plato, and rare elsewhere; cp. the use of sunagwgo/s, Prot. 322 C, Tim. 31 C.

a)nqrw/pou cu/mbolon. “But the indenture of a man” (Jowett): su/mbolon here is the tessera hospitalis; the host presents his departing guest with one half of a broken die (a)stra/galos), retaining the other half himself (see Smith D. A. s.v. “hospitium”). Cp. the use of the word by Empedocles, in his theory of reproduction stated in Arist. de gen. an. I. 18. 772^{b} 10 *)empedoklh=s...fhsi\ e)n tw=| a)/rreni kai\ e)n tw=| qh/lei oi(=on su/mbolon ei)=nai, o(/lon d' a)p' ou)dete/rou a)pie/nai— “ad quod decretum philosophi respexit fortasse Aristophanes” (Stallb.).

ai( yh=ttai. Lat. rhombi, a kind of flat-fish (perhaps plaice or turbot): Schol. i)xqu/dio/n ti tw=n platei/wn h( yh=tta, e)k du/o derma/twn sugkei=sqai th\n i)de/an dokou=n, o(/ tines sanda/lion kalou=sin ktl.: “genus piscium, quod oculos et nares in altera tantum parte capitis habet” (Stallb.). Cp. Ar. Lys. 115 (where the Schol. curiously defines y. as o)/rneon tetmhme/non kata\ to\ me/son, w(s oi( sfh=kes), Athen. VIII. p. 329.
filogu/naike/s. Cp. Cic. Tusc. IV. 11. 25 similiterque ceteri morbi...ut mulierositas, ut ita appellem eam, quae Graece filoguni/a dicitur, etc. The sing. is filogu/nhs (see L. and S.).

fi/landroi/. The word here has the bad sense noted in Hermog. de id. III. p. 324 W. th
 ga a)kolasi/an bou/letai nu=n dh/pou shmai/nein kai\ to\ moixeu/esqai. Somewhat different is the force in Soph. fr. 1006 N. (Hermog. Rhet. III. p. 324) kai\ o( *sofoklh=s de\ fi/landro/n pou th
 *)atala/nthn ei)=pe dia\ to\ a)spa/zesqai su
 a)ndra/sin ei)=nai: and Eur. Androm. 229; while in Ep. Titus ii. 4 filandri/a is a virtue.

e)k tou/tou...gi/gnontai. I follow Badham and Hug in rejecting these words as an adscript derived from the context (a view already suggested by Hommel). Badham writes, “si altero praedicato opus esse credidisset Plato, quod aegre adducar ut credam, aliquanto pulcrius orationem variasset quam gego/nasi in gi/gnontai mutando.” The three-fold repetition sounds clumsy.

gunaiko\s tmh=ma, i.e. a section of the gunh\ o(/lh (“Doppelweib”) of 191 B. Similarly below a)/rrenos tmh=ma refers to the a)nh\r o(/los (“Doppelmann”). With the theory of sex-characters here expounded, cp. Hippocr. de diaet. I. 28 ff.

ai( e(tairi/striai. Timaeus e(tairi/striai: ai( kalou/menai triba/des. Cp. Clem. Alex. Paed. III. 21, p. 264 P. gunai=kes a)ndri/zontai para\ fu/sin gamo<*>menai/ te kai\ gamou=sai gunai=kes: and Ep. Rom. i. 26.
te/ws a)\n. “I.q. e(/ws a)/n, quamdiu” (Ast). As this use is unique in Plato, Ast proposed to write e(/ws a)/n. In 191 B te/ws has its usual force. adhuc.
tema/xia. “Slices”: this recalls the comparison with yh=ttai, te/maxos being used esp. of fish.
sugkatakei/menoi. An example of this is Alcibiades: see his own account in 217 D ff.

a)ndreio/tatoi. An allusion, as Hommel remarks, to the ambiguity of the word a)ndrei=os. Cp. Hippocr. de diaet. I. 28 h)\n me\n ou)=n e)s a)/rsena ta\ sw/mata a)pokriqe/nta a)mfote/rwn tu/xh|...gi/nontai ou(=toi a)/ndres lamproi\ ta\s yuxa\s kai\ to\ sw=ma i)sxuroi/.
fasi\...tines. Cp. what Pausanias says in 182 A (w(/ste tina\s tolma=n le/gein ktl.).

a)rrenwpi/as. Etym. M. s.v. a)rrenwpo/s: o( a)/rrenos pro/swpon e)/xwn, kata\ sunekdoxh/n. h)/goun o( a)ndrei=os kai\ i)sxuro\s kai\ duna/menos pro\s e)xqro
 a)ntitaxqh=nai. The subst. is a(/p. leg., but the adj. occurs in Laws 802 E to\ dh\ megaloprepe\s ou)=n kai\ to\ th
 pro\s a)ndrei/an r(e/pon a)rrenwpo
 fate/on ei)=nai. Rettig regards all these apparently encomiastic terms as ironical.
telewqe/ntes. “When grown up,” cp. Rep. 377 B, 466 E.

a)/ndres is predicative: “Such as these, and they alone, turn out men (i.e. manly, capable) in public affairs”: Ficinus wrongly renders “cum adoleverint, soli ad civilem administrationem conversi, viri praestantes evadunt”; and Schleierm. also goes wrong. For the connexion between the paederastic temper and politics, cp. 182 C, Ar. Nub. 1093, Eq. 333 ff., etc.
a)ndrwqw=si. This verb is not found elsewhere in Plato: cp. Hdt. I. 123, Eur. H. F. 42.

fu/sei...a)nagka/zontai. Hug, on quite insufficient grounds, expunges these words. It is true that there was, so far as is known, no law at Athens to enforce matrimony, though there was such a law at Sparta, according to Stob. (Serm. 65 p. 410) and Pollux (VIII. 40), by which citizens were liable to a
grafh\ a)gami/ou (or o)yigami/ou). But, as Hommel notes, no/mos covers not only law but custom; and it appears that “certain disabilities attached, at Athens, to the state of celibacy; those who entered public life, as r(h/tores or strathgoi/, were required paidopoiei=sqai kata\ tou\s no/mous (Deinarch. c. Demosth. p. 99 § 72)”: see Smith D. A. I. 43 a. And it is to be noticed that it is precisely public men who are spoken of in the text. The antithesis fu/sei )( no/mw| derives from the Sophists (Hippias v. Protagoras), see my Philebus p. xxviii n., Adam R. T. G. pp. 279 ff., Gomperz G. T. I. pp. 401 ff.

filerasth\s. This applies to the e)rw/menos; cp. the use of filerasti/a in 213 D. Those who are paiderastai/ in manhood were filerastai/ in boyhood (filou=si tou\s a)/ndras 191 E), so that the words here are put in chiastic order, as Stallb. observes. Hommel absurdly suggests that p. te kai\ filerasth/s may denote “virum qui neque alios vituperet amatores puerorum, et ipse pueros amet.” The point is also missed by Rückert's “amicorum amator,” and Wolf's “sodalium amator.”
au)tw=|...h(mi/sei. This refers to 191 D, zhtei= dh\ a)ei\ to\ au(tou= cu/mbolon.
a)/llos pa=s. This is a short way of referring comprehensively to the segments of the other o(/la, viz. the androgynous and the “Doppelweib” (191 D, E).
qaumasta\ e)kplh/ttontai ktl. Cp. 211 D.
w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n. This qualifies the negatives in the clause, like paene dixerim: “Barely consenting to be sundered for even a moment.”

kai\ oi( diatelou=ntes ktl. “It is these who continue in fellowship their life long, although they could not so much as say what gain they expect from one another.” Schleierm. misses the force of ou(=toi by making it direct antecedent to oi(/ (“diese sind es welche” etc.). For the thought of this passage, cp. 181 D, 183 E, Phaedrus 254 A ff., 255 E ff.
tou/tou e(/neka, i.e. th=s tw=n a)fr. sunousi/as e(/neka.

kai\ ei)...e)/roito. The apodosis to this duplicated protasis is to be found in i)/smen o(/ti ktl. (192 E). For Hephaestus and his tools, see Od. VIII. 266 ff., esp. 274 e)n d' e)/qet' a)kmoqe/tw| me/gan a)/kmona, ko/pte te desmou\s | a)rrh/ktous a)lu/tous o)/fr' e)/mpedon au)=qi me/noien. He would also have his bellows (fu=sai), tongs (pu/ragra), and hammer (sfu=ra, r(aisth/r): see Il. XVIII. 372 ff., 474 ff.

sunth=cai. Cp. 183 E, Tim. 43 A puknoi=s go/mfois cunth/kontes: Eur. fr. 964 pa=sa ga\r a)gaqh\ gunh\, | h(/ tis a)ndri\ sunte/thke, swfronei=n e)pi/statai. For th/kein of the effects of love, cp. Theocr. id. I. 66; Xen. Symp. VIII. 3.

sumfush=sai. Stallb., Hommel and Jowett retain the vulgate, sumfu=sai, but the other lection gives a better sense—“to weld together,” conflare: cp. Il. XVIII. 470. There is a ref. to this passage in Arist. Pol. II. 4. 1262^{b} 11 kaqa/per e)n toi=s e)rwtikoi=s lo/gois i)/smen le/gonta to
 *)aristofa/nhn w(s tw=n e)rw/ntwn dia\ to\ sfo/dra filei=n e)piqumou/ntwn sumfu=nai kai\ gene/sqai e)k du/o o)/ntwn a)mfote/rous e(/na (Newman here reads sumfuh=nai), but the word sumfu=nai is probably due to a reminiscence of 191 A. For the sense, cp. Orph. Fr. 139 parh/gagen...to
 *)/erwta, e(nopoio
 o)/nta tw=n o(/lwn.
tou= o(/lou...o)/noma. This definition sums up the description of Eros given in 191 D ad init.

diw|ki/sqhmen ktl. This is apparently a reference—in spite of the audacious anachronism (cp. Introd. § VIII.), to the dioikismo/s of Mantinea in
385 B.C., for which see Xen. Hell. v. 2. 1 ff. e)k de\ tou/tou kaqh|re/qh me\n to\ tei=xos, diw|ki/sqh de\ h( *mantinei/a tetraxh= kaqa/per to\ a)rxai=on w)/|koun (i.e. kata\ kw/mas): Isocr. Pan. 67 A: Arist. Pol. II. 2, § 3.

katagrafh\n. Many editors divide the word kata\ grafh/n. Probably whichever reading we adopt the meaning is the same, “in profile,” the figures being bas-reliefs (crusta). Cp. Plin. XXXV. 34 hic catagrapha invenit, hoc est obliquas imagines.
w(/sper li/spai. These are diapeprisme/noi a)stra/galoi (Schol. ad loc., Suidas), like the su/mbolon of 191 D: cp. Ar. Ran. 826, Schol. ad Eur. Med. 610.
w(s o( *)/erws. The Bodleian's w(s, though doubtful, is possible. Perhaps the variants arose from an original o(/swn or e)n w(=|.
pra/ttei...a)pexqa/netai. This may contain an allusion, as Usener suggests, to some familiar verse such as, e.g., pra/ttei d' e)nanti/) o(\s qeoi=s a)ph/xqeto.

mh/ moi u(pola/bh|. This is one of three cases in Plato of “mh/ with the (independent) subjunctive implying apprehension coupled with the desire to avert the object of fear,”—the other cases being Euthyd. 272 C, Laws 861 E (see Goodwin G. M. T. § 264).

kwmw|dw=n to\n lo/gon. “Ridiculing my discourse,” cp. 189 B: so e)pikwmw|dw=n, Apol. 31 D. As Hug observes, A. is really kwmw|dw=n himself when, in comic contrast to the picture drawn of Agathon in Thesm. 31 ff., he here suggests that he is th\n fu/sin a)/rrhn.

a)mfo/teroi...a)/rrenes. “H. e. a)/rrenos e(no/s” Stallb. As Wolf (like Stallb.) says, a)/rrenes th\n fu/sin means “mares origine, tmh/mata seu tema/xia tou= a)/rrenos,” and implies further, as Rettig notes, “mares natura, geborene Päderasten.”
a)pelqw\n. “Returning,” “being restored to”: so, perhaps, a)ph=|men pro\s to\ a)/stu Rep. 327 B; cp. pa/lin a)pie/nai Phaedrus 227 E, etc. Hence Mehler's e)panelqw/n is superfluous.
u(mnou=ntes...u(mnoi=men. Cp. 184 D u(phretw=n o(tiou=n dikai/ws a)\n u(phretei=n ktl.: and Agathon's echo of the word (e)fumnou=nta) in 197 E.

div1.head: Third Interlude
div1.p: ei)s to\ oi)kei=on. Cp. Charm. 163 D o(/ti ta\ oi)kei=a/ te kai\ ta\ au(tou= a)gaqa\ kaloi/hs: Rep. 586 E. Possibly there is an intentional echo in the word of diw|ki/sqhmen, as used in 193 A.

e)lpi/das m. pare/xetai. Cp. 179 B marturi/an pare/xetai: Xen. Symp. IV. 25. For the aor. infin. (without a)/n) after a verb of “hoping,” cp. Phaedo 67 B (Goodwin G. M. T. § 136). Notice the rhetorical care with which this peroration echoes (i)asa/menos...eu)dai/monas) the exordium (i)atro\s...eu)daimoni/a, 189 D); also, in eu)se/beian we have an echo of eu)sebei=n, 193 A ad fin.: and the emphasis on i)asa/menos (with *)eruci/maxe in the next line) should not be missed.
a)lloi=os h)\ o( so/s. This serves to emphasize, by repetition, the statement made by A. in 189 C (a)/llh| ge/ ph|...le/gein ktl.).
w(/sper ou)=n e)deh/qhn sou. See 189 B, 193 B.

ti/ e(ka/teros. A. corrects himself with a precision worthy of Prodicus, the comparative form being more proper than the superlative (e(/kastos) in speaking of two only. Observe that Aristodemus (the narrator) should have spoken next after Eryx., but is here ignored: to have represented him as a chief speaker “wäre auch nicht richt passend gewesen” (Zeller).

kai\ ga/r...e)rrh/qh. “Indeed I was quite pleased with your discourse”: hence, Eryximachus could “let off” Aristophanes (cp. 189 C i)/sws...a)fh/sw se). Whatever the esoteric meaning of A.'s discourse may have been, Eryx. apparently regards it simply as a piece of pleasantry—“er hat sich also offenbar nicht verstanden, sondern hat sich blos an die lustige Aussenseite derselben gehalten” (Rettig).
ei) mh\ cunh/|dh ktl. For this construction with cu/noida, cp. Prot. 348 B i(/na tou/tw| me\n tau=ta suneidw=men (with Adam's note); Phaedo 92 D, Apol. 34 B.
pa/nu a)\n e)fobou/mhn. For the imperf. here (in an unfulfilled condition) as a primary tense, cp. Theaet. 143 E (Goodwin G. M. T. § 172).
*kalw=s...h)gw/nisai. This implies that the various encomiasts are engaged in a rhetorical contest (a)gw/n): “your display in the competition was a fine one.”
ei) de\ ge/noio ktl. Cp. Ter. Andr. II. 1. 9 tu si hic sis, aliter censeas. For ma=llon de\ i)/sws (rashly altered by critics) cp. Rep. 589 D, Ar. Vesp. 1486, and see Vahlen Op. Acad. I. 494 f.

e)peida\n ktl. Notice the elaborate courtesy, not devoid of irony, with which S. treats Agathon, who evidently is a man with a taste for flattery. Since the combination eu)= kai\ ma/la is open to suspicion, the regular forms being either eu)= ma/la (Gorg. 496 C, etc.) or kai\ ma/la (Phaedrus 265 A, etc.), I adopt the punctuation suggested by Vahlen. Other critics have proposed to eject either the kai\ or the eu)=: it would be equally easy to alter eu)= to su/, or transpose to kai\ eu)=. The text, punctuated after ei)/ph|, has been construed (1) as “plenius dictum pro eu)= ma/la” (Stallb.), the kai\ connecting ma/la with eu)= (Hommel), or (2) as eu)= ma/la with kai\, corresponding to the following kai\, interjected (so Ast); but neither of these explanations is tenable. In favour of construing eu)= with ei)/ph| may be cited eu)= e)rou=ntos three ll. below and eu)= e)rei= 198 A: for the order, cp. Rep. 613 B o(/soi a)\n qe/wsin eu)=: Laws 805 B, 913 B (see Vahlen Op. Acad. I. 494 ff.): add Thuc. I. 71. 7 pro\s ta/de bouleu/esqe eu)=, kai\ ktl.

e)n panti\ ei)/hs. “You would be at your wits' end,” in summa consilii inopia (Ast). Cp. Euthyd. 301 A e)n panti\ e)geno/mhn u(po\ a)pori/as: Rep. 579 B; Xen. Hell. v. 4. 29. Cp. the use of pantoi=os ei)=nai (gi/gnesqai).

*farma/ttein b. me. “To cast a spell upon me.” Extravagant praise was liable to cause nemesis and the evil eye: cp. Phaedo 95 B mh\ me/ga le/ge, mh/ tis h(mi=n baskani/a peritre/yh| to
 lo/gon to
 me/llonta le/gesqai (with Stallb. ad loc.): Virg. Ecl. VII. 27, and the Latin terms fascinum, mala lingua. For farma/ttein, cp. Meno 80 A gohteu/eis me kai\ farma/tteis. Both here and in Meno l. c. the phrase may be reminiscent of Gorg. Hel. 15 oi( de\ tw=n lo/gwn peiqoi= tini kakh=| th
 yuxh
 e)farma/keusan kai\ e)cegoh/teusan.

to\ qe/atron. “The house,”—rather absurdly applied to the small gathering of banqueters, but A. is still full of his recent triumph in the qe/atron proper and readily takes up the idea that he is again engaged in a literary a)gw/n (cp. h)gwni/sai, 194 A n.).
*)epilh/smwn. Cp. Ar. Nub. 129 ge/rwn w)\n ka)pilh/smwn kai\ bradu/s. As Hommel notes, the word is “senum decrepitorum constans epitheton.” Socrates applies it to himself also in Prot. 334 C, D.

th
 sh
...a)nabai/nontos. For the construction, cp. Ar. Ach. 93 (e)kko/yeie...) to/n ge so
 (o)fqalmo
) tou= pre/sbews. See Madv. Gr. Syntax § 67.

e)pi\ to\n o)kri/banta. It seems to have been usual for the poet, as well as the players and choreutae, to appear before the audience, wearing crowns but not in costume, at the proagw/n of the great Dionysia held in the Odeum of Pericles on the 8th of Elaphebolion: see Aesch. III. 67 (Schol.), Ar. Vesp. 1109 (Schol.). The o)kri/bas was apparently a platform (bh=ma, cp. Ion 535 E) in the Odeum, and not, as formerly supposed, the logei=on or stage in the theatre itself (cp. Smith D. A. II. 813 b, 818 b): Schol. o)kri/banta: to\ logei=on, e)f' ou(= oi( tragw|doi\ h)gwni/zonto. tine\s de\ killi/banta triskelh= fasi/n, e)f' ou(= i(/stantai oi( u(pokritai\ kai\ ta\ e)k metew/rou le/gousin. Another meaning of o)kri/bas is a painter's “easel.”

me/llontos e)pidei/cesqai. The force of me/llontos is seen when we remember that the a)na/basis of the poets took place at the proagw/n, before the actual performance of the play. For e)pidei/knusqai of theatrical displays, cp. Ar. Ran. 771 o(/te dh\ kath=lq' *eu)ripi/dhs, e)pedei/knuto toi=s lwpodu/tais ktl. With Agathon's self-assurance cp. Isocr. Paneg. 43 C mikro\n u(pe\r e)mautou= qrasuna/menos...poih/somai tou\s lo/gous.
ou(/tw qea/trou mesto\n. This means “theatri applausu inflatum esse” (Stallb.); rather than “stage-struck,” cp. Themist. 26. 311 B; Synes. de provid. 105 B qea/trou kai\ a)gora=s a)/plhstos.

pollw=n a)fro/nwn. As Wolf observes, “ein feines Compliment für das Parterre in Athen.” But such a lofty contempt for the bourgeois of the pit and gallery is quite in keeping with A.'s position as the artistic aristocrat. If Aristophanes flatters his public on their sofi/a (as in Ran. 1109 ff.), it is obvious that he does so with his tongue in his cheek. Cp. Laws 659 A, ou)/te ga\r para\ qea/trou dei= to/n ge a)lhqh= krith\n kri/nein manqa/nonta.

peri\ sou= ti e)gw\. “Nota vim pronominum...: de te, viro tanto tamque insigni, ego, homo vilis” (Hommel). For a)/groikos, cp. 218 B, Laws 880 A Theaet. 174 D a)/groikon de\ kai\ a)pai/deuton...gi/gnesqai.
mh\ ou)x...w)=men. For Platonic exx. of mh/ or mh/ ou) in “cautions assertions or negations,” see Goodwin G. M. T. § 265.
a)/llois...sofoi=s. Not “other wise men” but “others who are wise” (sc. unlike us).

i)/sws. This word is probably genuine. Possibly, however, it should be transferred to a place before, or after, ta/x' a)/n (for the combination i)/sws ta/x' a)/n, cp. Tim. 38 E, Laws 676 C, etc.; Schanz nov. comm. p. 14). The o)/n after ai)sxro/n is sufficiently confirmed by Rep. 425 C, Phaedo 77 A (see Vahlen, Op. Acad. I. 496 f. on the whole passage).
ou)de\n e)/ti dioi/sei...gi/gnesqai. For Socrates as filo/logos, see Apol. 38 A, Phaedo 61 E; and for his “cramp-fish” style of dialectic, Laches 187.
a)/llws te kai\ kalw=|. For Socrates as filo/kalos, cp. 213 C, 216 D: it is a mark of the e)rwtiko/s.
a)podou\s ou)=n. Cp. Polit. 267 A kalw=s kai\ kaqaperei\ xre/ws a)pe/dwka/s moi to\n lo/gon: Rep. 612 B, C; 220 D infra.

div1.head: Speech of Agathon
div1.p: prw=ton me\n...e)/peita ei)pei=n. Stallbaum, though reading w(s, punctuates like Hommel (who keeps the vulgate h(=|) after the first as well as after the second ei)pei=n, as if the meaning were “to speak in the way in which I ought to speak,” which is nonsense. The first ei)pei=n (=dhlou=n) is different in force from the other two (=lo/gon poiei=sqai), the sense being “first to state the proper method I am to adopt in my oration, and secondly to deliver it.” Agathon has imbibed a “worship of machinery”—the machinery of method— from the fashionable schools of rhetoric.

dokou=si ga/r moi. Agathon, like the rest (cp. 180 D, 185 E), adopts the favourite rhetorical device of criticizing the manner or thought of previous speakers: cp. Isocr. Busir. 222 B, 230 A; Hel. 210 B fhsi\ me\n ga\r e)gkw/mion... tugxa/nei d' a)pologi/an ei)rhkw/s ktl.: Panegyr. 41 B ff., 44 C.

oi(=os w)
 <oi(/wn>. This doubling of relatives is a favourite trick of poets and rhetors; cp. Soph. Aj. 923 oi(=os w)
 oi(/ws e)/xeis (“mighty and mightily fallen”), ib. 557, Trach. 995, 1045; Eur. Alc. 144; Gorg. Palam. 22 oi(=os w)
 oi(/w| loidorei=: id. Hel. 11 o(/soi de\ o(/sous peri\ o(/swn kai\ e)/peisan kai\ pei/sousi.

ei) qe/mis kai\ a)neme/shton. For excess in laudation as liable to provoke ne/mesis, see n. on farma/ttein, 194 A. For the thought (here and at the end of A.'s speech) cp. Spenser, H. to Love, “Then would I sing of thine immortall praise...And thy triumphant name then would I raise Bove all the gods, thee onely honoring, My guide, my God, my victor, and my king.”
w)= *fai=dre. Phaedrus is specially addressed because it is his thesis (e)n toi=s presbu/tatos o( *)/erws 178 A, C) which is here challenged.

me/ga de\ tekmh/rion. This serves to echo, and reply to, Phaedrus's tekmh/rion de\ tou/tou 178 B (cp. 192 A). For the attributes youth and beauty, cp. Callim. H. II. 36 kai\ me\n a)ei\ kalo\s kai\ a)ei\ ne/os (of Phoebus).

feu/gwn fugh=|. A poetical mode of giving emphasis. “fugh=| feu/gein nunquam sic legitur ut simplex feu/gein de victis militibus, sed per translationem, fugientium modo, h. e. omni contentione aliquid defugere atque abhorrere” (Lobeck Parall. II. p. 524). Prose exx. are Epin. 974 B, Epist. viii. 354 C; Lucian adv. indoct. 16.

taxu\ o)\n...prose/rxetai. Bast, “motus a)topi/a| sententiae,” condemned these words; but the presence of sophistical word-play is no reason for suspicion in A.'s speech. A. argues that Age, in spite of its “lean shrunk shanks,” is nimble, only too nimble indeed in its pursuit of men: therefore, à fortiori, the god who can elude its swift pursuit must be still more nimble. For the agility of Eros, cp. Orph. H. 58. 1, 2 (kiklh/|skw) *)/erwta...eu)/dromon o(rmh=|.

e)nto\s pollou=. Cp. Thuc. II. 77 e)nto\s ga pollou= xwri/ou th=s po/lews ou)k h)=n pela/sai. For the sense (abhorrence of age), cp. Anacr. 14. 5 h( de\ (nh=nis)...th
 me
 e)mh
 ko/mhn, | leukh\ ga/r, katame/mfetai ktl.

a)ei\ cu/nesti/ te kai\ e)/stin. Hug adopts Sauppe's addition <ne/os>, but this spoils the ring of the clause and it is best to leave it to be mentally supplied: for the ellipse, cp. 213 C geloi=os e)/sti te kai\ bou/letai. For meta\...su/nesti, cp. Laws 639 C; Plut. de Is. et Os. 352 A par' au)th=| kai\ met' au)th=s o)/nta kai\ suno/nta.

o(/moion o(moi/w|. The original of this is Hom. Od. XVII. 218 w(s a)ei\ to\n o(moi=on a)/gei qeo\s w(s to\n o(moi=on. Cp. 186 B supra, Lysis 214 A, Rep. 329 A; Aristaen. Ep. I. 10: and for a Latin equivalent, Cic. de Senect. 3. 7 pares cum paribus, vetere proverbio, facillime congregantur: so Anglicè, “birds of a feather flock together.” Similar in sense is h(=lic h(/lika te/rpei (Arist. Rhet. I. 11. 25).
*fai/drw|. The reference is to 178 B. Spenser (H. to Love) combines these opposite views,—“And yet a chyld, renewing still thy yeares, And yet the eldest of the heavenly Peares.”

*kro/nou kai\ *)iapetou= a)rxaio/tero/s. A proverbial expression to denote the
“ne plus ultra” of antiquity: cp. Moeris p. 200 *)iapeto/s: a)nti\ tou= ge/rwn. kai\ *ti/qwnos kai\ *kro/nos: e)pi\ tw=n gero/ntwn: Lucian dial. deor. 2. 1; Ar. Nub. 398, Plut. 581. Cronus and Iapetus were both Titans, sons of Uranus and Gê (Hes. Th. 507), and imprisoned together in Tartarus (Il. VIII. 479). Iapetus was father of Prometheus, and grandfather of Deucalion, the Greek “Adam”: hence “older than Iapetus” might be rendered “ante-preadamite.”

a(\ *(hsi/odos kai\ *p. le/gousin. These were the authorities adduced by Phaedrus (178 B). Hesiod relates such palaia\ pra/gmata in Theog. 176 ff., 746 ff.; but no such accounts by Parmenides are extant. Accordingly, it has been supposed (e.g. by Schleierm.) that A. is mistaken, and Ast proposed to read *)epimeni/dhs: but cp. Macrob. somn. Scip. I. 2 Parmenides quoque et Heraclitus de diis fabulati sunt. If P. did relate such matters in the poem of which portions remain, clearly (as Stallb. observed) it could only have been in Pt. II. (“The Way of Opinion”). Cp. Ritter and Pr. § 101 D, “Generati sunt deinceps (i.e. post Amorem) ceteri dei, de quibus more antiquiorum poetarum palaia\ pra/gmata narravit, v. Plat. Symp. 195 C, Cic. D. Nat. I. 11”; Zeller, Presocr. p. 596 (E. Tr.); Krische Forsch. p. 111 f. For *)ana/gkh in the cosmogonists, cp. Parmen. 84 K., kraterh\ ga\r *)ana/gkh | pei/ratos e)n desmoi=sin e)/xei, to/ min a)mfi\s e)e/rgei: id. 138 w(/s min a)/gous' e)pe/dhsen *)ana/gkh: Emped. 369 e)/stin *)ana/gkhs xrh=ma ktl.
ei)...e)/legon. Rettig and Stallb. rightly explain the imperf. as due to the reference to Phaedrus's mention of H. and P. (178 B).
e)ktomai\ ou)de\ desmoi\. Cp. Euthyph. 5 E ff., Rep. 377 E where such tales of divine immorality are criticized.
a(palo/s. Cp. Theogn. 1341 ai)ai=, paido\s e)rw= a(palo/xroos: Archil. 100 qa/lleis a(palo\n xro/a: Phaedrus 245 A labou=sa a(palh\n kai\ a)/baton yuxh/n.
*(/omhros ga\r. See Il. XIV. 92—3. Schol. pi/lnatai: prospela/zei, proseggi/zei.
tou\s gou=n...ei)=nai. As Hug observes, the occurrence of kai\ posi\ kai\ pa/nth| below is sufficient to establish the soundness of these words.

h)/qesi kai\ yuxai=s. “In the tempers and souls”: here h)=qos seems to be co-ordinate with yuxh/, but below (h)=qos e)xou/sh|, sc. yuxh=|) subordinate, i.e. A. uses the word loosely with more attention to sound than sense: cp. Lysis 222 A kata\ th\n yuxh\n h)\ kata/ ti th=s yuxh=s h)=qos h)\ tro/pous h)\ ei)=dos: 183 E above, 207 E infra. Notice also the material way in which h)/qh and yuxai/ are here conceived: cp. Moschus I. 17 e)pi\ spla/xnois de\ ka/qhtai: and the figure in such a phrase as “the iron entered into his soul.”
kai\ posi\ kai\ pa/nth|. “With feet and with form entire,” “nicht wie Ate blos mit Füssen” (Wolf): pa/nth|, like a)ei/, is A.'s own extension of the Homeric statement.
e)n malakwta/tois tw=n m. The genitive is governed by a(pto/menon, and e)n malakwta/tois is parallel to e)n toi=s (presbu/taton) 178 A: “the most soft of softest things.”
new/tatos...a(palw/tatos. Cp. Rep. 377 A ne/w| kai\ a(palw=| o(tw|ou=n.

u(gro\s to\ ei)=dos. u(gro/s, here opposed to sklhro/s, is often used “de rebus lubricis, lentis, flexibilibus, mollibus” (Stallb.): cp. Theaet. 162 B tw=| de\ dh\ newte/rw| te kai\ u(grote/rw| o)/nti (opp. to sklhrw=| o)/nti) prospalai/ein: Pind. Pyth. I. 17 (11) o( de\ (ai)eto\s) knw/sswn u(gro\n nw=ton ai)wrei=: Callistr. descript. 3 (of a bronze of Eros) u(gro\s me\n h)=n a)moirw=n malako/thtos. Another sense of u(gro/s, in erotic terminology, is “melting,” “languishing,” e.g. Anth. Plan. 306 e)p' o)/mmasin u(gra\ dedorkw/s: Anacr. XXVIII. 21: and in hymn. Hom. XVIII. 33 u(gro/s is an epithet of po/qos. “Supple of form” is the best rendering here. Arist. G. A. I. 7. 3 applies u(gro/ths (tou= sw/matos) to serpents.—periptu/ssesqai is a(/p. leg. in Plato, and mainly used in poetry.

summe/trou...i)de/as. “Acute vidit Astius su/mmetron referendum esse ad periptu/ssesqai. Amor enim, quia potest pa/nth| periptu/ssesqai, recte su/mmetros vocatur. Itaque ne hic quidem audiendus est Orellius qui su/mmetros legendum putabat” (Stallb., so too Rückert and Hommel). Rettig takes su/mmetros to be merely a synonym for u(gro/s, supposing that the proof of the statement u(gro\s to\ ei)=dos, which was first stated negatively, is here being stated positively—“nun hängt summetri/a mit der eu)sxhmosu/nh zusammen und ebenso u(gro/ths mit summetri/a. Vgl. Legg. VI. 773 A, Phileb. 66 B.” On the other hand Hug, supposing that summetri/a is introduced as a new attribute distinct from u(gro/ths, follows Jahn in ejecting the words kai\ u(gra=s. Rettig's view, adopted also by Teuffel, seems the most reasonable: A., with sophistical looseness, smuggles in the extra term su/mmetros beside u(gro/s in order to secure the applicability of eu)sxhmosu/nh. By summetri/a, properly used, is meant the perfect proportion of the parts in relation to one another which results in a harmonious whole: see my Phileb. p. 176. For eu)sxhmosu/nh, cp. Rep. 400 C ff.

e)k pa/ntwn. Cp. Theaet. 171 B e)c a(pa/ntwn a)/ra...a)mfisbhth/setai, “on all hands, then,...we find it disputed” (so Campbell ad loc., who observes that “this use of e)c has been needlessly disputed by Heindorf and others”). Ficinus seems to connect e)k p. with diaf., which is possible but less probable.

xro/as de\ ka/llos ktl. Possibly we have here a reminiscence of some passage in poetry: xro/as...a)/nqh admits, as Hug observes, of being scanned as a “catalectic pentapody” (like Eur. Phoen. 294). In the repeated mention in these lines of a)/nqos and its compounds, we may discern an allusion to Agathon's tragedy *)anqeu/s. Cp. Plato 32 (P. L. G. II. 311) au)to\s d) (sc. o( *)/erws) e)n kalu/kessin r(o/dwn pepedhme/nos u(/pnw| | eu(=den meidio/wn: Alcman 38 ma/rgos d' *)/erws oi(=a pai=s pai/sdei...a)/kr' e)p' a)/nqh kabai/nwn...tw= kupairi/skw: Simon. fr. 47 o(milei= d' a)/nqesin, (w(=te) me/lissa canqo\n me/li mhdome/na: Eros, like Titania, loves “a bank where the wild thyme blows” (eu)w/dhs to/pos), and might echo the song “where the bee sucks, there suck I,” etc. For the negative thought a)nanqei=...ou)k e)ni/zei, cp. Philo de meretr. merc. II. 264 e)cw/rois genome/nais (“when past the flower of their age,” sc. tai=s e(tai/rais) ou)dei\s e)/ti pro/seisin, a)pomwranqei/shs w(/sper tinw=n a)nqw=n th=s a)kmh=s. For eu)w/dhs to/pos, cp. Phaedrus 230 B. The description of Eros lying soft in Soph. Antig. 781 ff. is somewhat similar,
(*)/erws) o(\s e)n malakai=s pareiai=s | neani/dos e)nnuxeu/eis: cp. Hor. C. IV. 13. 6 ff. (Amor) virentis...pulcris excubat in genis. Also the echo of our passage in Aristaen. Ep. II. 1.
*peri\ me\n ou)=n...peri\ de\ ktl. Cp. Isocr. Pan. 47 C peri\ me\n ou)=n tou= megi/stou...tau=t' ei)pei=n e)/xomen. peri\ de\ tou\s au)tou\s xro/nous ktl.: Phaedrus 246 A.

peri\ de\ a)reth=s. In drawing out this part of his theme Agathon follows the customary four-fold division of a)reth/ into dikaiosu/nh, swfrosu/nh, a)ndrei/a, sofi/a. Adam (on Rep. 427 E) writes “There is no evidence to shew that these four virtues and no others were regarded as the essential elements of a perfect character before Plato.” Yet it certainly seems probable that these four were commonly recognized as leading a)retai/ at an earlier date (see the rest of the evidence cited by Adam), and a peculiarly Platonic tenet would hardly be put into the mouth of Agathon. Cp. Protag. 329 C ff.; and for a similar use made of this classification in encomiastic oratory, see Isocr. Hel. 31 ff., Nicocl. 31 ff., 36 ff. (cp. n. on 184 C).

ou)/t' a)dikei= ou)/t' a)dikei=tai. The maxims “love your enemies, do good to them which despitefully treat you” formed no part of current Greek ethics: cp. Meno 71 E au(/th e)sti\n a)ndro\s a)reth/,...tou\s me\n fi/lous eu)= poiei=n, tou\s d' e)xqrou\s kakw=s: Crito 49 B: Xen. Mem. II. 3. 14; and other passages cited by Adam on Rep. 331 E. See also Dobbs, Philos. etc. pp. 39, 127, 243. Notice the chiasmus a)dikei=...a)dikei=tai...u(po\ qeou=...qeo/n.

bi/a| pa/sxei. These words form one notion and are put as a substitute for a)dikei=tai, just as poiei= (sc. bi/a|) below is a substitute for a)dikei=. Cp. Polit. 280 D ta\s bi/a| pra/ceis. There may be a ref. here to the e)/rwtos a)na/gkai of Gorgias Hel. 19.

pa=s ga\r ktl. With but slight modification this would form an iambic trimeter. Cp. Gorgias ap. Phileb. 58 A h( tou= pei/qein polu\ diafe/rei pasw=n texnw=n: pa/nta ga\r u(f' au)th=| dou=la di) e(ko/ntwn a)ll' ou) dia\ bi/as, of which our passage may be a reminiscence.

a(\ d' a)\n ktl. The argument is that where mutual consent obtains, since bi/a is absent, there can be no a)diki/a. For a different view of dikaiosu/nh see Arist. Eth. N. v. 9. 1136^{b} 32 ff. e(/teron ga\r to\ nomiko\n di/kaion kai\ to\ prw=ton ktl.: Crito 52 E: Xen. Symp. VIII. 20.

oi( po/lews...no/moi. Apparently a quotation from Alcidamas, a rhetor of the
school of Gorgias: see Arist. Rhet. III. 1406^{a} 18 ff. dio\ ta\ *)alkida/mantos yuxra\ fai/netai: ou) ga\r h(du/smati xrh=tai a)ll' w(s e)de/smati toi=s e)piqe/tois, ou(/tw puknoi=s kai\ meizo/si kai\ e)pidh/lois, oi(=on...ou)xi\ no/mous a)lla\ tou\s tw=n po/lewn basilei=s no/mous (see Cope ad loc.). Two extant works are ascribed to Alcidamas, viz. an Odysseus and a de Sophistis: the latter is probably genuine and “seems to justify Aristotle's strictures on his want of taste in the use of epithets” (Cope loc. cit.).
