See further Vahlen, Alkidamas etc. pp. 508 ff.; Blass, Att. Bereds. II. 328.

ei)=nai ga\r...swfrosu/nh. This definition of “temperance” is common to both scientific and popular morals. Cp. Rep. 389 D swfrosu/nhs...au)tou\s (ei)=nai) a)/rxontas tw=n peri\ po/tous kai\ a)frodi/sia kai\ peri\ e)dwda\s h(donw=n (“temperance, soberness and chastity”): ib. 430 E, Phaedo 68 C: Antiphon fr. 6 swfrosu/nhn d' a)ndro\s...o(/stis tou= qumou= ta\s paraxrh=ma h(dona\s e)mfra/sswn kratei=n te kai\ nika=n h)dunh/qh au)to\s e(auto/n. See Dobbs op. cit. pp. 149 ff.; Nägelsbach, Nachhom. Theol. pp. 227 ff.

*)/erwtos de\ ktl. The argument is vitiated both by the ambiguity in the use of Eros (as affection and as person) and by the ambiguity in kratei= h(donw=n, which in the minor premiss is equivalent to e)sti\n h( krati/sth h(donh/. For similar fallacies, see Euthyd. 276 D ff.; Arist. soph. el. 165^{b} 32 ff. For e)/rws as a master-passion, cp. Rep. 572 E ff. Agathon here again echoes Gorgias (Hel. 6 pe/fuke ga\r ou) to\ krei=sson u(po\ tou= h(/ssonos kwlu/esqai, a)lla\ to\ h(=sson u(po\ tou= krei/ssonos a)/rxesqai kai\ a)/gesqai ktl.).
ou)d' *)/arhs a)nqi/statai. This comes from Soph. (Thyestes) fr. 235 N. pro\s th\n a)na/gkhn ou)d' *)/arhs a)nqi/statai. Cp. Anacreontea 27 A, 13 e)/laben be/lemnon (sc. *)/erwtos) *)/arhs.
w(s lo/gos. See Hom. Od. VIII. 266 ff., already alluded to in 192 D.
pa/ntwn a)\n...ei)/h. Another illegitimate conclusion. By means of a tacit substitution of the notion a)ndrei/a for kra/tos, it is assumed that o( kratw=n tou= a)ndrei/ou must be a)ndreio/teros.
w(/sper *)eruci/maxos. See 186 B.

pa=s gou=n ktl. An allusion to Eurip. (Stheneboea) fr. 663 N. poihth\n d' a)/ra | *)/erws dida/skei, ka)\n a)/mousos h)=| to\ pri/n. This last phrase had a vogue: cp. Ar. Vesp. 1074; Menander Com. 4, p. 146; Plut. amat. 17. 762 B, Symp. I. 622 C; Longin. de subl. 39. 2 (quoted with other passages by Nauck). For the ditties of a love-sick swain, cp. Lysis 204 D. See also Aristid. t. I. Or. IV. p. 30.
pa=san...mousikh/n. With A.'s bisection of poi/hsis cp. the analysis of the notion by Socrates, 205 B infra.
kai\ me\n dh\...ge. Porro etiam, quin etiam. (See Madv. Gr. Synt. § 236.)

*)/erwtos...sofi/an . sofi/an is here predicate (against Rückert) and stands for sofi/as e)/rgon. For Eros as “poetic” in this sense, cp. Spenser (H. to Love), “But if thou be indeede, as men thee call, The worlds great Parent.”

th\n...dhmiourgi/an. This branch of poi/hsis is really a distinct kind from the other two, as not involving invention or creation. For “demiurgic arts,” see Phileb. 55 D ff., and for i)atrikh/ as an example Phileb. 56 A; cp. 186 C, D supra. Cp. Isocr. Hel. 219 B (where H. is eulogized as the cause texnw=n kai\ filosofiw=n kai\ tw=n a)/llwn w)feleiw=n).

fano\s. Illustris: Hesych. fano/n: fwteino\n kai\ lampro/n: cp. Phaedrus 256 D. For gods as dida/skaloi and h(gemo/nes (197 E), cp. Isocr. Busir. 229 B—C tou\s qeou\s...h(gou=mai...au)tou/s te pa/sas e)/xontas ta\s a)reta\s fu=nai kai\ toi=s a)/llois tw=n kalli/stwn e)pithdeuma/twn h(gemo/nas kai\ didaska/lous gegenh=sqai.

*)apo/llwn a)neu=ren. For Apollo as the inventor of tocikh/, see Hom. Il. II. 827; of mantikh/, Il. I. 72; of i)atrikh/, 190 E ff. supra. See also h. Hom. Apoll. 131 ff.; and for mantikh/ in connexion with the cult of A., Rohde Psyche II. pp. 56 ff.
e)/rwtos...*)/erwtos. Here, as elsewhere in these lo/goi, there is a play on the double sense of the word as (1) a mental affection (i.q. e)piqumi/a), and (2) a personal agent.

kai\ *mou=sai mousikh=s. Supply (as Stallb. and Hug) *)/erwtos a)\n ei)=en maqhtai/. Less probable is the explanation of Ast and Rückert who, regarding w(/ste...maqhth/s as parenthetic, supply a)neu=ron with *mou=sai (and the other nominatives) and take mousikh=s (and the other genitives) as dependent on e)piqumi/as...h(gemoneu/santos mentally repeated. For the double genitive of person and thing, cp. Rep. 599 C ti/nas maqhta\s i)atrikh=s kateli/peto.
xalkei/as...i(stourgi/as. For Hephaestus, cp. 192 D n.; and for Athene as patroness of weavers Il. XIV. 178, V. 735; Hes. Op. D. 63.

*zeu\s kuberna=n. The sudden change of construction from genitive to bare infin., together with the unusual genit. after kuberna=n, are best explained by assuming (with Usener) that we have here another of Agathon's poetical tags. For Zeus as world-pilot, see Il. II. 205, IX. 98: cp. Parmen. fr. 128 M. dai/mwn, h(\ pa/nta kuberna=|: and below, 197 E ad init., kubernh/ths is applied to Eros (cp. 186 E).
kateskeua/sqh ktl. This sentence is quoted later on (201 A) by Socrates. ta\ pra/gmata echoes the palaia\ pra/gmata of 195 C. ka/llous is object. gen. after *)/erwtos.

ai)/sxei ga\r ktl. This repeats the assertion of 196 A—B. Rettig reads ai)/sxei...e)/stin, arguing that e)/stin, not e)/ni, is required by the ref. in 201 A: but ai)/sxei e)/stin as an equiv. for ai)/sxous e)/stin would be a strange use. The restoration e)/pi is as certain as such things can be.
e)n a)rxh=| ei)=pon. See 195 C. Notice that here as there A. refuses to make himself responsible for the ascription of violence to the gods, as shown by the saving clause w(s le/getai.
a)/llwn toiou/twn. Sc. oi(=a ka/llos kai\ a)reth/: cp. Rep. 372 D.

e)pe/rxetai de/ moi/ ktl. Here Agathon breaks out into verse of his own, whereas hitherto he had contented himself with quoting from others (196 C, E). Observe the alliterative effect, dear to the school of Gorgias, of the play with r and n, g and l, in the former, and of n and m in the latter of the two verses.

nhnemi/an...kh/dei. Both the punctuation and reading of this verse are doubtful. Rückert, Stallb., and the Zurich edd. print commas after galh/nhn and a)ne/mwn, Hug and Burnet only after a)ne/mwn, Hommel after galh/nhn and koi/thn. It would appear, however, from the Homeric passage (Od. V. 391 = XII. 168, a)/nemos me\n e)pau/sato h)de\ galh/nh | e)/pleto nhnemi/h), of which this is obviously an echo, that no stop should be placed after galh/nhn, but rather after nhnemi/an or a)ne/mwn: while the compound word a)nemokoi=tai, applied to a sect (ge/nos) in Corinth who claimed to be able tou\s a)ne/mous koimi/zein (see Hesych. and Suid. s.v.; also Welcker Kl. Schr. 3. 63; Rohde Psyche II. p. 88; and 202 E n.), makes it probable that a)ne/mwn koi/thn are meant to go closely together. Further, although as Zeller argues it is appropriate enough in general to describe Love as “is qui non aequoris solum sed etiam humani pectoris turbas sedat” (cp. Il. XXIV. 128 ff., Catull. 68. 1—8), still the reversion to human kh=dos after mentioning waves and winds is a little curious, and it is tempting to adopt Hommel's conjecture e)ni\ kh/tei which, if kh=tos can bear the sense of “sea-depths” (see L. and S. s.vv. kh=tos, megakh/ths) would furnish a more satisfactory disposition of ideas—“peace on land and on sea, repose in heaven above and in the depths below.” Or, if we assumed that an original nei e)ni\ nei/kh| (=nei/kei) was corrupted by haplography to e)ni\ kh, a fair sense would be obtained. If the ordinary text be kept, we may notice (with Vögelin) how the force of the prepos. in e)n a)nqr....e)ni\ kh/dei varies “in the style of the Sophists.” In Theaet. 153 C we have a similar combination, nhnemi/as te kai\ galh/nas, the only other Platonic ex. of nhnemi/a being Phaedo 77 E. galhno/s as an adj. occurs in Ax. 370 D.
a)llotrio/thtos ktl. For Eros as the peace-maker, cp. Isocr. Hel. 221 B eu(rh/somen tou\s *(/ellhnas di) au)th\n o(monoh/santas kai\ koinh\n stra/teian... poihsame/nous.
ta\s toia/sde cuno/dous. “Haec deiktikw=s dicta sunt: quale est hoc convivium nostrum” (Stallb.).

e)n qusi/ais. For q. Stob. has eu)qumi/ais, which looks like a gloss on some word other than qusi/ais. I am inclined to suspect that qia/sois should be restored: the word would fit in well between xoroi=s and h(gemw/n, “in festive bands.” The corruption might be due to the loss of the termination, after which qia/s was mistaken for qusia/s. Cp. Xen. Symp. VIII. 1 pa/ntes e)smen tou= qeou= tou/tou qiasw=tai.

a)gano/s. The a)gaqo/s of the MSS. cannot stand, and Stobaeus's a)gaqoi=s (adopted by most edd. since Wolf) is open to objection both as spoiling the symmetry and because of the occurrence of a)gaqw=n just below. We want a more exquisite word, and Usener's a)gano/s is more appropriate in sense than such possible alternatives as a)gauo/s or a)glao/s. For Agathon's antitheses, cp. Clem. Al. Strom. V. 614 D; Athen. V. 11.
trufh=s...xlidh=s. Moeris: xlidh\ *)attikoi/, trufh\ *(/ellhnes. Hence Hug omits trufh=s as a gloss on xlidh=s, and (to preserve symmetry) omits po/qou also.

e)n po/nw| ktl. These words have given rise to much discussion and many emendations (see crit. n.). Two main lines of interpretation are possible: either (1) we may suppose that maritime allusions are to be sought in these words to match those in kubernh/ths ktl.; or (2) we may suppose the latter set of words to be used in a merely metaphorical sense. Badham adopts line (1); so too Schütz regards the whole figure as borrowed “e re nautica. Nautis enim saepe timor naufragii, desiderium terrae, labor in difficultate navigandi, aerumna nauseantibus...accidere solet”; and he takes the following four substt. (kubern. ktl.) as referring in order to these four conditions. And, adopting this line, I myself formerly proposed to read (for e)n po/qw|, e)n lo/gw|) e)n po/rw|, e)n r(o/qw|. The 2nd line of explanation is adopted a by those who attempt to defend the vulgate, and b by some who have recourse to emendation. Thus a Stallb. commends Ast's view that lo/gos can stand here because Agathon's speech is full of “merus verborum lusus”; while Hommel takes the words e)n po/nw| etc. as “e re amatoria depromta,” expressing the affections of the lover while seeking the society of his beloved, and connects (in the reverse order) lo/gw| with kubern., po/qw| with e)pib., fo/bw| with parast., and po/nw| with swth/r. On the other hand, b Rettig—while altering the second pair to e)n mo/qw|, e)n lo/xw|—also disregards the maritime metaphor and
understands the passage “überhaupt von Kriegsgefahren und dem in solchen geleisteten Beistand,” comparing the allusions to such matters by Phaedrus (179 A) and Alcibiades (220 D ff.). Here Rettig is, I believe, partly on the right track; since the clue to the sense (and reading) here is to be looked for in Alcibiades' eulogy of Socrates. We find po/nw| echoed there (219 E toi=s po/nois...perih=n), and fo/bw| also (220 E fugh=| a)nexw/rei, 221 A e)n fo/bw|) and e)n lo/gw| may be defended by the allusions to Socrates' lo/goi (215 C ff., 221 D ff.). Thus the only doubtful phrase is e)n po/qw|, which has no parallel in Alcib.'s speech, and is also objectionable here because of the proximity of po/qou. In place of it I propose e)n po/tw| (cp. Phileb. 48 A), of which we find an echo (in sense if not in sound) in 220 A e)n t' au)= tai=s eu)wxi/ais...kai\ pi/nein... pa/ntas e)kra/tei. For maritime terms in connexion with lo/gos, cp. Lach. 194 C a)ndra/si fi/lois xeimazome/nois e)n lo/gw| kai\ a)porou=si boh/qhson: Parm. 137 A dianeu=sai...tosou=ton pe/lagos lo/gwn: Phaedrus 264 A; Phileb. 29 B. So both lo/gos and po/tos in Dionys. Chalc. 4. 1 ff. u(/mnous oi)noxoei=n...to/nde...ei)resi/h| glw/sshs a)pope/myomen...tou=d' e)pi\ sumposi/ou: decio/ths te lo/gou | *fai/akos *mousw=n e)re/tas e)pi\ se/lmata pe/mpei: id. 5. 1 ff. kai/ tines oi)=non a)/gontes e)n ei)resi/h| *dionu/sou, | sumposi/ou nau=tai kai\ kuli/kwn e)re/tai | <ma/rnantai> peri\ tou=de. Cp. also Cic. Tusc. IV. 5. 9 quaerebam utrum panderem vela orationis statim, an eam...dialecticorum remis propellerem. For parasta/ths, of Eros, cp. o( par' e(ka/stw| dai/mwn in later Stoic literature (Rohde Psyche II. 316): Epict. diss. I. 14. 12; Menander (ap. Mein. Com. IV. 238) a(/panti dai/mwn a)ndri\ sumpari/statai | eu)qu\s genome/nw| mustagwgo\s tou= bi/ou. For Socrates as swth/r, see 220 D ff.: the term is regularly applied to a h(/rws, e.g. Soph. O. C. 460 (Oedipus); Thuc. V. 11. 2 (Brasidas); Eur. Heracl. 1032 (Eurystheus): Pind. fr. 132 has the same combination, swth\r a)/ristos: cp. Spenser, “(Love) the most kind preserver Of living wights.” e)n po/nw| might be a reminiscence of Pind. Nem. X. 78 pau=roi...e)n po/nw| pistoi/: or used, Homerically, of “the toil of war” (=e)n maxai=s, cp. 220 D). For kubernh/ths used metonymously, cp. 197 B (n. on kuberna=n); so Emerson, “Beauty is the pilot of the young soul.” e)piba/ths, in the present context, must mean “a marine,” classiarius miles, and hence, by metonymy, “a comrade” in general.—The general sense of the passage is this: “in the contests both of war and peace the best guide and warden, comrade and rescuer is Eros.” Cp. also Procl. in I Alc. p. 40.
cumpa/ntwn...ko/smos. Cp. Gorg. Hel. 1 ko/smos po/lei me\n eu)andri/a, sw/mati de\ ka/llos.

h(gemw\n...e)fumnou=nta. The image is that of Eros as coryphaeus leading a
procession of singers, and singing (“a song of my beloved”) himself (w)|dh=s h(\n a)/|dei). Notice how Agathon repeats the phrase qew=n te kai\ a)nqrw/pwn (cp. 197 B). For h(gemw/n, cp. Spenser (H. to Love) “Thou art his god, thou art his mighty guide.” kalh=s is omitted in Ficinus' transl.
no/hma. Here used, poetically, as equivalent to nou=s: cp. Pind. Pyth. VI. 29; Theogn. 435; Emped. 329 St., ai(=ma ga\r a)nqrw/pois perika/rdio/n e)sti no/hma.
tw=| qew=| a)nakei/sqw. “Let it be presented as a votive-offering (a)na/qhma) to the God (sc. Eros).”
paidia=s...spoudh=s. Possibly an echo of Gorg. Hel. ad fin. *(ele/nhs me\n e)gkw/mion, e)mo\n de\ pai/gnion. For the antithesis, cp. 216 E; Laws 647 D; Phileb. 30 E; Ar. Ran. 389.

metri/as. “H.e. kosmi/as” (Stallb.), with, perhaps, a latent play on the other sense of me/tron, in allusion to the rhythmical style of A.'s oration; cp. 187 D, 205 C, Phaedrus 267 A e)n me/trw| le/gein.

div1.head: Fourth Interlude
div1.p: a)naqorubh=sai. Cp. Protag. 334 C ei)po/ntos ou)=n tau=ta au)tou= oi( paro/ntes a)neqoru/bhsan w(s eu)= le/goi: Euthyd. 276 B; Cic. Sen. 18. 64 a cuncto consessu plausus multiplex datus.
prepo/ntws...tw=| qew=|. Cp. Laws 699 D ei)/rhkas sautw=| te kai\ th=| patri/di prepo/ntws.
w)= pai= *)akoumenou=. Observe the mock-solemnity of this mode of address: cp. 172 A, 214 B. Socrates addresses Eryx. with allusion to his language in 193 E (ei) mh\ cunh/|dh ktl.).

a)dee\s...de/os dedie/nai. Schol. a)dee\s de/os: e)pi\ tw=n ta\ mh\ a)/cia fo/bou dedio/twn. o(/moion tou/tw| kai\ to\ yofodeh\s a)/nqrwpos (Phaedrus 257 D). Observe how Socr. here, in caricature of Agathon's style (e.g. 197 D), combines in one phrase the figura etymologica and the figure oxymoron: cp. Eur. I. T. 216 nu/mfan du/snumfon: ib. 566 xa/rin a)/xarin: id. Hel. 690 ga/mon a)/gamon.
a(\ nu=n dh\ e)/legon. The reference is to 194 A.

ou) me/llw ktl. Notice the change of tense in a)porei=n...le/cein: Plato uses pres., fut., and aor. infinitives after me/llw, of which the last is the rarest construction. For the sense, cp. Soph. 231 B.
pantodapo\n lo/gon. There is irony in the epithet. Socr. implies that he regards it as a motley lo/gos, “a thing of shreds and patches.” Cp. 193 E, and 198 E (pa/nta lo/gon kinou=ntes ktl.).

ou)x o(moi/ws me
 qaumasta/. The antithesis must be mentally supplied: “the earlier parts were not equally marvellous (although they were marvellous).” Stallb. explains differently, “ta\ me
 a)/lla accipi potest absolute pro et quod cetera quidem attinet; quo facto non inepte pergitur sic: ou)x o(moi/ws me
 qaumasta/, particula me
 denuo iterata.” But the former explanation (adopted by Rettig and Hug, after Zeller) is the simpler and better.

to\ de\ e)pi\ teleuth=s ktl. to\ is accus. of respect, going closely with e)pi\ teleuth=s, not with tou= ka/llous (as Rückert): “quod autem exitum orationis tuae attinet” (Stallb., and so Hommel). tou= ka/llous is governed by e)cepla/gh, as gen. of causative object (cp. Madv. Gr. Synt. § 61 b). a)kou/wn, “as he heard.”

tw=n o)noma/twn kai\ r(hma/twn. Cp. 199 B o)no/masi de\ kai\ qe/sei r(hma/twn. Properly, o)/noma and r(h=ma are distinguished as, in logic, the subject and predicate and, in grammar, the noun and verb respectively. But commonly o)/noma is used of any single word, and r(h=ma of a clause, or proposition (e.g. Protag. 341 E); cp. Apol. 17 B; Crat. 399 A, 431 B. Both here and below, as Athenaeus observes (V. 187 C), *pla/twn xleua/zei te ta\ i)so/kwla ta\ *)aga/qwnos kai\ ta\ a)nti/qeta. Cp. the criticism of the Sophistic style in Alcid. de Soph. 12 oi( toi=s o)no/masin a)kribw=s e)ceirgasme/noi kai\ ma=llon poih/masin h)\ lo/gois e)oiko/tes kai\ to\ me\n au)to/maton kai\ ple/wn a)lhqei/as a)pobeblhko/tes: Isocr. c. Soph. 294 D toi=s e)nqumh/masi prepo/ntws o(/lon to\n lo/gon katapoiki=lai kai\ toi=s o)no/masi eu)ru/qmws kai\ mousikw=s ei)pei=n.
ou)d' e)ggu\s tou/twn. Cp. 221 D below; Rep. 378 D tou\s poihta\s e)ggu\s tou/twn a)nagkaste/on logopoiei=n.
o)li/gou. I.e. o)li/gou dei=n. Cp. Theaet. 180 D; Euthyd. 279 D.
*gorgi/ou...a)nemi/mnh|sken. For Agathon as a “Gorgiast,” see Introd. § III. 5. Cp. Philostr. de vit. Soph. I. kai\ *)aga/qwn...pollaxou= tw=n i)ambei/wn gorgia/zei: Xen. Symp. II. 26, IV. 24.

to\ tou= *(omh/rou. See Od. XI. 632 e)me\ de\ xlwro
 de/os h(/|rei | mh/ moi gorgei/hn
kefalh
 deinoi=o pelw/rou | e)c *)ai/dew pe/myeien a)gauh\ *persefo/neia. Miss Harrison (Proleg. p. 191) renders gorgei/hn by “grizzly,” with the note “Homer does not commit himself to a definite Gorgon”: his Gorgoneion is “an underworld bogey, an a)potro/paion.” That “the Gorgon was regarded as a sort of incarnate evil eye” (ibid. p. 196) appears from Athen. V. 64. 221 ktei/nei to
 u(p' au)th=s qewrhqe/nta, ou) tw=| pneu/mati a)lla\ th=| gignome/nh| a)po\ th=s tw=n o)mma/twn fu/sews fora=| kai\ nekro
 poiei=. Rohde (Psyche II. 407) points out that “Hekate selbst wird angerufen als *gorgw\ kai\ *mormw\ kai\ *mh/nh kai\ polu/morfe: hymn bei Hippol. ref. haer. 4. 35 p. 73 Mill”; and that *gorgw/ appears to be a shorter form for *gorgu/ra (*)axe/rontos gunh/, Apollod.). For the pun on Gorgias-Gorgon, cp. that on a)gaqw=n (174 B n.). As against Dümmler's inference that Gorgias' previous death is here implied, see Vahlen op. Acad. I. 482 ff.

e)n tw=| lo/gw|. Cp. 201 A, Gorg. 457 D, Theaet. 169 B. To eject these words with Hug, or to substitute pelw/rou with Badham, would (as Voegelin and Rettig contend) destroy the antithesis e)n tw=| l. )( e)pi\ to\n e)mo\n l., and spoil the “Gorgianische Wortspiel.” Further, the phrase serves as a parallel to the Homeric e)c *)ai/dew. Observe, as a feature of the parody, the different sense in which Socr. uses deino/s: also, how the sentence as a whole forms a playful retort to Agathon's remark in 194 A (farma/ttein bou/lei me ktl.). For the adverbial use of teleutw=n, cp. Phaedrus 228 B, C; Gorg. 457 D. (See also Vahlen, l.c. for a discussion and defence of the text.)
to/te...h(ni/ka. The to/te goes with w)/n which is imperf. partic.: the ref. is to 177 D.
e)gw\ me\n ktl. The me/n here is answered by the de/ in to\ de\ a)/ra below. For a)belteri/a, cp. Theaet. 174 C, Phileb. 48 C (see my note ad loc.).

tou=to me\n u(pa/rxein. “That this (viz. the statement of the facts) should be the ground-work”: there is no need to insert, with Bast, prw=ton or me/giston after tou=to. For this sense of u(pa/rxein, cp. Menex. 237 B. For the thought, cp. Emerson “Veracity first of all and forever. Rien de beau que le vrai.”

e)c au)tw=n de\ tou/twn. Rettig's comment on this is “mit Beziehung auf das collective in tou=to gedachte ta)lhqh=.” This is misleading, since tou=to means
to\ ta)lhqh= le/gein, a singular notion, and au)ta\ tau=ta here represents simply ta)lhqh=. In the Socratic theory of rhetoric here stated we have the following order of treatment proposed: (1) to\ ta)lhqh= le/gein, (2) h( tw=n kalli/stwn e)klogh/, (3) h( eu)preph\s qe/sis. But it is implied that the 2nd and 3rd of these—artistic selection and arrangement—are valueless, except in so far as they are based on the 1st requisite: in other words, matter is more important than form. Cp. Procl. in Tim. p. 27 ai( ga\r a)po\ th=s ou)si/as eu)fhmi/ai pasw=n proe/xousen, w(s kai\ o( e)n tw=| *sumposi/w| *swkra/ths paradi/dwsin.

w(s ei)dw\s th
 a)lh/qeian. I follow Badham and Hug in bracketing the next words (tou= e)painei=n o(tiou=n) as an erroneous gloss on a)lh/qeian, with which we must supply peri\ tou= e)/rwtos, as required by deino\s ta\ e)rwtika/ above and the passage there alluded to (175 D). Cp. Phaedrus 259 E a)=r' ou)=n ou)x u(pa/rxein dei= toi=s eu)= ge kai\ kalw=s r(hqhsome/nois th
 tou= le/gontos dia/noian ei)dui=an to\ a)lhqe\s w(=n a)
 e)rei=n pe/ri me/llh|. Rettig defends the traditional text, asking “ist denn h( a)lh/qeia tou= e)painei=n o(tiou=n hier nicht identisch mit h( a)lh/qeia peri\ *)/erwtos?” To this the answer is “no!”: for if the tradition be kept we must take th
 a)lh/qeian as equivalent to th
 a)lhqh= (or rather o)rqh
) me/qodon, which is a very unlikely equation, especially so soon after ta)lhqh= in another sense: Stallb.'s rendering may serve to indicate the difficulty involved,—“utpote veram tenens laudationis cujuslibet naturam et rationem”: Jowett's “thinking I knew the nature of true praise” shirks the difficulty.
to\ de\ a)/ra. For to\ de\, “but in reality,” cp. Meno 97 C (with Thompson's note), Apol. 23 A (with Stallb.'s note).
ou) tou=to, i.e. ou) to\ ta)lhqh= le/gein.

to\...a)natiqe/nai. Perhaps an allusion to the term used by Agathon, a)nakei/sqw 197 E. For Socrates' criticism, cp. Phaedrus 272 A, Menex. 234 C oi(\ ou(/tw kalw=s e)painou=sin, w(/ste kai\ ta\ proso/nta kai\ ta\ mh\ peri\ e(ka/stou le/gontes, ka/llista/ pws toi=s o)no/masi poiki/llontes gohteu/ousin h(mw=n ta\s yuxa/s: Isocr. Busir. 222 B dei= tou\s me\n eu)logei=n tinas boulome/nois plei/w tw=n u(parxo/ntwn a)gaqw=n proso/nt' a)pofai/nein (which sentiment is, perhaps, referred to here).
prourrh/qh. Cp. 180 D. The reference is to 177 D.
e)gkwmia/zein do/cei. The emphasis is on do/cei, implying the regular Platonic antithesis do/ca )( a)lh/qeia. Cp. Simon. 76 to\ dokei=n kai\ ta\n a)la/qeian bia=tai (cited in Rep. 365 C).
pa/nta lo/gon kinou=ntes. “Raking up every tale.” Cp. Phileb. 15 E; Theaet. 163 A; Rep. 450 A.
o(/pws a)\n fai/nhtai. fai/nhtai here, as do/cei above, is emphatic. A comparison with 195 A shows that Socr. is alluding especially to Agathon's oration.
ou) ga/r dh/ pou ktl. Cp. Gorg. 459 A ou) ga\r dh/ pou e)/n ge toi=s ei)do/si tou= i)atrou= piqanw/teros e)/stai: and for ou) ga/r pou... 200 B, Euthyph. 13 A.

kai\ kalw=s g) ktl. Earlier editors generally print a full stop after ei)do/si. Socr. here sarcastically endorses the approval with which Agathon's e)/painos had been received (w(s prepo/ntws ei)rhko/tos ktl., 198 A).

h( glw=ssa ou)=n ktl. Euripides' line (h( glw=ss' o)mw/mox' , h( de\ frh\n a)nw/motos Hippol. 612) soon became a familiar quotation: see Ar. Thesm. 275, Ran. 101, 1471; Theaet. 154 D; Cic. de offic. III. 29. 108 iuravi lingua, mentem iniuratam gero.

xaire/tw dh/. “I say good-bye to it”: cp. Laws 636 D to\...tou= mu/qou xaire/tw: id. 886 D. Rettig suggests that here the formula may be intended as another echo of Euripides: cp. Med. 1044 ou)k a)\n dunai/mhn: xaire/tw bouleu/mata | ta\ pro/sqen: Hippol. 113.
ou) ga\r e)/ti ktl. “I withdraw my offer to eulogize.” e)gkwmia/zw must here be a “present for future” (see Madv. Gr. Synt. § 110. 3), since Socr. has not yet begun the eulogy.

kat' e)mauto/n, ou) pro\s ktl. “In my own fashion, not entering into competition with your orations.” For kata\ c. acc. in this sense, cp. Apol. 17 B ou) kata\ tou/tous ei)=nai r(h/twr (“not after their pattern”): Gorg. 505 D.
ge/lwta o)/flw. This resumes the notion in katage/lastos w)/n, 198 C.
w)= *fai=dre. Socrates, like Agathon (197 E), politely appeals to Ph. as the path\r lo/gou: cp. 194 D.
ei)/ ti ktl. For ei)/ ti, numquid, cp. Rep. 526 E skopei=sqai dei= ei)/ ti pro\s e)kei=no tei/nei ktl.

o)no/masi de\ ktl. See 198 B n. Of o(poi/a dh/ Ast cites no instance; the
force of dh/ is to heighten the notion of indefiniteness which lies in o(poi/a (so Hug).
e)/ti toi/nun ktl. e)/ti goes with e)re/sqai. Socrates appeals thus to Ph. because Ph. had previously (194 D, E) debarred him from catechizing A.
a)nomologhsa/menos ktl. Cf. 200 E, Gorg. 489 A. For ou(/tws h)/dh, cp. 194 D. For e)nqe/nde poqe\n, 178 A.

div1.head: Discussion between Socrates and Agathon
div1.p: kaqhgh/sasqai. The ref. is to A.'s exordium, 195 A.
i)/qi ou)=n. agedum; cp. Gorg. 452 D, Rep. 376 D.

tinos...h)\ ou)deno/s. These are objective genitives to be construed with the second e)/rws: “Is Love love for some object or for none?” For the use of the indef. in such phrases, cp. Phileb. 35 B o(/ g' e)piqumw=n tino\s e)piqumei=.

ou)k ei) mhtro/s tinos ktl. These words have been variously interpreted: (1) Lehrs and Prantl construe the genitives as subjective (“love felt by a mother”); (2) Ast as objective (“love for a mother”): (3) Rückert, followed by Hommel and Hug, takes them to be genn. of origin; so too Zeller renders “ich meine damit aber nicht, ob er eine Mutter oder einen Vater hat.” Of these, (1) seems the least probable in point of sense, and with subjective genitives tinos would be superfluous. It is a serious objection (as Hug admits) to (3) that it compels us to regard the “absurdity” (geloi=on) of the question as lying in its form rather than its substance. That the “absurdity” lies in the substance of the statement is shown, e.g., by Lysis 221 A h)\ geloi=on to\ e)rw/thma, o(/ ti/ pot) e)/stai to/te h)\ mh\ e)/stai; ti/s ga\r oi)=den; (cp. Phaedrus 274 C). But if so, recourse must be had to textual alteration: we must strike out either the second e)/rws, with Sommer, or the whole block of words ei) *)/erws... patro/s, as Hug (followed by Jowett) suggests. This, however, is a hazardous alternative. On the whole, then, the explanation (2) put forward by Ast seems the most probable. Construing, “I do not ask whether Eros has for its object a father or a mother, since to ask whether Eros is eros for a parent
were an absurd question,” the point will be taken to lie in the fact that e)/rws, as properly denoting sexual passion, cannot naturally have for its object a parent. The same interpretation might be kept if we struck out—as perhaps we ought—the words mhtro\s h)\ patro/s, and construed “the question would be absurd if (or granting that) Eros is (really) e)/rws (i.e. sex-love).”

au)to\ tou=to pate/ra h)rw/twn. Rettig approves Stallbaum's explanation, “h. e. pate/ra, au)to\ tou=to o(/per e)/stin ut mox loquitur. Vult autem cogitari de patris notione, qualem mente informatum habemus.” But the use of the neuter in apposition to the masc. is sufficient to indicate that “cogitari de patris notione”; and it is most natural to regard au)to\ tou=to as implying a reference to the previous use of “this very word, path/r.”
ei)=pes a)\n. “You would at once reply.” (See Goodwin G. M. T. § 414, Thompson on Meno 72 B.)
h( mh/thr w(sau/tws. Sc. e)sti\n ui(e/os ge h)\ qugatro\s mh/thr.
*ei) ga\r e)roi/mhn. For apodosis we may supply ti/ a)\n fai/hs; or the like: cp. 204 D, Prot. 311 E.
au)to\ tou=q' o(/per e)/stin. “Notionally,” “in its abstract significance.”

*tou=to me\n...o(/tou. Rettig, Rückert and Lehrs put a comma before memnhme/nos, rendering “hoc igitur apud animum serva (sc. alicujus esse) atque cujus sit, memento.” Hommel and Hug, on the other hand, follow Ast and Schleierm. in removing the comma, explaining o(/tou (sc. o( *)/erws e)/rws e)sti/n) as epexegetic of tou=to, and construing fu/lacon memnhme/nos closely together: thus Schleierm. renders “Dieses nun, habe Socrates gesagt, halte noch bei dir fast in Gedanken, wovon sie (er) Liebe ist.” On this latter view—which is certainly preferable—we must suppose Socrates to be alluding to the definition of the object of love (viz. ka/llos) previously given by Agathon (in 197 B), while debarring him from restating it at this point in the discussion.

e)piqumei= au)tou=. For au)tou= resuming e)kei/nou, cp. 195 A, Soph. O. T. 248. Observe that the entire argument here is based on the identification of e)/rws with e)piqumi/a (see 205 D): cp. the use of e)ra=n in Theogn. 256 prh=gma de\ terpno/taton, tou= tis e)ra=|, to\ tuxei=n. Cp., for the question here discussed, Lysis 221 D f.
a)nti\ tou= ei)ko/tos. Cp. Phaedrus 267 A, 269 D; see Blass, Att. Bereds. I. 78.

e)piqumei=n ou(= e)ndee/s e)stin. Cp. Lysis 221 D to/ ge e)piqumou=n, ou(= a)\n e)ndee\s h)=|, tou/tou e)piqumei=: Eryx. 405 E ai( d' e)piqumi/ai pa=sai ou)de\n e(/teron h)\ e)/ndeiai/ tinwn: Gorg. 496 D. A similar theory is implied in Phileb. 35 A o( kenou/menos... e)piqumei= tw=n e)nanti/wn h)\ pa/sxei: kenou/menos ga\r e)ra=| plhrou=sqai (which also illustrates the use of e)ra=n and e)piqumei=n as synonyms). Cp. also Isocr. Hel. 219 A (quoted below, on 200 C).
qaumastw=s...w(s. For w(s thus separated from its adverb, cp. Phaedo 95 A, 99 D, Theaet. 157 D. Thus Bast's suspicions as to the soundness of the text were unfounded.

*ei) ga\r kai\ ktl. In this sentence we have an ex. of anacoluthon: after the protasis the sentence is interrupted by a parenthesis (i)/sws...le/gw), then the protasis is resumed in an altered form (a)ll' o(/tan tis ktl.), which leads up finally to the apodosis in the form ei)/poimen a)\n au)tw=| ktl. The main purpose of the whole paragraph is to guard against a possible misunderstanding as to the nature of bou/lhsis and e)piqumi/a which might arise from carelessness in analyzing the sense of popular phraseology.
tau=ta oi)hqei/h . tau=ta and pa/nta ta\ toiau=ta are accusatives of “remoter object” with oi)hqei/h, “with regard to these and all similar cases.”

bou/lomai...kai\ e)piqumw=. The point here emphasized is that bou/lhsis and e)piqumi/a, when their sense is investigated, are found to apply only to the future (ei)s to
 e)/peita xro/non), not to the present (e)n tw=| paro/nti). For investigation shows that “I wish for what I have” is really an abbreviated phrase for “I wish to continue having in the future what I now at present have” (bou/lomai ta\ nu=n paro/nta parei=nai). For the force of bou/lhsis, cp. Isocr. Hel. 219 A tw=n me
 ga a)/llwn, w(=n a)
 e)n xrei/a| genw/meqa, tuxei=n mo/non boulo/meqa... tw=n de\ kalw=n e)/rws h(mi=n e)ggi/gnetai, tosou/tw| mei/zw tou= bou/lesqai r(w/mhn e)/xwn, o(/sw|per kai\ to\ pra=gma krei=tton e)sti/n (with which cp. also 205 D below).
a)/llo ti o(mologoi= a)/n; For the interrogative a)/llo ti, a)/llo ti h)/, see Meno 82 C (with Thompson's note); Prot. 353 C (with Adam's note).

*ou)kou=n tou=to/ g) e)sti\n ktl. The main construction is rightly explained by Stallb.: “to\ ei)s to\n e)/peita xr. ktl. relativo pronomini per epexegesin adduntur, nec assentior Rückerto interpunctionem post au)tw=| e)stin inferenti”: to\ is in the nominative, where we should rather expect tou= in apposition to e)kei/nou, owing to assimilation to o(/. For the reading of the last words in the sentence, see crit. n. Rettig reads mh\ paro/nta “in hypothetisch-causalem Sinne.” More attractive is Usener's excision of the words moi paro/nta, adopted by Hug. The objection to kai\, printed by Burnet, is that it fails to supply an explanation of B's moi: hence I prefer to read kai\ a)ei\, supposing that an abbreviated kai\ blending with a)ei\ might account for both variants.
*kai\ ou(=tos ktl. ou(=tos represents the typical tis and a)/nqrwpos of 200 C; and a)/llos pa=s serves to generalise, cp. 192 B.
e)/ndeia parh=|. This sounds like a jocular contradiction in terms: in Eros there is a plentiful lack.
e)/fhsqa e)n tw=| lo/gw|. See 197 B: cp. Isocr. Hel. 219 A tw=n de\ kalw=n e)/rws h(mi=n e)ggi/gnetai.

e)pieikw=s g' e)/leges. For e)pieikw=s, probe, recte, cp. Rep. 431 E, Laws 635 A. I have ventured to read e)/leges for the traditional le/geis. In the present context le/geis seems objectionable because of its ambiguity, since “You say well” would more naturally be taken to refer to A.'s reply (ei)=pon ga/r) than to his previous statement. This objection is not touched by Rettig's defence of the tense: “auch das Präsens ist ganz an seinem Platze. Da Agathon bestätigt, dass er sich so geäussert habe, wie Sokrates angebe, so gilt seine obige Aeusserung auch jetzt.”
ou(=...kai\ mh\ e)/xei. “Sic dictum est ut o(/ apud e)/xei repetendum est” (Stallb.).

to\ e)ndee\s ka/llous. With reference to this Proclus (in Tim. p. 128) comments: e)ndee\s ka/llous e)n sumposi/w| prosei=pe to\ mh\ prw/tws kalo\n a)lla\ mete/xon ka/llous: cp. ib. p. 110. For the tautologous form of expression, cp. 185 A n.; Eur. Ion 680 au)th\ d' a)/pais h)=| kai\ leleimme/nh te/knwn: id. Heracl. 530, etc. (see Vahlen op. Acad. II. 366).
*kinduneu/w...ei)=pon . ei)de/nai is past, not present, in sense.

*kai\ mh\n...ei)=pes. Not “recte dixisti” (Ficinus), but “praeclare dixisti”
(Wolf). What Socr. alludes to is not A.'s foregoing reply, but his oration (cp. 198 B, 199 C); and the point of his remark is to suggest that formal beauty of diction does not necessarily involve the more essential beauty of a)lh/qeia.

ta\ de\ a)gaqa\ kala/. For the coincidence of these two concepts, cp. Prot. 360 B, Hipp. Maj. 297 B, C, Phileb. 64 E ff. It might be near the truth to say that to\ kalo/n is neither less nor more than to\ a)gaqo\n in its external aspect, “goodness” as apprehended by the aesthetic faculty, or goodness qua attractive and soul-stirring. See also Plotin. de pulcr. p. 46; Procl. in I Alc. p. 329.

*)egw/...soi\...su\. The personal pronouns are, by position and repetition, emphatic. Agathon means to imply that he yields not so much to the force of argument as to the wordplay of Socrates' invincible dialectic: cp. 216 B below: Xen. Symp. V. 8.

div1.head: Speech of Socrates
div1.p: *kai\ se\...e)a/sw. “You I will now release”: this is said with reference to the phrase used in 199 B e)/ti...pa/res moi *)aga/qwna ktl.

*mantinikh=s *dioti/mas. Probably both these names are meant to be etymologically significant: the resemblance of the adj. to mantikh\ is patent (in fact some MSS. give mantikh=s, and Ficin. fatidica muliere), while as illustrating the omen of *dioti/ma one might cite Soph. fr. 226 N. sofo\s ga ou)dei\s plh
 o(
 a)
 tima=| qeo/s. See further Introd. § IV. C. Hug quotes an imitative passage from Dio. Chrys. I. p. 59 R. mu=qon...o(
 e)gw/ pote h)/kousa gunaiko\s *)hlei/as h)\ *)arkadi/as u(pe *(hrakle/ous dihgoume/nhs. See also Max. Tyr. diss. XXIV. 4, p. 588; Clem. Al. Strom. VI. p. 631 B.

pro\ tou= loimou= ktl. For the Great Plague at Athens in 430 B.C. see Thuc. II. 47, Bury H. G. p. 407. That the plague had been rife elsewhere for some time previously is implied by Thuc. l. c. For similar instances of the averting or postponing of impending evils by divine or prophetic agency, see Hdt. I. 91 tri/a ga e)/tea e)paneba/leto (sc. o( *loci/hs) th
 *sardi/wn a(/lwsin:
Athen. XIII. 602 B: Euseb. praep. evang. V. 35, p. 233 B, C: cp. Virg. Aen. VII. 313 ff., VIII. 398 ff. (where “decem annos” is the interval named). A specially interesting parallel, as mentioning the same 10 years' interval, is Laws 642 D a)kh/koas w(s *)epimeni/dhs ge/gonen a)nh qei=os...e)lqw
 de\ pro\ tw=n *persikw=n de/ka e)/tesi pro/teron par' u(ma=s...qusi/as te e)qu/sato tinas...kai\ dh\ kai\ foboume/nwn to
 *persiko
 *)aqhnai/wn sto/lon ei)=pen o(/ti de/ka me
 e)tw=n ou)x h(/cousin ktl.

au)to\s e)p' e)mautou=. Rückert alone retains the lection a)p' e)mautou=. Cp. I Alc. 114 B ei) me\n bou/lei, e)rwtw=n me, w(/sper e)gw\ se/, ei) de\ kai\ au)to\s e)pi\ sautou= lo/gw| die/celqe: Soph. 217 C.

w(/sper su\ dihgh/sw. I think the traditional text, supported also by the Papyrus, may stand, taking dihgh/sw to imply—with veiled contempt—a lengthy or meticulous disquisition. Schanz's dh\ h(gh/sw is open to a double objection, (1) the repeated dh\ is unpleasing, and (2) h(gh/sw is a feeble word to apply to Agathon's dogmatic exposition (in 195 A) of the rules of method. Sauppe's u(fhgh/sw is appropriate enough (cp. Gorg. 455 D, Crat. 392 D), but does not explain the corruption.

dielqei=n au)to\n ktl. Here Socrates cites almost verbatim the language used by Agathon in 195 A lo/gw| dielqei=n...do/seis. Observe however the significant addition by Socr. of the words ti/s e)stin: he requires a statement of the essential notion (ti/s e)sti) as well as of the attributes (poi=o/s tis).

ei)/h de\ tw=n kalw=n. The genitive is not masc. nor one of origin (=e)k tw=n kalw=n) as Wolf thought, but as Stallb. rightly notes “kalw=n pendet ex *)/erws, quod etiam hic positum est ut p. 196 D”: cp. 201 A, 204 D, for similar genn. of the object.

ai)sxro\s a)/ra ktl. Socrates represents himself (ironically) as unversed in the rules of logic, and habitually confusing contradictory with contrary notions (ou)-kalo/s with ai)sxro/s): for the distinction, cp. Soph. 257 B, 257 D ff.; Euthyd. 283 B, 285 A ff., Crat. 429 B ff.
*)=h kai\ a)\n mh\ ktl. “H. e. a)/n ti mh\ sofo/n. Nam ti e superiore o(/ ti facile intelligas” (Stallb.).

*to\ o)rqa\ doca/zein ktl. This distinction between do/ca and e)pisth/mh is much insisted on by Plato; see esp. Rep. 477 ff.; Meno 99 A: cp. Isocr. Hel. 209 A. For to\ e)/xein lo/gon dou=nai as the distinctive mark of e)pisth/mh, cp. Meno 98 A; but this definition is criticised unfavourably in Theaet. 201 C ff. (see Zeller, Plato, pp. 171 ff.). I bracket kai\ before a)/neu: if retained, we must render with Rückert (and Hug) “auch ohne Rechenschaft geben zu können.” For this “intensive” use of kai/, see Thompson on Meno 71 B. Rettig defends the Bodleian o)rqodoca/zein thus “o)rqa\ doca/zein ginge auf Einzelnes und Thatsächliches, nicht auf den Begriff als solchen und die geistige Eigenschaft”: but this distinction is imaginary, and there is no other evidence, in Plato or elsewhere, for the existence of this compound, Aristotle's word (E. N. VII. 8. 4) being o)rqodoce/w. Possibly we should write kai\ <o)/nta> a)/., cp. Rep. 413 A.
metacu\ fron<*>sews ktl. Cp. Rep. 477 A metacu/ ti...a)gnoi/as te kai\ e)pisth/mhs: ib. 478 D.

*mh\ toi/nun a)na/gkaze. “I. q. mh\ a)nagkai=on no/mize, v. Heindorf ad Euthyd. (sic) p. 432 C” (Stallb.). For this use to denote logical compulsion, cp. also Crat. 432 E mh\ a)na/gkaze pa/nt' e)/xein ta\ gra/mmata...a)ll' e)/a ktl.: Parmen. 133 C.
*tw=n mh\ ei)do/twn. Sc. para\: cp. Crat. 408 D, Soph. 243 D, etc. A similar distinction had been drawn twice by Socr. himself, see 194 B ff., 199 A.

ka)gw\ ei)=pon...e)/fhn. We might avoid this tautology (for which cp. 177 A) by reading ka)gw/, *ei)=pon pw=s ktl., construing ei)=pon as 1st aor. imper., as in Meno 71 D. Cp. Rep. 338 D a)lla\ safe/steron ei)pe\ ti/ le/geis.

*(ra|di/ws. Sc. tou=to le/gw. For the use of r(a|di/ws with le/gw and the like, often with a bad meaning, of ill-timed lightness, cp. Meno 94 E (with Thompson's note), Rep. 377 B, 378 A. Here, however, the meaning is probably r(a/|dio/n e)stin o(\ le/gw (so Rettig), or as Stallb. “sic ut res facilem habet explicationem”: cp. Rep. 475 E a)lla\ pw=s au)to\ le/geis; *ou)damw=s, h)=n d) e)gw/, r(a|di/ws pro/s ge a)/llon: se\ de\ oi)=mai ktl. It would also be possible to suppose that Diotima is, playfully, adapting her reply to the form rather than the sense of Socr.'s question: “In what way do you speak thus?” “I speak it lightly” (without compunction): i.e. the le/gw to be supplied with r(a|di/ws may mean “I say, utter the word,” whereas the le/geis of Socr. meant “do you mean.”

eu)dai/monas ei)=nai ktl. Badham's excision of both kai\ kalou/s and kalo/n te kai\ is plausible: if the words are sound, we must assume the stress in each clause to be laid on the terms here in question, eu)dai/monas...eu)dai/mona.
*eu)dai/monas de\ dh\ ktl. Cp. the phrases used by Agathon in 195 A.

*(wmolo/ghka ga/r. Socr. represents himself as having already conceded to Diotima exactly as much as Agathon had conceded to him (cp. 201 E sxedo\n ga/r ti ktl.): for A.'s concession of the point here in question, see 200 A, E.
a)/moiros. This word had already been employed by Agathon, 197 D (cp. 181 C); it is a poetical word rarely used by Plato elsewhere, except in Laws (693 E, etc.).
*(/wsper ta\ pro/tera. Viz. the exx. of a mean between extremes given in 202 A, B.

*dai/mwn me/gas. The epithet serves to point the correction of Socrates' definition, me/gas qeo/s (202 B). Cp. Olympiod. in Alcib. I. p. 22 “dai/mona” de\ w(s me/son au)to\n prosagoreu/ei: me/sos ga/r e)stin o( *)/erws ou)si/as kai\ e)nergei/as kai\ e)rwme/nou kai\ e)rastou=: “me/gan” de/, e)peidh\ u(pe\r ai)/sqhsin kai\ noerw=s e)nergei=. Procl. in Alcib. I. p. 64 Cr., p. 66. For to\ daimo/nion as metacu/, cp. Eur. Troad. 55—6: Med. 1391: Hel. 1137 o(/ ti qeo\s h)\ mh\ qeo\s h)\ to\ me/son ktl. (see Rohde, Psyche II. 249 n. 1).

*(ermhneu=on ktl. For the term e(rmhneu/ein to describe the mediating office of dai/mones, cp. Epin. 985 B e(rmhneu/esqai (dai/monas) pro\s a)llh/lous te kai\ tou\s...qeou\s pa/ntas te kai\ pa/nta. Hommel bids us take e(rmhneu=on with a)nqr. ta\ para\ qew=n (as “eiusdem atque *(ermh=s radicis”) and diaporqmeu=on with qeoi=s ta\ par' a)nqrw/pwn (the office of the porqmeu/s, Charon, being “animas e terra ad sedes deorum transvehere”). This is probably right; but in any case it is a mistake to regard the two words as synonymous, as do L. and S. (s. v. diaporqmeu/w, “to translate from one tongue into another, to interpret”).

a)moiba\s [tw=n qusiw=n]. a)moibh/ as a “return-present” (in transactions between gods and men) is used in Hom. Od. I. 318 soi\ d' a)/cion e)/stai a)moibh=s (sc. to\ dw=ron): ib. III. 58 a)/lloisi di/dou xari/essan a)moibh
...a)gakleith=s e(kato/mbhs: cp. Eur. Or. 467 oi(=s...a)pe/dwk' a)moiba\s ou) kala/s. Pollux (VI. 187) when quoting our passage ignores tw=n qusiw=n. Cp. also Procl. in Alcib. I. p. 46, 63: Plut. de Is. et Os. 26, p. 361 B o(/ te *pla/twn e(rmhneutiko
 to\ toiou=ton o)noma/zei ge/nos kai\ diakoniko
 e)n me/sw| qew=n kai\ a)nqrw/pwn, eu)xa\s me
 e)kei= kai\ deh/seis...a)nape/mpontas, e)kei=qen de\ mantei=a deu=ro kai\ do/seis a)gaqw=n fe/rontas: Apuleius de deo Socr. 6 hos Graeci nomine dai/monas nuncupant, inter homines caelicolasque vectores hinc precum inde donorum, qui ultro citro portant hinc petitiones inde suppetias, ceu quidam utrisque interpretes et salutigeri. per hos eosdem, ut Plato in symposio autumat, cuncta denuntiata et magorum varia miracula omnesque praesagiorum species reguntur: see also Plut. de or. def. 415 A; Philo Jud. de somn. p. 586 D (dai/mones) ta\s tou= patro\s e)pikeleu/seis toi=s e)kgo/nois, kai\ ta\s tw=n e)kgo/nwn xrei/as tw=| patri\ diagge/llousi.

e)n me/sw| de\ o)\n. This calls for no alteration (such as is suggested by
Vermehren): with sumplhroi= sc. a)mfote/rous. The me/son serves as the desmo/s by which the extremes (here qnhtoi/ and a)qa/natoi) are united into an organic whole (o(/lon). Cp. Procl. in Alc. I. pp. 69, 72, 77.

ta\s teleta\s. “Ritual”: cp. Rep. 365 A lu/seis te kai\ kaqarmoi\ a)dikhma/twn...a(\s dh\ teleta\s kalou=sin: Phaedrus 244 E (with Thompson's note): Laws 738 C qusi/as teletai=s summi/ktous. That kaqarmoi/ (and teletai/) included periqeiw/seis, loutra/, perirra/nseis appears from Crat. 405 A. Rohde (Psyche II. 70 n. 3) points out that “diese ma/nteis entsprechen in allem Wesentlichen den Zaubern und Medicinmännern der Naturvölker. Wahrsager, Arzt, Zauberer, sind hier noch eine Person.” E.g. Apis in Aesch. Suppl. 260 ff.; cp. Eur. Heracl. 401, Phoen. 1255 ff., and the part played by Empedocles. In Hippocr. de morb. sacr. p. 591 the ma/nteis and kaqartai/ are witch-doctors, claiming control of the elements, as rain-makers, etc. (kaqarmou\s prosfe/rontes kai\ e)paoida\s... perikaqai/rwn kai\ mageu/wn...te kai\ qu/wn selh/nhn te kaqairh/sei kai\ h(/lion a)faniei= kai\ xeimw=na kai\ eu)di/hn poih/sei ktl.): cp. 197 C n.

th
 magganei/an pa=san. Geel's correction magganei/an is perhaps slightly preferable, on the ground of Platonic usage, to Badham's magei/an. Cp. Laws 908 D e)c w(=n ma/nteis te kataskeua/zontai polloi\ kai\ peri\ pa=san th
 magganei/an kekinhme/noi: id. 933 A a)/llh de\ (farmakei=a) h(\ magganei/ais te/ tisi kai\ e)pw|dai=s kai\ katade/sesi legome/nais pei/qei ktl. (cp. 933 C): Gorg. 484 A ta\ h(me/tera gra/mmata kai\ magganeu/mata kai\ e)pw|da/s: also [Dem.] XXV. 79 labw
 ta\ fa/rmaka kai\ ta\s e)pw/|das...magganeu/ei kai\ fenaki/zei. Hug objects to gohtei/an, as elsewhere used by Plato in a bad sense. There is, however, no need to suppose that any of these terms are intended here to convey more than a neutral sense; and to represent h( *mantinikh/ as a disbeliever in any of the arts of divination or wizardry would be less artistic than pedantic. Moreover, the language used here is supported by the echo it finds in the description of Eros below (203 D ad fin.) as deino\s go/hs kai\ farmakeu\s kai\ sofisth/s. Rep. 364 B, C shows Plato's own low opinion of current mantikh/, but Socrates was probably more credulous, see Xen. Mem. I. 1. 9, 4. 15.

qeoi=s pro\s a)nqrw/pous ktl. Since the participles can neither be construed with qeoi=s, because of the sense, nor with a)nqrw/pous, because of the case, it is necessary to supply some such supplement as that adopted in the text. Rettig accepts Stallbaum's explanation of the traditional text: “Quum enim
dicatur o(milei=n tini et diale/gesqai/ tini, etiam o(mili/a kai\ dia/lektos tini recte dici potuit. Et quum antea...perspicuitatis caussa usus esset praepositione pro\s addito casu accusativo, nunc ad legitimam constructionem revertens, neglecta grammatica diligentia, dativum post accusativum recte inferri potuit.” But at this rate one might justify anything in the way of distorted grammar! Hug marks a lacuna after a)nqrw/pous. For the ref. to divine communications in sleep (“the visions of the head upon the bed”), cp. Pind. fr. 131. 3 ff.; Rep. 571 D ff. (with Adam's notes); Rohde, Psyche I. 6 ff.
daimo/nios a)nh/r. Compare the etymological definition (dai/mwn=dah/mwn) in Crat. 398 C. For Socrates as an example of the daimo/nios a)nh/r, see 219 B.

peri\ te/xnas...ba/nausos. Cp. Theaet. 176 C, Laws 644 A; Arist. Rhet. I. 9. 1367^{a} 31 (e)leuqe/rou shmei=on) to\ mhdemi/an e)rga/zesqai ba/nauson te/xnhn. The question as to why manual labour is held in contempt is asked in Rep. 590 C, and answered in Rep. 495 D (see Adam's notes ad loc.).

oi( dai/mones. Other Platonic passages mentioning these intermediary beings are Rep. 392 A, 427 B, 617 D (with Adam's note), Laws 713 D, 717 B. For later developments see esp. Plutarch (de defect. orac., de Is. et Os., de daem. Socr., etc.). Cp. Rohde, Psyche I. 153.
*patro\s de/...ti/nos ktl. These are genitives of origin. Here we have it tacitly assumed that Phaedrus's statement (178 B), that Eros is unbegotten, is untrue.

*po/ros. We find in Alcman fr. 16 (with the Schol. o(/ti to
 *po/ron ei)/rhke to
 au)to
 tw=| u(po\ tou= *(hsio/dou memuqeume/nw| *xa/ei) a precedent for this personification of *po/ros. *peni/a is personified by Aristophanes in the Plutus, passim. For *mh=tis, see Hes. Theog. 886 *zeu\s de\ qew=n basileu\s prw/thn a)/loxon qe/to *mh=tin, | plei=sta qew=n te i)dui=an i)de\ qnhtw=n a)nqrw/pwn: (mh=tis is, in Epic, the especial attribute of Zeus, as mhtie/ta): *mh=tis was also an Orphic alias of
Eros. For nectar as the primeval substitute for wine, cp. Hom. Il. V. 341, etc., also Phaedrus 247 E tou\s i(/ppous...ne/ktar e)po/tise. The celestial dei=pnon was, it appears, followed by a sumpo/sion. Spenser, H. to Love, speaks of the god as “Begot of Plentie and of Penury.” See further Introd. § IV. C 2.

ei)s to\n tou= *dio\s kh=pon. Cp. Soph. fr. (Ion) 297 N. e)n *dio\s kh/pois a)rou=sqai mo/non eu)dai/monas o)/lbous. It is interesting to notice that Origen (Contra Cels. IV. 39) identifies the “garden of Zeus” with Paradise, Poros with Adam, Penia with the Serpent. With the intoxication and its results we might compare the O. T. stories of Noah and his sons and of Lot and his daughters. For the neo-Platonic interpretation of the myth, see Plotinus Enn. III. 5. 2, 292 F ff., 298 F: cp. also Introd. § IV. C 2. A similar Orphic legend is mentioned by Porphyry de antr. nymph. 16 (Orphica p. 180) para\ de\ tw=| *)orfei= o( *kro/nos me/liti u(po\ *dio\s e)nedreu/etai: plhsqei\s ga\r me/litos mequ/ei kai\ skotou=tai w(s u(po\ oi)/nou kai\ u(pnoi=, w(s para\ *pla/twni o( *po/ros tou= ne/ktaros plhsqei/s, ou)/pw ga\r oi)=nos h)=n. Another classical example is the trick played by Lady Macbeth on Duncan's “spongy officers” (“his two chamberlains Will I with wine and wassail so convince” etc.).
bebarhme/nos. A later form for the Epic bebarhw/s (Od. III. 139): cp. Theocr. XVII. 61 bebarhme/na w)di/nessin.

paidi/on poih/sasqai e)k ktl. So Andoc. IV. 22 ui(o\n e)c au)th=s pepoi/htai: and pai=das poiei=sqai in Crito 45 D, Laws 674 B, 783 D, as equiv. to the cpd. paidopoiei=sqai (Rep. 449 D, Laws 784 A, B, E). These parallels are sufficient to defend the text (see crit. n.), without resorting to Rettig's absurd notion that paidi/on p. is “verecundior” than the cpd.

th=s *)afrodi/ths...qera/pwn. Cp. Orph. fr. 139 th
 ga *)afrodi/thn parh/gagen o( dhmiourgo\s...kai\ to
 *)/erwta o)pado
 au)th=s: Sappho fr. 74 (le/gei h( *)afrodi/th) su/ te kalo\s (ka)mo\s Bgk.) qera/pwn *)/eros: Hes. Theog. 201 th=| d) (sc. *)afrodi/th|) *)/eros w(ma/rthse kai\ *(/imeros e(/speto kalo\s | geinome/nh| taprw=ta ktl.: Max. Tyr. diss. XXIV. p. 297.
e)rasth\s w)\n peri\ to\ kalo/n. Cp. 204 B, 206 E. For the thought, cp. Sir T. Browne (Rel. Med.) “I am naturally amorous of all that is beautiful.”
prw=ton me\n ktl. Here follows a list of the properties which attach to Eros in virtue of his descent from Penia. Observe that the order is chiastic— here Penia-Poros, above Poros-Penia.

oi(=on oi( polloi\ oi)/ontai. This popular opinion had been esp. voiced by Agathon, 195 C ff.; and he had used the term sklhro/s in 195 E, 196 A. The properties of Eros are, as observed by Max. Tyr. diss. XXIV. 4. p. 461, a)texnw=s oi(=a ei)s au)to\n *swkra/thn e)/skwpton e)n *dionusi/ois oi( kwmw|doi/: cp. Themist. or. 13. p. 161 D ff.

au)xmhro\s. This is evidently intended as the contrary of Agathon's epithet u(gro/s, 196 A. Cp. Ar. Plut. 80 ff. (*plou=tos) a)qli/ws diakei/menos...au)xmw=n badi/zeis; and the echoes in Plut. de fort. p. 98 D, in amat. 759 A.

a)nupo/dhtos...a)/strwtos. These, too, are characteristics of the Socratic (and Cynic) way of life. For a)nupo/dhtos, see 173 B, 220 B; for xamaipeth\s kai\ a)/strwtos the account given by Alcibiades in 220 B, C. Compare also the description of the *selloi/ (“fakirs”) in Il. XVI. 234 ff. *selloi/, a)nipto/podes, xamaieu=nai ktl. (see Welcker Kl. Schr. 3. 90 f.; Rohde, Psyche I. 122).

e)pi\ qu/rais ktl. For the qurauli/ai of e)rastai/, see 183 A, Anthol. V. 5; and for this phrase as applicable to Socrates, 175 A, 220 C, Ar. Nub. 169 ff. So too Penia was described in 203 B as (ou)=sa) peri\ ta\s qu/ras. u(pai/qrios and su/noikos are words of a poetical flavour: cp. Xen. Symp. VIII. 24 o( a)ei\ su/noikos e)moi\ e)/rws.

i)/ths. “Energetic” (“go-ahead”): Schol. i)/ths: i)/stwr, e)pisth/mwn, w(s e)ntau=qa. lamba/netai de\ kai\ e)pi\ tou= i)tamou= kai\ qrase/os. The Scholiast's w(s e)ntau=qa is clearly wrong, and that Plato connected the word with i)e/nai is shown by Protag. 349 E po/teron tou\s a)ndrei/ous qarrale/ous le/geis h)\ a)/llo ti; kai\ i)/tas g), e)/fh, e)f) a(\ oi( polloi\ fobou=ntai i)e/nai. Cp. Prot. 359 C: Callinus I. 9—10 a)lla/ tis i)qu\s i)/tw | e)/gxos a)nasxo/menos ktl. Here, however, the special sense of intellectual progress (me/qodos, a)/nodos) may be implied, cp. 210 *l (meti/h|, i)o/nta, i)e/nai), and my note on a)ndrei/an 212 B (also 205 D).

qhreuth\s deino/s. “A mighty hunter,” a very Nimrod. For the notion of the chase in erotics, cp. the use of e(lei=n and diw/kein in 182 E, etc., and of qh/ra in Soph. 222 D th=| tw=n e)rw/ntwn qh/ra| (cp. qhrw=mai in Isocr. Hel. 219 D): for the same notion applied to philosophical enquiry, cp. Phaedo 66 C th\n tou= o)/ntos qh/ran: Gorg. 500 D, Theaet. 198 A ff. So Emerson (On Beauty), “The sharpestsighted hunter in the world is Love, for finding what he seeks and only that.”

ple/kwn mhxana/s. “Weaving plots,” “intriguing”: cp. Eur. Androm. 66 poi/as mhxana\s ple/kousin au)=; Orph. H. 55. 3 (*)afrodi/th) doloplo/ke: Aelian H. A. III. 30 sofw/tatos o( ko/kkuc, kai\ ple/kein eu)po/rous e)c a)po/rwn mhxana\s deino/tatos.
po/rimos. As son of *po/ros. Agathon, too, had described Eros as (pra|o/thta) pori/zwn, 197 D.

deino\s go/hs ktl. For go/hs, see 203 A n.; and for Socrates as wizard or charmer, 215 C ff., Meno 80 A ff., Xen. Mem. III. 11. 17—18. For sofisth/s, cp. 177 B, 208 C; Rep. 596 D; Xen. Cyrop. VI. 1. 41 nu=n tou=to pefiloso/fhka meta\ tou= a)di/kou sofistou= tou= *)/erwtos: Maxim. Tyr. XXIV. 9 (=Sappho fr. 125) to
 *)/erwta *swkra/ths sofisth
 le/gei, *sapfw\ muqoplo/kon. The esoteric meaning of these epithets is thus explained by Hermias in Plat. Phaedr. p. 97: (ei)=pe to
 *)/erwta) filo/sofon me
 w(s to\ logiko
 h(mw=n diegei/ronta e)pi\ ta\ kala/: go/hta de\ w(s to
 qumo
 kataste/llonta: farmake/a <de\> w(s to\ e)piqumhtiko
 khlou=nta: sofisth
 de\ w(s th
 fu/sin a)patw=nta kai\ delea/zonta—this however must be taken “with a grain of salt.” Cp. also Procl. in Cratyl. p. 94, 158 o(/ti oi)=den o( *pla/twn to\ o)/noma to
 sofisth
 e)pi\ semnw=| ta/ttein pra/gmati: to
 ga pro\s e(auto
 ta\ a)/lla duna/menon e)pistre/fein ou(/tws kalei=, oi(=on to
 *di/a (Min. 319 C), to
 *(/aidhn (Crat. 403 E), to
 *)/erwta.

qa/llei. Cp. Crat. 414 A au)to/ ge to\ qa/llein th\n au)/chn moi dokei= a)peika/zein th\n tw=n ne/wn. For the alternation of life and death in Eros, compare the case of Polydeuces in Pind. Nem. X. 87 ff.
o(/tan eu)porh/sh|. These words are condemned, on no sufficient grounds, by Hug and others as “sehr prosaische und abschwächend.”

a)ei\ u(pekrei=. “Die geistigen Güter werden uns zu Theil nur insofern wir sie erwerben” (Rettig). The cpd. u(pekrei=n is a(/p. leg. in Plato, but cp. Euthyd. 291 B ai( d) (e)pisth=mai) a)ei\ u(pece/fugon.

ou)/te a)porei=...ou)/te ploutei= . a)pori/a is a quality of the mother of Eros (dia\ th\n au)th=s a)pori/an 203 B), as plou=tos of the father. On the other hand peni/a is described as a mean between plou=tos and ptwxei/a in Ar. Plut. 552.

e)/sti ga/r. Sc. sofo/s: cp. Simon. 5. 10 qeo\s a)\n mo/nos tou=t' e)/xoi ge/ras (sc. e)sqlo\n e)/mmenai). For the midway position of the filo/sofos, cp. Phaedrus 278 D, Lysis 218 A; Plotin. Enn. VI. 7. 35 ff.

au)to\ ga\r tou=to/ ktl. “Precisely herein is ignorance a grievous thing, (viz.) that” etc. If, with Stallb., we take au)to\ tou=to as adverbial accus. of respect, with to\ mh\...i(kano/n as an epexegetic supplement, no emendation is required. For the neuter xalepo\n in appos. to a)maqi/a, cp. 176 D, Phileb. 12 C.

*dh=lon dh/...kai\ paidi/. Cp. Euthyd. 279 D tou=to de\ ka)\n pai=s gnoi/h: ib. 301 B, Lysis 205 C (Schanz nov. comm. p. 72). Observe how sharply Diotima snubs Socrates, w(/sper oi( te/leoi sofistai/ (208 C). For my cj. w(=n ei(=s, cp. 203 A.

filo/sofon ei)=nai. Cp. Procl. in Tim. 52 du/o tou/tous qeou\s o( *pla/twn filoso/fous e)ka/lese, to/n te *)/erwta kai\ th
 *)aqhna=n (Tim. 24 D),...h)=n ga o( dhmiourgo\s “kai\ *mh=tis prw=tos gene/twr kai\ *)/erws poluterph/s” (Orph. Theog. fr. 8. 11), kai\ w(s me
 *mh=tis ti/ktei th
 *)aqhna=n, w(s de\ *)/erws a)pogenna=| th
 e)rwtikh
 seira/n.
a(bro\n. Agathon (here alluded to) had used the subst. a(bro/ths (197 D), besides the epithets a(palo/s and u(gro/s (195 C ff.).
makaristo/n. The only other Platonic exx. are Rep. 465 D, Phaedrus 256 C. Cp. the use of makari/zw in 216 E infra.
ti/na xrei/an ktl. Here begins the second section of Socrates-Diotima's exposition. For xrei/a, “utility,”—equiv. here to the do/seis of 195 A, the e)/rga of 199 C—cp. Gorg. 480 A, etc.
*tou=to dh\ meta\ tau=t) ktl. “Ebenso 180 D, 186 A, 189 D, 194 E. Also wohl parodisch und spöttisch” (Rettig).

e)/sti de\ tw=n kalw=n. This is object. genitive: cp. 201 E, 206 E. As Rettig notes, Diotima herself affects peri\ to\ kalo/n in preference to tou= kalou= (after e)/rws, etc.); and this may be used as an argument against Jahn-Usener's su/mfh|s.
ei) de/ tis ktl. For the omission of the apodosis, cp. 199 E ei) ga\r e)roi/mhn ktl.

safe/steron e)rw=. The preceding query had been ambiguously worded, since tw=n kalw=n might be taken either as a partitive gen. dependent on ti/, or as an object. gen. with *)/erws (ti/ being adverbial accus.): that the latter was the construction intended is now shown by the revised statement of the query— o( e)rw=n...ti/ e)ra=|; I am inclined to suspect that we should read o(/ra (see 204 E n.) for e)rw= (e)ra=| MSS.).

e)/ti poqei=. If we read e)pipoqei= we must ascribe to the proposition its full force, “craves further”; the other exx. of the cpd. in Plato are Prot. 329 D tou=t' e)sti\n o(\ e)/ti e)pipoqw=: Laws 855 E. The former of these supports Rückert's e)/ti e)pipoqei=.
*ou) pa/nu...e)/ti. For ou) pa/nu, cp. Meno 71 C (with Thompson's note).
metabalw\n. Here the participle “adverbii partes agit,” cp. Gorg. 480 E, Phileb. 51 A. For the ellipse, cp. 204 D, 199 E.

fe/re, w)= *s., ora. Most editors bracket the MSS.' e)ra=|: Stallb., after
Winckelmann, retains it with the punctuation e)ra=| o( e)rw=n tw=n a)gaqw=n: ti/ e)ra=|;—a mode of expression which is “vehementius quam ut aptum videri possit huic loco” (Rettig). Rückert defends the Aldine reading e)rw= as a permissible superfluity “in familiari sermone.” I suspect that here, as above, we should read o(/ra: cp. o(/ra ti/ poiei=s 189 A; Rep. 596 C; Crat. 385 D fe/re...ei)pe/.
i(/na ti/. Sc. ge/nhtai: for this colloquial use see Goodwin G. M. T. § 331.

te/los...e)/xein. Because it is recognized that eu)daimoni/a constitutes in itself the ethical te/los or “summum bonum”: cp. Clit. 410E e)mpo/dion tou= pro\s te/los a)reth=s e)lqo/nta eu)dai/mona gene/sqai : Arist. E. N. I. 7. 1097^{a} 33 a(plw=s dh\ te/leion to\ kaq' au(to\ ai(reto\n a)ei\...toiou=ton d' h( eu)daimoni/a ma/list' ei)=nai dokei=. Cp. also 210 E pro\s te/los h)/dh i)w/n ktl.
pa/ntas...a)ei/. Here a)ei/ goes with bou/lesqai, not with au(toi=s ei)=nai (as in 206 A below).

*ti/ dh\ ou)=n ktl. Diotima here points out an apparent contradiction between the previous conclusion (koino\n pa/ntwn) and common opinion, due to the ambiguity of the term e)/rws (e)ra=n) which is used both in a generic and in a specific sense.
*(/wsper ti/; “For example—?”

poi/hsi/s. The selection of this term as an ex. of varying connotation is partly, no doubt, due to the fact that it was one of the matters specially emphasized by Agathon, 197 A. For polu/, multiplex, cp. Polit. 282 A.

h( ga/r toi ktl. For the definition, cp. Soph. 219 B, 265 B poihtikh\n...pa=san e)/famen ei)=nai du/namin, h(/ tis a)\n ai)ti/a gi/gnhtai toi=s mh\ pro/teron ou)=sin u(/steron gi/gnesqai: also Phileb. 26 D; Xen. Mem. II. 2. 3; Procl. inst. theol. p. 74.

ai(...e)rgasi/ai. Cp. Gorg. 450 C tw=n me\n (texnw=n) e)rgasi/a to\ polu/ e)sti. The word denotes manufacturing processes: cp. n. on peri\ te/xnas ktl., 203 A. For u(po\ c. dat., a construction rare in Attic prose, cp. Phileb. 58 A: Hipp. Maj. 295 D ta/ te u(po\ th=| mousikh=| kai\ ta\ u(po\ tai=s a)/llais te/xnais (o)/rgana): Rep. 511 A. Cp. Aristotle's use of u(po\ c. acc. to denote the subordination of arts, E. N. I. 1. 1094^{a} 10 ff. o(/sai d' ei)si\ tw=n toiou/twn u(po\ mi/an tina\ du/namin ktl.

e(\n mo/rion. Equivalent to e(\n ei)=dos (205 B): for this logical use of the term cp. Gorg. 464 B, Laws 696 B. For a)fori/zw, cp. Soph. 257 C, 268 D th=s poih/sews a)fwrisme/non e)n lo/gois...mo/rion.
to\ peri\...ta\ me/tra. Cp. 187 D, 196 E.

to\ me\n kefa/laio/n ktl. Opinions are divided as to the construction of to\ kefa/laion: it may be construed (1) as nominative and subject, “the generic concept (sc. tou= e)/rwtos) is—”; so Hommel, Vermehren, Hug, Prantl, comparing Gorg. 463 A kalw= de\ au)tou= (sc. th=s r(htorikh=s) to\ kefa/laion kolakei/an: or (2) as adverbial accus. (of respect), “in its generic aspect,” cp. Phileb. 48 C e)/sti dh\ ponhri/a me/n tis to\ kefa/laion: Euthyphr. 8 E. The latter is certainly the more natural mode of construing here, since no genitive (au)tou=) is added. But other difficulties remain: what is the subject of e)sti, if to\ kefa/laion is adverbial? Should we a construe with Ficinus (followed by Stallb.^{2}, Lehrs, Zeller, Jowett and others) “nam summatim quidem omnis bonorum felicitatisque appetitio maximus et insidiator amor est cuique”? Or b should we rather, with Stallb.^{1} and Prantl, supply o( e)/rws as the subject of e)sti and construe pa=sa h(...eu)daimonei=n as the predicate? To my mind the latter is the more natural method. Next arises the question, how are we to deal with the last part of the sentence, o( me/gisto/s...panti/? If with most edd. (except Rückert, Stallb.^{2} and Rettig) we regard dolero\s as corrupt, the best plan is to excise the whole clause with Hug (and Stallb.^{1}), since none of the corrections of dolero\s hitherto proposed (see crit. n.) are at all convincing. The chief objection to dolero\s is, not so much the meaning of the word itself (which may be defended by 203 D), as rather (to quote Stallb.^{2}) “conjunctio superlativi me/gistos cum dolero/s positivo.” But even this objection
is not, I think, insuperable; for if we construe panti/ closely with dolero\s as “all-ensnaring,” we get a superlative idea which balances me/gistos, while in sense it is supported by 203 B, D and Sappho's doloplo/ke *)afrodi/ta. If, adopting this explanation, we retain the traditional text, it seems best to regard the clause o( me/gisto/s...panti/ as an appositional quotation and to construe, with Prantl, “nämlich jene grösste und für jeden verfängliche Liebe.” Hommel is singular in taking tou= eu)daimonei=n (sc. h( e)piqumi/a), as well as to\ kefa/laion, as subject (“und das Streben nach dem höchsten Gute, d. i. nach Glückseligkeit, ist die grösste Liebe”).

e)/rwta...e)rastai/. This sequence is irregular. Usually with o)/noma e)/xein the name is in the nominative, in apposition with the subject, e.g. Laws 956 C diaithtai\ o)/noma...e)/xontes (so here e)rastai/): but the accus. is also possible (in appos. with o)/noma), as in Plut. Arist. 2. But the combination of the two constructions is certainly awkward, and the words may well be, as Schanz supposes, a gloss.
*kai\ le/getai ktl. An allusion to Aristophanes' speech, esp. 192 B, E ff.: cp. 212 C. For ou)/q' o(/lou, below, cp. 192 E.

e)pei\ au(tw=n ge ktl. Cp. Xen. Mem. I. 2. 54 e)/lege d' o(/ti kai\ zw=n e(/kastos e(autou=, o(\ pa/ntwn ma/lista filei=, tou= sw/matos o(/ ti a)\n a)xrei=on h)=| kai\ a)nwfele\s au)to/s te a)fairei= kai\ a)/llw| pare/xei. au)toi/ te/ ge au(tw=n o)/nuxas te kai\ tri/xas kai\ tu/lous a)fairou=si ktl.: Ev. Matth. 5. 30 kai\ ei) h( decia/ sou xei\r skandali/zei se, e)/kkoyon au)th/n ktl.
ei) mh\ ei)/. See Goodwin G. M. T. § 476^{4}.

to\ me
 a)gaqo
 oi)kei=on. Cp. Rep. 586 E ei)/per to\ be/ltiston e(ka/stw|, tou=to kai\ oi)keio/taton (with Adam's note): Charm. 163 C, D e)ma/nqanon to
 lo/gon, o(/ti ta\ oi)kei=a/ te kai\ ta\ au(tou= a)gaqa\ kaloi/hs: Arist. E. N. X. 7.
h)\ tou= a)gaqou=. For the assumption that ta)gaqo\n is the final end of desire, cp. Phileb. 20 B ff., Gorg. 467 D ff., etc. The statement here is referred to by Proclus in Alcib. I. p. 129.
a(plou=n. Equivalent to a)/neu prosqe/sews a)lhqe/s: cp. 183 D; Phaedrus 244 A ei) me\n ga\r h)=n a(plou=n to\ mani/an kako\n ei)=nai ktl. (“true without qualification,” Thompson); Prot. 331 C.
o( e)/rws e)sti\n a)ei/. Most edd. follow Bekker in ejecting a)ei/: Rettig, however, rightly keeps it with the note “a)ei/=die gegebene Definition gilt überall und für alle Fälle”; cp. 205 A, B.
au)to\. Sc. to\ ta)gaqo\n au(toi=s ei)=nai a)ei/.

h( su/ntasis. Cp. 203 D (*)/erws e)sti) su/ntonos: Phileb. 46 D su/ntasin a)gri/an poiei= (with my note): Euthyd. 288 D. For the limitation of the notion of Eros here (a)\n kaloi=to), cp. that in 205 A ff. (kalou=ntai, C, D).
tugxa/nei o)\n. Not “what does it happen to be,” but “what in reality is it”: see Verrall on Eur. Med. 608: cp. Phaedo 65 D—E.
*ou) menta)\n ktl. For the suppressed protasis (sc. ei) tou=to ei)=xon ei)pei=n), cp. 175 D.
e)foi/twn para\ se\ . foita=n is the regular word for “attending” lectures or a school, see Prot. 326 C ei)s didaska/lwn...foita=n: Rep. 328 D deu=ro par' h(ma=s foi/ta: Phaedo 59 B.

to/kos e)n kalw=|. The act of procreation appears to be called almost indifferently (1) to/kos, as here, (2) ge/nnhsis (206 C, E, 209 D), (3) ge/nnhsis kai\ to/kos (206 E), (4) in passive aspect ge/nesis (206 D, 207 D). Similarly with the verbs: we find ti/ktein (206 C, 210 C, etc.), genna=n (206 D, 207 A, etc.), ti/ktein kai\ genna=n (206 D, 209 B, C).

*mantei/as...manqa/nw. Notice the play on the stem-sound. Rettig, citing Eur. Hippol. 237 (ta/de mantei/as a)/cia pollh=s), writes “Witzspiel mit Anklang an Eur. und Anspielung auf Diotima's Heimath und Beruf”: the latter allusion is likely enough, but the “Anklang an Eur.” is very problematical; had it been specially intended we should have had a)/cia or pollh=s echoed as well.

kuou=si. ku/hsis, “pregnancy,” is properly the condition intermediate between conception (su/llhyis) and delivery (to/kos). Cp. Achill. Tat. I. 10 kai\ neani/skos e)/rwtos prwtoku/mwn ou) dei=tai didaskali/as pro\s to\n toketo/n. For the language and thought of this whole passage, cp. Theaet. 150 ff., Phaedrus 251 A ff., Tim. 91 A: also Max. Tyr. diss. XVI. 4, p. 179 kuou=si de\ pa=sai me\n yuxai\ fu/sei, w)di/nousi de\ e)/qei, ti/ktousi de\ lo/gw| ktl.: Clem. Al. Strom. V. 552 B: Themist. or. XXXII. p. 355 D.

e)n th=| h(liki/a| g. I adopt Badham's correction thi for tini since the change involved is very slight and e)/n tini h(liki/a| is unexampled in Plato: cp. Gorg. 484 C e)n th=| h(liki/a|: Rep. 461 B; Phaedrus 209 B below; 255 A; Meno 89 B. Plato also uses e)n h(liki/a|, e.g. Rep. 461 B: Charm. 154 A: Laws 924 E.

ti/ktein de\...kalw=|. There is much to be said for Rettig's view that this sentence (as well as the next) is a gloss. As he argues, the words “gehören also ihrem Inhalte nach nicht an die Stelle, an welcher sie stehen, sondern sie müssten nach dem Satze e)/sti de\ tou=to ktl. folgen. An dieser Stelle collidiren sie aber mit den gleichbedeutenden Worten ta\ de\ e)n tw=| a)narmo/stw|...a(rmo/tton,
für deren Glosse ich sie ansehe. Worauf sollten auch die Worte e)/sti de\... pra=gma gehen, wenn ihnen die Worte ti/ktein de\...kalw=| unmittelbar vorangingen?” It is just possible, however, to retain the clause as a kind of parenthetic addendum to the preceding sentence, which forestalls, somewhat confusingly, the sentences ta\ d' ...a(rmo/tton. The omission of the article before kalw=|, confirmed by the Papyrus, is certainly an improvement. For the thought, cp. Plotin. Enn. III. V. p. 157 B.

[h( ga\r...to/kos e)sti/n.] Most edd. (except Hommel and Stallb.) agree in excising this clause as a meaningless intrusion. Hommel and Stallb. explain the words as intended to introduce the first part of the exposition of to/kos, viz. to/kos kata\ sw=ma: and Stallb. renders “nam (ga/r=nemlich) viri et mulieris coitus, est ille nihil aliud nisi to/kos.” Susemihl's comment is “die Zeugung werde als die wahrhafte Aufhebung der Geschlechtsdifferenz bezeichnet.” But, as Rettig shows, none of these attempts to justify the clause are satisfactory. Perhaps it is a gloss on h(liki/a|.

e)/sti de\ tou=to ktl. Cp. Laws 773 E, 721 C gamei=n de\...dianohqe/nta w(s e)/stin h(=| to\ a)nqrw/pinon ge/nos fu/sei tini\ metei/lhfen a)qanasi/as: ou(= kai\ pe/fuken e)piqumi/an i)/sxein pa=s pa=san ktl.: Cicero Tusc. I. 35 quid procreatio liberorum, quid propagatio nominis...significant, nisi nos futura etiam cogitare?: Clem. Al. Strom. II. p. 421 C e)piskeua/sas th\n a)qanasi/an tou= ge/nous h(mw=n (sc. dia\ tou= ga/mou), kai\ oi(onei\ diamonh/n tina paisi\ pai/dwn metalampadeuome/nhn.
e)n tw=| a)narmo/stw|. For the connexion of Eros with a(rmoni/a, see 187 A ff.; for harmony of the body, cp. Rep. 591 D; and of the soul, Rep. 430 E ff., Phaedo 85 E ff.

*moi=ra...*ei)lei/quia. Cp. Pind. Ol. VI. 41 ta=| me\n o( *xrusoko/mas prau/mhti/n t' *)elei/quian pare/stase/n te *moi/ras: id. Nem. VII. 1 *)elei/quia pa/redre *moira=n baqufro/nwn. *moi=ra (“the Dispenser”) is a birth-goddess also in Hom. Il. XXIV. 209 tw=|d' w(/s poqi *moi=ra kratai/h | gignome/nw| e)pe/nhse li/nw|. For Eileithyia, see also Il. XII. 270, Hes. Theog. 922; and it is noteworthy that Olen made out Eros to be the son of Eileithyia (see Paus. IX. 27). Libanius (or. V. t. I. p. 231 R.) identifies Eil. with Artemis.

h( *kallonh/. Usener was no doubt right in taking kallonh/ here as a proper name, in spite of Rettig's objection that “deren Existenz nachzuweisen ihm aber nicht gelungen ist”; for such a personification, in this context, requires no precedent. “Beauty acts the part of our Lady of Travail at the birth.” Possibly we ought to insert e)pi\ after e)sti(n) or read e)/pi in place of e)sti.
prospela/zh|. For this poetical word, cp. Hom. Od. IX. 285, and (of sexual converse) O. T. 1101 *pano\s prospelasqei=sa .
i(/lew/n. Cp. 197 D.

diaxei=tai. This word may signify both physical and emotional effects: for the former cp. Laws 775 C tw=n swma/twn diakexume/nwn u(po\ me/qhs: for the latter, Suidas (Hesych.) diaxei=tai: xai/rei, diaxe/etai, and the Psalmist's “I am poured out like water.”

suspeira=tai ktl. Schol. suspeira=tai: sustre/fetai. Suid. kuri/ws de\ a)ni/llesqai to\ a)paciou=n. They are realistic terms to express aversion, derived perhaps from the action of a snail in drawing in its horns and rolling itself into a ball. Cp. Plotin. Enn. I. VI. 2. 51 h( yuxh\...pro\s to\ ai)sxro\n prosbalou=sa a)ni/lletai kai\ a)rnei=tai kai\ a)naneu/ei e)p' au)tou= ou) sumfwnou=sa kai\ a)llotrioume/nh. Usener and Hug may be right in bracketing kai\ a)potre/petai, on which Hug comments “Zwischen dem der Gleichnissprache angehörenden suspeira=tai und a)ni/lletai ist das matte, prosaische a)potre/petai unpassend”; but the extra word helps to add emphasis, if nothing more, and Plotinus too uses three verbs. In a)nei/lletai Rettig sees an “Anspielung auf a)neilei/quia” (cp. Eur. Ion 453). Cp. Plut. de s. n. v. p. 562 A.

spargw=nti. For sparga=n, lacte turgere, cp. Rep. 460 C: in Phaedrus 256 A (spargw=n de\ kai\ a)porw=n periba/llei to\n e)rasth\n kai\ filei=) spargw=n=Venere tumens. The Scholiast here has spargw=nti: o(rmw=nti, o)rgw=nti, tarattome/nw|, h)\ a)nqou=nti. lamba/netai de\ kai\ e)pi\ tw=n mastw=n peplhrwme/nwn ga/laktos. Here the realism of the language and the juxtaposition of kuou=nti compels us to construe “great with child” (as L. and S.) or “with swelling bosom”—not merely “bursting with desire” or excitement. Cp. sfrigw= as used in Ar. Lysistr. 80.

h( ptoi/hsis. “Sic feliciter emendavit Abresch”—his conj. turning out to have some MS. support. The subst. occurs also in Prot. 310 D gignw/skwn au)tou= th
 a)ndrei/an kai\ th
 ptoi/hsin: Crat. 404 A th
 tou= sw/matos ptoi/hsin kai\ mani/an: and the verb (e)ptoh=sqai) in Rep. 439 D, Phaedo 68 C, 108 A. Cp. Mimnermus 5. 2 ptoiw=mai d' e)sorw=n a)/nqos o(mhliki/hs. It seems a vox propria for the condition of the lover “sighing like a furnace”: cp. Plotin. de pulcr. p. 26 (with Creuzer's note).

w)di=nos a)polu/ein. This is the office of *kallonh\ as *ei)lei/quia: cp. Theaet. 151 A tau/thn...th\n w)di=na e)gei/rein te kai\ a)popau/ein h( e)mh\ te/xnh (sc. h( maieutikh\) du/natai: Rep. 490 B w(=| plhsia/sas kai\ migei\s tw=| o)/ntws o)/nti, gennh/sas nou=n kai\ a)lh/qeian...kai\ ou(/tw lh/goi w)di=nos: Max. Tyr. diss. XVI. 4, p. 179 lo/gos maieu/etai yuxh\n kuou=san kai\ w)di/nwn mesth/n.

to
 e)/xonta. “Sc. tau/thn th
 w)di=na” (Wolf): but Hommel and Stallb. supply au)to/, i.e. to\ kalo/n. Cp. Phaedrus 252 A to
 to\ ka/llos e)/xonta i)atro
 eu(/rhke mo/non tw=n megi/stwn po/nwn,—which settles the question.
ti/...gennh/sews ; ti/, answered by o(/ti, means “why” or “wherein” rather than “what” (as in 204 D), and the genitive, like those preceding, is objective. Supply e)sti\n o( e)/rws.

a)eigene/s. This is practically a re-assertion of the statement in 206 C (qew=n to\ pra=gma ktl.). Cp. Laws 773 E w(s xrh\ th=s a)eigenou=s fu/sews a)nte/xesqai tw=| pai=das pai/dwn katalei/ponta ktl.

ei)/per tou= a)gaqo
 ktl. Against Bekker, Dindorf, Ast, Stallb.^{1} who adopted tou= ta)gaqo
 Rückert wrote: “etiam vulg. proba est. Construe: ei)/per tou= a)gaqou= e)/rws e)sti
, quibus e)chghtikw=s addita sunt verba e(autw=| ei)=nai a)ei/. In quibus supplendum est subj. o( e)/rws.” To this Stallb.^{2} and Rettig assent, comparing Pind. Ol. III. 33 tw=n nin gluku\s i(/meros e)/sxen...futeu=sai: Thuc. V. 15. 1 e)piqumi/a| tw=n a)ndrw=n tw=n e)k th=s nh/sou komi/sasqai (where Poppo cites for the epexegetic infin. Crito 52 C, Xen. Cyr. V. 231). None the less, the MSS.' text seems—if not “sine ullo sensu” as Wolf put it—at least very awkward Greek. The obvious allusion to the former definition, o( e)/rws e)sti\ tou= to\ a)gaqo
 au(tw=| ei)=nai a)ei/ (206 A ad fin.), supports Bekker's reading here as the right one: but if we read tou= ta)gaqo/n here consistency requires that we also read meta\ ta)gaqou= in the preceding line, an easy change but supported by no authority. Hence I content myself with the minimum of alteration, viz. a)gaqo
 for a)gaqou=.

w(s deinw=s diati/qetai. “In welchem gewaltsamen Zustande sich die Thiere befinden” (Schlei.). The phrase is echoed by Alcibiades in 215 E, cp. 207 B, 208 C. For dia/qesis see Phileb. 11 D, with my note.
nosou=nta...peri\. Cp. Phaedrus 228 B nosou=nti peri\ lo/gwn a)koh/n: Soph. fr. 162 (Dindf.) no/shm' e)/rwtos tou=t' e)fi/meron kako/n (but Nauck fr. 153 reads the verse otherwise).

kai\ diama/xesqai ktl. This is a correction of Phaedrus's statement (179 B ff.): cp. 220 D ff. For the fact, cp. Aelian H. A. I. 18, II. 40: Laws 814 B mh/d' w(/sper o)/rniqas peri\ te/knwn maxome/nas...e)qe/lein a)poqnh/|skein ktl.

kai\ au)ta\ ktl. “Schleiermacher: um sie nur zu ernähren. Recte. Fallitur enim Hommel, w(/ste sic usurpari negans ideoque voculam ejectam cupiens. Conf. De Rep. VIII. p. 549 C al.” (Stallb.). As Stallb. explains, au)ta\ ktl. depend on ai)sqa/nei, the construction being changed, and au)ta\=sponte. For paratei/nesqai, “racked,” cp. Lysis 204 C: Ar. fr. 421.

ti/s ai)ti/a ktl. For ai)ti/a with the (anarthrous) infin., cp. Phaedo 97 A ai)ti/a...gene/sqai. For the foregoing description of the phenomena connected with reproduction in the animal-world, cp. (with Rettig) Od. XVI. 216 ff.; Laws 814 B; Arist. Hist. An. VIII. 1; Cic. de fin. III. 19. 62.
*dianoei=. “Do you fancy—?”: cp. Laws 755 B mhke/ti...th\n thlikau/thn a)rxh\n w(s a)/rcwn dianohqh/tw. Notice the tone of indignant scorn in which Diotima speaks, cp. 204 B.
deino\s ta\ e)rwtika/. Cp. 193 E, 198 D.
o(/per nu=n dh\ ei)=pon. See 206 B.
ou(= polla/kis w(m . ou(= means a)qanasi/as: polla/kis refers not only to 206 E f. but also to other conversations such as are implied in 207 A (e)di/daske/ me o(po/te ktl.).
e)ntau=qa. “Here,” i.e. in the case of ta\ qhri/a, as distinguished from that of humans.
to\n au)to\n...lo/gon. Adv. accus.; cp. 178 E.
kata\ to\ dunato\n. This implies (cp. 208 A ad fin., B) that only partial immortality, at the best, can attach to h( qnhth\ fu/sis.

a)ei\ to\ ei)=nai a)qa/natos. I retain the reading of B rejected by recent edd. (see crit. n.): a)ei\ goes with the preceding words, cp. Rep. 618 C to\n belti/w e)k tw=n dunatw=n a)ei\ pantaxou= ai(rei=sqai: and 206 A, B supra. If, with Burnet, we adopt the reading of T, we must suppose ei)=nai to be doing double duty, “both to exist (ei)=nai) always and to be (ei)=nai) immortal.” For the desire of this mortal “to put on immortality,” cp. Eur. fr. 808 w)= filo/zwoi brotoi\... ou(/tws e)/rws bro/toisin e)/gkeitai bi/ou: Browne Hydriot. c. 5 “Restless inquietude for the diuturnity of our memories unto present considerations seems a vanity almost out of date, and superannuated piece of folly.”

du/natai ktl. This introduces the explanation of the saving phrase kata\ to\ dunato/n. tau/th| is adverbial (equiv. to tau/th| th=| mhxa/nh| in 208 B ad init.), and th=| gene/sei, if genuine, is an epexegetic supplement. Possibly we should excise th=| gene/sei, with Vermehren; or else alter to th=| gennh/sei. But the use of th=| gene/sei above (206 D) in the sense of “the process of generation,” combined with the emphasis, by repetition of its moods and tenses, laid on gi/gnesqai in the sequel (207 D—208 A), may make us hesitate to adopt any change; cp. also the passage quoted in the next note.

a)ei\ katalei/pei ktl. Cp. Laws 721 C ge/nos ou)=n a)nqrw/pwn...tou/tw| tw=| tro/pw| a)qa/naton o)/n, tw=| pai=das pai/dwn kataleipo/menon tau)to
 kai\ e(
 o)
 a)ei\ gene/sei th=s a)qanasi/as meteilhfe/nai: ib. 773 E (cited above). On this “conceit” of “a fruitful issue wherein, as in the truest chronicle, they seem to outlive themselves,” Sir T. Browne (Rel. Med. § 41) observes “This counterfeit subsisting in our progenies seems to me a mere fallacy” etc.

e)pei\ kai\ ktl. We should expect this first clause to be followed by something like ou)k e)/sti to\ au)to\ a)lla\ ne/on a)ei\ gi/gnetai, ta\ de\ a)po/llusi or ou)de/pote ta\ au)ta\ e)/xei e)n e(autw=|, but, affected by the parenthetic clause oi(=on...ge/nhtai, the
sentence follows a different course. Cp. the cases of anacoluthon in 177 B, 182 D.

ne/os...ta\ de\ a)pollu/s. For the omission of ta\ me
, cp. Theaet. 181 D, Protag. 330 A, Rep. 451 D. I think it not unlikely that for a)lla\ we should read a(/ma: the processes of growth and decay are synchronous. For the substance of this passage cp. Heraclitus fr. 41 di\s e)s to
 au)to
 potamo
 ou)k a)
 e)mbai/hs: (Heraclitus ap.) Plut. de EI Delph. c. 18 o( xqe\s (a)/nqrwpos) ei)s to
 sh/meron te/qnhken, o( de\ sh/meron ei)s to
 au)/rion a)poqnh/|skei. me/nei d' ou)dei/s, ou)d' e)/stin ei(=s, a)lla\ gigno/meqa polloi\ peri\ e(
 fa/ntasma: Max. Tyr. diss. XLI. 4 metabolh
 o(ra=|s swma/twn kai\ gene/sews a)llagh/n, o(do
 a)/nw kai\ ka/tw kata\ to
 *(hra/kleiton ktl.: Plut. cons. ad Apoll. 10: Crat. 439 D ff.: see also Rohde Psyche II. 148.

The influence of “the flowing philosophers” is noticeable also in Epicharm. fr. 40. 12 ff. (Lorenz)— w(=de nu=n o(/rh kai\ to\s a)nqrw/pous: o( me
 ga au)/ceq' , o( de/ ga ma
 fqi/nei. e)n metallaga=| de\ pa/ntes e)nti\ pa/nta to
 xro/non. o( de\ metalla/ssei kata\ fu/sin kwu)/pok' e)n twu)tw=| me/nei, a(/teron ei)/h ka to/d' h)/dh tou= parecestako/tos. kai\ tu\ dh\ ka)gw\ xqe\s a)/lloi kai\ nu
 a)/lloi tele/qomes, kau)=qis a)/lloi kwu)/pox' wu(toi\ katto
 au)to
 au)= lo/gon.

Cp. Spenser F. Q. VII. 7. 19 And men themselves do change continually, | From youth to eld from wealth to poverty...Ne doe their bodies only flit and fly, | But eeke their minds (which they immortall call) | Still change and vary thoughts, as new occasions fall.”
ai( e)pisth=mai. The word is used here in the popular sense— “notitiae rerum in sensus cadentium” (Rückert); cp. Rep. 476 D ff.
meleta=n. See note on a)mele/thtos 172 A supra.

lh/qh ga\r ktl. Cp. Phaedo 75 D ou) tou=to lh/qhn le/gomen...e)pisth/mhs a)pobolh/n; Phileb. 33 E e)/sti ga\r lh/qh mnh/mhs e)/codos: Meno 81 C; Laws 732 C. For the phgh\ *lh/qhs (*mnhmosu/nhs) in Hades, see Pind. fr. 130; Rohde, Psyche II. 209^{3}, 390^{1}.

[mnh/mhn].
