This word is either interpolated or corrupted (pace Rettig who attempts to defend it by citing Phileb. 34 B): a)piou/shs must refer to the same subst. as e)ciou/shs above, viz. th=s e)pisth/mhs, while kainh/n must qualify the same subst. as a)piou/shs. For later reff. to this doctrine, see Philo Jud. de nom. mut. p. 1060; Nemes. de nat. hom. 13, p. 166.

a)lla\ tw=|...oi(=on au)to\ h)=n. This view is reproduced by Aristotle, de an. II. 4. 415^{a} 26 ff. fusikw/taton ga\r tw=n e)/rgwn toi=s zw=sin...to\ poih=sai e(/teron oi(=on au)to/...i(/na tou= a)ei\ kai\ tou= qei/ou mete/xwsin...e)pei\ ou)=n koinwnei=n a)dunatei= tou= a)ei\ kai\ tou= qei/ou th=| sunexei/a|...koinwnei= tau/th|...kai\ diame/nei ou)k au)to\ a)ll' oi(=on au)to/, a)riqmw=| me\n ou)x e(/n, ei)/dei d' e(/n: cp. id. Pol. I. 1252^{a} 26 ff.; de gen. an. II. 735^{a} 17 ff.
tau/th| th=| m. Cp. tau/th|, 207 D ad init.

a)du/naton de\ a)/llh|. Stallb.^{2}, retaining the traditional a)qa/naton, comments: “haec addita videntur et oppositionis gratia et propter verba extrema kai\ ta)=lla pa/nta: quae ne falso intelligerentur, sane cavendum fuit”—which, as Hommel points out, is unsatisfactory. Against a)du/naton Rückert absurdly objects that Plato would have written a)/llh| de\ a)du/naton.

panti\...e(/petai. Since e(/pesqai is more naturally used of attendance on a divinity (cp. 197 E, Phaedrus 248 A etc.) perhaps e)/pestin ought to be read (cp. 183 B crit. n.). h( spoudh\ serves to recall 206 B.

*ei)=en. “Really!”: “In irrisione verti potest so?” (Ast). This is a somewhat rare use; cp. Rep. 350 E e)gw\ de/ soi, w(/sper tai=s grau=sin tai=s tou\s mu/qous legou/sais, “ei)=en” e)rw=: ib. 424 E; Euthyd. 290 C. For the doubled “verbum dicendi” (ei)=pon...h)=n), cp. 177 A, 202 C.

w(/sper oi( te/leoi sofistai/. We might render “in true professorial style.” The reference may be partly (as Wolf and Hommel suggest) to the fact that the sophistic, as contrasted with the Socratic, method was that of didactic monologue (do/lixon katatei/nousi tou= lo/gou Prot. 329 A)—the lecture rather than the conversation. Thus in the sequel (208 C—212 A) Diotima developes her own doctrine without the aid of further question-and-answer. Stallb., however, explains the phrase as intended to ridicule the pretended omniscience of the sophists; Rettig sees in it an indication that what follows is meant, in part, as a parody of the earlier speeches; and by Ast and Schleierm. it is taken to refer only to the dogmatic tone of eu)= i)/sqi. For te/leos sofisth/s, cp. Crat. 403 E (applied to Hades); sofisth/s applied to Eros, 203 D; oi( xrhstoi\ sofistai/, 177 B; oi( sofoi/, 185 C. It is possible also that in te/leos there may be a hint at the mystery-element in D.'s speech (cp. 210 A and pro\s te/los 210 E).
ei) e)qe/leis ktl. For filotimi/a, cp. 178 D. The thought here recalls Milton's “Fame is the spur that the clear spirit doth raise” etc.

qauma/zois a)\n ktl. Stallb., defending peri\, says “ad e)nnoei=s facillime e superioribus intelligitur au)ta/.” But we may justly complain here, as Badham does at Phileb. 49 A, of “the dunce who inserted peri\.”

kai\ kle/os...kataqe/sqai. “Ex poeta aliquo petita esse ipse verborum numerus declarat” (Stallb.): but it is just as probable that Diotima herself is the authoress—rivalling Agathon. Cp. Tyrtaeus 12. 31—2 ou)de/ pote kle/os e)sqlo
 a)po/llutai ou)d' o)/nom' au)tou= | a)ll' u(po\ gh=s per e)w
 gi/gnetai a)qa/natos: Theogn. 245—6 ou)de\ to/t' ou)de\ qanw
 a)polei=s kle/os, a)lla\ melh/seis | a)/fqiton a)nqrw/pois ai)e
 e)/xwn o)/noma: Simon. 99. 1 a)/sbeston kle/os...qe/ntes. For the thought, see also Cic. Tusc. I. p. 303; Cat. Mai. 22. 3.

u(perapoqnh/|skein. An obvious allusion to 180 A ff.: Diotima corrects Phaedrus by showing the motive for self-sacrifice to be not so much personal e)/rws as e)/rws for immortal fame. The use of the cognate accus. (kindu/nous, po/nous) is another poetical feature in this passage—reminiscent of Agathon's style.

*ko/dron. Schol.: pole/mou toi=s *dwrieu=sin o)/ntos pro\s *)aqhnai/ous, e)/xrhsen o( qeo\s toi=s *dwrieu=sin ai(rh/sein ta\s *)aqh/nas, ei) *ko/dron to
 basile/a mh\ foneu/sousin. gnou\s de\ tou=to o( *ko/dros, stei/las e(auto
 eu)telei= skeu/h| w(s culisth
 kai\ dre/panon labw/n, e)pi\ to
 xa/raka tw=n polemi/wn proh/|ei. du/o de\ au)tw=| a)panthsa/ntwn polemi/wn to
 me
 e(/na pata/cas kate/balen, u(po\ de\ tou= e(te/rou a)gnohqei\s o(/stis h)=n, plhgei\s a)pe/qane. This “popular story” is late: “according to the older tradition Codrus fell in battle” (see Bury Hist. Gr. p. 169): the traditional date of the event is about 1068 B.C. Notice the rare proapoqanei=n (once each in Hdt., Antiphon, Xen.), and the “sophistic” jingle in pro-, e)p-, a)poqanei=n. For later allusions to Codrus, see Cic. Tusc. I. 48; Hor. C. III. 19. 2.

a)qa/naton mnh/mhn ktl. Cp. Simon. 123 mnh=ma d' a)pofqime/noisi path\r *mega/ristos e)/qhken | a)qa/naton qnhtoi=s paisi\ xarizo/menos: id. 4. 8 (*lewni/das) a)reta=s leloipw\s | ko/smon a)e/naon kle/os te: id. 96. Observe how near a)qa/naton ...e)/sesqai goes to forming a complete hexameter.

a)reth=s a)qana/tou. Cp. Soph. Philoct. 1419
o(/sous ponh/sas kai\ diecelqw\n po/nous
a)qa/naton a)reth\n e)/sxon
: Pind. Ol. VII. 163 a)/ndra te pu\c a)reta\n eu(ro/nta: id. Nem. X. 2 fle/getai d' a)retai=s muri/ais e)/rgwn qrase/wn e(/neken (“countless monuments” J. B. Bury, see Append. A in his ed.): id. Isthm. IV. 17 (with Bury, App. F): Thuc. I. 33. 2: Rep. 618 B e)pi\ ge/nesi kai\ progo/nwn a)retai=s: Xen. Cyrop. VIII. 1. 29: Anth. Pal. VII. 252. These passages show that a)reth/ can denote not only “excellence” but its result, reward or token, “renown,” “distinction,” whether or not embodied in a concrete “monument.” For the thought cp. Spenser F. Q. III. iii. 1 “Most sacred fyre, that burnest mightily In living brests...which men call Love...Whence spring all noble deedes and never dying fame.”

eu)kleou=s. Cp. Simon. 95 eu)kle/as ai)=a ke/keuqe, *lewni/da, oi(\ meta\ sei=o | th=|d' e)/qanon: Menex. 247 D. With the thought of this passage, cp. Sir T. Browne Hydriot. c. 5 “There is no antidote against the opium of time....But the iniquity of oblivion blindly scattereth her poppy, and deals with the memory of men without distinction to merit of perpetuity....In vain do individuals
hope for immortality, or any patent from oblivion, in preservations below the moone.” Also Soph. Philoct. 1422 e)k tw=n po/nwn tw=nd' eu)klea= qe/sqai bi/on .
oi( me\n ou)=n e)gku/mones. Here first the two kinds of pregnancy, bodily and mental,—mentioned together in 206 B, C—are definitely separated.
pro\s ta\s g. m. tre/pontai. Cp. 181 C, 191 E.

a)qanasi/an ktl. Hug points out that by a few slight alterations this can be turned into an elegiac couplet:— a)qa/naton mnh/mhn keu)daimoni/an sfi/sin au)toi=s ei)s to\n e)/peita xro/non pa/nta porizo/menoi. Hommel had already printed ei)s...xro/non as a half-verse.
oi( de\ kata\ th\n yuxh/n. Sc. e)gku/mones o)/ntes. In this anacoluthic period Rettig sees a parody of Phaedrus's style with its “langathmigen, anakoluthischen und regellosen Perioden.”

kai\ kuh=sai kai\ tekei=n. Hug's conjecture, tekei=n for kuei=n, is fortunate in finding confirmation in the Papyrus. If kuei=n be read, what is the point of the distinction of tenses? Schleierm. renders by “erzeugen und erzeugen zu wollen”; Schulthess, “zeugen und empfangen”; Rettig explains that “kuei=n geht auf den dauernden, kuh=sai auf den vollendeten Process”; Stallb. “et concepisse (quae est actio semel...perfecta) et conceptum tenere.” But there is certainly not much point here in making any such fine-spun distinction, unless it be to imply that Diotima is playing the part of a sofisth/s!
fro/nhsin...a)reth/n. “Moral wisdom and virtue in general”: the phrase is an echo of that in 184 D. For fro/nhsis, cp. Rep. 427 E (with Adam's note); Meno 88 B (with Thompson's note).

oi( poihtai\. That the poets were ethical teachers and the stage a pulpit— just as Homer was the Greek Bible—was an axiom in the Hellenic world. See the appeal to the authority of poets in the Protagoras (and Adam's note on 338 E); Ar. Ran. 1009 (Eurip. loquitur) belti/ous te poiou=men tou\s a)nqrw/pous e)n tai=s po/lesin: Lysis 214 A ou(=toi ga\r (sc. oi( poihtai\) h(mi=n w(/sper pate/res th=s sofi/as ei)si\ kai\ h(gemo/nes. The fact that most kinds of poetry were produced in connexion with, and under the sanction of, religion, had no doubt something to do with this estimate of it. See further Adam R. T. G. pp. 9 ff.
dhmiourgw=n...eu(retikoi\. An allusion to 197 A dhmiourgi/an...a)neu=ren.
megi/sth...th=s fronh/sews. Cp. Crat. 391 B o)rqota/th th=s ske/yews: Rep. 416 B; Thuc. I. 2 th=s gh=s h( a)ri/sth: see Madv. Gr. S. § 50 a, R. 3.

swfrosu/nh te kai\ dikaiosu/nh. Cp. Phaedo 82 A oi( th
 dhmotikh/n te kai\ politikh
 a)reth
 e)pitethdeuko/tes, h(
 dh\ kalou=si swfrosu/nhn te kai\ dikaiosu/nhn, e)c e)/qous te kai\ mele/ths gegonui=an a)/neu filosofi/as te kai\ nou=: Meno 73 A. For these virtues in the Republic, see Adam on 432 A, 434 C. Here they combine to form a description of “ordinary civil virtue.”

tou/twn au)= ktl. Here the main statement is resumed. With Stephens (followed by Ast, Rückert and Hug) I read e)piqumh=|, whereas Burnet prints e)piqumei=. zhtei= dh\ ktl., with commas after yuxh
 and h(liki/as. Stallb. takes kai/ as intensive rather than connective, and renders qei=os w)/n “quippe divinus.” Burnet adopts Parmentier's h)/|qeos, but there seems little point in emphasizing the celibacy of the youth. If alteration be required, the best would be e)/nqeos, for which cp. 179 A, 180 B. But in Meno 99 C ff. qei=os, in much the same sense as e)/nqeos, is applied to the very classes here mentioned—o)rqw=s a)
 kaloi=men qei/ous te, ou(\s nu=n dh\ e)le/gomen xrhsmw|dou\s kai\ ma/nteis kai\ tou\s poihtikou\s a(/pantas: kai\ tou\s politikou\s...fai=men a)
 qei/ous te ei)=nai kai\ e)nqousia/zein ktl. (see Thompson ad loc.): hence the word may well be sound here also. For th=s h(liki/as (and qei=os) cp. 206 C.
zhtei=...periiw\n. Cp. Prot. 348 D periiw\n zhtei= o(/tw| e)pidei/chtai: Rep. 620 C: Apol. 23 B. periie/nai occurs also in 193 A, 219 E.
e)n tw=| ga\r ai)sxrw=|. A repetition of 206 C: cp. Rep. 402 D, Phaedrus 253 A ff.

kai\ a)\n...eu)fuei=. Notice the iambic rhythm. For the sense of gennai=os, “well-bred” (of a dog, Rep. 375 A), cp. (Eurip. ap.) Gorg. 485 E. For eu)fuh/s also cp. (Eurip. ap.) Gorg. 484 C ff.; Rep. 409 E. Cp. for the sense Plotin. de pulcr. 309 (Cr.); Rep. 620 B; Cic. Lael. 14; and esp. Phaedrus 276 E.
to\ cunamfo/teron. Cp. I. Alc. 130 A yuxh\n h)\ sw=ma h)\ cunamfo/teron.
eu)porei= lo/gwn. Cp. 223 A; Tim. 26 D i(/na eu)poroi=en lo/gwn met' e)mou=.

kai\ [peri\] oi(=on ktl. peri\ is retained by Hommel and Stallb. who renders “quale sit in quo tractando versari debeat is qui boni viri nomen et dignitatem obtinere velit,” taking oi(=on as neut., and by Rettig who regards the “redundance and tautology” of the words as due to the “sophistical character” of the passage.
tou= kalou=. This is masc., not neuter, as the context shows.

kai\ parw\n kai\ a)pw\n. A rhetorical formula; cp. Soph. Antig. 1109 oi(/ t' o)/ntes oi(/ t' a)po/ntes : El. 305: Crat. 420 A, Laws 635 A. As Hommel observes, memnhme/nos (sc. au)tou=) can in strictness apply only to a)pw/n.
to\ gennhqe\n ktl. Cp. 207 B, Phaedrus 276 E.

th=s tw=n pai/dwn. Hug prints tw=n x x x pai/dwn with the note (after Vermehren) “es scheint ein Epitheton wie fu/sei o. ähnl. ausgefallen zu sein.” Stallb. explains h( koinwni/a tw=n pai/dwn to mean “conjunctio ex liberorum procreatione oriunda.” The simplest remedy is to bracket the words th=s tw=n pai/dwn (see crit. n.).
a)qanatwte/rwn. For this Hibernian comparison cp. Phaedo 99 C.

zhlw=n oi(=a ktl. I.e. zhlw=n au)tou\s o(/ti toiau=ta ktl., “With envy for the noble offspring they leave.” For oi(=os=o(/ti toiou=tos, cp. Xen. Cyr. VII. 3. 13 (Madv. Gr. S. § 198 R. 3). Rückert punctuates after *(hsi/odon, Hommel after a)po/bleyas, and it is evident from Rettig's note,—“Homer kann man nur bewundern, mit andern Dichtern ist es eher möglich zu wetteifern,”—that he too mistakes the construction: we must supply au)tou/s (as Stallb.) with zhlw=n and construe all the accusatives as depending on ei)s: cp. I. Alc. 120 A, 122 B, C. This passage is quoted by Proclus ad Pl. Rep. p. 393.
a)qa/naton kle/os kai\ mnh/mhn. Cp. 208 D (note).
au)ta\ toiau=ta. Rettig says “sc. a)qa/nata”; but the words imply kle/os as well as a)qanasi/a.
ei) de\ bou/lei. See on 177 D. This is a brachylogy for ei) de\ bou/lei, zhlw=n *lukou=rgon oi(/ous pai=das ktl.
pai=das kateli/peto. For the middle, cp. Laws 721 C, Rep. 594 C.

swth=ras th=s *l. “Dadurch, dass sie den revolutionären Bewegungen ein Ende machten” (Rettig). Agathon had already applied swth/r to Eros (197 E). For Plato's philo-Laconism, see Zeller's Plato (E. T.) p. 484. For the mythical lawgiver “Lycurgus” (vulgarly dated at 885 B.C.), see Bury H. Gr. p. 135. The statement that his laws were the salvation “practically” of Hellas may be taken to refer to the part played by the Spartans during the Persian invasions, cp. Pind. Pyth. I. 77 ff. See also the parallel passage in Xen. Symp. VIII. 38—9.
ti/mios de\ ktl. For this emphatic position of the adj., cp. Laws 730 D ti/mios me\n dh\ kai\ o( mhde\n a)dikw=n.
a)/lloi a)/lloqi pollaxou=. An echo of 182 B: cp. Prot. 326 D. This passage is alluded to by Clem. Al. Strom. I. p. 130. 38 e)/n te tw=| sumposi/w| e)painw=n *pla/twn tou\s barba/rous ktl.
polla\...e)/rga. Another rhetorical “tag,” as is shown by the parallel in Menex. 239 A polla\...kai\ kala\ e)/rga a)pefh/nanto ei)s pa/ntas a)nqrw/pous: cp. Phaedrus's expressions in 179 B, C.
pantoi/an a)reth/n. Cp. Critias 112 E kata\ th\n tw=n yuxw=n pantoi/an a)reth/n : Eur. Med. 845 (e)/rwtas) pantoi/as a)reta=s cune/rgous.

i(era\ polla\. For the shrine of Lycurgus, see Hdt. I. 66, Plut. Lyc. 31. The language echoes Aristophanes' me/gist' a)\n au)tou= i(era\ kataskeua/sai (189 C); and it is cited by Clem. Al. Strom. I. p. 300 P.

*tau=ta...ka)
 su\ muhqei/hs. Here Diotima passes on to the final section of her discourse on erotics (see 210 D n.). Hug and P. Crain (following C. F. Hermann and Schwegler) suppose that ka)
 su\ m. indicates that what follows is something beyond the ken of the historical Socrates, whose view
they regard as correctly represented in Xen. Symp. VIII. 97 ff. But although we may admit (with Thompson, Meno p. 158) that “we often find Plato making his ideal Socrates criticise the views the real Socrates held,” we are not hereby justified in assuming such criticism on every possible occasion. And, in the case before us, another and more probable explanation of the words lies to hand. Socrates throughout—with his usual irony—depicts himself as a mere tiro in the hands of the Mantinean mistress; but he is still, in spite of his mock-modesty, the ideal philosopher of Alcibiades' encomium. As it was a part of his irony that he had already (201 E) put himself on the level of Agathon and the rest of the unphilosophic, so the contemptuous ka)
 su\ here serves to keep up the same ironical fiction,—i.e. it applies neither to the ideal nor to the real (historical) Socrates, but to the hypothetical Socrates—the disguise assumed by the ideal Socrates when he played the part of pupil (cp. Rettig's note, and F. Horn Platonstud. p. 248). The attitude of Socr. may be illustrated by the words of S. Paul (1 Cor. iv. 6) tau=ta de/, a)delfoi/, metesxhma/tisa ei)s e)mauto
 kai\ *)apollw\ di) u(ma=s, i(/na e)n u(mi=n ma/qhte ktl. For muhqei/hs, see next note.

ta\ de\...e)poptika/. Cp. Phaedrus 250 C eu)dai/mona fa/smata muou/menoi/ te kai\ e)popteu/ontes: ib. 249 C tele/ous a)ei\ teleta\s telou/menos. On the former passage Thompson comments, “muou/menoi and e)popteu/ontes are not to be distinguished here, except in so far as the latter word defines the sense of the former. Properly speaking mu/hsis is the generic term for the entire process, including the e)poptei/a, or state of the epopt or adept, who after due previous lustrations and the like is admitted into the adytum to behold the au)toptika\ a)ga/lmata (Iambl. Myst. II. 10. 53)”: “the distinction between the two words (mu/hsis and e)poptei/a), as if they implied, the one an earlier, the other a more advanced stage of imitation, was a later refinement.” According to Theo Smyrnaeus (Math. p. 18) there were five grades of initiation, viz. kaqarmo/s, h( th=s teleth=s para/dosis, e)poptei/a, a)na/desis kai\ stemma/twn e)pi/qesis, h( qeofilh\s kai\ qeoi=s sundi/aitos eu)daimoni/a. For the language and rites used in the mysteries, see also Plut. de Is. c. 78; id. Demetr. 26; Clem. Al. Strom. v. p. 689; Rohde Psyche II. 284; and the designs from a cinerary urn reproduced in Harrison, Proleg. p. 547.
w(=n e(/neka. “The final cause”: cp. 210 E, Charm. 165 A.
tau=ta. Repeating tau=ta...ta\ e)rwtika/: see the recapitulation in 211 C.

oi(=o/s t' a)\n ei)/hs. Sc. muhqh=nai: this, as Thompson observes, shows that mu/hsis includes e)poptei/a. Notice the emphasis laid, here at the start and throughout, on educational method, to\ o)rqw=s metie/nai.

proqumi/as...a)polei/yw. Cp. Rep. 533 A to/ g' e)mo
 ou)de
 a)
 proqumi/as a)polei/poi.

peirw= de\ <kai\ su\> e(/pesqai. I have added kai\ su\ from the Papyrus; it serves
to lay an appropriate stress on the personal effort required on the part of the disciple, the incapacity of whose “natural man” is so persistently emphasized.

dei= ga/r ktl. The sentence runs on without a full stop till we reach the close of 210 D: Rettig sees in this straggling style a parody of the style of Pausanias. The passage following was a favourite with the neo-Platonists; see the reff. in Alcinous isag. 5; Plut. quaest. Plat. 3. 2. 1002 E; Themist. or. 13, p. 168 C; Plotin. Enn. I. 6. 1, p. 50; Procl. in Alcib. I. p. 330.
o( h(gou/menos. The educational “conductor” is represented as a mustagwgo/s. So we have a)gagei=n 210 C, paidagwghqh=| 210 E, a)/gesqai 211 C.

e(no\s au)to
 sw/matos. If we retain sw/matos—and emphasis requires its retention,—it is difficult to justify the Bodleian au)tw=n: and au)to
, which has the support of the Papyrus, although rather otiose, is preferable to such substitutes as Hommel's au)= tw=n (swma/twn) or Vermehren's au)= tou, since au)= is hardly in place here. Voegelin's objection to au)to
, endorsed by Rettig, that it should involve the repetition of dei=, does not strike one as fatal; and I follow Rückert and Stallb. in adopting it.
to\ e)pi\...sw/mati. Cp. 186 A.

to\ e)p' ei)/dei kalo/n. This has been interpreted in three ways: (1) “das in der Idee Schöne” (Schleierm.), “das Schöne der Gesammtgattung” (Schulthess); so too Zeller and F. Horn; (2) “quod in specie (opp. to ‘summo genere’) pulchrum est” (Stallb., after Wyttenbach), so too Hommel; (3) “das in der Gestalt Schöne” (Ruge), “pulcritudo quae in forma est atque sensibus percipitur” (Rückert). The last of these is undoubtedly right, and has the support also of Vermehren, Rettig and Hug; for ei)=dos of physical “form” or “outward appearance,” cp. 196 A, 215 B.
mh\ ou)x...h(gei=sqai. See Goodwin G. M. T. § 817.
e)nnoh/santa katasth=nai. Sc. au)to\n dei=, resuming the oblique construction.
to\ sfo/dra tou=to. “Idem est quod tou=to to\ sfo/dra e)ra=n vel to\n sfodro\n tou=ton e)/rwta” (Stallb.). We have had a description of this sfodro/ths already, in 183 A ff.
w(/ste kai\ e)a\n ktl. The uncontracted form kai\ e)a/n is very rare in Plato, see Schanz nov. comm. p. 95. For a)/nqos, cp. 183 E.

[kai\ zhtei=n]. Ast rightly condemned these words as “ineptum glossema.” To excise kai\ only (as Badham) is unsatisfactory, since as Hug justly observes ti/ktein zhtei=n lo/gous “ist unerträglich matt.” Stallb. attempts to justify the words thus: “Diotima hoc dicit, talem amatorem non modo ipsum parere quasi et ex se procreare, sed etiam aliunde quaerere et investigare eiusmodi sermones, qui iuvenes reddant meliores”; so too Rettig. But this is futile.
e)n toi=s e)pithdeu/masi. “In Morals” (Stewart): cp. Laws 793 D o(/sa no/mous h)\ e)/qh tis h)\ e)pithdeu/mata kalei=: Rep. 444 E: Gorg. 474 E.

i(/na to\...ei)=nai. This clause is subordinate to, rather than coordinate with, the preceding i(/na clause (like the e(/ws a)\n clause in D below),—a juxtaposition which sounds awkward. Hence it is tempting either to excise this clause with Hug, or with Ast to read a)nagkasqei\s for a)nagkasqh=|, and delete the second i(/na. Against Hug's method it may be urged that the words are wanted to correspond to e(no\s...smikro\n h(ghsa/menon in 210 B above, and to emphasize the “littleness” of corporeal beauty even when taken in the mass. For this belittling of things of the earth, cp. Theaet. 173 E h( de\ dia/noia, tau=ta pa/nta h(ghsame/nh smikra\ kai\ ou)de/n, a)tima/sasa...fe/retai ktl. Observe how pa=n ...cuggene/s here balances (pa=n) ka/llos...a)delfo/n in 210 B.
a)gagei=n. The construction is still dependent upon dei=, but the subject to be supplied (viz. to\n h(gou/menon) is changed.

mhke/ti tw=| par' e(ni/ ktl. tw=|, sc. kalw=|, is governed by douleu/wn, and the phrase contains a clear reference to the language of Pausanias in 183 A ff. w(/sper oi)ke/ths, “like a lackey,” is of course contemptuous, as in Theaet. 172 D kinduneu/ousin...w(s oi)ke/tai pro\s e)leuqe/rous teqra/fqai. For a)gapw=n, “contented with,” cp. Menex. 240 C. If we retain the MSS.' to\ par' e(ni/ the construction is
awkward, as Stallb.^{2} admits—“quod olim accusativum defendendum suscepimus, videtur nunc interpretatio loci quam proposuimus, quamvis Rückerto et Hommelio probata, nimis contorta nec satis simplex esse.” I am inclined to suspect the phrase h)\ a)nqrw/pou tino\s. Schirlitz proposed to excise h)\ a)nqrw/pou: I suggest paidari/ou ka/llos [h)\] a)/nou tino\s, “of some witless urchin,” and suppose a reference to what Pausanias said in 181 B e)rw=si...w(s a)\n du/nwntai a)nohtota/twn: 181 D ou) ga\r e)rw=si pai/dwn, a)ll' e)peida\n h)/dh a)/rxwntai nou=n i)/sxein (cp. next n.).
fau=los...smikrolo/gos. Cp. 181 B, where those who follow Aphrodite Pandemos (loving women and boys) are described as oi( fau=loi tw=n a)nqrw/pwn.

e)pi\ to\ polu\ pe/lagos . pe/lagos of itself connotes vastness; cp. Rep. 453 D ei)s to\ me/giston pe/lagos me/son (a)/n tis e)mpe/sh|): Prot. 338 A feu/gein ei)s to\ pe/lagos tw=n lo/gwn. The phrase is alluded to in Clem. Al. protrept. 69 A; Plut. quaest. Plat. 1001 E; Themist. or. XIII. p. 177 C.

qewrw=n. This should be taken closely (supplying au)to/) with what precedes, not with pollou\s...lo/gous (as Ast's Dict. s.v. implies). The parable suggests that the spectator, having reached the hill-top, turns himself about and gazes, wonder-struck, at the mighty ocean of beauty which lies spread before him, till the spectacle quickens his soul and moves it to deliver itself of many a deep-lying thought.

kalou\s...megaloprepei=s. Cp. Menex. 247 B: ib. 234 C: Rep. 503 C neanikoi/ te kai\ m. ta\s dianoi/as: ib. 486 A, 496 A genna=n dianoh/mata/ te kai\ do/cas. Cp. for the sense Plotin. de pulcr. 8 C (Cr.).
a)fqo/nw| . a)/fqonos is used alike of fruits (Polit. 272 A) and of soils (Soph. 222 A), thus meaning both “abundant” and “bountiful”—“unstinted” and “unstinting.”
r(wsqei\s. Cp. Phaedrus 238 C; 176 B supra.

e)pisth/mhn mi/an. This unitary science—e)pisth/mh in the strict Platonic sense, called also (211 C) ma/qhma—is dialectic: cp. Phaedrus 247 B th\n e)n tw=| o(/ e)stin o)\n o)/ntws e)/pisth/mhn ou)=san. See parallels in Plotin. de pulcr. 2 A (Cr.); Procl. in I. Alc. p. 246.
peirw= de/ moi ktl. Here again, as at 210 A (peirw= de\ e(/pesqai ktl.), a climax in the exposition is marked.

e)fech=s te kai\ o)rqw=s. “In correct and orderly succession”; see 211 B ad fin. tou=to ga\r dh/ e)sti to\ o)rqw=s...i)e/nai ktl., and 210 A where the right order of procedure (prw=ton...e)/peita, etc.) is specially emphasized.
pro\s te/los h)/dh i)w\n . “pro\s te/los i)e/nai dicebantur ii, qui superatis gradibus tandem ad spectanda arcana admittebantur” (Hommel). Cp. the use of te/lea in 210 A, te/leon 204 C, te/los 205 A.

e)cai/fnhs. “On a sudden”: this suggests the final stage in the mysteryrites, when out of darkness there blazed forth suddenly the mystical fe/ggos, and e)n au)gh=| kaqara=| the fa/smata (Phaedrus 250 C) or i(era\ mustika/—consisting probably of images of Demeter, Iacchus and Persephone, and other sacred emblems—were displayed to the awe-struck worshipper (makari/a o)/yis te kai\ qe/a). Cp. Plotin. Enn. 43. 17 o(/tan h( yuxh\ e)cai/fnhs fw=s la/bh| ktl.; Plato Ep. vii. 341 C e)cai/fnhs, oi(=on a)po\ puro\s phdh/santos e)cafqe\n fw=s, e)n th=| yuxh=| geno/menon (sc. the highest ma/qhma). See further Rohde, Psyche II. 284.
kato/yetai. Cp. 210 D above, and Phaedrus 247 D (kaqora=| me\n au)th\n dikaiosu/nhn ktl.), which suggest that kaqora=n was a vox propria for viewing ritual displays.

qaumasto
...kalo/n. Similarly Phaedrus 250 B ka/llos de\ to/t' h)=n i)dei=n lampro/n. For qaumasto/n cp. 219 B: it often connotes the supernatural, e.g. Rep. 398 A proskunoi=men a)
 au)to
 w(s i(ero
 kai\ q. kai\ h(du/n.
ou(= dh\ e(/neken ktl. “The goal to which all our efforts have been directed”: cp. 210 A; Phaedrus 248 B ou(= d' e(/nex' h( pollh\ spoudh\ ktl. See the parallel in Plotin. de pulcr. 42 C, D (Cr.).

prw=ton me\n...e)/peita...ou)d) au)= ktl. The Ideal object is distinguished by three leading characteristics, viz. (1) eternity and immutability; (2) absoluteness, or freedom from relativity; (3) self-existence. Compare the accounts of Ideal being given in Phaedo 78 C ff., Phaedrus 247 C ff., Crat. 386 D, 439 C ff., Rep. 476 A, 479 A ff., Soph. 249 B ff., Phileb. 15 B, 58 A, Tim. 51 D ff. The description has, necessarily, to be conveyed by means of negative propositions, i.e. by way of contrast with phenomenal objects. See also the parallels in Plotin. Enn. V. viii. 546 C, VI. vii. 727 C.
th=| me\n...th=| de\. “In part...in part”: so Theaet. 158 E, Polit. 274 E, Laws 635 D.
pro\s me\n to\...to\. This denotes varying “relation,” as in the Aristotelian to\ pro/s ti.

w(/s tisi\...ai)sxro/n. Rettig defends this clause, quoting Wolf's note, “tisi/ (geht) auf alle vier (vorher genannten) Ideen, Theile, Zeit, Verhältniss, Ort.” Teuffel argues that “ausser Platon selbst hätte nicht leicht Jemand einen Anlass gehalt einen Beisatz zu machen.” None the less, I believe we have here another “ineptum glossema.”
fantasqh/setai au)tw=|. Sc. tw=| qewme/nw|. fanta/zesqai often connotes illusive semblance; cp. Phaedo 110 D, Rep. 572 B.

ou)de/ tis lo/gos. It is difficult to be sure of the sense in which lo/gos is used here. (1) It is most natural to refer it, and e)pisth/mh following, to the lo/goi and e)pisth=mai of 210 C, and to render by “discourse,” “argument” (with Gomperz, Stewart and Zeller). This rendering has in its favour the fact that this is the usual sense of lo/gos (lo/goi) throughout this dialogue. (2) Or lo/gos may mean “concept”; so Rettig, who comments: “Die Ideen sind nicht blosse Begriffe, sie sind vielmehr Existenzen, xwristai/, wie Aristoteles sich ausdrückt, und Bedingungen des Seins und Werdens der Dinge der Sinnenwelt.” Cp. Phaedrus 245 E, Laws 895 E, Phaedo 78 C, in which places (to quote Thompson) “lo/gos is equivalent to o(/ros or o(rismo/s, of which ou)si/a is the objective counterpart.” This more technical sense is, perhaps, less probable in the present context; but, after all, the difference between the two renderings is not of vital importance. The essence of the statement, in either case, is that the Idea is not dependent upon either corporeal or mental realization, i.e. that it is not subjective, as a quality or product of body or mind, but an objective, self-conditioned entity. A third possible sense of lo/gos is “ratio,” or mathematical relation. Perhaps “formula” would best render the word here.

ou)de/ pou o)
 . pou is probably used in a local sense: cp. Arist. Phys. III. 4. 203^{a} 7 *pla/twn de\ e)/cw me
 ou)de
 ei)=nai sw=ma, ou)de\ ta\s i)de/as, dia\ to\ mhde/ pou ei)=nai au)ta/s. But though the Ideas are extra-spatial, it is Platonic (as Aristotle implies, de An. III. 4. 429^{a} 27) to say th
 yuxh
 ei)=nai to/pon ei)dw=n.

monoeide\s. Cp. Phaedo 78 D m. o)\n au)to\ kaq' au(to/: ib. 80 B monoeidei= kai\ a)dialu/tw|: Theaet. 205 D: Tim. 59 B: Rep. 612 A ei)/te polueidh\s ei)/te monoeidh/s (h( a)lhqh\s fu/sis). Stewart renders “of one Form,” but the full force may be rather “specifically unique,” implying that it is the sole member of its class.
mete/xonta. For the doctrine of “participation,” see esp. Phaedo 100 C ff., Parmen. 130 B ff.
toiou=ton, oi(=on. Equiv. to toiou=ton w(/ste (see Madv. Gr. S. § 166 c).
e)kei=no. Sc. (au)to\) to\ kalo/n. So frequently “e)kei=no et e)kei=na das Uebersinnliche significat, ta/de vero vel tau=ta das Sinnliche” (Ast): cp. Phaedrus 250 A, Phaedo 74 B, etc.
mhde\ pa/sxein mhde/n. As to the a)pa/qeia of the Idea, see Soph. 248 A ff., 251 C ff., and my article on “The Later Platonism” in Journal of Philol. XXIII. pp. 189 ff.
e)paniw\n. Cp. Rep. 521 C tou= o)/ntos ou)=san e)pa/nodon, h(\n dh\ filosofi/an a)lhqh= fh/somen ei)=nai: ib. 532 B, C.
tou= te/lous. This combines the senses “goal” and “sacred symbol”: cf. 210 A; Soph. fr. 753 N. w(s tri\s o)/lbioi | kei=noi brotw=n, oi(\ tau=ta derxqe/ntes te/lh | mo/lws' e)s *(/aidou.
tou=to ga\r dh/ ktl. Here commences a recapitulation of “the Ascent of Love” as described in 210 A—211 B; cp. Rep. VI., VII. for both language and thought.
u(p' a)/llou a)/gesqai. This refers to the paidagwgo/s or mustagwgo/s of 210 E, not (as Wolf thought) to the operation of a dai/mwn.

e)panabaqmoi=s. For the notion of a ladder of ascent cp. Rep. 510 B ff., 511 B ta\s u(poqe/seis poiou/menos ou)k a)rxa\s a)lla\...oi(=on e)piba/seis te kai\ o(rma\s i(/na me/xri tou= a)nupoqe/tou e)pi\ th
 tou= panto\s a)rxh
 i)w
...ou(/tws e)pi\ teleuth
 katabai/nh| ktl. Cp. Tennyson's “the great world's altar-stairs”; the dream-ladder at Bethel; and the Titanic heaven-scaling of 190 B. Possibly a contrast is intended between the futile attempt of the Earth-born ei)s to
 ou)rano
 a)na/basin poiei=n, and the successful efforts of the Heaven-born lover e)pi\ to\ kalo
 e)panie/nai. For later parallels, see Plotin. de pulcr. 60 B (Cr.); Clem. Al. Strom. v. p. 611 D.

kai\ a)po\ tw=n maqhma/twn ktl. The reading and construction of this passage
are uncertain. I follow Usener in changing teleuth/sh| to the infinitive and in inserting i(/na after ma/qhma (retaining, however, kai\ before gnw=| which he needlessly deletes). The objection to Schanz's w(s (for kai\) a)po\ tw=n m. is that w(s, in the final use, occurs but once elsewhere in Plato, according to Weber's statistics (see Goodwin, G. M. T. p. 398), being very rare in all good prosewriters except Xenophon. Another possible expedient would be to read gnw=nai in place of gnw=|. e)/st' a)/n is a non-Platonic form.
teleuth=sai...teleutw=n. The repetition serves to emphasize the finality of the Idea.
au)to\...o(\ e)/sti. For this formula to express ideality, cp. Phaedo 74 B, 75 B oi(=s e)pisfragizo/meqa tou=to o(\ e)/sti: Theaet. 146 E.

e)ntau=qa...ei)/per pou a)/lloqi. “There above all places”; so Phaedo 67 B e)kei=...ei)/per pou a)/lloqi: cp. 212 A ei)/per tw| a)/llw|...e)kei/nw|. For e)ntau=qa c. gen. cp. Theaet. 177 C, Rep. 328 E. For bi/os biwto/s, cp. Apol. 38 A, Eur. Alc. 802.

ou) kata\ xrusi/on ktl. Similar is Proverbs viii. 11 “Wisdom is better than rubies; and all the things that may be desired are not to be compared to it.” That Socr. held this view is shown in 216 D, E. For kata/ c. acc., of comparison, cp. Gorg. 512 B, Rep. 466 B.

cuno/ntes...mh/te pi/nein. Cp. 191 A ff.; also Sappho 2, Archil. 103, Soph. fr. 161 N. (o)mma/teios po/qos): Rel. Med. “There are wonders in true affection— when I am from him I am dead till I be with him,” etc.
ti/ dh=ta...oi)o/meqa. Sc. gene/sqai au)tw=|, or the like.
ei)likrine/s ktl. Cp. Phileb. 52 D to\ kaqaro/n te kai\ ei)likrine/s: Phaedo 66 A, Rep. 478 E.

mh\ a)na/plewn. Tim. a)na/plews: a)napeplhsme/nos: xrh=tai de\ e)pi\ tou= memolusme/nou: cp. Phaedo 83 D and the use of the verb in Phaedo 67 A mhde\
a)napimplw/meqa th=s tou/tou (sc. tou= sw/matos) fu/sews, a)lla\ kaqareu/wmen a)p' au)tou=. Also Rep. 516 E, Theaet. 196 E. This passage is cited by Plotin. Enn. I. vi. 7, p. 56.
xrwma/twn. For the Idea as a)xrw/matos ou)si/a, see Phaedrus 247 C.

fluari/as qnhth=s. “Lumber of mortality”: cp. Phaedo 66 C e)rw/twn de\ kai\ e)piqumiw=n kai\ fo/bwn kai\ ei)dw/lwn pantodapw=n kai\ fluari/as e)mpi/plhsin h(ma=s pollh=s (sc. to\ sw=ma); Gorg. 490 C; Rep. 581 D.
fau=lon bi/on. For the sense, cp. Soph. fr. 753 N., Eur. fr. 965 D. o)/lbios o(/stis ...a)qana/tou kaqorw=n fu/sews | ko/smon a)gh/rw ktl.

e)kei=no w(=| dei=. “With the proper organ,” sc. tw=| nw=|: cp. Phaedrus 247 C h( ga...a)nafh\s ou)si/a, o)/ntws ou)=sa, yuxh=s kubernh/th| mo/nw| qeath\ nw=| ktl.: Phaedo 65 E; Rep. 490 B au)tou= o(\ e)/stin e(ka/stou th=s fu/sews a(/yasqai w(=| prosh/kei yuxh=s e)fa/ptesqai tou= toiou/tou: ib. 532 A pri
 a)
 au)to\ o(\ e)/stin a)gaqo
 au)th=| noh/sei la/bh|. For the organ of intellectual vision (to\ o)/rganon w(=| katamanqa/nei e(/kastos...oi(=on ei) o)/mma), see Rep. 518 C: cp. S. Matth. vi. 22 ff. So Browne Hydriot. “Let intellectual tubes give thee a glance of things which visive organs reach not”: cp. Plotin. de pulcr. 60 B (Cr.).

ou)k ei)/dwla...a)ll) a)lhqh=. Rettig writes, “ei)/dwlon ist hier nicht Trugbild, sondern Abbild. ei)/dwla a)reth=s sind...Tugenden zweiten Grades. Vgl. Pol. VII. 516 A, 534 C, X. 596 A, 598 B...Commentar zu unserer Stelle ist Symp. 206 D.” On the other hand, cp. Theaet. 150 A ei)/dwla ti/ktein, with 150 C po/teron ei)/dwlon kai\ yeu=dos a)poti/ktei tou= ne/ou h( dia/noia h)\ go/nimo/n te kai\ a)lhqe/s. Evidently here the point of ei)/dwla lies in the inferiority rather than the similarity of the objects when compared with o)/ntws o)/nta. But it is scarcely probable that an allusion is intended, as Zeller suggests, to the myth of Ixion “der seine frevelnden Wünsche zu Here erhob, aber statt ihrer ein Wolkenbild umarmte und mit ihm die Centauren erzeugte.”

e)faptome/nw|. Of mental action, cp. Rep. 490 B (quoted above). Voegelin proposed to omit the second e)faptome/nw|, but Plato never omits the participle with a(/te. For parallels, see Phaedo 67 B, Rep. 534 C; Plotin. de pulcr. 46 E (Cr.).
qreyame/nw|. Cp. 209 C.
qeofilei=. Cp. Rep. 612 E, Phileb. 39 E.
ei)/per tw| a)/llw|. Cp. Phaedo 58 E, 66 A; and 211 D above (ad init.).

a)qana/tw|. Cp. Soph. fr. 864 N. ou)k e)/sti gh=ras tw=n sofw=n, e)n oi(=s o( nou=s | qei/a| cu/nestin h(me/ra| teqramme/nos. A passage such as this might have evoked the remark in Isocr. c. Soph. 291 E mo/non ou)k a)qana/tous u(pisxnou=ntai tou\s suno/ntas poih/sein.
pe/peismai ktl. “Beachte man das Spiel mit pe/peismai, pepeisme/nos, peirw=mai, pei/qein” (Rettig). Cp. 189 D e)gw\ ou)=n peira/somai ktl.
kth/matos. I.e. au)tou= tou= kalou=. Cp. Phileb. 19 C ti/ tw=n a)nqrwpi/nwn kthma/twn a)/riston: ib. 66 A.
sunergo\n. Cp. 180 E; and 218 D tou/tou de\ oi)=mai/ mou sullh/ptora ou)de/na kuriw/teron ei)=nai sou=.

dio\ dh\...tima=n. This echoes both Phaedrus's ou(/tw dh\ e)/gwge/ fhmi *)/erwta qew=n...timiw/taton (180 B) and Agathon's w(=| xrh\ e(/pesqai pa/nt' a)/ndra (197 E). Probably tima=n here implies practical veneration; cp. the Homeric use of timh/ (*r 251, l 304, w 30, etc.), and Hes. Theog. 142.

ta\ e)rwtika\...a)skw=. For Socrates' devotion to “erotics,” see 177 D ou)de/n fhmi a)/llo e)pi/stasqai h)\ ta\ e)rwtika/, 198 D ad init. Probably a)skw= (like timw=) has a religious connotation here, “I am a devotee of”; cp. Hesych. a)/skeia: qrh/skeia, eu)se/beia: Pind. Nem. IX. 9 (with J. B. Bury's note). In spite of Rettig's objection that Usener's conj. (see crit. n.) “bewirkt eine Tautologie mit dem Folgenden kai\ nu=n...*)/erwtos,” it seems to me—as to Hug—an improvement, and (as modified by Schanz) I adopt it: a certain amount of tautology is inevitable, unless we resort to excision. For kai\ (intensive) diafero/ntws cp. Phaedo 59 A, Rep. 528 D. Vahlen, reading a)skw=n, construes kai\ au)to\s t. and kai\ t. a)/. parak. as parallel: but in this case I should expect au)to/s <te>. Most edd. (Bekk., Bt., etc.) put commas after tima=n and a)skw=.

th\n du/namin kai\ a)ndrei/an. For the du/namis of Eros cp. 188 D (Eryx.) pa=san du/namin e)/xei...o( pa=s *)/erws: and for his a)ndrei/a, 179 A (Phaedr.), 196 C ff. (Agathon) ei)/s ge a)ndrei/an ktl., 203 D (Socr.) a)ndrei=os w)/n (cp. 219 D ff.). The intention here may be (as I find suggested also by Schirlitz) that the long
course of paidagwgi/a described above requires a)ndrei/a in the learner who is to attain pro\s to\ te/los: cp. Meno 81 D e)a/n tis a)ndrei=os h)=| kai\ mh\ a)poka/mh| zhtw=n. Neither Badham's xrei/an (cp. 204 C) nor Hug's athetesis of a)ndrei/an is probable.

div1.head: Fifth Interlude
div1.p: ei) me\n bou/lei...ei) de/. Cp. Euthyd. 285 C (with Gifford's n.); Goodwin G. M. T. § 478.
o(/ ti...xai/reis o)noma/zwn. Cp. Prot. 358 A; Phaedrus 273 C; Eur. fr. 967 D. soi\... *zeu\s ei)/t' *)ai/dhs | o)nomazo/menos ste/rgeis.
tou\s me\n e)painei=n. Observe that Socr. is not so enthusiastically applauded as Agathon (pa/ntas a)naqorubh=sai, 198 A): Socrates appealed rather tw=| e)/xonti w)=ta a)kou/ein.
le/gwn...peri\ tou= lo/gou. See 205 D ff. kai\ le/getai...lo/gos ktl.
th\n au)/leion qu/ran. For this “street-door,” which generally opened inwards and gave admittance to a narrow passage (qurwrei=on), see Smith D. A. I. 661 b.

krouome/nhn. As the Porter in Macbeth would say, “there was old knocking at the door.” For krou/ein cp. Prot. 310 A, 314 D; but the usual Attic word is ko/ptein (Moeris ko/ptei th\n qu/ran e)/cwqen...*)attikw=s, krotei= de\ *(ellhnikw=s: Schol. ad Ar. Nub. 132 e)pi\ me\n tw=n e)/cwqen krouo/ntwn ko/ptein le/gousin, e)pi\ de\ tw=n e)/swqen yofei=n), or pata/ssein Ar. Ran. 38. Cp. Smith D. A. I. 990 b.

w(s kwmastw=n. “Ut comissatorum, h. e. quasi comissatores eum (sc. strepitum) excitarent” (Stallb.). Stallb. rightly removed the comma placed after parasxei=n in Bekker's text. kwmastai/, “flown with insolence and wine,” would naturally be in a noisy mood. For Alcib. as a reveller, see Plut. Alcib. 193D.

au)lhtri/dos fwnh\n. Not “tibicinae vocem,” as Wolf, but rather “sonum tibiae, quam illa inflavit,” as Stallb. For fwnh/ thus (poetically) applied to instrumental music, cp. Rep. 397 A pa/ntwn o)rga/nwn fwna/s: similarly Xen. Symp. VI. 3 o(/tan o( au)lo\s fqe/gghtai. For the au)lhtri/s as a regular accessory of kw=moi, cp. 176 E, Theaet. 173 D: similar are the e(tai=rai of Rep. 373 A, 573 D: cp. Catullus's “cenam non sine candida puella.”
kalei=te. “Invite him in”; cp. 174 D, E, 175 B.

a)napauo/meqa h)/dh. “We are retiring already,” rather than “the drinking is over” (Jowett): cp. Prot. 310 C e)peidh\...dedeipnhko/tes h)=men kai\ e)me/llomen a)napau/esqai ktl. The statement here would be a social fiction (see 174 D n.).

sfo/dra mequ/ontos ktl. Hommel and Hartman may be right in regarding e)rwtw=ntos as a gloss: for boa=n followed directly by a question the former quotes Asclep. Epigr. XIX. 5 th=| de\ tosou=t' e)bo/hsa bebregme/nos: a)/xri ti/nos, *zeu=;
a)/gein ou)=n. Evidently the subject of this infin. is not Agathon's pai=des, as implied in Schleierm.'s transl., but Alcib.'s own attendants.

u(polabou=san. For u(polabei=n in this physical sense, “casurum sustentare,” cp. Rep. 453 D (the only other ex. in Plato), and Hdt. I. 24 of the dolphin “supporting” by “getting under” Arion (L. and S.'s “take by the hand” is probably wrong).
e)pi\ ta\s qu/ras. “Intellige fores ipsius domus, in qua convivae erant, sive th\n me/taulon qu/ran” (Stallb.).

au)to\n...i)/wn. “More Graecorum abundat au)to/n propter oppositionem taeniarum quas gestabat in capite” (Wolf). Violets were specially in fashion at Athens, as implied in the epithet i)oste/fanoi (Pind. fr. 46). Other favourite materials for wreaths were myrtle and roses: cp. Stesich. 29 polla\ de\ mu/rsina fu/lla | kai\ r(odi/nous stefa/nous i)/wn te korwni/das ou)/las.

taini/as. Cp. Thuc. IV. 121 dhmosi/a| me\n xrusw=| stefa/nw| a)ne/dhsan...i)di/a| de\ e)taini/oun ktl.: Pind. Pyth. IV. 240; Hor. Carm. IV. 11. 2. See Holden on Plut. Timol. p. 266: “taini/a, taenia, lemniscus, a sort of fillet or riband, given as a reward of honour, either by itself, or more commonly as a decoration to be fastened upon other prizes, such as crowns, wreaths, which were considered more honourable when accompanied with a lemniscus than when they were simply given by themselves. Originally it was made of linden-bark or of wool, but afterwards of gold and silver tinsel (Plin. N. H. 21. 4).”
mequ/onta...pa/nu sfo/dra. The peculiar order—“a drunken fellow right royally (drunk)”—seems intended to indicate that the speaker is, or feigns to be, considerably mixed.
xqe\s. I.e. at the main celebration of Agathon's victory, cp. 174 A.

e)a\n ei)/pw ou(twsi\. Since Wolf most edd. agree in obelizing these words as a (misplaced) gloss on the following clause. Hommel's conj. is ingenious, though far-fetched—e)a=n ei)=pon (addressed to his attendants) “dixi iam saepius, mitti me velle liberum a vestris manibus.” I have proposed e)a\n e)/ti oi(=o/s t' w)=, ou(twsi\ a)nadh/sw, “if I am still capable of doing so,” in jesting allusion to his own incapable condition: or perhaps the original had neani/skou. The scenic effectiveness of ou(twsi\, used deiktikw=s, I should be loth to use. Jowett's “as I may be allowed to call him” cannot be got out of the Greek.
au)to/qen. Statim, illico (Stallb.); cp. Thuc. VI. 21. 2.

e)pi\ r(htoi=s. “On the terms stated” (cp. Laws 850 A), i.e. as a sumpo/ths. This is made clear by the following clause, sumpi/esqe h)\ ou)/; which repeats the condition already stated in 212 E (mequ/onta...de/cesqe sumpo/thn): Rückert, as Stallb. observes, is wrong in saying “at nullam (conditionem) dixit adhuc.” That Alcibiades meant his “conditions” to be taken seriously is shown by the sequel, 213 E ff.
a)naqorubh=sai. Cp. 198 A. For kalei=n, see 212 D ad init.
u(po\ tw=n a)nqrw/pwn. Including, we may suppose, the au)lhtri/s, see 212 D.

e)pi/prosqe...*swkra/th. “Und da er sie sich vor die Augen hielt, bemerkte er Sokrates nicht” (Zeller). Ficinus, followed by Wolf and Schleierm., wrongly renders “Socratem, licet e conspectu adstantem, non vidit”; so too Hommel writes “ante oculos habuit et vidit Socratem, sed eum non agnovit.” For e)pi/prosqen e)/xein, cp. Critias 108 C.
para\ to\n *)aga/qwna. I.e. on the e)sxa/th kli/nh: for the disposition of the company see 175 C.
paraxwrh=sai. “Locum dedisse”: cp. Prot. 336 B.

w(s e)kei=non katei=den. The adoption of this reading from the Papyrus obviates the necessity of bracketing the words (see crit. n.). Adam on Rep. 365 D writes “w(s for w(/ste...is a curious archaism, tolerably frequent in Xenophon... but almost unexampled in Plato,” citing as instances Prot. 330 E, Phaedo 108 E, II. Alc. 141 B, and our passage: Goodwin, however (G. M. T. § 609), recognizes only one instance of w(s=w(/ste c. infin. in Plato (viz. Rep. l.c.). Certainly this is no fit context for the introduction of a “curious archaism.”
*(upolu/ete. “Calceos solvite”: see Smith D. A. I. 393 b. The opposite process is u(podei=n (174 A).
e)k tri/twn. Cp. Gorg. 500 A, Tim. 54 A; Eur. Or. 1178.

touti\ ti/ h)=n; “Mirandi formula, qua utuntur, quibus aliquid subito et praeter exspectationem accidit” (Stallb.). The idiom is common in Aristophanes, e.g. Vesp. 183, 1509, Ran. 39, etc. The words *s. ou(=tos are, as Rettig observes, “nicht Ausruf, sondern an sich selbst gerichtete Frage des Alcibiades.”
e)lloxw=n. Cp. Prot. 309 A a)po\ kunhgesi/ou tou= peri\ th\n *)alkibia/dou w(/ran; I. Alc. 104 C. See also the description of Eros in 203 D (e)pi/boulos ktl.).
e)cai/fnhs a)nafai/nesqai. Cp. 210 E; Theaet. 162 C ei) e)cai/fnhs ou(/tws a)nafanh/sei ktl.

kai\ ou) para\ ktl. I adopt Hermann's kai\ for the w(s of the MSS. Stallb. explains w(s by “quippe, nam, ut mox in verbis w(s e)moi\...ge/gonen”: Hommel, putting a question-mark after bou/letai, renders “warum setzest du dich grade dahin, als zum Beispiel nicht neben A.” etc.: but, if w(s be kept, it would be best to mark a question after katekli/nhs.

geloi=os...bou/letai. With bou/letai, supply geloi=os ei)=nai. For Aristoph. as geloi=os, cp. 189 B. The sense is, as Rettig puts it, “Was hast du geloi=os und
u(bristh/s bei dem liebenswürdigen Tragiker zu thun, du gehörst zu dem Spottvogel Aristophanes”: “birds of a feather should flock together.” Rückert suggests that the antithesis geloi=os )( ka/llistos may imply a reflection on “Aristophanis forma.”
diemhxanh/sw. For erotic scheming, cp. 203 D ff.
e)pamu/neis. “In animated language the present often refers to the future, to express likelihood, intention, or danger” (Goodwin, G. M. T. § 32).
prosble/yai. This may have been the vox propria for a lover's glance, cp. Ar. Plut. 1014 (quoted below).
h)\ ou(tosi\. This (elliptical) use of h)/, alioquin, “but that,” is “regular with dei=, prosh/kei, and the like, in the preceding clause” (Adam on Prot. 323 A).
zhlotupw=n. This is a a(/p. ei)r. in Plato: cp. Ar. Plut. 1014 ff. o(/ti prose/bleye/n me/ tis, | e)tupto/mhn dia\ tou=q' o(/lhn th\n h(me/ran. | ou(/tw sfo/dra zhlo/tupos o( neani/skos h)=n.
qaumasta\ e)rga/zetai. Cp. Laws 686 C q. e)rgasa/menon; Theaet. 151 A q. drw=ntes; 182 E above q. e)/rga e)rgazome/nw|: similarly 218 A poiou=si dra=n te kai\ le/gein o(tiou=n.
tw\ xei=re. This and 214 D below are the only exx. in Plato of a)pe/xesqai in the sense continere (manum): elsewhere it occurs mainly in poetry (Od. XXII. 316, etc.).
mani/an. Cp. Laws 839 A lu/tths...e)rwtikh=s kai\ mani/as: Soph. fr. 162 no/shm' e)/rwtos tou=t' e)fi/meron kako/n: and 173 D supra.
filerasti/an. “Amor quo quis amatorem amplectitur” (Ast); equivalent to a)nte/rws (Phaedrus 255 D): cp. 192 B.
o)rrwdw=. Horresco, a strong word for “quaking with fear.”

diallagh/. Alcib. catches up Socrates' word dia/llacon and negatives it with a “What hast thou to do with peace?” “But,” he proceeds, “I'll have
that out with you by-and-bye!” (see 214 C ad fin. ff.). Then, with a sudden change of tone from bullying and banter to affectionate earnestness, he begins nu=n de/ moi ktl.

th
 tou/tou...kefalh/n. “Incipit Alc. dicere th
 tou/tou kefalh/n, quod priusquam elocutus est, sentit nimis languidum esse; inde revertitur quasi ac denuo progreditur, positis verbis tauthni\ th
 q. k.” (Rückert). Perhaps as Alc. says these words (notice the deictic tauthni/) he playfully strokes the head of Socr. tou/tou is expanded by Jowett into “of this universal despot.”
nikw=nta. The present symposium was part of Agathon's epinikian celebration (see 174 A), and his victory also was gained by lo/goi (cp. 194 B).
e)/peita. Tamen, “yet after all,” i.e. in spite of the fact of his perpetual victoriousness. Cp. Prot. 319 D, 343 D.
katakli/nesqai. Ever since he first discovered Socrates, Alcibiades had been standing (see 213 B ad fin. a)naphdh=sai).
*ei)=en dh/. “Come now”: “die Worte enthalten hier eine Aufforderung” (Rettig). Cp. 204 C, Phaedo 95 A. The question to drink or not to drink is now resumed from 213 A ad init.
ou)k e)pitrepte/on. “This can't be allowed”: cp. Rep. 379 A and 219 C infra.
w(molo/ghtai ktl. See 212 E f.

a)/rxonta...th=s po/sews. “As symposiarch”: cp. the Latin arbiter (magister) bibendi Hor. C. I. 4. 17, II. 7. 25. For the qualifications proper in such “archons,” see Laws 640 C ff.; and for other details, Smith D. A. II. 740 b ff. The emphatic position of e)mauto/n is to be noticed.
fere/tw, *)aga/qwn. Sc. o( pai=s: I adopt Burnet's improved punctuation, which renders further change needless.

to
 yukth=ra. “Yonder wine-cooler.” Suid. yukth=ra: ka/ddon h)\ poth/rion me/ga, a)po\ tou= qa=tton yu/xesqai e)n au)tw=| th
 kra=sin: Poll. VI. 99 o( de\ yukth poluqru/lhtos, o(
 kai\ di=non e)ka/loun, e)n w(=| h)=n o( a)/kratos: oi( polloi\ de\ a)kratofo/ron au)to
 kalou=sin. ou) mh
 e)/xei puqme/na a)ll' a)stragali/skous. Other names for it were pro/xuma (Moeris, Schol. Ar. Vesp. 617) and ka/laqos (Hesych. s.v.): for details see Smith D. A. s.v. Psycter; cp. Xen. Mem. II. i. 30 i(/na de\ h(de/ws pi/h|s,...tou= qe/rous xio/na periqe/ousa zhtei=s: Xen. Symp. II. 23 ff.

o)ktw\ kotu/las. The kotu/lh or h(mi/na (=6 ku/aqoi) was 48 of a pint, so that 8 kotu/lai are nearly equal to 2 quarts. For a yukth/r this seems to have been a small size, since Athenaeus (v. 199) mentions yukth=res holding 18 to 54 gallons. Alcib. was not alone in his taste for an e)/kpwma me/ga: cp. Anacr. 32 triku/aqon kele/bhn e)/xousa: Alcaeus 41. 2 kad' d' a)/eire kuli/xnais mega/lais: Xen. Symp. l.c. o( pai=s e)gxea/tw moi th\n mega/lhn fia/lhn: Gouffé (Le Verre) “Nous devons aux petites gens Laisser les petits verres.”
e)mplhsa/menon. “Ast: implevisse. Immo implendum curasse” (Rückert).

e)gxei=n. Cp. Soph. fr. 149 D forei=te, masse/tw tis, e)gxei/tw baqu\n krhth=ra: Alcaeus 31. 4 e)/gxee ki/rnais e(/na kai\ du/o ktl.: Theogn. 487 su\ d' e)/gxee tou=to ma/taion | kwti/lleis a)ei/: tou)/neka/ toi mequ/eis. Notice that Alcib. adopts the order e)pi\ decia/, see 175 E.
to\ so/fisma/ moi ou)de/n. “My trick avails nothing.” For so/fisma, “a witty invention,” cp. Lach. 183 D, Rep. 496 A; Aesch. P.V. 470. Alcib., with his so/fisma, recals Eros the sofisth/s (203 D).
ou)de\n...mequsqh=|. See Goodwin G.M.T. § 295. For Socrates' invincible head for wine, see also 176 C, 220 B, 223 C.

*pw=s ou)=n...poiou=men. The present indic. differs from the subjunctive, “quod dicitur de eo quod revera iam fit, neque adhuc suscipiendum est” (Stallb.): contrast a)lla\ ti/ poiw=men (deliberative) just below. For the indignant ou(/tw cp. Hom. Il. II. 158 ou(/tw dh\ oi)=ko/nde...feu/contai.

ou)/te ti a)/|domen. This lection is preferable to B.'s ou)/t' e)pa/|domen which is accepted by most later editors. Eryx. would not propose to “chant spells,” the only sense in which the compound word is used by Plato. For the idea of trolling a catch over one's cups, cp. Gouffé (Couplets) “On boit
chez eux, on boit beaucoup Et de bourgogne et de champagne; Mais rien ne vaut un petit coup Qu'un petit couplet accompagne.”
For lo/goi e)pikuli/keioi, cp. Athen. 2 A; Lucian Timon, c. 55.

*)=w *)eruci/maxe ktl. Alcibiades—as if to show how ready he is a)/|dein ti— replies with an iambic trimeter—“A noble sire's most noble, sober son!” The superlatives are not without irony, cp. 177 B, Xen. Mem. III. 13. 2.
xai=re. “All hail!” Alcibiades pretends not to have noticed the doctor before.

i)htro\s ga\r...a)/llwn. From Il. XI. 514: “Surely one learnèd leech is a match for an army of laymen.” Pope's rendering—“the wise physician skilled our wounds to heal”—hardly deserves the name, although Jowett paid it the compliment of borrowing it.
e)pi/tatte. “Prescribe”: the techn. term for a medical prescription, cp. Rep. 347 A kata\ th\n te/xnhn e)pita/ttwn: Polit. 294 D, Laws 722 E.
e)/doce ktl. See 177 D.
w(s du/naito ka/lliston. Cp. Thuc. VII. 21 nau=s w(s du/nantai plei/stas plhrou=sin (Madv. Gr. S. § 96): there is no need to insert a)/n, as Sauppe suggested.
kai\ e)kpe/pwkas. “But have finished your draught.”

mequ/onta...paraba/llein. “mequ/onta negligentius dictum est pro lo/gon a)ndro\s mequ/ontos” (Wolf). For the brachylogy cp. 180 C meta\ de\ *fai=dron ktl. (see note ad loc.); 217 D e)n th=| e)xome/nh| e)mou= kli/nh|. With paraba/llein we must supply as subject tina (with Rettig) rather than se, i.e. *)eruci/maxon (with Wolf). Of conjectures Bast's is the most plausible. Cp. Theogn. 627 ai)sxro/n toi mequ/onta par' a)ndra/si nhfo/si mei=nai.
For a stricture on e)/painoi mequ/ontos, see Phaedrus 240 E.
w(= maka/rie. “Gutmuthig-ironisch” (Rettig): cp. 219 A.

pei/qei...ei)=pen; “H. e. pei/qei se/ ti tou/twn a(\ *s. a)/rti ei)=pen;...h. e. noli quidquam eorum credere quae modo dixit S.” (Stallb.). A. is alluding to 213 C—D (a)p' e)kei/nou ga\r tou= xro/nou ktl.).
ou)k a)fe/cetai ktl. “Satis lepide iisdem fere verbis hic utitur Alcib. quae Socr. l. l. exhibuit” (Hommel); A. is turning the tables on S.

*ma\ to\n *poseidw=. This form of oath is rare in Plato, see Schanz nov. comm. Plat. p. 23. The main reason why A. chooses Poseidon to swear by is, no doubt, because P. was the special deity of the ancient aristocracy of Athens (see R. A. Neile's ed. of Ar. Knights, p. 83); but A. may also be punning on po/sis, as if *poseidw/n meant “drink-giver,” and invoking a “deus madidus” as appropriate to his own “madid” condition. Cp. Euthyd. 301 E, 303 A.
timwrh/swmai. This echoes the timwrh/somai of 213 D.
*ou(=tos. “Ho, there!” Cp. 172 A.
e)pi\ ta\ geloio/tera. “To make fun of me”: cp. Phileb. 40 C (h(donai\) memimhme/nai ta\s a)lhqei=s e)pi\ ta\ geloio/tera (“caricatures”): so e)pi\ ta\ ai)sxi/ona Polit. 293 E, 297 C.
e)paine/sei. Plato always uses the middle form of the future, with the doubtful exception of Laws 719 E (where Burnet, after Bekker, corrects e)paine/soi to e)paine/sai), see Veitch Gk. Verbs s.v.
*ou)k a)\n fqa/noimi. Sc. ta)lhqh= le/gwn: iamiam dicam. Cp. 185 E, Phaedo 100 C, Euthyd. 272 D (in all which places the participle is expressed).
kai\...poi/hson. Hommel rashly proposes to read poih/swn for poi/hson and remove the stop after the word. For kai\ me/ntoi, see Madv. Gr. S. § 254.
e)pilabou=. “Pull me up,” “call me to order.” Cp. Gorg. 469 C, 506 B e)pilamba/nou e)a/n ti/ soi dokw= mh\ kalw=s le/gein.

div1.head: Alcibiades Praises Socrates
div1.p: a)/llo a)/lloqen. “In a wrong order,” or “in promiscuous fashion”: cp. Il. II. 75, Aesch. Ag. 92, etc. Alcib. forestalls criticism by this apology for the “mixed” style of his reminiscences, on the ground of what he calls his “present condition” (w(=d' e)/xonti=mequ/onti, crapula laboranti).
ou) ga/r ti r(a/|dion. For ou)/ti, handquaquam, cp. 189 B.

a)topi/an. Cp. Gorg. 494 D; 221 C infra. That Socrates is an “out-of-theway” character, a walking conundrum, is, in fact, the main theme of Alc.'s speech: it is a mistake to limit this a)topi/a to the contradiction between his outer and inner man, as Susemihl does.

ou(/tws...di) ei)ko/nwn. For ou(/tws with an epexegetic phrase, cp. 193 C, Laws 633 D, Rep. 551 C ou(/tw...a)po\ timhma/twn. For ei)ko/nes, “similes,” see Ar. Rhet. III. 4, where they are described as a kind of metaforai/ (“A simile is a metaphor writ large, with the details filled in,” Cope ad loc.). ei)kasi/ai (“conundrums”) were also “a fashionable amusement at Greek social gatherings” (Thompson on Meno 80 C), see for exx. Ar. Vesp. 1308 ff., Av. 804 ff.: cp. Rep. 487 E, Phaedo 87 B; Xen. Symp. VI. 8 ff.
e)pi\ ta\ geloio/tera. Sc. ou(/tws poih/sein, or the like: cp. 214 E.

toi=s silhnoi=s ktl. These were statuettes representing a Silenus playing a flute or pipe; the interiors were hollow and served as caskets to hold little figures of gods wrought in gold or other precious materials. But the precise fashion of their construction and how they opened (dixa/de dioixqe/ntes) is by no means clear. (1) Hug thinks they were made with a double door (dikli/des): similarly Stallb. and Hommel (“in contrariis Silenorum lateribus duobus duo foramina erant, quae epistomio quodam claudi poterant”). (2) Schulthess supposes that one section telescoped into the other (“Schiebt man sie auseinander, so erblickt man inwendig Götterbilder”). (3) Panofka, with Schleiermacher, supposes that the top came off like a lid. (4) Lastly, Rettig “denkt an ein Auseinandernehmen in zwei Hälfte,” though exactly how this differs from (3) he does not clearly explain. But—as Rettig himself observes—“mag es verschiedene Arten solche Gehäuse gegeben haben,” and in the absence of further evidence it would be rash to decide which of the possible patterns is here intended: the language (dixa/de dioixqe/ntes) rather favours the idea that the figures split into two, either horizontally or vertically—possibly, also, with a hinge. Cp. Synes. Ep. 153, p. 292 B w(/sper e)poi/oun *)aqh/nhsin oi( dhmiourgoi\ *)afrodi/thn kai\ *xa/ritas kai\ toiau=ta ka/llh qew=n a)ga/lmasi silhnw=n kai\ satu/rwn a)mpi/sxontes: Maximus comm. in Dion. Areop. de div. nom. c. ix. t. II. p. 201 f. (ed. Cord.) e)kei=noi ga\r oi(=a/ tinas a)ndria/ntas
e)poi/oun mh/te xei=ras mh/te po/das e)/xontas, ou(\s e(rma=s e)ka/loun: e)poi/oun de\ au)tou\s diake/nous, qu/ras e)/xontas, kaqa/per toixopurgi/skous: e)/swqen ou)=n au)tw=n e)ti/qesan a)ga/lmata w(=n e)/sebon qew=n ktl. (cp. Etym. Magn. s.v. a)rma/rion): Xen. Symp. IV. 19; Julian Or. VI. p. 187 A.
toi=s e(rmoglufei/ois. “The statuaries' shops,” apparently a a(/pac ei)r.: cp. Luc. Somn. 2. 7.
a)ga/lmata...qew=n. Cp. 222 A, Phaedrus 251 A.

fhmi\ au)= ktl. This second comparison arises out of the first, since the Satyr is himself akin to the Sileni: on the connexion between the two (as both originally horse-demons) see Harrison, Proleg. p. 388. Schol.: *marsu/as de\ au)lhth/s, *)olu/mpou ui(o/s, o(\s...h)/risen *)apo/llwni peri\ mousikh=s kai\ h(tth/qh, kai\ poinh\n de/dwke to\ de/rma darei/s, ktl.

to/ ge ei)=dos. For the Satyr-like ugliness of Socr., cp. Schol. ad Ar. Nub. 223 e)le/geto de\ o( *swkra/ths th\n o)/yin *seilh/nw| paremfai/nein: simo/s te ga\r kai\ falakro\s h)=n: Theaet. 143 E prose/oike de\ soi\ th/n te simo/thta kai\ to\ e)/cw tw=n o)mma/twn: ib. 209 B, Meno 80 A f.; Xen. Symp. IV. 19, V. 7.—dh/pou <a)/n> a)mfisb. (cp. Meno 72 C) is another possible order of words.

u(bristh\s ei)=. “You are a mocker” or “a bully” (Jowett): so too Agathon had said, in 175 E. For the present Alcib. forbears to enlarge on this Satyr-like quality, but he resumes the subject in 216 C ff., see esp. 219 C, 222 A. Observe also that Alcib. is here turning the tables on Socr., who had brought practically the same charge against A. in 213 C, D. Schleierm.'s rendering, “Bist du übermüthig, oder nicht?”, is based on a wrong punctuation.
ou)k au)lhth/s. I.e. (as Schol. B puts it) en h)/qei. e)kei/nou, sc. *marsu/ou.
*)/olumpos. For *)/olumpos o( *fru/c as ta\ paidika/ of Marsyas, cp. Minos 318 B; Paus. X. 30; also Laws 677 D, 790 D ff.; Arist. Pol. V. 5. 1340^{a} 8 ff.; Clem. Al. Strom. I. p. 307 C.

For kate/xesqai of “possession” (by supernal or infernal powers), cp. Meno 99 D, Phaedrus 244 E; Ion 533 E ff. (Rohde Psyche II. pp. 11, 18 ff., 48^{1}, 88). The orgiastic flute-music (having a cathartic effect parallel to that of tragedy) provided, as Aristotle explains, a kind of homoeopathic remedy for the fit of e)nqousiasmo/s.
M. le/gw pou, tou= d. I venture on this slight innovation: otherwise it were best, with Badham, to cut down the tou/tou to tou=.

dhloi=...deome/nous. Cp. the imitative passage in Minos 318 B kai\ mo/na kinei= kai\ e)kfai/nei tou\s tw=n qew=n e)n xrei/a| o)/ntas. qew=n deo/menoi is virtually equiv. to korubantiw=ntes (215 E); cp. Rohde Psyche II. 48^{1}. “mo/na=vorzugsweise. Vgl. Symp. 222 A” (Rettig).
yiloi=s lo/gois. I.e. “in prose,” devoid of metrical form as well as of musical accompaniment (a)/neu o)rga/nwn). Cp. Laws 669 D lo/gous y. ei)s me/tra tiqe/ntes: Menex. 239 C.
o(/tan me/n ktl. Observe the antitheses sou= )( tou a)/llou—tw=n sw=n lo/gwn )( a)/llous lo/gous—pa/nu fau=los...le/gwn )( panu\ a)gaqou= r(h/toros.
h)\...a)/llou le/gontos. A case in point is the Symposium itself, where Socrates' lo/goi are reported at second-hand.
e)a/n te gunh\ ktl. “No sex or age is impervious to the impression”—in antithesis to the preceding universal negative ou)deni/. For e)/kplhcis as a love-symptom, cp. Charm. 154 C.
komidh=|...mequ/ein. Schol. komidh=|: i)sodunamei=...tw=| sfo/dra kai\ tele/ws. Cp. 212 E.

ei)=pon o)mo/sas a)\n. “I would have stated on my oath,” i.e. I would not merely have described the facts, as I am about to do, but would have called Heaven to witness by a o(/rkos (cp. 183 A). Hommel supposes that Alcib. “rem silentio praeterire apud se constituit”; but this is confuted by the context. For a ref. to this passage, see Procl. in I. Alc. p. 89.

tw=n korubantiw/ntwn. Tim. korubantia=n: paremmai/nesqai kai\ e)nqousiastikw=s kinei=sqai: Schol. ad Ar. Vesp. 9 korubantia=n: to\ koru/basi kate/xesqai. Cp. Crito 54 D tau=ta...e)gw\ dokw= a)kou/ein, w(/sper oi( korubantiw=ntes tw=n au)lw=n
dokou=sin a)kou/ein: Ion 533 E, 536 C. Among the symptoms of korubantiasmo/s were the hearing of faery flute-notes, visions, hypnotic dreams, dance-motions etc. (see Rohde Psyche II. 47 ff.): cp. also Plut. adv. Colot. 1123 D.
h(/ te kardi/a phda=|. Cp. Ion 535 C, Phaedrus 251 C; Sappho 2. 5 to/ moi ma/n | kardi/an e)n sth/qesin e)pto/asen: Ar. Nub. 1393 oi)=mai/ ge tw=n newte/rwn ta\s kardi/as | phda=n o(/ti le/cei.
u(po\ tw=n l. t. tou/tou. Rettig seems right in arguing that a Glossator would be unlikely to write thus; and repetitions of this kind are characteristic of Alc.'s speech (cp. 221 D).

*perikleo/us de\ a)kou/wn. For the oratorical powers of Pericles, cp. Phaedrus 269 E, Meno 94 A, Menex. 235 E; Thuc. II. 65; Ar. Ach. 530 ff.; Cic. Brut. XI. 44, de or. III. 34; and esp. Eupolis *dh=moi (fr. 6. 34) kra/tistos ou(=tos (sc. *periklh=s) e)ge/net' a)nqrw/pwn le/gein | ...peiqw/ tis e)peka/qizen e)pi\ toi=s xei/lesin | ou(/tws e)kh/lei, kai\ mo/nos tw=n r(hto/rwn to\ ke/ntron e)gkate/leipe toi=s a)krowme/nois. Comparing this with our passage,—taken in conjunction with 213 D (nikw=nta e)n lo/gois pa/ntas a)nqrw/pous), 215 B (e)kh/lei tou\s a)nqrw/pous), 218 A (plhgei/s te kai\ dhxqei\s u(po\ tw=n...lo/gwn), 221 C (oi(=os au)= *periklh=s ktl.),—it seems probable that Plato has this passage of Eupolis in mind, and represents Alcib. as confuting Eupolis— as a return for the raillery he had suffered at the hands of E. in his *baptai/: cp. the story told in Cic. Att. VI. 1 that Alcib. got Eupolis drowned.
mou h( yuxh\. For this position of the genitive of the pronoun, which gives it nearly the force of an ethic dat., cp. Rep. 518 C, Phaedo 117 B (cp. Vahlen op. Acad. I. 440 ff.).
w(s a)ndrapodwdw=s d. Cp. Xen. Mem. IV. 2. 39: 210 D w(/sper oi)ke/ths... douleu/wn.
mh\ biwto\n. This echoes, by way of contrast, 211 D e)ntau=qa... biwto/n.
e)/xonti w(s e)/xw. Cp. w(=d' e)/xonti, 215 A.
ou)k...a)lhqh=. Notice these repeated protestations of veracity: cp. 214 E, 215 B (and see Introd. § II. A).
ou)k a)\n karterh/saimi. Contrast with this the karteri/a of Socr., 219 D, 220 A.

bi/a|...feu/gwn. “Invitus mihique ipsi vim inferens aufugio” (Rückert). Hommel wrongly takes bi/a| with e)pisxo/menos. bu/wn, the conjecture of Abresch, based on Hesych. (bu/wn ta\ w)=ta: e)pifra/ttwn) makes the order awkward and produces tautology. e)pisxo/menos ta\ w)=ta is the opposite of the foregoing pare/xein ta\ w)=ta: cp. Plut. Pomp. 55; Hor. Ep. II. 2. 105 obturem patulas impune legentibus aures; Acts vii. 57 sune/sxon ta\ w)=ta au)tw=n: Ps. lviii. 4, 5 (A.V.) “they are like the deaf adder that stoppeth her ear; which will not hearken to the voice of charmers, charming never so wisely.” For the *seirh=nes, cp. Hom. Od. XII. 39 ff., and see Harrison Proleg. pp. 197 ff.

au)tou=...para\ tou/tw| . au)tou= is not really “redundant” (as Ast)—“sitting still here beside him,” i.e. “müssig und entfernt von Staatsgeschaften” etc. (Rettig); cp. Ar. Ran. 1490 ff.; Apol. 31 C ff.
kataghra/sw. Perhaps a double entendre—A. implying that S.'s moralizings (“rumores senum severiorum”) would soon make an old man of him.
o(\ ou)k...e)nei=nai. This is a specimen of the naive candour which characterizes Alcib. throughout. For Alcib.'s self-assurance, cp. Xen. Mem. I. 2. 47.

h(tthme/nw|...pollw=n. “Me honori, quo me ornet populi multitudo, succumbere” (Stallb.). Cp. Rep. 359 A: Xen. Cyrop. III. 3. 2 h(/desqai th=| u(po\ pa/ntwn timh=|: Thuc. I. 130. 1. For the thought, cp. Rep. 491 C ff.
drapeteu/w. “I take to my heels,” like a runaway slave (drape/ths, Meno 97 E).
ta\ w(mologhme/na. I.e. the conclusions as to his own e)/ndeia forced upon him by S.; cp. 216 A a)nagka/zei...o(mologei=n.
polu\ mei=zon. So me/ga kh/detai Il. II. 26.
ou)k e)/xw o(/ ti xrh/swmai. Since Alcib. is here generalizing, the (dubitative) subj. seems preferable to the more definite fut., as Hommel argues against Stallb.

Alcib. is in the position of a “Dipsychus,” “halting between two opinions”
or rather two instincts. Cp. Soph. fr. 162. 8 ou(/tw ge tou\s e)rw=ntas au(to\s i(/meros | dra=n kai\ to\ mh\ dra=n polla/kis proi+/etai: Anacr. fr. 89 e)rw= te dhu)=te kou)k e)rw= | kai\ mai/nomai kou) mai/nomai.
oi(=s e)gw\ h)/|kasa au)to\n. Sc. toi=s silhnoi=s. h)/|kasa recals the di) ei)ko/nwn of 215 A.

ou)dei\s...gignw/skei. Plato may mean by this, as Hug suggests, that the majority of the admirers and followers of Socr. possessed a very dim insight into the sources of his real greatness—a)ll' e)gw\ (Plato, behind the mask of Alcib.) dhlw/sw.

e)rwtikw=s dia/keitai ktl. For Socrates as (professing to be) subject to intense erotic emotion, see the vivid description in Charm. 155 C ff. e)gw\ h)/dh h)po/roun, kai/ mou h( pro/sqen qrasu/ths e)ceke/kopto...kai\ e)fle/gomhn kai\ ou)ke/t' e)n e)mautou= h)=n ktl.

kai\ au)=...oi)=den. Most of the later critics (including Voeg., Teuffel, Hug) agree in ejecting this clause. Rettig, who defends it, writes: “die Worte gehen auf den vermeintlichen Stumpfsinn des S., wie er so häufig mit roher Sinnlichkeit verbunden ist...Die Worte ei)rwneuo/menos...diatelei= den obigen kai\ au)=...oi)=den gegensätzlich gegenüberstanden...Da nicht blos die Silene e)rwtikw=s dia/keintai ktl., so würde ohne unsere Worte die folgende Frage w(s to\ sxh=ma...ou) silhnw=des; kaum motivirt sein.” But (as generally interpreted) the clause seems hardly pertinent to the main argument, which is the contrast between the outward appearance of eroticism and the inner swfrosu/nh of Socr.: the clause ei)rwneuo/menos ktl. does nothing to strengthen the case for the reference to gnw=sis here; while there is no reason to suppose that professions of ignorance were specially characteristic of Sileni (in spite of the story of Midas and Silenus in Plut. ad Ap. de consol. 115 C (*seil.) ou)de
 e)/qelen ei)pei=n a)lla\ siwpa=n a)rrh/tws). If retained as it stands the clause is best taken closely with the previous words, as expressing an erotic symptom. [Possibly, however, for pa/nta we should read pa/ntas and for ou)de
, ou)de/n), taking the words as masc. (sc. tou\s kalou/s).] This implies of course that oi)=den bears the sense “agnoscit” (and a)gnoei= the opposite), for which cp. Eur. H. F. 1105 ff. e)/k toi pe/plhgmai...ti/s...du/sgnoian o(/stis th
 e)mh
 i)a/setai; safw=s ga ou)de
 oi)=da tw=n ei)wqo/twn: id. El. 767 e)/k toi dei/matos dusgnwsi/an | ei)=xon prosw/pou: nu=n de\ gignw/skw se dh/. (Cp. for this sense, Vahlen op. Ac. II. 63 f.)

w(s to\ sxh=ma au)tou=. “Which is the rôle he affects.” For this use of sxh=ma
of an acted part, cp. I. Alc. 135 D, Rep. 576 A: similarly sxhmati/zw, simulo, Phaedr. 255 A ou)x u(po\ sxhmatizome/nou tou= e)rw=ntos, a)ll' a)lhqw=s tou=to peponqo/tos. This is preferable to rendering by “forma et habitus,” as Stallb. The punctuation of the passage has been disputed: “vulgo enim legebatur kai\ ou)de
 oi)=den, w(s to\ sxh=ma au)tou= tou=to ou) seilhnw=des sfo/dra ge, quod Stephanus ita corrigebat ut pro ou) seilhnw=des scriberet o)
 seil.” (Stallb.): Stallb., Rückert, Badham, Schanz and Hug follow Bekk. and Schleierm. in putting a comma after oi)=den and a full stop after au)tou= (so too Hommel, but proposing ou)de/ for ou)de/n): Rettig follows Bernhardy in putting the full stop after tou=to, with a comma at oi)=den: Burnet puts a full stop at oi)=den, and no further stop before silhnw=des;: Ast proposed pw=s for w(s. Bast, reading pa/nth for pa/nta and ejecting kai\ ou)de
 oi)=den, construed w(s...sfo/dra ge/ as dependent on a)gnoei=: and Stephens's ou)de/ involves a similar construction.

peribe/blhtai. “Has donned” as it were a “cloak” of dissimulation: cp. Xen. Oec. II. 5 ei)s de\ to\ so\n sxh=ma o(\ su\ peribe/blhsai: Ps. cix. 18 “he clothed himself with cursing like as with his garment.”
e)/ndoqen de\ a)noixqei\s. Cp. 215 B: Soph. Antig. 709. The word e)/ndoqen recals Socrates' prayer in Phaedrus 279 B w)=...qeoi/, doi/hte/ moi kalw=| gene/sqai ta)ndo/qen.
i)/ste o(/ti ktl. For the general sense, cp. Charm. 154 B.
o(/son ou)d' a)\n ei(=s. Cp. 214 D.

plou/sios...timh\n e)/xwn. Stallb. renders “aut praeterea honore aliquo ornatus,” distinguishing timh/ from ka/llos and plou=tos; whereas Rückert states that “timh/ dicta est h. l. de re, quae honorem habet efficitque timi/a|, ita ut ka/llos et plou=tos etiam timai/ esse possint.” Rettig supports Stallb., but probably the other two a)gaqa/ are also classed in A.'s mind as ti/mia. Cp. 178 C, 216 B: Pind. fr. inc. 25.
tw=n...makarizome/nwn. Sc. timw=n.

kai\ h(ma=s ou)de\n ei)=nai. “h. e. atque nos, qui talia magni faciamus nullo in numero habendos censet” (Stallb.). This,—or Rückert's “nos ipsos qui pulcri, qui divites sumus,”—seems to bring out rightly the point of the personal reference; in spite of Rettig, who writes “vollig fremd ist der Platonischen Stelle der Zusatz, welchen Stallb. hier macht.” For this use of ou)de\n (=ou)deno\s a)ci/ous) cp. 219 A, 220 A. The attitude here ascribed to Socr. is very like that ascribed to his admirer Apollodorus in 173 C, D.

le/gw u(mi=n. There is no objection, at least in A.'s speech, to this kind of parenthetic interjection (cp. oi)/esqe, D above); cp. Apol. 30 A, Thuc. VI. 37. 2, Eur. Med. 226. Similarly in Gorg. 464 C, 526 C “asseverandi causa orator ad ea quae maxime attendi vult addit illa fhmi/, le/gw” (see Vahlen op. Acad. I. 479). I am, however, inclined to suspect that the words are misplaced, and originally stood after a)lla/, three lines lower down; if so, we should read a)lla/— le/gw u(mi=n—e)gw\ ktl., or perhaps a)lla\ a(\ le/gw u(mi=n e)gw\: this would serve to echo the a)ll' e)gw\ dhlw/sw of D ad init. Cp. also 222 B a(\ dh\ kai\ soi\ le/gw.
ei)rwneuo/menos. Schol. ei)rwn.: u(pokrino/menos, xleua/zwn. Cp. 218 D; Rep. 337 A au(/th e)kei/nh h( ei)wqui=a ei)rwnei/a *swkra/tous.

ta\ e)nto\s a)ga/lmata. See 215 A n.: a)/galma, as e)f' w(=| tis a)ga/lletai, can fitly be applied to spiritual as well as material treasures: cp. the use of i(ero/n in Eur. Hel. 1002. This passage is cited in Procl. in Alc. I. p. 89; Clem. Alex. Strom. VII. 5, p. 846 P.: cp. Cic. de Legg. I. 22 “ingeniumque in se suum sicut simulacrum aliquod dedicatum putabit.”

xrusa=. “Nur ein poetischer mit kalo/s synonymer Ausdruck” (Rettig); no doubt the material a)ga/lmata referred to were of gold or gilt, cp. Critias 116 D xrusa=...a)ga/lmata e)ne/sthsan . For the metaph. use, cp. Hipp. Mai. 301 A, Phaedrus 235 E fi/ltatos ei)= kai\ w(s a)lhqw=s xrusou=s: Gorg. 486 D xrush=n e)/xwn...th\n yuxh/n: and Shakspere's “Golden lads and lasses.”
e)/mbraxu. “In short,” used to qualify a universal statement expressed by a relative such as o(/stis: cp. Gorg. 457 A (with Heindorf ad loc.), Hipp. Min. 365 D; Ar. Vesp. 1120.

e)spoudake/nai e)pi\ ktl. Observe how this contrasts with the pai/zein of 216 E: A., we are to infer, had not as yet (at the date of the incident following) learnt the “irony” of Socr. With the attitude of Alcib. here cp. what Pausanias says in 184 B ff.
w(/ra| . w(/ra as flos aetatis is nearly equiv. to a)/nqos (183 E, 210 C): cp. 219 C, Phaedrus 234 A, I. Alc. 131 E ta\...sa\ lh/gei w(/ras, su\ d' a)/rxei a)nqei=n.
e)fro/noun ktl. For Alc.'s vanity, cp. I. Alc. 104 A.

ta)lhqh=...yeu/domai. Cp. 216 A, 214 E for similar protestations. Observe the effectiveness of this pause in the narration, and of the challenge to contradiction, as marking an approaching climax: cp. Phaedo 85 D.
e)n e)rhmi/a|. “Tête-à-tête”: cp. Rep. 604 A, Phaedrus 236 C e)sme\n...mo/nw e)n e)rhmi/a|.
a)/n...w)/xeto. If a)/n is right we must take it to denote repeated action, “solebat identidem discedere” (Stallb.): cp. Apol. 22 B (Madv. Gr. S. § 117 b, R. 3; L. and S. s.v. a)/n C).
sunhmereu/sas. The only other ex. in Plato is Phaedrus 240 C paidikoi=s... e)rasth\s...ei)s to\ sunhmereu/ein pa/ntwn a)hde/staton.
cuggumna/zesqai. For this practice, cp. 182 C, Menex. 236 D, Rep. 452 A ff.; and Xen. Symp. II. 16 ff., where Socr. treats of public and private gymnastics.
ou)de\n...ple/on h)=n. “Nihil enim proficiebam” (Stallb.): cp. 222 D.

e)peidh\ de\ ktl. Rettig supposes an allusion to Eur. Hipp. 390 ff. e)peidh\ toisi/d' ou)k e)ch/nuton *ku/prin | krath=sai, katqanei=n e)/doce/ moi. For other reff. to Eurip., see 177 A, 189 C, 196 E.

i)ste/on...pra=gma. Reynders is alone in approving of Wyttenbach's “restoration,” i)te/on h)/dh e)pi\ to\ pra=gma: for, as Rückert argues, this must imply either that A. had as yet made no “conamen alliciendi S.,” which is untrue, or that he had not as yet begun his narration, which is equally untrue. The sense of the text is “I must get to the bottom of the matter without more ado,” i.e. discover the real ground of Socrates' indifference. Cp. Apol. 20 C to\ so\n ti/ e)sti pra=gma;

prokalou=mai dh\ ktl. Here comes the third and most desperate expedient,
in which Alcib. reverses their respective rôles and acts towards Socr. no longer as paidika/ but as e)rasth/s (cp. 213 C, 222 B, and see Introd. § VI. 3). For three as a climacteric number cp. Phileb. 66 D, Euthyd. 277 C, Rep. 472 A. For e)pibouleu/wn, cp. 203 B, 203 D.

a)ei\...nuktw=n. “Usque ad multam noctem” (Stallb.). For this force of a)ei/, cp. a)ei\ dia\ tou= bi/ou Phaedo 75 B, etc.; so with po/rrw, Gorg. 486 A tou\s po/rrw a)ei\ filosofi/as e)lau/nontas. For the plural nu/ktes, “night-watches,” cp. 223 C, Prot. 310 C po/rrw tw=n nuktw=n: Phileb. 50 D.
e)n th=|...kli/nh| . e)mou= is short for th=s e)mh=s (or e)mou=) kli/nhs: cp. the similar brachylogy in 214 C: Hom. Od. VI. 308.
oi)kh/mati. “Room”: cp. Prot. 315 D, Phaedo 116 A.
me/xri...deu=ro. So Laws 814 D th=s...duna/mews to\ me/xri deu=ro h(mi=n ei)rh/sqw.
kai\ pro\s o(ntinou=n le/gein. This reminds one of Diotima's language in 209 E ff. (tau=ta me\n ou)=n ktl.).

to\ lego/menon ktl. Photius explains thus: oi)=nos a)/neu pai/dwn du/o paroimi/ai: h( me\n oi)=nos kai\ a)lh/qeia, h( de\ oi)=nos kai\ pai=des a)lhqei=s. For the first of these, cp. Alcaeus fr. 57 B, Theocr. Id. XXIX. 1. We might render “In wine and wean is candour seen.” Cp. Schol. ad h. l.; Athen. II. 37 E *filo/xoros de/ fhsin o(/ti oi( pi/nontes ou) mo/non e(autou\s e)mfani/zousin oi(/tine/s ei)sin, a)lla\ kai\ tw=n a)/llwn e(/kaston a)nakalu/ptousi, parrhsi/an a)/gontes. o(/qen “oi)=nos kai\ a)lh/qeia” le/getai: Alcaeus fr. 53 oi)=nos ga\r a)nqrw/pois di/optron: Hor. Sat. I. 4. 89 condita cum verax aperit praecordia Liber. Similar sayings about the effects of wine are Ar. Plut. 1048 mequ/wn o)cu/teron ble/pei: Theogn. 479 ff. oi)=nos...kou=fon e)/qhke no/on. The explanations of H. Müller (“Trunkene sagten die Wahrheit, mochten Diener zugegen sein oder nicht”) and of Hommel (“si proverbio illo vinum, quod neque praesentiam neque absentiam servorum curat (alluding to the a)ko/louqos of 217 A), non esset veridicum”) are clearly wrong. Cp. Xen. Symp. VIII. 24.

a)fani/sai. “To keep dark”: notice the play a)fani/sai...fai/netai, which Lehrs represents by “eine helle That des S. ins Dunkle zu setzen.” fai/netai after the impf. h)=n is one of Alc.'s anacolutha.

u(perh/fanon. The adj. here, though prima facie eulogistic, evidently contains (as Rückert notes) “grata quaedam ambiguitas,” as alluding to the u(/bris of Socr., cp. the use of u(perhfani/a to denote “superbia cum contemtione coniuncta” (Ast) in 219 C. For the good sense of the word, cp. Phaedo 96 A, Gorg. 511 D.

to\ tou= dhxqe/ntos ktl. For this proverbial case, cp. Aristides or. 15, I. p. 234 w(/sper to\n u(po\ th=s e)xi/dnhs fasi\ plhge/nta mh\ e)qe/lein e(te/rw| le/gein a)ll' h)\ o(/stis pepei/ratai: id. or. 49, II. p. 395: Xen. Symp. IV. 28 w(/sper u(po\ qhri/ou tino\s dedhgme/nos...e)n th=| kardi/a| w(/sper knh=sma/ ti e)do/koun e)/xein: id. Mem. I. 3. 12 ff. e)ni/hsi ga/r ti ta\ fala/ggia kata\ to\ dh=gma...w(/ste mai/nesqai poiei=n. This last passage refers to the “bite of love,” for which cp. Soph. fr. 721 e)/rwtos dh=gma: Socrates (Bergk P. L. G. II. p. 288) po/qw| dhxqei/s. Rückert is no doubt right in holding that there is allusion here “ad certam fabellam, nobis licet ignotam.” Cp. also Aesch. Cho. 996.

pa=n...le/gein. “Alii de remediis totoque curationis genere (haec) verba intelligunt, alii de motibus, gestibus furibundis, dictisque quae doloris magnitudo elicuerit, sanis hominibus nil nisi risum moturis” (Rückert). The former of these views is adopted by Stallb. and Rettig (who takes the phrase to refer to the superstitious use of charms, amulets, etc.), the latter by Hommel. The phrase recals 182 E qaumasta\ e)/rga...tolmw/h| poiei=n: 208 D pa/nta poiou=sin: cp. Rep. 576 A. It seems best here to interpret it broadly of the results of the dh=gma, whether or not directly aiming at a cure: i.e. as covering both the senses indicated above.
to\ a)lgeino/taton. “In my most sensitive part.”

th
 kardi/an. Schol. B, o(/ti th
 kardi/an (kardi/an th
 Herm.) yuxh
 kalei=. This implies—as Usener inferred—that the words h)\ yuxh
 were absent from the Scholiast's text: none the less, in view of the context, I think it rash to expunge the words, and content myself with obelizing ga/r. For h)\ o(/ti ktl., cp. 212 C.
u(po\ tw=n...lo/gwn. Cp. 210 D lo/gous...e)n filosofi/a| a)fqo/nw|. For plhgei/s, cp. Euthyd. 303 A w(/sper plhgei\s u(po\ tou= lo/gou a)/fwnos e)kei/mhn: Epist. vii. 347 D.
ne/ou yuxh=s. Rost, removing the comma before ne/ou, connected n. yuxh=s with e)/xontai, wrongly: for e)/xesqai without a genitive, cp. Gorg. 494 E.
Observe the word-play e)/x-ontai e)x-i/dnhs.
mh\ a)fuou=s. Cp. 209 B yuxh=|...eu)fuei=.
*fai/drous ktl. For a similar (generalizing) use of the plural of proper names, cp. Menex. 245 D, Ar. Ran. 1040 ff., Av. 558 f.
suggnw/sesqe. This echoes the suggnwsome/nois of 218 A supra.
oi( de\ oi)ke/tai. This echoes Diotima's w(/sper oi)ke/ths, 210 D ad init.: cp. Ar. Ach. 242, Ran. 41 for the nomin. of address.

be/bhlo/s. Cp. Schol. Aristid. III. p. 471 e)/sti de\ kh/rugma mustiko\n to\ “qu/ras... be/bhloi,” w(/s pou kai\ *)orfeu\s dhloi= “fqe/gcomai oi(=s qe/mis e)sti/: qu/ras d' e)pi/qesqe be/bhloi”: Tim. be/bhloi: a)mu/htoi. Alcib.'s language, like Diotima's, is suggestive of mystery-lore: cp. Theaet. 155 E; Eur. Bacch. 70 ff., 472; Horace's “odi profanum volgus et arceo.”
pu/las...toi=s w)si\n. Cp. Theogn. 421 polloi=s a)nqrw/pwn glw/ssh| qu/rai ou)k e)pi/keintai | a(rmo/diai.
o(/ te lu/xnos a)pesbh/kei. Cp. Ar. Plut. 668 w(s de\ tou\s lu/xnous a)posbe/sas... e)gkaqeu/dein: Juv. IX. 104, Hor. C. III. 6. 28.

poiki/llein. “Artificiose, h. e. obscure vel ambigue loqui” (Ast): “to beat about the bush.” Cp. the use of poiki/los in 182 B: Laws 863 E to/ te di/kaion kai\ to\ a)/dikon...safw=s a)\n diorisai/mhn ou)de\n poiki/llwn: Soph. Trach. 421, 1121.

e)leuqe/rws ei)pei=n. Cp. Pind. Nem. IX. 49 qarsale/a de\ para\ krath=ri fwna\ gi/netai. Notice the word-play e)/doce...e)do/kei. For kinh/sas, cp. Rep. 329 D boulo/menos e)/ti le/gein au)to\n e)ki/noun kai\ ei)=pon ktl.

e)mou=...a)/cios. Whether e)mou= goes closely with e)rasth\s or with a)/cios is open to doubt: Jowett renders “the only one who is worthy of me,” whereas Rettig writes “a)/cios absolut=würdig, beachtenswerth.”
o)knei=n ktl. “To be shy of mentioning (your love) to me”: cp. I. Alc. 103 A oi)=mai/ se qauma/zein o(/ti prw=tos e)rasth/s sou geno/menos...tosou/twn e)tw=n ou)de\ prosei=pon.
th=s ou)si/as...tw=n fi/lwn. Cp. 183 A h)\ xrh/mata...u(po\ fi/lwn. For h)\ tw=n fi/lwn =h)\ th=s tw=n fi/lwn, cp. the brachylogy in 217 D (e)mou=).
