presbu/teron. Poll. II. 12 kai\ presbeu/ein to\ tima=n para\ *pla/twni kai\ to\ “ou)de/n e)sti presbu/teron” a)nti\ tou= “ou)de\n timiw/teron”: 186 B, 188 C supra.

sullh/ptora. For the e)rasth/s as an aid to a)reth/, see 185 A; cp. Socrates' description of Eros as sunergo/s, 212 B. moi was taken by Stallb. with sullh/ptora, by Rückert with ei)=nai, but it is better to say with Hommel that, as an ethic dat., “ad totum verborum complexum refertur.”
kuriw/teron. “More competent”: cp. Theaet. 161 D.

tou\s froni/mous...a)/fronas. Compare the similar aristocratic sentiment of Agathon, 194 B. It is worth noticing that whereas Pausanias had spoken of those who disapprove of xari/zesqai as tine/s, here they are termed oi( polloi/. Cp. Xen. Mem. I. 6. 13. Similarly Browne, Rel. Med. “This noble affection falls not on vulgar and common constitutions.”
sfo/dra e(autou=. “Very characteristically”: cp. “suum illud est” Cic. Tusc. I. 42. 99.

ou) fau=los. “Kein Dummkopf” (Hug); cp. 174 C, 175 E. Socr. means that if Alcib. proposes to make such a profitable bargain, bartering his own cheap ka/llos for the rare ka/llos of Socr., he evidently is a “cute” man of
business. Cp. Diog. L. III. 63 o( gou=n fau=los le/getai par' au)tw=| (sc. Platoni) kai\ e)pi\ tou= a(plou=, w(s kai\ par' *eu)ripi/dh| e)n *likumni/w| ktl. (see Eurip. fr. 476 N. fau=lon, a)/komyon, ta\ me/gist' a)gaqo/n ktl.).

a)mh/xano/n ktl. Supply from the context, with Stallb., “nam hoc ita si sit.” Rückert, after Schleierm., wrongly connects this clause with the preceding, “qua fiat, ut tu melior evadas, atque exinde immensam in me pulcritudinem cernas”; while Hommel makes it depend upon ei)/per. Cp. Rep. 509 B, 608 D; Charm. 155 D.
eu)morfi/as. For the notion of a beauty-competition here suggested, cp. Xen. Symp. V. 1. Cp. also the sofi/a-match of 175 E.
a)nti\ do/chs a)lh/qeian k. “Real for sham beauties”: a)lh/qeian kalw=n=a)lh/qina kala/. Cp. Phileb. 36 C ff.; and for the antithesis, cp. 198 E, 212 A supra.

xru/sea xalkei/wn. A “familiar quotation” from Il. VI. 235—6 (*glau=kos) o(\s pro\s *tudei/dhn *diomh/dea teu/xe) a)/meiben | xru/sea xalkei/wn, e(kato/mboi) e)nneaboi/wn. Later reff. to the proverb are frequent, e.g. Plut. adv. Stoic. 1063 E; Clem. Alex. Cohort. ad Gent. 71 C. Cp. Winter's Tale I. 2 “take eggs for money.” In xru/sea there is an obvious allusion to the a)ga/lmata xrusa= of 216 E.

h(/ toi...o)/yis. For this idea of the inverse development of vision, cp. Laws 715 D, II. Alc. 150 D. Rettig thinks that in this passage there may lie a ref. to Phaedrus 253 D ff., and an indication that the views there put forward are crude and the book itself “eine jugendliche Schrift.”

e)n ga\r tw=| ktl. Thus Socr. practically defers the consideration of the matter to “the Greek Kalends.” Rettig calls attention to the catalectic hexameter in e)n ga\r...bouleuo/menoi, which gives a touch of jocular liveliness.

a)fei\s w(/sper be/lh. Sc. tou\s lo/gous. For this image applied to “winged words,” cp. the use of balw/n 189 B; Phileb. 23 B be/lh e)/xein e(/tera tw=n e)/mprosqen lo/gwn: Theaet. 180 A; Pind. Ol. I. 112.
tetrw=sqai. “I thought I had winged him.” Cp. Theogn. 1287 a)lla/ s' e)gw\ trw/sw feu/gonta/ per: and the description of Eros as qhreuth\s deino/s, 203 D.

tri/bwna. Cp. Prot. 335 D; Ar. Ach. 184, etc. The vogue of the “philosopher's cloak” (pallium) seems to date from Socrates: cp. Plut. de disc. ad. 56 C. For the incident, see also Lysias in Alcib. XIV. 25 (Teichmüller Litt. F. II. 267 ff.); Theocr. Id. XVIII. 19; cp. Theogn. 1063 ff. e)n d' h(/bh| pa/ra me\n cu\n o(mh/liki kal li=q' eu(/dein | i(mertw=n e)/rgwn e)c e)/ron i(e/menon. Notice the stylistic effect produced both by the row of successive participles, mostly asyndetic (“der Sturmlauf ist vergeblich” Rettig); and by the repetition of the pronoun (tou/tw|, -ton, -toui/, -tw|, ou(=tos). “Forsan haec illustrat Soph. Trach. 944. Respexit Alciphron I. 38” (Wyttenb.).
daimoni/w|. Cp. 202 D.
kai\ ou)de\ tau=ta ktl. Alcib.'s fourth appeal to Socr. for confirmation, cp. 217 B.

tosou=ton. “Dictum est deiktikw=s et per quandam exclamationem ut significet: mirum quantum me vicit” (Stallb.): Rückert and Hommel, on the other hand, suppose that “sequi debebat w(/ste” so as to give the sense “ut non aliter ab eo surrexerim,” etc. (Rückert), or w(/ste kai\ katafronh=sai ktl. (Hommel). Rückert's view, which explains the change of construction as due to the intervening parenthesis, seems the most probable.
periege/neto/ ktl. Alcib. is fond of piling up synonyms by way of emphasis; cp. 207 A, 219 D, 221 E.
u(/brise . u(/bris is a vox propria in erotic literature for the “spretae iniuria formae”; cp. Anthol. Pal. V. 213 ou)k oi)/sw ta\n a)pa/laistron u(/brin.

Anacreon fr. 129 u(bristai\ kai\ a)ta/sqaloi (*)anakre/wn a)peilei= toi=s *)/erwsin... e)peidh/per e(w/ra to\n e)/fhbon o)li/gon au)tou= fronti/zonta...ei) mh\ au)tw=| titrw/skoien
au)ti/ka to\n e)/fhbon ktl.). Cp. Spenser's, “Thou hast enfrosen her disdainefull brest,” and “Whilst thou tyrant Love doest laugh and scorne At their complaints, making their paine thy play, Whylest they lie languishing like thrals forlorne” (cp. katadedoulwme/nos 219 E below).
kai\ peri\ e)kei=no <o> ge ktl. So I have ventured to write on the strength of the evidence of the Papyrus.

Rettig keeps the Bodleian kei=no, as tolerable “in hac Alcibiadis oratione singularia amantis,” and refers to Poppo ad Thuc. VIII. 86, Lob. ad Phryn. p. 7, and other authorities: but to bolster up the double anomaly “vain is the strength of man”: if kei=no be retained we must assume prodelision ()kei=no).
ti\ ei)=nai. “Magni quid esse” (Rückert): cp. Gorg. 472 A: it is the opposite of ou)de\n ei)=nai, 216 E, 219 A.

dikastai\. Alcib. appeals to the audience to try the case, the notion of a lawsuit (grafh\ u(/brews) having been suggested by the word u(/brisen. We have already had, in this speech, terms suggestive of legal proceedings, viz. 214 D timwrh/swmai u(mw=n e)nanti/on: 215 B ma/rturas pare/comai: and dikasth/s itself was already used by Agathon in 175 E.
ma\ qeou/s, ma\ qea/s. Such an invocation of the whole pantheon is unusual, but cp. Tim. 27 C.
ou)de\n peritto/teron. Haud aliter, cp. Isocr. III. 43.
katadedarqhkw\s. Cp. 223 C, Apol. 40 D. For the incident cp. Petron. 128 non tam intactus Alcibiades in praeceptoris sui lecto iacuit: Lucian vit. auct. 15; Corn. Nep. Alcib. c. ii.

ti/na...dia/noian. A.'s feelings were a blend of chagrin and veneration: cp. the perplexity described in 216 C; Theogn. 1091 ff. a)rgale/ws moi qumo\s e)/xei peri\ sh=s filo/thtos: | ou)/te ga\r e)xqai/rein ou)/te filei=n du/namai, ktl.
h)tima/sqai. Cp. Theogn. 1313 e)mh\n de\ meqh=kas a)ti/mhton filo/thta.
a)ga/menon. This is an echo, both of Phaedrus's language in 179 C, 180 A, and of a)gasto/s applied to Eros (197 D). Observe the assonance h(gou/menon... a)ga/menon. Cp. Xen. Symp. VIII. 8.

th\n tou/tou fu/sin ktl. Hommel renders “des Mannes ganzem Wesen besonders seiner Besonnenheit und Charakterfestigkeit” etc.; Rettig explains fu/sis as “die geistige Naturanlage des S., seine theoretische und spekulative Begabung, ingenium, sofi/a (vgl. Theaet. 144 A).” The former seems the more natural interpretation; fu/sis may be intended also as an echo of Aristophanes' use of the word (189 D etc.).

fro/nhsin...karteri/an . “fro/nhsis verbunden mit karteri/a ist doch nichts Anderes als die Auflösung des Begriffs der swfrosu/nh in seine beiden Bestandtheile. Vgl. Pol. IV. 430 E, Phädr. 237 E, Krat. 411 E” (Rettig).
ou)/q)...ei)=xon. Of moral impossibility, as in 190 C, Phaedrus 241 A.
a)/trwtos. “Invulnerable on all sides”: cp. tetrw=sqai 219 B. For the incorruptibility of Socr., shown by his sending back Alcib.'s presents, see Stob. Flor. XVII. 17, Ael. v. h. IX. 29.
sidh/rw| o( *ai)/as. For the impregnable seven-fold shield of Ajax, see Pind. Isthm. V. 45; Soph. Aj. 576; Welcker Kl. Schr. II. p. 267.
w(=| te w)/|mhn. Sc. th=| w(/ra| (cp. 219 C): the antecedent, kata\ tou=to (diapef.), has to be supplied.
katadedoulwme/nos. Cp. Euthyd. 303 C. Above, 215 E, we had a)ndrapodwdw=s diakei/menos.
perih=|a. “I wandered about,” suggestive of aimless despair: cp. Prot. 348 D, Rep. 620 C: so peritre/xwn 173 A.

stratei/a...koinh=|. Potidaea revolted from Athens in 435 B.C. and after 5 years of war was reduced in 430 (see Bury's Hist. Gr. pp. 392—3): Socr.'s part in the campaign is alluded to also in Apol. 28 E, Charm. 153 A, C: cp. Plut. adv. Colot. p. 1117 E.
sunesitou=men. “We were mess-mates” (su/ssitoi). This implies personal friendship rather than proximity of origin; for Socr. and Alcib. belonged to different fulai/ and to different ta/ceis.
toi=s po/nois. Cp. 197 E (*)/erws) e)n po/nw|...a)/ristos.
a)polhfqe/ntes. “Cut off,” “a commeatu intercepti et prohibiti” (Stallb.): cp. Hdt. II. 115. 2; Thuc. VI. 22; Gorg. 522 A.
oi(=a dh\ ktl. Sc. filei= gi/gnesqai, or the like; cp. Rep. 467 B oi(=a dh\ e)n pole/mw| filei= (sc. gi/gnesqai); Euthyd. 272 A.
ou)de\n h)=san...pro\s ktl. Cp. 195 D oi(=os h)=n...pro\s ktl., and 216 E ou)de\n ei)=nai.
eu)wxi/ais. Cp. Laws 666 B e)n toi=s sussiti/ois eu)wxhqe/nta: 203 B supra.

ta/ t) a)/lla ktl. The construction is loose; we may either explain it (with Stallb.) as a brachylogy for ta/ t' a)/lla kai\ dh\ kai\ tou=to o(/ti...e)kra/tei, or say (with Wolf) that e)kra/tei is carelessly put for kratw=n. Hug construes pi/nein closely with a)nagkasqei/h, marking ou)k e)qe/lwn as a parenthesis; but it is simpler to regard pi/nein as a kind of accus. of respect (“at drinking”) with e)kra/tei. For the a)na/gkh of the “symposiarch's” ruling cp. 176 A, 223 B.

e(w/raken. The plpf. e(wra/kei (in spite of Rettig, etc.) is inconsistent with pw/pote. For Socr.'s invincibility in carousals, see 176 C, 214 A, 223 C; and cp. Theogn. 491 a)ni/khtos de/ toi ou(=tos | o(\s polla\s pi/nwn mh/ ti ma/taion e)rei=.
au)ti/ka...e)/sesqai. I.e. we shall have proof, before the night is over, of Socr.'s karteri/a in this regard.
deinoi\...xeimw=nes. Cp. Thuc. II. 70 o(rw=ntes me\n th=s stratia=s th\n talaipwri/an e)n xwri/w| xeimerinw=|: Aesch. Pers. 495 ff.
qauma/sia ei)rga/zeto. An echo of 182 E and 213 D.
oi(/ou deinota/tou. I.e. toiou/tou oi(=os deino/tato/s e)stin: cp. Apol. 23 A (Madv. Gr. S. § 96. 1).
pi/lous. Schol. pi=los: i(ma/tion e)c e)ri/ou pilh/sews gino/menon, ei)s u(etw=n kai\ xeimw/nwn a)/munan. Cp. Laws 942 D; Hes. Op. 541 ff. “Had their feet swathed in felt and fleeces” (Jowett).
a)rnaki/das. Schol. a)rnaki/des de\ a)rnw=n kw/dia: Suid. a)rnaki/s: to\ tou= a)rno\s kw/dion, to\ meta\ tw=n e)ri/wn de/rma. Cp. Themist. or. IV. 50 B.

i(ma/tion...forei=n. Cp. 220 A n.; Xen. Mem. I. 2. 1, 6. 2 kai\ i(ma/tion h)mfi/esai ou) mo/non fau=lon a)lla\ to\ au)to\ qe/rous te kai\ xeimw=nos, a)nupo/dhtos de\ kai\ a)xi/twn diatelei=s. For a)nupo/dhtos, see also 174 A, 203 D.

u(pe/blepon. “Looked askance (suspiciously) at him,” i.e. “quippe quem ipsos despicere opinarentur” (Stallb.>. Cp. Eryx. 395 A u(poble/yas...w(/sper ti a)dikou/menos: Crito 53 B u(poble/yontai/ se diafqore/a h(gou/menoi tw=n no/mwn.
*kai\ tau=ta...tau=ta. For this formula of transition, dismissing the subject, cp. Laws 676 A.
oi(=on d) au)=...a)nh\r. From Hom. Od. IV. 242, with the slight alteration oi(=on d' au)= for a)ll' oi(=on: there it is spoken by Helen in describing Odysseus.

cunnoh/sas. Rettig holds that the following section is an illustration of the “spekulative Begabung” (fu/sis 219 D) of Socr.; but it describes, primarily, another phase of his karteri/a. For S.'s habit of thought-immersion, cp. 174 E ff., Gell. N. A. II. 1; similarly, in Indian gymnosophists, Plin. H. N. VII. 2. 22. The similar incident in 174 E ff. is there construed by Agathon as a symptom of sofi/a (see 175 C—D).

*)iw/nwn. Rückert comments “Iones illo tempore sub Atheniensium ditione erant, unaque militabant”; but most recent editors suspect corruption after Mehler (ad Xen. Symp. p. 75) “Neque fuere eorum in ordinibus, neque Platonis haec sunt verba.” To Mehler's restoration, tw=n new=n, Rettig objects that “den Athenern gleichviel ob jung oder alt diese Weise des Sokrates kaum auffallend war, da man ihn genugsam kannte”; while in favour of his own conj. *paio/nwn, he cites Thuc. I. 59, 61, etc. But I agree with Usener (Rhein. Mus. LIII. p. 372) that *)iw/nwn may well be genuine.
xameu/nia. tapeina\ klini/dia (Schol.); ta\ e)pi\ th=s gh=s strwnnu/mena (Tim.): cp. (Eros) xamaipeth/s, 203 D: Hipponax 67 e)n staqmi/w| te kai\ xameuni/w| gumno/n.

proseuca/menos tw=| h(li/w|. Hesiod (Op. 339) prescribes prayer at sunrise and sunset; cp. Laws 887 E, 966 D; Soph. O. C. 477; Ar. Plut. 771 kai\ proskunw= ge prw=ta me
 to
 h(/lion. The suggestion here may be that the Sun-god (Phoebus, the revealer, “the light of the world”) brings mental illumination, and that Socr.'s eu)xh/ was in part a thanksgiving therefor. As a parallel to Socr., we may refer to “the devotion of Orpheus to Helios” as pointed out in Harrison Proleg. p. 462. Moreover, Socr. regarded Apollo as his special patron-god, see Apol. 39 D ff., Phaedo 85 B, Tim. 40 A (Adam, R. T. G. pp. 325, 434 ff.): and the sun is the symbol of ideal Good, see Rep. 530 A, Phileb. 28 D. For the content of a Socratic prayer, see Phaedrus 279 B—C; Xen. Mem. I. 3. 2 hu)/xeto de\ pro\s tou\s qeou\s a(plw=s ta)gaqa\ dido/nai. Of prayers to Helios we have exx. in Soph. Aj. 845 ff.; id. fr. 772 *)he/lios oi)ktei/reie/ me | o(
 sofoi\ le/gousi gennhth
 qew=n | kai\ pate/ra pa/ntwn.
*ei) de\ bou/lesqe. Sc. a)kou=sai oi(=os h)=n, or the like; cp. 177 B. Alcib. here passes on to treat of the a)ndrei/a of Socr.
a)podou=nai. “Tanquam debitum persolvere” (Stallb.).
h( ma/xh. “Illa pugna (omnibus nota)” (Rückert); i.e. the fight (in 432 B.C.) which preceded the blockade of Potidaea, cp. 219 E n., Thuc. I. 62 ff., II. 2.
e)/swsen. With this, and sundie/swsen below, cp. Eros as swth\r a)/ristos, 197 E.

ou)k e)qe/lwn a)polipei=n. This passage echoes the language of Phaedrus in 179 A: e)gkatalipei=n ge ta\ paidika\ ktl., and o(/pla a)pobalw/n. To rescue a man's arms was to save him from the disgrace attaching to o(/plwn a)pobolh/.
ou)/te me/myh|. Here for the fifth time Alcib. challenges Socr. to contradict him (cf. 219 C): for me/mfomai, cp. 213 E.
a)ci/wma. “Social standing”: “erat genere Alcmaeonida...ipse Periclis in tutela erat” (Rückert). Cp. I. Alc. 104 B; Thuc. II. 37, V. 43, etc.

h)/ sauto/n. We should expect ma=llon h)\ au)to/s, but the accus. is put in order to balance e)me\, “propter oppositionis gravitatem” (Stallb.). For the omission of ma=llon after words “denoting a wish or choice,” see Madv. Gr. S. § 93 c.
a)po\ *dhli/ou. For this famous battle in Boeotia (424 B.C.), when the Athenians under Hippocrates were routed by the Thebans under Pagondas, see Thuc. IV. 76 ff., Bury's Hist. Gr. pp. 442—3.
kai\ *la/xhs. Cp. Lach. 181 B. Athenaeus (V. 329 ff.) perversely contends that Socr. took part in no battle.
peritugxa/nw. Cp. Hermann on Ar. Nub. 196, “e)pitugxa/nein dicitur qui quaerit, peritugx. qui non quaerens in aliquid incidit.”
ka/llion e)qeasa/mhn. “I got a finer view of”: cp. Rep. 467 E e)f' i(/ppwn... ka/llista/ te qea/sontai...kai\ a)sfale/stata ktl.
e)n fo/bw|. Cp. 197 D.
e)/mfrwn. “Cool,” “collected”; cp. Ion 535 B po/teron e)/mfrwn ei)=, h)\ e)/cw sautou= gi/gnei; Laws 791 B a)nti\ manikw=n...e(/ceis e)/mfronas e)/xein.

to\ so\n dh\ tou=to. An accus. absol., like to\ lego/menon: “ut tuo illo utar” (Stallb.). Cp. Soph. 233 B, Euthyd. 284 C (with Schanz, nov. comm. pp. 76 f.). The ref. is to Ar. Nub. 362 o(/ti brenqu/ei t' e)n tai=sin o(doi=s kai\ tw)fqa/lmw paraba/lleis. The Clouds was not produced until the year after the battle of Delium, viz. 423 B.C.

brenquo/menos. “Stalking like a pelican” (Jowett): Schol. ad Nub. 362 brenqu/ei: a)posemnu/neis seauto\n e)n tw=| sxh/mati kai\ taurhdo\n o(ra=|s: kompa/zeis kai\ u(peroptikw=s badi/zeis: cp. Schol. ad Pax 25, ad Lysist. 887. “Nimirum ductum est verbum a bre/nqos, quod significat avem aquaticam, frequenter ad paludes commorantem altisque pedibus incedentem” (Stallb.).

tw)fqalmw\ paraba/llwn. “H. e. torno vultu oculos in obliquum vertens”
(Stallb.). Rettig objects that this rendering is inconsistent with h)re/ma fili/ous, and explains by “oculis prope admotis intueri, also scharf ansehen,” cp. Phaedo 103 A, Rep. 531 A. Ast gives “oculos in aliquid immotos habere intentos”: Reynders, to\ ble/mma a)/nw kai\ ka/tw kinei=n: Jowett, “rolling his eyes.”

h)re/ma paraskopw=n. This verb is a(/p. ei)r. in Plato, and perhaps conveys a literary allusion: Rückert explains it to mean “oculis quasi comitari, observare, ut omnes motus lento oculorum motu notare videaris.”
dh=los...po/rrwqen. “Similiter Apollodorus, qui Socratis incessum imitatus est, tw=n ou)=n...po/rrwqen e)ka/lesen ktl.” (Hommel).

o( e(tai=ros. So Jahn, after Aristides t. II. p. 72: the more definite term is preferable, as Rettig argues against Teuffel. For confusion of the two words in the codd., cp. 183 C (crit. n.), and see Schanz, nov. comm. p. 59.

protropa/dhn. “In headlong rout”—an Epic (Il. XVI. 304) word, a(/p. ei)r. in Plato. For the sense, cp. Tyrt. 11. 11—13 oi(\ me\n ga\r tolmw=si... pauro/teroi qnh/|skousi ktl.: Seneca, Ep. 94 audentes fortuna iuvat (see Bergk, ad Simon. fr. 227): Il. V. 531 f. ai)dome/nwn d' a)ndrw=n ple/ones so/oi h)e\ pe/fantai: | feugo/ntwn d' ou)/t' a)\r kle/os o)/rnutai ou)/te tis a)lkh/: ib. XV. 561 ff.
*polla\...kai\ a)/lla ktl. Cp. 195 B, 201 D. Hirschig's qauma/sai gives us (as Rettig argues) “einen matten Gedanken.”
qau/matos. “Of wonder” (the subjective feeling), cp. Phileb. 36 D, Laws 967 A: elsewhere in Plato qau=ma means “quod mirum est.”
oi(=os ga\r ktl. For Achilles, see Od. IV. 267 ff.; and cp. 179 E f.
*brasi/dan. For this famous Spartan leader, who fell fighting at Amphipolis in 422 B.C., see Thuc. II. 25, 85 ff., V. 6; Bury, Hist. Gr. pp. 445 ff.
*periklh=s. See 215 E n., Gorg. 515 C ff., 519 A.

*ne/stora kai\ *)anth/nora. Comparable to Pericles on the ground of eloquence (cp. 215 E, Pericles as a)gaqo\s r(h/twr). For Nestor, see Hom. Il. I. 247 ff.; for Antenor, Il. VII. 347 ff.; Hor. Ep. I. 2. 9.
th\n a)topi/an. “Originalität” (Wolf): see 215 A n.
a)nqrw/pwn me\n ktl. See 215 A, B, 216 E.
pagge/loioi. Cp. 189 B, 215 A; the context shows that -ge/loios here is nearly equiv. to katage/lastos. Of Socr., as of S. Paul, it was said that “his speech was contemptible.”
o)no/mata kai\ r(h/mata. See 198 B n.
e)/cwqen periampe/xontai. Cp. 216 B e)/cwqen peribe/blhtai.
satu/rou [a)\n] tina\. Stallb. vainly argues in a long note “a)/n tenendum et per ellipsin verbi (i.e. ou)=san) explicandum esse.”
u(bristou=. Cp. 215 B, 175 E. In dora/n, the satyr's “hide,” there is an allusion, no doubt, to the flaying of Marsyas by Apollo.

o)/nous ga\r ktl. “His talk is of pack-asses and smiths and cobblers and curriers” (Jowett). Schol. kanqhli/ous: tou\s bradei=s noh=sai h)\ a)fuei=s. a)po\ ka/nqwnos, o(/s e)stin o)/nos, ei)rhme/noi, ktl.: cp. Ar. Vesp. 170 ff., 177 ff. For o)/noi in Plato, cp. Gorg. 516 A, Rep. 563 C; for xalkei=s, Prot. 319 D, Crat. 388 D, 389 E. Cp. Gorg. 490 C ff., where Callicles objects a)texnw=s ge a)ei\ skute/as te kai\ knafe/as kai\ magei/rous le/gwn kai\ i)atrou\s ou)de\n pau/ei ktl.: Xen. Mem. I. 2. 37 o( de\ *kriti/as, *)alla\ tw=nde/ toi/ se a)pe/xesqai, e)/fh, deh/sei, w)= *sw/krates, tw=n skute/wn kai\ tw=n tekto/nwn kai\ tw=n xalke/wn: ib. IV. 4. 5—6: Max. Tyr. diss. IX. 1.

i)dw\n au)= tis. “a)/n cum participio cohaeret hoc sensu, e)a/n tis i)/dh|... si quis forte viderit” (Rückert); Stallb., too, defends a)/n, citing Rep. 589 E, Phaedo 61 C, Euthyd. 287 D; the objection of Rückert and Rettig, that au)= ought to stand after dioigome/nous rather than after i)dw/n, is not fatal.
mo/nous...tw=n lo/gwn. For the contrast implied, cp. Homer's oi)=os pe/pnutai, tai\ de\ skiai\ a)i+/ssousin (Meno 100 A). A similar ascription of life to lo/goi is to be found in Phaedrus 276 A.
qeiota/tous ktl. Cp. 216 D—E. The whole of this account of Socrates' lo/goi is virtually an encomium of his sofi/a.
tei/nontas...e)pi\ pa=n. Cp. 188 B e)pi\ pa=n o( qeo\s tei/nei: Rep. 581 B. For echoes of phrases in the previous speeches here, and throughout Alcib.'s speech, see Introd. § vi (3).

a(\ me/mfomai ktl. “Verba ita connectenda sunt: kai\ summi/cas au)= a(\ me/mfomai ei)=pon u(mi=n a(/ me u(/brise” (Stallb.). Stephens erroneously put a comma, Wolf a full stop, after me/mfomai. Rückert, agreeing with Stallb., put a comma after summi/cas, and Hommel added another after au)=. Jowett's transl.,—“I have added my blame of him for his ill-treatment of me”—seems to imply a different view of the construction. The points alluded to are those mentioned in 217 B ff., 219 C.
*xarmi/dhn. For Charmides, Plato's avunculus, see Charm. 154, 157; Xen. Mem. III. 7, Symp. III. 9 etc.
*eu)qu/dhmon. This Euthydemus, son of Diocles (see Xen. Mem. IV. 2. 40), is not to be confounded with his namesake the sophist, who appears in the dialogue Euthyd.

paidika\...a)nt) e)rastou=. “The object rather than the subject of love.” This may fairly be construed, with Rettig, as an indication that Socr., the
embodiment of the ideal ka/llos, is exalted above Eros (cp. 201 A): contrast 180 B qeio/teron e)rasth\s paidikw=n. For the reversal of the rôles of Alc. and Socr., cp. I. Alc. 135 D kinduneu/somen metabalei=n to\ sxh=ma, w)= *sw/krates, to\ me\n so\n e)gw/, su\ de\ tou)mo/n. ou) ga\r e)/stin o(/pws ou) paidagwgh/sw se ktl. Cp. also Xen. Symp. VIII. 5; and see Introd. § VI. 3.

a(\ dh\...e)capata=sqai. Hommel and Rettig, after Stallb., take the infin. clause to be epexegetic of a(/: Rückert construes e)cap. as a second accus. depending on le/gw: Hug makes the infin. depend on a(\ le/gw (equiv. to “I give you this warning”) as on a “verbum voluntatis.” It may be simply an oblique imperative.

kata\ th
 paroimi/an. Cp. Hom. Il. XVII. 33 r(exqe
 de/ te nh/pios e)/gnw: ib. XX. 198: Hes. Op. 218 paqw
 de/ te nh/pios e)/gnw: Hdt. I. 207 paqh/mata maqh/mata: Aesch. Ag. 177, Cho. 313: Soph. O. C. 143: and our English proverb “a burnt child dreads the fire.” Schol. r(exqe
...e)/gnw: e)pi\ tw=n meta\ to\ paqei=n sunie/ntwn to\ a(ma/rthma. e)pi\ to\ au)to\ e(te/ra paroimi/a: o( a(lieu\s plhgei\s nou=n fu/sei: ktl.

div1.head: Conclusion of the Dialogue
div1.p: parrhsi/a|. “Naivetät” (Wolf); see A.'s excuses for it in 217 E.

*nh/fein moi dokei=s. Echoing the phrase previously used by Alcib. (dokei=te ga/r moi nh/fein 213 E), Socr. jocosely derides his repeated plea of intoxication 212 E, 214 C, etc.), saying in effect: “It's sober you are, not drunk; otherwise you could never have excogitated so deep a scheme.”
komyw=s. Of a “pretty” trick; cp. Theaet. 202 D, Soph. 236 D.

ku/klw| periballo/menos. See Ast ad Phaedrus 272 D “imago desumta est ab amictu, quem rhetores, priusquam perorarent, componere solebant: V. Quintil. XI. 3. 116”: Cic. de or. III. 39. 138 se circumvestit dictis. For ku/klw| cp. Ar. Rhet. I. 9. 33 (with Cope's note), III. 14. 10, and Virgil's “per ambages” (G. II. 45).
e)pi\ teleuth=s. I.e. as if it were an after-thought only: cp. 198 B, Phaedrus 267 D.
e)me\...diaba/llein. “To set us at variance”: cp. 222 D, Rep. 498 C.
oi)o/menos dei=n ktl. I.e. thinking that you must at once monopolise Socr. as your e)rasth/s and Agathon as your paidika/. For dei=n, cp. 222 E.
a)ll) ou)k e)/laqes ktl. For the conversational carelessness of the repeated a)lla/, cp. 175 B (four times).

to\ saturiko/n sou dra=ma ktl. A playful allusion to the ei)ko/nes employed by Alcib. in his encomium (see 215 B). For “satyric drama” see Smith, D. A. II. 860 b: “The satyr-drama was so-called because the Chorus consisted of satyrs attendant on Dionysus...it was aptly described as pai/zousa tragw|di/a”: Jevons, Hist. Gk. Lit. p. 186.
mhde\n ple/on ktl. An echo of the language of Alcib. in 217 C.
xwri\s diala/bh|. “Dictum hoc eleganter cum amphibolia quadam, ut et de spatio possit cogitari et de animorum disiunctione” (Stallb.): cp. Phileb. 55 D.

u(poka/tw e)mou=. The original order of the places on this (e)sxa/th) kli/nh was (1) Agathon, Socrates (see 175 C—D): then Alcibiades on his entrance had seated himself in the middle (213 B ad init.), thus making the order (2) Agathon, Alcib., Socr.: now Socrates invites Agathon to shift his position so as to change the order to (3) Alcib., Socr., Agathon: presently, in the sentence following, Alcibiades suggests that, instead of this, Agathon should take the middle place (e)n me/sw| h(mw=n), which would result in the order (4) Alcib., Agathon, Socrates. But the adoption of this last order is, as Socr. hastens to point out, impossible, inasmuch as it would cause serious dislocation in the series of lo/goi which are bound to proceed in order from left to right (see 214 C), each speaker taking for his theme his next neighbour on the right. If the order (4) were adopted, it would be the duty of the next speaker, Agathon, to eulogize Socrates, a task already performed by Alcib. himself; whereas by adopting the order (3), the next speech would fall to Socr., and he would have for his theme Agathon, an arrangement unobjectionable in itself and well-pleasing to Socr. (pa/nu e)piqumw= au)to\n e)gkwmia/sai, 223 A) as well as to Agathon (i)ou= i)ou= ktl., 223 A).
oi(=a au)= pa/sxw. “How I am fooled” (Jowett). This echoes 215 D oi(=a dh\ pe/ponqa ktl.: cp. 184 B kakw=s pa/sxwn (sc. o( e)rw/menos).
u(po\ soi\ . o( u(po/ tini (or u(poka/tw tinos) is equiv. to o( e)pi\ decia/ (cp. 175 C n.).

ou) dh/ pou ktl. If we retain the MS. reading, this clause is best printed as interrogative (so Bt. and Lehrs)—taking the place of a regular apodosis, such as deh/sei au)to\n e)me\ pa/lin e)painei=n. Against Badh.,—who wrote “monstri vero simile est, pri\n u(p' e)mou= ma=llon e)paineqh=nai,”—Rettig attempts to defend the text thus: “Statt der Worte: ‘er wird eher wollen von mir gelobt werden, als mich loben,’ setze man: es wird nicht verlangt werden können, dass er mich lobe, bevor ich vielmehr ihn gelobt habe”; i.e. ou) dh/pou e)paine/setai is equiv. to ou) dh/pou e)painei=n e)qelh/sei. This, however, is awkward; and some corruption must, I believe, be assumed: if so, the changes I have proposed seem the most plausible.

*)iou= i)ou=. For a distinction between i)ou=, as a cry of joy, and i)ou/, of pain, see Schol. on Ar. Nub. 1170. Here it denotes jubilation, not commiseration as Hommel suggests (“Wehe, wehe, armer Alkibiades” etc.).
*tau=ta e)kei=na. Cp. 210 E, Charm. 166 B (Schanz nov. comm. p. 16).

eu)po/rws. This echoes phrases in the description of Eros, son of *po/ros, see 203 D (po/rimos), 203 E (eu)porh/sh|), 204 B (patro\s...eu)po/rou). Similarly piqano\n suggests the plausible tongue of the go/hs and sofisth/s of 203 D.
piqano\n lo/gon hu(=ren. For this “inventiveness of plausible argument” as belonging to the art of the sophistical rhetor, cp. Gorg. 457 A ff., Phaedrus 269 D.

e)cai/fnhs de\ ktl. Cp. the “sudden” tumultuous entrance of Alcibiades (212 C kai\ e)cai/fnhs ktl.). The incursion here is devised in order to save the situation. For the sake of artistic effect, the series of lo/goi must now stop: the climax having been reached in the encomium of Socr. by Alcib., to add a eulogy of any lesser personage would be bathos.

e)cio/ntos tino\s ktl. Hommel comments: “imaginem proponit comissatorum contra nitente eo, qui iam exiturus erat, aditum vi expugnantium.” But, as Rettig remarks, there is no hint in the text of vis or of nisus. The words e)cio/ntos tino\s are merely put in to explain how it was that they found the doors open. ei)s to\ a)/ntikrus is connected by Hommel and Stallb.^{2} with e)cio/ntos, but by Rückert, Ast and Stallb.^{1} with poreu/esqai: the former view is preferable.

*)eruci/maxon. Eryx. and Phaedrus are represented throughout as “hunting in couples”; and it is characteristic of the former, as an authority on health, and of the latter, as a valetudinarian, that they should be the first to escape from the scene of qo/rubos and pampolu\s oi)=nos: cp. 176 B ff., 214 A ff.
makrw=n tw=n nuktw=n. This indication of date would suit either the Lenaea in January or the Great Dionysia in March, though rather favouring the former (cp. Introd. § VIII a).

a)lektruo/nwn a)|do/ntwn. Cp. Theaet. 164 C a)lektruo/nos a)gennou=s di/khn...a)/|dein. The hour of cock-crow was, theoretically, the 3rd watch (12—3 a.m.): cp. Ev. Mc. xiii. 35. Jowett's “he was awakened by a crowing of cocks” misses h)/dh, which goes with a)|do/ntwn.
kai\ oi)xome/nous. We should expect h)/ rather than kai/: but (as Rückert observes) oi( me\n a)/lloi fall into two subdivisions,—those absent in spirit (kaqeu/d.), and those absent in body (oi)xom.).
e)grhgore/nai ktl. Cp. Athen. V. 192 A *swkra/ths...e)grh/gore...kai\ pi/nei e)c a)rgurou= fre/atos: kalw=s ga/r tis ta\ me/gala poth/ria ou(/tws w)no/mase ktl.
ta\ me\n a)/lla ktl. This is artistic selection disguised under the cloke of imperfect recollection, cp. 178 A, 180 C.
to\ me/ntoi kefa/laion. “The gist of it was...”: cp. 205 D ad init.

tou= au)tou= a)ndro\s ktl. Cp. Ion 534 B te/xnh| poiou=ntes. Here both te/xnh| and e)pi/stasqai are emphatic, with no distinction between them implied. The point of Socrates' argument is that the scientific poet must be master of the art of poetry in its universal, generic aspect, and therefore of both its included species, tragedy and comedy. This thought, if developed, might be shown to mean that full knowledge both of lo/goi and of yuxai/, and of the effects of the one on the other, is requisite to form a master-poet. Which is equivalent to saying that, just as the ideal State requires the philosopherking, so ideal Art is impossible without the filo/sofos-poihth/s. The thesis here maintained by Socrates finds in the supreme instance of Shakspere both illustration and confirmation: “The Merry Wives” came from the same hand as “Othello” and “Lear.”
The statement in Schol. ad Ar. Ran. 214 and Philostr. (vit. soph. I. 9, p. 439) that Agathon wrote comedies as well as tragedies is probably due to a blunder: see Bentley, opusc. phil. p. 613.
ou) sfo/dra e(pome/nous. “Erant enim vino languidi. Ad e(pome/nous intelligi potest toi=s legome/nois Euthyphr. p. 12 A ou)x e(/pomai toi=s legome/nois” (Stallb.).
katakoimi/santa. An allusion, perhaps, to Agathon's koi/thn u(/pnon t' e)ni\ kh/dei, 197 C. Cp. Laws 790 D katakoimi/zein ta\ dusupnou=nta tw=n paidi/wn.
<e(\>. I.e. Aristodemus, the narrator: for his practice (ei)w/qei) of dogging the footsteps of the Master, cp. 173 B, 174 B (e(/pou).

*lu/keion. This was a gymnasium, sacred to Apollo Lyceus, situated in the eastern suburbs of Athens, though the exact site—whether S.E. or N. of the
Cynosarges—is uncertain. The Lyceum is mentioned also in the beginning of the Lysis and of the Euthyphro; cp. Xen. Mem. I. 1. 10, Paus. I. 19. 4. “Ibi Socr. versabatur propterea quod sophistae in eo scholas habebant, quorum inscitiam solebat convincere, et quod plurimos illic adolescentes nanciscebatur, quibus cum sermones instituere posset” (Stallb.).
